('10', 0, 1, 2, 41) 1. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 0, 2, 3, 68) [LONDON,] August 5, 1909
('10', 0, 3, 4, 93) MY LORD, I beg to acknowledge your two letters of yesterday’s date.
('10', 0, 3, 5, 161) I hope to send you copies 1 of your letters at the earliest opportunity.
('10', 0, 3, 6, 234) My letter 2 in reply to yours of the 3rd instant has already gone forward.
('10', 0, 3, 7, 309) With reference to the allegation as to the question of educated Indians being a new question—I deal with it on a separate sheet of paper 3 in order to enable you to use it without having to refer to this letter.
('10', 0, 3, 8, 521) The terms of the proposed amendment to be submitted are also enclosed herewith.
('10', 0, 3, 9, 601) 4 I fully realise that the difficulty will be on the question of right.
('10', 0, 3, 10, 673) I have given many an anxious night to find out a solution without insisting on the “right”, but I have failed because anything short of it, in my humble opinion, implies a record on the Statute book of the Colony of racial inferiority, and this reply to your question is also the reply to Your Lordship’s suggestion that, in the enumeration of demands, the status of educated Indians should be replaced by “the occasional admission of the few highly educated Indians” , etc.
('10', 0, 3, 11, 1148) Any such substitution is not possible because the fight is not that of getting the few educated Indians admitted, but it is essentially that of having the potential or theoretical right recognised.
('10', 0, 3, 12, 1346) Physicians, lawyers, etc., have been mentioned in connection with the question in order to emphasise the tangible consequences of a denial of the “right”, and this became necessary in order to satisfy Mr. Cartwright’s friends as … 5 [Colon]ial stand [point it] is necessary for them to know in a tangible form that our demand does not involve the admission of more than six such Indians into the Colony; as a matter
('10', 0, 4, 13, 1762) 1 Lord Ampthill had asked for copies of his letters to Gandhiji, as he had not retained any with him.
('10', 0, 4, 14, 1864) 2 Vide “Letter to Lord Ampthill”, 4 8 1909. 3 Vide enclosure 1.
('10', 0, 5, 15, 1928) 4 The original enclosure is not available.
('10', 0, 5, 16, 1971) But the text of the amendment prepared by Gandhiji, which was forwarded by Lord Ampthill to General Smuts on August 10, is given here as enclosure 2. For the proviso later on added to it by Gandhiji, vide “Letter to Lord Ampthill”,9 8 1909.
('10', 0, 6, 17, 2212) 5 Some words are missing here.
('10', 1, 0, 1, 2243) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 1, 1, 2, 2283) of fact, there may not be even two per year applying for such admission and, personally, I should want no assurance from the local Government that they would admit six or a smaller number.
('10', 1, 1, 3, 2472) The principle being conceded, mere admission is a matter of detail and I frankly confess that , had it been purely a question of admitting a few such Indians, I should never have advised tremendous suffering on the part of my countrymen of the Transvaal.
('10', 1, 1, 4, 2727) I am much obliged to Your Lordship for your further and valuable suggestions as to improving the statement 1 .
('10', 1, 1, 5, 2838) In concert with Mr. Ritch, I am attending to it directly.
('10', 1, 1, 6, 2896) After the suggestions are incorporated, I will have a few copies struck and will forward them to you, but final order for printing them will not be given until I have received your approval and permission to circulate it.
('10', 1, 2, 7, 3118) I am, etc., [ENCLOSURE 1] AS TO THE ALLEGATION THAT THE QUESTION OF EDUCATED INDIANS IS A NEW QUESTION It is necessary to bear in mind that there were two conferences; the one in the January of 1908 when Mr. Gandhi was still in prison.
('10', 1, 3, 8, 3354) At that time the question of educated Indians was not mentioned because no such mention was necessary.
('10', 1, 3, 9, 3457) This is so because the repeal of Act 2 of 1907, on condition of voluntary registration being gone through, would have automatically re instated British Indians possessing educational attainments.
('10', 1, 3, 10, 3653) The second conference took place on the 20th August between the Executive Council and the leaders of the Progressive Party, Mr. Cartwright, Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Quinn.
('10', 1, 3, 11, 3819) This is the meeting concerning which it is alleged that the question of educated Indians was not among the points discussed.
('10', 1, 3, 12, 3944) This allegation received direct refutation in General Botha’s despatch, No.
('10', 1, 3, 13, 4020) 528, dated the 5th September 1908, at page 43, cd.
('10', 1, 3, 14, 4071) 4327. General Botha says there: “The ninth subject of discussion was the fresh demand made for the immigration of Asiatics not claiming previous domicile in the Transvaal, but who could pass an education test.” This is an admission that this subject was discussed at the conference, but, it is claimed by
('10', 1, 4, 15, 4376) 1 Vide “Statement of Transvaal Indian Case”, 16 7 1909.
('10', 1, 5, 16, 4432) 2 Gandhiji was sentenced to two months’ imprisonment on January 10, 1908, but was released on January 30 following the settlement; vide “Trial at Johannesburg”, 10 1 1908 and “Interview to “the Transvaal Leader”, 30 1 1908.
('10', 2, 0, 1, 4656) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 3
('10', 2, 1, 2, 4697) General Botha, it was a fresh demand brought up there.
('10', 2, 1, 3, 4752) But this is also wrong, as is shown from the correspondence between Mr. Smuts and Mr. Gandhi, commencing from the 22nd February 1908. 1 Indeed, as a matter of fact, the conference was brought about because the negotiations that were going on with General Smuts for repeal of the Act fell through, inasmuch as General Smuts imposed a fresh condition as to the prohibition of educated British Indians before he would repeal the Act.
('10', 2, 1, 4, 5183) Moreover, in the … 2 [above quotation] a claim which ministers had previously decided was inadmissible and even had it been otherwise, it is difficult to see by what means a Bill providing for the immigration of Asiatics and the clause in question could be passed through either of the Houses of Parliament in view of the almost universal feeling of the white colonists on the subject.” It may also be added that at this conference there was no agreement come to.
('10', 2, 1, 5, 5647) The Asiatic leaders retired with distinct instructions from the members of the Executive Council and the Progressive Leaders that they were to put before their respective committees the points that were discussed at the conference and inform General Smuts of the decision of the committees.
('10', 2, 1, 6, 5938) Accordingly and immediately, Asiatic meetings were held, and both Messrs Gandhi and Quinn reported to General Smuts.
('10', 2, 1, 7, 6055) In the Blue book above mentioned, the whole of the letter written at the special request of the Private Secretary to Mr. Smuts is not given.
('10', 2, 1, 8, 6196) The following are the opening sentences from the letter to Mr. Lane (Mr. Smuts’ Private Secretary), dated the 20th August: 3
('10', 2, 2, 9, 6321) Mr. Cartwright told me that I should write to you what I told him as to the decision of the meeting today, and to give my impressions also.
('10', 2, 3, 10, 6461) I placed before the meeting, for the third time today, the terms that I told them the Government were prepared to offer, and I told them further that these would form an Acceptable compromise, if some provision was made for highly educated Indians and Mr. Sorabjee’s re instatement; but the meeting would not listen to anything short of repeal of the Asiatic act and the recognition of highly educated Indians under the general clause of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act.
('10', 2, 3, 11, 6932) All I could persuade them to accept was that, the statutory right being recognised, there would be no objection to an administrative discrimination against educated Indians, so that only the most highly educated Indians could enter.
('10', 2, 4, 12, 7165) 1 Vide “Letter to General Smuts”, 22 2 1908.
('10', 2, 5, 13, 7210) 2 Some words are missing here.
('10', 2, 5, 14, 7241) 3 Vide “Letter to E.F.c.Lane”, 20 8 1908.
('10', 2, 6, 15, 7283) 4 Lord Ampthill, acknowledging this letter on August 7, wrote that this memorandum seemed to be quite convincing and would be of immediate use to him.
('10', 3, 0, 1, 7434) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 3, 1, 2, 7474) [ENCLOSURE 2]
('10', 3, 2, 3, 7488) AMENDMENT Part of sub section 1 of Section 2 of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act No.
('10', 3, 2, 4, 7572) 15 of 1907 reads as follows: “Any person who when asked whether within or outside this Colony by a duly authorised officer shall be unable through deficient education to write out (from dictation or otherwise) and sign in the characters of an European language an applic ation for permission to enter this Colony or such other document as such officer may require; provided that for the purpose of this sub section Yiddish shall be accepted as an European lang uage; provided further that” (what follows is immaterial)
('10', 3, 3, 5, 8091) Proposed Amendment of sub section 1. as follows: “Any person who when asked whether within or outside this Colony by a duly authorised officer shall be unable through deficient education to pass an examination test in an European language that may be set; provided that for the purposes of this Section Yiddish shall be accepted as an European language and provided further that the Immigration Officer shall have full discretion as to the nature of the examination which may vary in respect of persons or classes and that the decision of the Immigration Officer in respect of the examination shall not be subject to review by or appeal to the Supreme Court or any other Courts of the Colony, and provided further that any Asiatic passing the examination test put to him by the Immigration Officer and not being otherwise in terms of this Act deemed a prohibited immigrant shall not be subject to the provisions of Act 36 of 1908, provided further that” NOTES HEREON
('10', 3, 4, 6, 9058) 1. If Act 2 of 1907 had been repealed and if there were no Act 36 of 1908, there would be no occasion for reference to Act 36 in the proposed amendment.
('10', 3, 4, 7, 9211) But the reference has become necessary as Act
('10', 4, 0, 1, 9257) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 5
('10', 4, 1, 2, 9298) 36 contains a removal clause, and as sub section 4 of Section 2 of Act 15 provides that any person being subject to a removal order becomes a prohibited immigrant in spite of his passing the examination tests.
('10', 4, 1, 3, 9508) Said sub section 4 reads as follows:
('10', 4, 2, 4, 9545) Any person who at the date of his entering or attempting to enter this Colony is subject or would if he entered this Colony be subject to the provisions of any law in force at such date which might render him liable either at such date or thereafter if found therein to be removed from or to be ordered to leave this Colony whether on conviction of any offence against such law or for failure to comply with its provision or otherwise in accordance with its provisions, provided that such conviction be not result of the commission by such person elsewhere than in this Colony of an offence for which he has received a free pardon.
('10', 4, 2, 5, 10177) 2. The proposed amendment as to examination has been given in order to satisfy the objection raised by General Smuts that the present law may not contain sufficient discretion for the Immigration Officer, to warrant him putting one test before one immigrant and a different test before another.
('10', 4, 3, 6, 10472) Colonial Office Records : 291/142; also, from a photostat : of the typewritten office copy : S. N. 4980

('10', 6, 6, 19, 13700) Whilst the negotiations are going on, he does not want any public activity at this end.
('10', 6, 6, 20, 13788) He will meet General Smuts next Monday ; we are to meet Lord Crewe next Tuesday.
('10', 6, 6, 21, 13869) Next week, therefore, will definitely decide the course of action to be taken here.
('10', 6, 6, 22, 13953) Your activity, however, need not be affected by what is going on here, unless a definite settlement is arrived at; but even if it is, I think you should take every advantage of

('10', 9, 1, 2, 19255) 5. LONDON
('10', 9, 2, 3, 19265) Friday, August 6, 1909
('10', 9, 3, 4, 19288) NATAL DEPUTATION
('10', 9, 4, 5, 19305) Messrs Amod Bhayat, H. M. Badat and M. C. Anglia arrived here safely on Saturday last.
('10', 9, 4, 6, 19392) They were received by Mr. Ritch, Mr. Hajee Habib, Miss Polak, Mr. Azam Haffeji, Mr. Hussain Dawad, Mr. Abdul Caadir and Mr. Gandhi.
('10', 9, 4, 7, 19524) They are staying in the same hotel as the Transvaal deputation.
('10', 9, 4, 8, 19588) The delegates have met Sir Muncherjee, Nawab Saheb Major Syed Hussain Bilgrami and Mr. Gupta.
('10', 9, 4, 9, 19682) They applied for interviews with Lord Crewe and Lord Morley; the former has already replied fixing Thursday, August 12, for the interview.
('10', 9, 4, 10, 19821) They have prepared a statement 1. I am afraid the deputation’s visit will prove unavailing.
('10', 9, 4, 11, 19913) For one thing, it is too late, and they have come to raise an issue which is a very old one.
('10', 9, 4, 12, 20006) However, the experience they will carry with them may be of some benefit to the community.
('10', 9, 4, 13, 20097) They are trying to see some other men who count.
('10', 9, 4, 14, 20146) At this time [of the year], most of the leading men in British public life are generally on holiday and do not return till September.
('10', 9, 4, 15, 20280) Mr. Justice Ameer Ali, also, is not present here; he has left for a distant place.
('10', 9, 6, 16, 20363) Mrs. Ritch has suffered terribly through illness.
('10', 9, 6, 17, 20413) The good lady has been in pain for the past two years.
('10', 9, 6, 18, 20468) Her wound has had to be cut open four times, and she has been confined to bed.
('10', 9, 6, 19, 20547) Mr. Ritch is quite buried under the expenses of [her] treatment.
('10', 9, 6, 20, 20612) It is impossible to say when he will be able to shake off that burden.
('10', 9, 6, 21, 20683) He has started practice at the Bar, where he has even made a mark for himself and won some important cases.
('10', 9, 6, 22, 20791) But a new barrister does not earn much here.
('10', 9, 6, 23, 20836) I advise Indians to address a letter of sympathy to Mr. Ritch.
('10', 9, 6, 24, 20899) His address is : L. W. Ritch, Esq., 5 Pump Court, Temple, E. C., London.
('10', 9, 6, 25, 20972) I am hopeful that Mrs. Ritch will eventually recover.
('10', 9, 7, 26, 21026) SUFFRAGETTES
('10', 9, 8, 27, 21039) The suffragettes have been straining every nerve.
('10', 9, 8, 28, 21089) The more I see of their work, their skill in organization and their power of endurance, the more I feel that, compared to their effort, ours is of little worth.
('10', 9, 9, 29, 21250) 1 This was evidently drafted by Gandhiji himself; vide the preceding item.
('10', 10, 0, 1, 21325) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 11
('10', 10, 1, 2, 21367) They have a large number of volunteers who force themselves into ministers’ meetings and so get arrested.
('10', 10, 1, 3, 21473) In gaol, they take no food and so the autho rities release them.
('10', 10, 1, 4, 21538) They harass the latter in a number of ways; they have taken a pledge to allow themselves no rest till they get the franchise.
('10', 10, 2, 5, 21664) UNION OF SOUTH AFRICA
('10', 10, 3, 6, 21686) The Bill in regard to this has been passed by the House of Lords.
('10', 10, 3, 7, 21752) It will be in the House of Commons in a few days.
('10', 10, 3, 8, 21802) Mr. Schreiner is still exerting himself, but I do not see what good that can do.
('10', 10, 3, 9, 21883) There has been plenty of discussion.
('10', 10, 3, 10, 21920) Irrespective of the outcome, Mr. Schreiner’s ability, his strenuous efforts and his philanthropic zeal deserve the highest commendation.
('10', 10, 4, 11, 22057) DHINGRA
('10', 10, 5, 12, 22065) Mr. Dhingra has been awarded the death penalty.
('10', 10, 5, 13, 22113) He will probably be executed on the 10th.
('10', 10, 5, 14, 22155) Some whites have been trying to secure remission of the death penalty.
('10', 10, 5, 15, 22226) They argue that he acted out of foolishness.
('10', 10, 5, 16, 22271) Moreover, they add, the act was not inspired by any personal motive and, therefore, should not be treated as ordinary murder.
('10', 10, 5, 17, 22397) The white printer of The Indian Sociologist has been sentenced to four months’ imprisonment for printing [the particular issue of] the journal.
('10', 10, 5, 18, 22541) Being a very poor man, he is put to great loss.
('10', 10, 5, 19, 22589) He had no knowledge whatever of the contents of the issue.
('10', 10, 5, 20, 22648) But ignorance is no defence in law.
('10', 10, 5, 21, 22684) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 4 9 1909
('10', 10, 6, 22, 22725) 6. DEPUTATION NOTES [–VI ]
('10', 10, 7, 23, 22752) [Before August 7, 1909] I have no special information to give this week, as I had none last week, for everything is confidential.
('10', 10, 7, 24, 22882) Lord Ampthill has himself been active.
('10', 10, 7, 25, 22921) There is a slight hope that an amicable solution will be found.
('10', 10, 7, 26, 22985) Even if that happens, I see no possibility of any other gain besides the repeal of the Act and the recognition of the rights of the educated.
('10', 10, 7, 27, 23127) It should be understood that “ the rights of the educated” mean those that have often been explained in Indian Opinion.
('10', 10, 7, 28, 23247) That is, those Indians with the highest attainments will be allowed to come in and, from among such men, only six.
('10', 10, 7, 29, 23362) Of course, in the law itself, there
('10', 11, 0, 1, 23398) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 11, 1, 2, 23439) will be no mention of “six”, and no racial discrimination.
('10', 11, 1, 3, 23498) The law will be the same, but it may be implemented in a different way.
('10', 11, 1, 4, 23570) Provided the law is the same, there will be no humiliation.
('10', 11, 1, 5, 23630) It will be there if the law itself makes distinctions.
('10', 11, 1, 6, 23685) It should be noted by every Indian that, apart from these two points, other miscellaneous matters will not be included in the settlement.
('10', 11, 1, 7, 23823) I hope to be able to give a little more information next week.
('10', 11, 1, 8, 23886) Sir Muncherji has also been taking great pains on this question.
('10', 11, 1, 9, 23951) He wrote [to General Smuts] seeking an interview with him.
('10', 11, 1, 10, 24010) A reply has been received saying that General Smuts will fix a time for interview after he is free from the pressure of engagements in connection with the Act of Union.
('10', 11, 1, 11, 24179) The deputation will meet Lord Crewe on Tuesday, the 9th 1. That is the day on which a number of Indians are due to be released.

('10', 13, 1, 2, 27282) 8. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 13, 2, 3, 27309) [LONDON,] August 9, 1909
('10', 13, 3, 4, 27334) MY LORD, Before I write on the subject which to my colleague and myself is of the utmost importance, may I once more thank Your Lordship for the very great interest you have taken in the struggle?
('10', 13, 3, 5, 27531) Whatever may be the ultimate result, my countrymen and I can never be sufficiently grateful for what you have done for us.
('10', 13, 3, 6, 27654) If I understood you correctly, in your opinion the entry as a matter of right will be recognised if the number were limited by the law itself.
('10', 13, 3, 7, 27797) If that be so, it appears to me that the concession should be given coupled with repeal of the Act, without any bargaining with the passive resisters, but on thinking the matter over, if General Smuts is really desirous of meeting us, he should have no objection to accepting the amendment 1 I have submitted, together with the proviso I give hereunder.
('10', 13, 3, 8, 28151) It should be read after “1908” and before “ Provided further that”– “Provided that it shall be lawful for the Governor in Council to restrict by regulation the number of persons belonging to different nationalities (notwithstanding their having passed such examination) who may be allowed to enter the Colony as immigrants.” This amendment just—and only just—satisfies the Indian covenant.
('10', 13, 3, 9, 28541) It still creates no disqualification on the Statute book against British Indians as such.
('10', 13, 3, 10, 28631) It completely, in my opinion, meets the objections raised by, or on behalf of, General Smuts.
('10', 13, 3, 11, 28725) In submitting this amendment, I recognise that I am becoming a party to a dangerous precedent in the history of Colonial legislation, but in deference to the views of Your Lordship and of other distinguished fri ends of our cause, I am prepared to advise my countrymen to accept this further proviso, and if it is not accepted, it would be, I am sure, patent to you that there is no desire on the part of the Transvaal Government to offer an honourable settlement.
('10', 13, 3, 12, 29190) With the
('10', 13, 4, 13, 29199) 1 Vide enclosure 2 to “Letter to Lord Ampthill”,5 8 1909 The proviso was inserted by Lord Ampthill in the draft of the amendment which he sent to General Smuts.
('10', 14, 0, 1, 29360) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 15
('10', 14, 1, 2, 29402) knowledge—right or wrong—that I have of the methods of General Smuts, may I suggest that Your Lordship should not put this amendment as coming from me, but ask him independently—unless you have closed entirely the negotiations with him—whether he would be prepared to amend the Immigration Act in the direction above indicated?
('10', 14, 1, 3, 29730) This proviso I am submitting because of my earnest desire to promote an immediate settlement and to avoid your long and arduous labours proving abortive; but if nothing comes of it, I should like Your Lordship to treat it as if it had never been suggested.
('10', 14, 1, 4, 29987) The first amendment submitted by me is such, as I for one should advise my people to accept at any stage of the struggle, but the proviso I am now submitting does not fall under that category.
('10', 14, 1, 5, 30180) Kindly let me know whether you have any further suggestions with reference to the statement, of which I sent you twenty copies, and whether it may now be published and circulated.

('10', 15, 1, 2, 31381) 10. STATEMENT OF NATAL INDIAN GRIEVANCES 1
('10', 15, 2, 3, 31424) [LONDON,] August 10, 1909 A SHORT STATEMENT OF THE GRIEVANCES OF THE BRITISH INDIANS
('10', 15, 3, 4, 31509) IN NATAL BY THE NATAL DELEGATION The delegation consists of Messrs Abdul Caadir, Acting Chairman of the Natal Indian Congress; Amod Bayat, of pietermaritz burg, a merchant of twenty five years’ standing; Hoosen Mahomed Badat, a merchant of Pietermaritzburg and Richmond, of twenty two years standing; and Mahomed Cassim Anglia, of Durban, merchant and Joint Honorary Secretary of the Natal Indian Congress.
('10', 15, 3, 5, 31916) The delegates were unanimously appointed at a British Indian meeting presided over by Mr. Abdoola Hajee Adam, Acting president, Natal Indian Congress, and held at Durban on the 7th day of July last, and have received numerous telegrams supporting the mission.
('10', 15, 3, 6, 32176) A petition 2 has been forwarded to the Colonial Office, a copy of which has since been received by the delegates.
('10', 15, 3, 7, 32290) The British Indians of Natal have suffered for a long time from a number of serious disabilities arising out of certain laws enacted by the Colonial Legislature and by reason of certain municipal laws.
('10', 15, 3, 8, 32492) The delegation desires respectfully to place on record its gratitude to His Majesty’s Government for having refused Imperial sanction to the Municipal Corporations Act of 1906 and the Natal Licensing Acts of 1908, all of which measures threatened their community with still further disabilities.
('10', 15, 3, 9, 32788) The British Indians of Natal are practically unrepresented in the
('10', 15, 4, 10, 32854) 1 The draft of this statement, evidently drawn up by Gandhiji, was ready on August 6; vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 6 8 1909. The statement was sent to the Colonial Office on August 11 by M. C. Anglia, who made a further statement at the interview with Lord Crewe on August 12; vide Appendix XIX.
('10', 15, 4, 11, 33154) On the following day, the delegation issued the former representation to “responsible politicians … in the hope that they will render to the suffering British Indians in Natal whatever assistance they can to obtain redress and justice.” 2 Dated July 10, 1909, this petition was made on behalf of the Natal Indian Congress and other Natal Indian organizations, and covered grievances in respect of indenture, franchise, trade and other matters; vide “London”, After 12 8 1909.
('10', 16, 0, 1, 33630) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 17
('10', 16, 1, 2, 33672) Natal Parliament, and are therefore obliged almost entirely to rely upon the protection of the Imperial Government.
('10', 16, 1, 3, 33788) For them Self Government has no special or beneficial meaning.
('10', 16, 1, 4, 33851) The delegates propose, however, to restrict their representations to three very serious and tangible grievances : The Dealers’ Licenses Act, 18 of 1897; The Indentured Immigration Law of 1895 ; and The policy with reference to the Education of Indian children.
('10', 16, 1, 5, 34112) THE DEALERS’ LICENSES ACT, 1897 This Act is felt by the whole British Indian community to be extremely unjust and tyrannical.
('10', 16, 1, 6, 34238) It affects the whole of the Indian mercantile population.
('10', 16, 1, 7, 34296) In its wording it is of general application, but in practice it has been employed more and more extensively for depriving Indian traders of their licenses.
('10', 16, 1, 8, 34452) The powers conferred by the Dealers’ Licenses Act of 1897 were, it would appear, abused from the beginning.
('10', 16, 1, 9, 34560) Mr. Chamberlain went as far as to intimate that, if its one sided administration against Indian traders did not cease, he should be compelled to take serious action.
('10', 16, 1, 10, 34726) The immediate effect would appear to have been that circulars were sent round to the different Municipalities by the Government of Natal (at Mr. Chamberlain’s suggestion) to the effect that, although they had been given arbitrary powers, they were expected, on pain of being deprived thereof, to use them in a reasonable and general manner, and that in no case, if they wished to retain those powers, were they to touch vested interests.
('10', 16, 1, 11, 35164) Two cases of recent occurrence may be cited by way of illustration.
('10', 16, 1, 12, 35232) Mr. M. A. Goga, a British Indian merchant of Ladysmith, long estab lished and widely supported by Europeans both as sellers and customers, was, in June last, refused permission by the Licensing Officer, who is invested with almost autocratic powers in this matter, to take transfer of a license from another Indian in Ladysmith of equal standing.
('10', 16, 1, 13, 35579) The premises in which the business was conducted were the property of Mr. Goga’s mother.
('10', 16, 1, 14, 35668) Appeal was made by Mr. Goga to the Licensing Board, which, however, declined to reverse the decision of their Licensing Officer.
('10', 16, 1, 15, 35797) In the course of an appeal to the Licensing Board from a refusal to renew another license of this applicant the previous year, Mr. Wyllie, K.C., M.L.A., remarked:
('10', 17, 0, 1, 35960) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 17, 1, 2, 36001) “You as a Council are not going to see injustice done even to an Indian.
('10', 17, 1, 3, 36074) Take the license away and the business is at an end.
('10', 17, 1, 4, 36127) You and the inhabitants of Ladysmith have enabled him to build up a business, and I submit that you cannot take that license away.
('10', 17, 1, 5, 36258) If he comes today and asks for a new license, then you can refuse.
('10', 17, 1, 6, 36325) He tells you that 95 per cent.
('10', 17, 1, 7, 36356) of the business is with Europeans; therefore, it is a conve nience to the burgesses of the town.
('10', 17, 1, 8, 36453) It would be utterly impossible to come before you with a stronger case.
('10', 17, 1, 9, 36525) I ask you to deal with it without bias as to anything that happened previous to entering this room, and with justice to the appellant.” Commenting upon the recent decisions of the Klip River Licensing Board, The Times of Natal said:
('10', 17, 2, 10, 36758) “A SCANDALOUS INJUSTICE”
('10', 17, 3, 11, 36783) “A more arbitrary and unjust proceeding could not be imagined; and we have no hesitation in saying that had the Boer authorities, in the days of the South African Republic, been guilty of such conduct, they would have instantly been brought up with a round turn by the Imperial Government.
('10', 17, 3, 12, 37073) Here we have a number of reputable Indian shopkeepers, who have built up business in which a large amount of capital is invested, suddenly and arbitrarily deprived of their trading licenses through alleged non compliance with the law.
('10', 17, 3, 13, 37308) They had complied with the law as far as it was in their power to do so, and those who could not write in English had their books made up in English at the end of each week by a competent book keeper.
('10', 17, 3, 14, 37509) They have done this for years past, and not a word has been said against the practice till now.
('10', 17, 3, 15, 37605) We can only describe the decision of the Ladysmith Licensing Board as a scandalous injustice, and illegal as well; and if the applicants had the right of appeal—which, of course, under the law they have not—the Board’s decision would imme diately be quashed by the Supreme Court.
('10', 17, 3, 16, 37885) We wish to be perfectly clear in this matter.
('10', 17, 3, 17, 37931) We have no sympathy with Indian traders, and we should be glad to see an end of Indian trading.
('10', 17, 3, 18, 38027) We would support the most drastic restrictions at the port of entry, and would go so far as to favour no fresh licenses being granted to Indian applicants.
('10', 17, 3, 19, 38183) But to decline to renew a trading license in the case of Indians who have been allowed to settle in the country, who have been conducting their business in a perfectly legitimate manner for years past, and who have invested their capital in commercial enterprises on the strength of the license to trade, is to do something which conflicts with the laws of all civilised nations and with the most elementary notions of justice.
('10', 17, 3, 20, 38611) We hope that stringent
('10', 18, 0, 1, 38634) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 19
('10', 18, 1, 2, 38676) instructions will be issued to all licensing officers in order to prevent a repeti tion of the Ladysmith scandal; otherwise, Natal will gravely embarrass the Imperial Government in its relationships with the people of India.” In 1908, Col.
('10', 18, 1, 3, 38916) Greene, M.L.A., appeared to support the appeals of a number of Estcourt Indian traders.
('10', 18, 1, 4, 39004) He remarked as follows: “Throughout his Parliamentary career he had maintained that it was undesirable that the Indian mercantile community should be allowed to increase, and it was with great surprise that he had been approached and asked to take up these appeals; but it was pointed out to him that in the House he had said that we, as a community, had to face the position like men, and that we had not to do any injustice, but that we had to take steps that would be perfectly just to the men whom we had encouraged and allowed to come into the country and obtain vested interests there.
('10', 18, 1, 5, 39596) He said that they, as a superior race, had a duty to perform to the community, and that, if there was any dirty work to be done, it was for Parliament to face it, and to take the right steps.
('10', 18, 1, 6, 39788) It had never been intended by the law that any dirty work of this sort should be done by local boards of this sort, and, upon my soul, if you refuse this application, I think it will make us all feel like worms.” The other case is that of one of the delegates, Mr. H. M. Badat of Pietermaritzburg and Richmond.
('10', 18, 1, 7, 40099) Last year, a license granted to him in the latter place by the Licensing Officer for buildings owned by him was, at the instigation of a few European rivals, taken away by the Licensing Board.
('10', 18, 1, 8, 40292) The Licensing Officer again granted it and again the Board overrode his decision.
('10', 18, 1, 9, 40374) In 1907, renewals of 11 Indian licenses were refused in the division of Klip River: Ten renewals of licenses were refused in Inanda Two ,, ,, ,, Alexandra Five ,, ,, ,, Victoria Three ,, ,, ,, Weenen Last year there was a further crop of similar refusals.
('10', 18, 1, 10, 40630) The delegates desire to point out that this harsh and arbitrary conduct towards Indian traders is not adopted at the instance of the general European population of the Colony, but from the pressure of European trade rivals.
('10', 18, 1, 11, 40854) The Licensing Boards which are the final courts of appeal in this matter consist largely of European storekeepers.
('10', 19, 0, 1, 40969) 20 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 19, 1, 2, 41010) Supreme Court has, on more than one occasion, commented upon the arbitrary powers conferred upon the Licensing Boards and has deplored its inability to interfere with their decisions.
('10', 19, 1, 3, 41194) The Licensing Officers who, in the first instance, decide the fate of Indian merchants, are in most cases the appointees and servants of the Licensing Boards.
('10', 19, 1, 4, 41353) They decide whether a license shall be granted, renewed or transferred.
('10', 19, 1, 5, 41425) Very rarely are their decisions not upheld by the Licensing Boards.
('10', 19, 1, 6, 41493) The declared policy is to reduce the movement of Indian traders, and the outcome of this policy is the almost complete failure on the part of British Indian traders to obtain common justice in the matter of new licenses, renewals or transfers.
('10', 19, 1, 7, 41737) Proof of this could be adduced by citing numerous instances which have occurred during the twelve years that the Law has been in operation.
('10', 19, 1, 8, 41877) Respectability and responsibility in the applicants or considerations of vested interests have hardly appeared to count if they have been Indian.
('10', 19, 1, 9, 42023) For instance: The second signatory hereto, in 1907, purchased a business in Wee nen from a trustee.
('10', 19, 1, 10, 42123) The Licensing Officer declined to transfer and license the business to him.
('10', 19, 1, 11, 42199) On appeal to the Licensing Board, the latter upheld the decision of its officer.
('10', 19, 1, 12, 42280) The Supreme Court, being moved, declared its powerlessness to grant relief.
('10', 19, 1, 13, 42356) In 1906, the fourth signatory hereto was the transferee of a license of a business in Port Shepstone.
('10', 19, 1, 14, 42458) The transfer of the license was duly allowed and renewed once.
('10', 19, 1, 15, 42521) When next applied for, further renewal was refused at the instigation of trade rivals.
('10', 19, 1, 16, 42608) It is obviously merely a question of time—by no means remote—when the whole class of Indian traders in Natal will be extinguished, unless the Dealers’ Licenses Act is so amended as to give the aggrieved party the right of appeal to the Supreme Court.
('10', 19, 1, 17, 42859) THE INDENTURED IMMIGRATION LAW AMENDMENT ACT, 1895
('10', 19, 2, 18, 42910) During the last half century, Natal has relied for its labour and prosperity upon indentured Indian immigrants.
('10', 19, 2, 19, 43022) The fact stands admitted by nearly every Natal statesman, past and present.
('10', 19, 2, 20, 43098) Natal’s chief industries have depended for their very existence almost entirely upon this class of labour, but the labourer, after he has given the Colony the best energies of the best years of his life, is now denied an opportunity to settle down and finish his years in the Colony as a respectable freeman.
('10', 19, 2, 21, 43407) Every effort is made to compel him either to re indenture or to leave the Colony.
('10', 19, 2, 22, 43489) A prohibitive special annual tax of £ 3 per head is imposed upon him and upon his wife and his children—
('10', 20, 0, 1, 43594) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 21
('10', 20, 1, 2, 43636) a tax that presses so severely upon him that it has ruined many a freed Indian and has driven many more to questionable practices and moral degradation.
('10', 20, 1, 3, 43789) The imposition of this tax has not been defended save on the grounds of political expediency.
('10', 20, 1, 4, 43883) Thanks to the firm attitude of His Majesty’s Government, the Government of the Colony has hitherto failed to carry into effect the desired and long contemplated plan of repatriating the Indian indentured labourers upon completion of their indentures.
('10', 20, 1, 5, 44134) The delegates respectfully submit, however, that His Majesty’s Government should with equal propriety and justice have refused their sanction to the imposition of the iniquitous special annual tax, which very nearly produces the same result.
('10', 20, 1, 6, 44376) The delegates feel that, in the interests of the Colony, of the free Indian population, and even of the indentured labourers themselves, the whole system of indenture should be put an end to.
('10', 20, 1, 7, 44568) They consider that the mere fact that these unhappy people are able, during the term of their indentures, to earn a little more money in Natal than in India , is a matter of relative unimportance.
('10', 20, 1, 8, 44765) What material advantage thereby accrues to them is as nothing compared to the deterioration of their manhood and the vicious consequences that react upon the Colony as a whole.
('10', 20, 1, 9, 44942) If, however, the supply of indentured labour cannot suddenly be withdrawn without jeopardising the chief industries of Natal, the special tax above referred to should, in the humble opinion of the delegates, certainly be abolished.
('10', 20, 2, 10, 45174) THE EDUCATION OF INDIAN CHILDREN
('10', 20, 3, 11, 45207) The delegates feel keenly that a deliberate attempt is being made to starve the Natal British Indian community intellectually, by depriving them of even such limited facilities for educating their children as have hitherto existed.
('10', 20, 3, 12, 45439) The Indian schools supported by the Government have never supplied British Indian children with any but very elementary education.
('10', 20, 3, 13, 45570) The general schools of the Colony are, of course, closed altogether to Indian children.
('10', 20, 3, 14, 45658) The Government higher grade school no longer permits Indian children to remain as pupils after completing the age of thirteen; consequently, such education as might be acquired in the upper standards, if the children were given the chance of reaching them, is no longer available to them.
('10', 20, 3, 15, 45947) The effect of this policy has been to drive out a large number of Indian children, whose education was scarcely begun, from the Indian
('10', 21, 0, 1, 46082) 22 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 21, 1, 2, 46123) schools.
('10', 21, 1, 3, 46132) This lack of facilities for acquiring education operates as a very serious handicap upon, and causes the gravest anxiety to, the thoughtful members of the Indian community.
('10', 21, 1, 4, 46305) They are deeply concerned for the future of their children.
('10', 21, 1, 5, 46365) The delegates respectfully submit that this important matter should be equally a matter of concern to the European Colonists themselves, inasmuch as the condemnation of a section of the population of the Colony to a condition of illiteracy is bound to affect the general intellectual and moral well being of the State.
('10', 21, 1, 6, 46684) In view of the above facts, British Indians in Natal naturally approach the proposed Union of the South African Colonies in fear and trembling.
('10', 21, 1, 7, 46828) It is generally recognised that an anti Indian wave is passing over South Africa.
('10', 21, 1, 8, 46910) Three of the four States of the proposed Union are admittedly hostile to British Indians.
('10', 21, 1, 9, 47000) The Cape has already shown signs of joining the hostile movement, so that the Union will represent a combination of hostile forces which hitherto have been working independently of each other.
('10', 21, 1, 10, 47193) British Indians feel, therefore, that the proposed Union in South Africa will mean further degradation of a class of loyal subjects of His Majesty domiciled in South Africa, who already labour under a double disability, viz, of being British Indians, and of classification with the so called “coloured races”.
('10', 21, 1, 11, 47503) It is submitted here that, whatever may be said in regard to the other Colonies in South Africa, the Imperial Government have, undoubtedly, facilities for securing justice to the British Indians of Natal.
('10', 21, 1, 12, 47708) This Colony cannot take all and give nothing.
('10', 21, 1, 13, 47754) It has, on its own admissions, to depend upon the goodwill of the Imperial Govern ment for the development and retention of its industries.
('10', 21, 1, 14, 47894) The least that Natal can be asked to do in return for the supply of indentured labour that is permitted to flow on to her lands is to grant common justice and fair treatment to those British Indians who have settled there, and who have thus acquired vested interests.
('10', 21, 2, 15, 48162) ABDUL CAADIR AMOD BAYAT H. M. BADAT M. C. ANGLIA

('10', 22, 1, 2, 48287) 11. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 22, 2, 3, 48315) [LONDON,] August 10, 1909
('10', 22, 3, 4, 48341) MY LORD,
('10', 22, 4, 5, 48350) Mr. Hajee Habib and I have just returned from the interview with Lord Crewe.
('10', 22, 4, 6, 48427) His Lordship was very sympathetic; he gave a patient hearing.
('10', 22, 4, 7, 48489) I slightly sketched before him, as I saw that the opportunity was too great to be missed, the amendment that I sent to you last evening.
('10', 22, 4, 8, 48626) I took the liberty of mentioning that we had discussed the question fully with Your Lordship.
('10', 22, 4, 9, 48720) Lord Crewe nodded appreciatingly and said that you had taken great pains over the question.
('10', 22, 4, 10, 48812) From what Lord Crewe said, I imagine that the negotiations still continue.
('10', 22, 4, 11, 48887) I think he admits that the amendment that I have suggested is very reasonable and that he would press it upon General Smuts.
('10', 22, 4, 12, 49012) I do not know what should now be done in the circumstances.
('10', 22, 4, 13, 49072) I await Your Lordship’s advice.
('10', 22, 5, 14, 49104) I remain, etc.,
('10', 22, 6, 15, 49120) From a photostat of the typewritten office copy : S. N. 4996

('10', 24, 1, 2, 51520) 14. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('10', 24, 2, 3, 51549) [LONDON,] August 10, 1909
('10', 24, 3, 4, 51575) MANILAL, I have received your letter.
('10', 24, 3, 5, 51613) There is little hope of any settlement; I am therefore writing this on Tuesday, for there is likely to be a greater pressure of work on me than before.
('10', 24, 3, 6, 51765) The words in your letters are sometimes incomplete.
('10', 24, 3, 7, 51817) You will do better if you form the habit of reading the letters after writing them.
('10', 24, 3, 8, 51901) As regards having another tank, my advice is that you should carry on for the present without buying a new one.
('10', 24, 3, 9, 52013) The rains will now set in and it will be possible to carry on with one tank.
('10', 24, 3, 10, 52090) Meanwhile, I hope to be able to go there.
('10', 24, 3, 11, 52132) We shall see to it then.
('10', 24, 3, 12, 52157) I am glad that you have given up worrying [about your studies].
('10', 24, 3, 13, 52221) The more I observe things here, the more I feel that there is no reason to believe that this place is particularly suited for any type of better educa tion.
('10', 24, 3, 14, 52378) I also see that some of the education imparted here is faulty.
('10', 24, 3, 15, 52441) How ever, there is a constant desire in my mind that each of you should be able to come and stay here for a while at least.
('10', 24, 3, 16, 52565) If we go on doing our duty properly, we need not worry about the future.
('10', 24, 3, 17, 52638) Your studying there ear nestly would be your preparation for coming here.
('10', 24, 3, 18, 52712) Mr. West’s mother is just 150 miles away from London and yet she has never visited this city.
('10', 24, 3, 19, 52806) The distance between London and Louth is only three and a half hours.
('10', 24, 3, 20, 52876) That there are more fruit trees on the land than we can look after shows our lack of competence.
('10', 24, 3, 21, 52973) You should grow only so much as you can look after yourself.
('10', 24, 3, 22, 53034) Please let me know what made Anibehn ill, the nature of her illess and for how many days she has gone to Tongaat, and other news.
('10', 24, 3, 23, 53164) It is a matter of joy that Kababhai got a son.
('10', 24, 3, 24, 53211) However, as you know my ideas in the matter, I feel sorry too.
('10', 24, 3, 25, 53274) Thinking of the state of affairs in the country, I believe very few Indians need marry at the present time.
('10', 24, 3, 26, 53382) The significance of marriage is also very deep.
('10', 24, 3, 27, 53430) A person who marries in order to satisfy his carnal desire is lower than even the beast.
('10', 24, 3, 28, 53519) For the married, it is considered proper to have sexual intercourse only for having progeny.
('10', 24, 3, 29, 53612) The scriptures also say so.
('10', 24, 3, 30, 53640) Thus considered, all the progeny that is born now is the issue of passion.
('10', 25, 0, 1, 53715) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 25, 1, 2, 53756) Hence it is that the children born are mean and faithless and continue to be so.
('10', 25, 1, 3, 53837) I do not want to discuss these things further with you; for that one has to go deeper into them.
('10', 25, 1, 4, 53934) But I want you to understand the purport of what I have said above; and, understanding it, conquer your senses.
('10', 25, 1, 5, 54046) Do not be scared by this and think that I want to bind you not to marry even after the age of 25. I do not want to put undue pressure on you or on anyone whatever.
('10', 25, 1, 6, 54210) I just want to give you advice.
('10', 25, 1, 7, 54242) If you do not think of marriage even at the age of 25, I think it will be to your good.
('10', 25, 1, 8, 54330) But in case you feel like marrying then, I would like to explain to you the meaning of marriage from Kababhai’s example.
('10', 25, 1, 9, 54451) I am putting this serious subject before you, though you are but a child, simply because I have a high opinion of your character.
('10', 25, 1, 10, 54581) I would not place these thoughts before any other child of your age, for he would not understand them.
('10', 25, 1, 11, 54684) More you will know from my letters to Ba and others, which I shall write hereafter.
('10', 25, 2, 12, 54768) Blessings from
('10', 25, 4, 13, 54783) From the original Gujarati in Gandhiji’s hand : C. W. 85
('10', 25, 5, 14, 54840) Courtesy : Sushilabehn Gandhi
('10', 25, 6, 15, 54870) 15. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD CREWE
('10', 25, 7, 16, 54916) [LONDON,] August 11, 1909
('10', 25, 8, 17, 54942) SIR, In connection with the interview that the Earl of Crewe was pleased to grant Mr. Hajee Habib and me yesterday on the British Indian struggle in the Transvaal, I beg to mention that a cablegram 1
('10', 25, 9, 18, 55142) has been received by the South Africa British Indian Committee from Lorenco Marques, showing that probably a hundred British Indians— presumably passive resisters—are likely to be deported any day through that port to India.
('10', 25, 9, 19, 55367) His Lordship is doubtless aware that this method of deportation has caused a great deal of misery and has formed a subject of repeated communications to the Colonial Office.
('10', 25, 10, 20, 55541) 1 L. W. Ritch wrote on the same day to the Foreign Office, quoting the cable which read: “Probably hundred deportees any day here.
('10', 25, 10, 21, 55672) No reply intervention.
('10', 25, 10, 22, 55695) Consul referred Imperial July sixteenth.” The matter had been referred to the British Consul at Lorenco Marques, but no reply was forthcoming.
('10', 26, 0, 1, 55838) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 27
('10', 26, 1, 2, 55880) In view, however, of the negotiations that are going on for a settlement of the question, may I request His Lordship’s intervention with a view at least of postponing any such deportation during negotiations.

('10', 26, 6, 7, 56245) [LONDON,] August 11, 1909
('10', 26, 7, 8, 56271) MY LORD, I beg to thank you for your letter of the 10th instant.
('10', 26, 7, 9, 56336) I am glad that you are pleased with the proviso I have suggested.
('10', 26, 7, 10, 56402) 1 May I say that the proviso does not, in my opinion, involve a sacrifice of any essential principle.
('10', 26, 8, 11, 56504) As the negotiations are still to continue, it will be perhaps as well not to circulate the statement among the newspaper editors or amongst sympathisers.
('10', 26, 8, 12, 56658) Newspaper editors as editors are hardly interested in anything that is not sent to them for publication, and I am chary of circulating the statement among sympathisers without taking them into confidence as to what is going on.
('10', 26, 8, 13, 56886) Subject, therefore, to Your Lordship’s confirmation, I shall hold over the circulation of the statement pending negotiations.
('10', 26, 8, 14, 57012) 3 Although I know that I am trespassing upon your time, as I am
('10', 26, 9, 15, 57076) 1 Vide “Letter to Lord Ampthill”,9 8 1909 Commenting on this Lord Ampthill had observed: “So far as I can judge, you would actually be securing a recognition of right, though of course a very limited one, if the law itself were to declare that six Indians per annum may be admitted annually as permanent residents.
('10', 26, 9, 16, 57391) It would be the gain of a practical and positive, though limited, right as against the theoretical and unavailable right which you are contending.
('10', 26, 9, 17, 57538) The ‘proviso’ which you suggest seems to me to be a clever solution of the difficulty and I shall at once try what can be done with it, but without letting it be known that it comes from you.” 2 This assertion has reference to Lord Ampthill’s remark: “I am more glad than I can say to know that you are thus far prepared to make a sacrifice as, after our talk yesterday, I despaired of a settlement.” 3 Lord Ampthill had suggested that it might be helpful to give the “Statement” to newspaper editors only for their information and to sympathisers for their confidential use.

('10', 28, 2, 3, 60241) Mr. Dhingra, it is said, will be hanged on the 17th.
('10', 28, 2, 4, 60294) But it is also likely that the death penalty will be commuted.
('10', 28, 3, 5, 60357) HOUSE OF COMMONS
('10', 28, 4, 6, 60374) There has been quite a row in the House of Commons about the budget proposals recently introduced.
('10', 28, 4, 7, 60473) The sessions continue right through the night, with the result that half the number of members stretch themselves out for a nap right in the midst of all, wake up when it is time for voting and resume the nap as soon as the voting is over.
('10', 28, 4, 8, 60713) Such is the condition of the greatest Parliament in the world.
('10', 28, 4, 9, 60776) How, in these circumstances, they attend to the nation’s business—readers may imagine for themselves.
('10', 28, 4, 10, 60878) We find that most people are selfish.
('10', 28, 4, 11, 60916) It will not be wrong to say that the sun of pure justice has set.
('10', 28, 4, 12, 60982) Relatively, the British people behave somewhat better and that is why they outshine the other nations.
('10', 28, 4, 13, 61085) However, it does not seem likely that Western civilization will survive much longer.

('10', 30, 1, 2, 64038) While these negotiations were proceeding, there was a cable from Delagoa Bay to say that about a hundred Indians were likely to be deported.
('10', 30, 1, 3, 64179) The information has been forwarded to Lord Crewe.
('10', 30, 2, 4, 64229) Everything possible is being done in the matter.
('10', 30, 2, 5, 64278) While I was writing this, I received a cable 2 from Johannesburg, reporting the release of satyagrahis and the immediate re entry of Mr. Rustomjee.

('10', 30, 2, 7, 64512) Reading it, I felt happy and cried too.
('10', 30, 2, 8, 64552) This is exactly what I had expected of Rustomjee.
('10', 30, 2, 9, 64602) He has been beyond praise.
('10', 30, 2, 10, 64629) It made me happy to think that there are such men among Indians.
('10', 30, 2, 11, 64694) I cried because he had to suffer so much.
('10', 30, 2, 12, 64736) It is only when leading Indians set such examples that the people will acquire a backbone.
('10', 30, 2, 13, 64827) If everyone followed this example, Indians would have nothing to suffer.
('10', 30, 2, 14, 64900) I see from experience that we have now plenty of brave Indians who are ready to go through extreme suffering for the sake of the motherland.
('10', 30, 2, 15, 65041) If we have a settlement, so much the better; should there be none, however, my only prayer to Indians is this: “Do not betray your pledge.
('10', 30, 2, 16, 65180) Suffering for a just cause brings more real happiness than what generally passes as such.
('10', 30, 2, 17, 65270) At any rate, in the broken state that we are in, we have no right whatever to indulge in luxury.
('10', 30, 2, 18, 65367) We shall get used to suffering after a little experience.
('10', 30, 2, 19, 65425) Therefore, train yourself to endure suffering.” I for one know of no other way.

('10', 32, 1, 3, 68202) In the main, however, the statement appears to me to be accurate.
('10', 32, 1, 4, 68268) I am sending the translation to show what avoidable hardships most British Indian political prisoners are undergoing in the Transvaal prisons.
('10', 32, 1, 5, 68411) I deliberately use the adjective “political” .
('10', 32, 1, 6, 68458) I am quite aware of the fact that there is no legal division of prisoners in the Transvaal.
('10', 32, 1, 7, 68550) At the same time, there is no doubt that the Government recognise the fact that there are prisoners who are hardened criminals, and there are prisoners who have committed only technical breaches of the laws of the Colony.
('10', 32, 1, 8, 68772) Unfortunately, this natural division is not only not recognized in favour of Indian passive resisters, but there seems to be a desire to treat them somewhat more harshly because they are passive resisters.
('10', 32, 1, 9, 68978) The insufficiency and the unsuitability of food and the fact of Indian prisoners being classed with native prisoners are two very serious difficulties, causing a great deal of misery.
('10', 32, 1, 10, 69162) My colleague and I trust that His Lordship will be pleased to inquire into the matter and, if possible, secure some relief whilst some members of the Transvaal Government are in the metropolis.

('10', 32, 3, 12, 69395) EXTRACT TRANSLATION FROM A LETTER RECEIVED BY MR. GANDHI FROM MR. MAHOMED KHAN AT JOHANNESBURG, DATED 19TH JULY, 1909 I was discharged on the 12th July last.
('10', 32, 3, 13, 69553) The only regret I had was that I could not meet you in the gaol.
('10', 32, 3, 14, 69618) The day I was admitted I asked the chief warder to let me see you, but he did not grant the permission.
('10', 32, 3, 15, 69722) I was kept in the ‘reserve camp’ which has been established only lately.
('10', 32, 3, 16, 69795) There was much suffering there.
('10', 32, 3, 17, 69827) The water supply was not sufficient.
('10', 32, 3, 18, 69864) There was no bathing facility.
('10', 32, 3, 19, 69895) I had hardly a bath during the two months I was in the prison.
('10', 32, 3, 20, 69958) I complained to the officer.
('10', 32, 3, 21, 69987) He said: “Are you blind?
('10', 32, 3, 22, 70012) Do you not see that there is no bathroom here?
('10', 32, 3, 23, 70059) ” I then said: “What are prisoners to do if there is no bathroom for a year?
('10', 32, 3, 24, 70136) ” He then said: “They have to do without.” The food supply was also not enough.
('10', 32, 3, 25, 70216) Moreover, on Saturdays, when the prisoners have to wash their towels, socks, etc., there was only one tank among 200. I received no ghee (clarified butter).
('10', 32, 4, 26, 70373) 1 Acknowledging this letter on September 3, the Colonial Office informed Gandhiji that a copy of these papers had been sent to the Governor of the Transvaal for a report.
('10', 33, 0, 1, 70544) 34 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 33, 1, 2, 70585) mixed fat with rice, which I did not eat.
('10', 33, 1, 3, 70627) I complained about it, but my complaint went unheeded.
('10', 33, 1, 4, 70682) I drew the attention of the chief warder to the fact that you had complained about absence of ghee, and the chief warder said that, as you were not able to eat enough because of the want of ghee, you were told that other Indian prisoners also would be supplied with ghee, in order to induce you to take your food.
('10', 33, 1, 5, 70996) You know the disposition of the Governor of the gaol and the chief warder.
('10', 33, 1, 6, 71071) When we have to complain, they do not tarry long enough to listen to it.
('10', 33, 1, 7, 71144) Later, I received food according to the new scale.
('10', 33, 1, 8, 71195) The latter also is not sufficient.
('10', 33, 1, 9, 71230) Four ounces of bread were allowed, but I never felt that I had more than two ounces.
('10', 33, 1, 10, 71315) Gruel is only gruel in name because it is all water, and, then, it is too little.
('10', 33, 1, 11, 71397) From the bread, rice, vegetables etc., supplied, the Native prisoners working in the yard steal a great deal.
('10', 33, 1, 12, 71507) The quantity of rice allowed was six ounces, but hardly three ounces were received by me.
('10', 33, 1, 13, 71597) I believe that about fifteen dishes full of food are stolen by the Kaffirs and the warders say nothing.
('10', 33, 1, 14, 71701) Moreover, the warders are abusive.
('10', 33, 1, 15, 71736) I put up with all this silently.
('10', 33, 1, 16, 71769) The work was not extra heavy.
('10', 33, 1, 17, 71799) I was taken with a span consisting of 32 men to Lord Selborne’s bungalow.
('10', 33, 1, 18, 71873) There we had to do grasscutting, roller turning, digging, stone breaking, cutting, trees, cleaning ground, and also watering trees.
('10', 33, 1, 19, 72005) Of this work, digging alone was somewhat difficult, because it was all stony; the stone was, moreover, very hard.
('10', 33, 1, 20, 72119) The garden was situated on a rise.
('10', 33, 1, 21, 72154) We were locked up with the.
('10', 33, 1, 22, 72182) Kaffirs.
('10', 33, 1, 23, 72191) There was not a single European officer who described us as Indians.
('10', 33, 1, 24, 72260) We were called “ sammies” or “coolies”.
('10', 33, 1, 25, 72300) Most of the warders were Dutch; some of them were youngsters, who had no knowledge of the work.
('10', 33, 1, 26, 72396) At length came 74 Madras Indians.
('10', 33, 1, 27, 72430) They were in very great distress; they are suffering much.
('10', 33, 1, 28, 72489) Among them are five very old men, over perhaps sixty.
('10', 33, 1, 29, 72543) They could not walk well.
('10', 33, 1, 30, 72569) These also are sent out to work early in the morning in a shivering condition, and as the tramp is long, they, poor fellows, get tired, and yet they utter not a word of complaint.
('10', 33, 1, 31, 72749) Therein lies their bravery.
('10', 33, 1, 32, 72777) The whole of the Pretoria Location is empty.
('10', 33, 2, 33, 72822) Colonial Office Records: 291/142; also, from a photostat of the typewritten office copy: S. N. 4949 and 5015
('10', 33, 3, 34, 72931) 1 In their reply of September 30, the Transvaal Ministers pointed out to the Governor that “the allegation that the water supply in the Pretoria Prisoners Reserve Camp is not sufficient is absolutely untrue”, that prisoners had ample bathing facilities, that the other allegations made in Khan’s statement were without basis, that the Indian prisoners were invariably housed in cells by themselves and were treated humanely and that there was no desire on the part of the prison officers to treat them harshly because they were passive resisters.

('10', 35, 0, 1, 75455) 36 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 35, 1, 2, 75496) You will recall the question.
('10', 35, 1, 3, 75526) The present legislation of the Transvaal creates a racial distinction as to immigration–i.e., no new Asiatic, however cultured he may be, may enter the Transvaal because he is an Asiatic.
('10', 35, 1, 4, 75714) Indians contend that this is a departure from the traditional colonial policy and that it is unnecessary.
('10', 35, 1, 5, 75820) The Cape, Natal and Australia make good their policy of restricting Asiatic immigration by having an education test applicable to all, but varying in its severity.
('10', 35, 1, 6, 75984) This policy cannot be described as dishonest because the scope of the Act is known to all.
('10', 35, 1, 7, 76075) But to prohibit even a very limited immigration of Asiatics as such, is to put a deliberate affront on a whole race.
('10', 35, 1, 8, 76192) Moreover the recognition of such a racial distinction cannot fail to reflect upon the resident Asiatic population and be used as a precedent for further disabling legislation.
('10', 35, 1, 9, 76368) From the Colonial standpoint too there would seem to be no justification for the drastic policy underlying the Transvaal Act.
('10', 35, 1, 10, 76494) British Indians accept the policy of virtual exclusion.
('10', 35, 1, 11, 76550) The question is as to the manner of procuring it.
('10', 35, 1, 12, 76600) The Transvaal manner importing the colour bar offends the self respect of Asiatics.
('10', 35, 1, 13, 76684) Hence the terrible suffering undergone by over 2,500 Indian passive resisters.
('10', 35, 1, 14, 76763) If you will give my colleague and me an appointment, we would wait upon you 1. I am personally more concerned with our aspirations than with agitating for relief from the Imperial Government.
('10', 35, 3, 15, 76955) Yours truly,
('10', 35, 4, 16, 76968) M. K. GANDHI THE HONOURABLE W. P. SCHREINER MORLEY’S HOTEL TRAFALGAR SQUARE, W. C.

('10', 40, 4, 15, 87097) 29. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD CREWE [LONDON,] August 24, 1909
('10', 40, 5, 16, 87169) SIR, I beg to invite Lord Crewe’s attention to the fact that a cablegram has just been received from Mr. Polak, who is at present representing the Transvaal British Indians in India, to the effect that a public meeting is to be held at Bombay in connection with the Indian struggle on the 31st instant.
('10', 40, 5, 17, 87472) The cablegram adds that two Indians have arrived in Bombay, having been deported by the Transvaal Government.

('10', 44, 4, 26, 95329) 33. DEPUTATION · NOTES [–IX]
('10', 44, 5, 27, 95358) [August 27, 1909] This week has been like the last: a settlement is nowhere in sight.
('10', 44, 5, 28, 95444) It has also been reported that General Smuts may leave for the Transvaal in the course of the week.
('10', 44, 5, 29, 95544) One does not know therefore what to say.
('10', 44, 5, 30, 95585) It does not seem that there has been duplicity [on anyone’s part].
('10', 44, 5, 31, 95652) Sir Muncherji has received a reply today, August 27, to the letter which he wrote to General Smuts seeking an interview.
('10', 44, 5, 32, 95773) The reply says that, since private negotiations for a settlement are in progress, the [proposed] meeting has been postponed for the time being.
('10', 44, 5, 33, 95917) This has led people to believe that, perhaps, a settlement will come about.
('10', 44, 5, 34, 95993) On the other hand, it is also thought that the continued delay indicates some difficulty in getting our demands accepted.
('10', 44, 5, 35, 96115) It is difficult to know what the true position is.
('10', 44, 5, 36, 96166) Speaking for myself, I can
('10', 45, 0, 1, 96193) 46 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 45, 1, 2, 96234) only say that we are little concerned with the outcome of the negotiations for a settlement; be that as it may.
('10', 45, 1, 3, 96346) If one is prepared to suffer, what is there for one to fear or be anxious about ?
('10', 45, 1, 4, 96428) I have no doubt whatever, nor should any satyagrahi have any, that our demands are bound to be accepted sooner or later.
('10', 45, 1, 5, 96549) Lord Ampthill also has information that the negotiations are still proceeding.

('10', 45, 2, 7, 96670) 34. LONDON
('10', 45, 3, 8, 96681) [After August 27, 1909]
('10', 45, 4, 9, 96705) NATAL DEPUTATION
('10', 45, 5, 10, 96722) The members are still busy dispatching copies of their statement to several people, and meeting public men.
('10', 45, 5, 11, 96830) They have sent a large number of copies to India with a forwarding letter.
('10', 45, 5, 12, 96905) The following is a summary of the letter 1 :
('10', 45, 6, 13, 96950) APPEAL TO INDIA
('10', 45, 7, 14, 96966) We are sending herewith a copy of the statement made before the Colonial Secretary regarding the condition of Indians in Natal.
('10', 45, 7, 15, 97094) We who have been specially deputed to see the authorities in London and to inform public opinion have already waited on the Secretary of State for the Colonies and other officials and have circulated very widely copies of the statement.
('10', 45, 7, 16, 97331) We feel that, unless India helps us seriously, it is not likely that Lord Crewe and Lord Morley will be able to secure much relief.
('10', 45, 7, 17, 97463) British Indians in Natal form a very considerable portion of the inhabitants of Natal, have very large interests in that Colony and are drawn from all parts of India.
('10', 45, 7, 18, 97630) They number over 100,000, of whom about 10,000 belong to the trading class, the rest are either indentured Indians or those who have once been under indenture and are now free.
('10', 45, 7, 19, 97807) It is an acknowledged fact that the prosperity of Natal depends largely, if not entirely, on
('10', 45, 8, 20, 97900) 1 This was dated August 27, 1909. The English text of the letter is reproduced here from Indian Opinion, 25 9 1909, with some changes needed to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati version.
('10', 46, 0, 1, 98096) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 47
('10', 46, 1, 2, 98138) the help she receives from India in the shape of indentured labour.
('10', 46, 1, 3, 98206) We have also spared no pains to help India.
('10', 46, 1, 4, 98250) At the time of the last two famines, subscriptions were collected from rich and poor to the best of their means and forwarded to the famine funds.
('10', 46, 1, 5, 98397) We ask for no pecuniary assistance, but we do feel that India can successfully alleviate by kindly assistance the very great distress we are suffering in Natal.
('10', 46, 1, 6, 98558) As will appear from the statement, we are being crushed out of existence in Natat in a threefold manner.
('10', 46, 1, 7, 98663) Our trade is slowly being reduced by means of an unjust and tyrannical administration of a licensing law that leaves in the hands of the Licensing Officer and the Licensing Board—who are themselves our trade rivals—unlimited powers, without any check from the judicial tribunals of the Colony.
('10', 46, 1, 8, 98957) Indian labourers are worked almost as slaves for the benefit of Natal, but, as soon as they have finished their service under the Natal planters of mine owners, they, their wives and children are taxed exorbitantly, and thus prevented from settling in the Colony and earning an honest livelihood as free men, and our future progress is almost entirely prevented by depriving us of even ordinary facilities for giving a suitable education to our youth.
('10', 46, 1, 9, 99409) Unless, therefore, by means of meetings, memorials and such other ways continuously adopted, India insists on our grievances being redressed, it is only a question of time when we shall be slowly starved out of the Colony.
('10', 46, 1, 10, 99632) There is a tangible remedy at the disposal of the Indian Government, and that is, to stop the supply of indentured labour that annually flows into it unless the Colony deals justly by the Indian traders and labourers.
('10', 46, 1, 11, 99850) This course was adopted by Lord Curzon and he even sent a dispatch to the Natal Ministers almost threatening to take action unless redress was granted, especially to British Indian traders.
('10', 46, 1, 12, 100040) We do not know what the result of those negotiations was, but, instead of any redress being vouchsafed to us, our condition ever since that time has become much worse owing to the stringency of the measures stated above and their almost remorseless enforcement.
('10', 46, 1, 13, 100302) Our means of subsistence are curtailed every day, and our very existence in the Colony in the enjoyment even of the elementary rights of British citizenship is imperilled.
('10', 47, 0, 1, 100474) 48 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 47, 1, 2, 100515) LETTER TO “ THE TIMES”
('10', 47, 2, 3, 100538) A statement appeared in The Times to the effect that the deputation had given up the demand for the franchise.
('10', 47, 2, 4, 100649) There were other incorrect statements also.
('10', 47, 2, 5, 100693) A letter was, therefore, addressed over Mr. Anglia’s signature, which I summarize below: 1
('10', 47, 3, 6, 100784) You say in your yesterday’s issue that the British Indians have no grievance as regards the Parliamentary franchise.
('10', 47, 3, 7, 100901) Although we do not lay great stress in the political franchise, we have never admitted it not to be a grievance.
('10', 47, 3, 8, 101014) Our grievances are many, but the most pressing have been placed before Lord Crewe, so that his attention and our energy may be concentrated only upon them.
('10', 47, 3, 9, 101170) Franchise and other rights will‚ be of no use to us if, by a simple “stroke of the pen” by the Licensing Officer, we are deprived of the facility for honestly earning our livelihood, no matter how large and long acquired our vested right may be, and of the future generations’ ability to utilize the right of vote, by being intellectually starved in the way of education, and if the best Indian labourers in the Colony may be condemned to servitude by a ruinous special tax.
('10', 47, 3, 10, 101645) We have presented the British public with this trinity of grievances (and our requests have been universally admitted to be very moderate).
('10', 47, 3, 11, 101785) They affect our physical and intellectual wants.
('10', 47, 3, 12, 101834) The withholding of the franchise under democratic institutions will ever remain to the British Indians in Natal a serious grievance.
('10', 47, 3, 13, 101967) In not pressing this point home at the present moment, we have bowed before the storm.
('10', 47, 3, 14, 102054) We have shown our hereditary self restraint and, in the very act, we are proving our fitness for political rights.
('10', 47, 3, 15, 102169) You say that “the British Indians claim on racial and intellectual grounds a position of superiority to the Native races of South Africa”.
('10', 47, 3, 16, 102308) I submit with due respect that we do not want to lay any such claim, nor, in my opinion, is it necessary to make these fine distinctions with reference to the enjoyment of elementary rights that every civilized man should possess in civilized countries.
('10', 47, 4, 17, 102562) 1 This letter appeared in The Times, 27 8 1909. The text is reproduced here from Indian Opinion, 25 9 1909, with some changes needed to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati version.

('10', 51, 7, 10, 108043) 37. LETTER TO AMEER ALI
('10', 51, 8, 11, 108067) [LONDON,] August 30, 1909
('10', 51, 9, 12, 108093) DEAR MR. AMEER ALI,
('10', 51, 10, 13, 108113) I have your postcard.
('10', 51, 10, 14, 108135) I have purposely refrained from writing to you, in order that I may not interfere with your rest.
('10', 51, 10, 15, 108233) Had there been anything striking, I should certainly have written.
('10', 51, 10, 16, 108300) Moreover, I waited for the letter that you promised in your postcard.
('10', 51, 10, 17, 108370) Not having had the letter, I concluded that you were too busy to write it.
('10', 51, 10, 18, 108445) The Transvaal matter is still the subject of negotiations.
('10', 51, 10, 19, 108504) General Smuts left on Saturday and gave the following message to Reuter:
('10', 51, 11, 20, 108577) 1 In his letter of August 24, Lord Ampthill had expressed himself as disconcerted at the unexpected departure of General Smuts for South Africa without replying to his suggestions.
('10', 51, 11, 21, 108758) He had also referred to a leading article in The Times, which gave a “distinct hint that there would be some settlement of the British Indian question”.
('10', 51, 11, 22, 108911) In his letter of August 26, he referred to Lord Crewe’s reply that “the negotiations are still going on, so that there is yet hope of something being settled”.
('10', 51, 11, 23, 109071) Lord Ampthill decided not to raise the question in the House of Lords, as he had intended to.
('10', 51, 11, 24, 109165) “I cannot think of anything,” he added, “which we are leaving undone or which we could do with advantage at the present moment; we must still wait patiently.” 2 Vide the following item.
('10', 52, 0, 1, 109351) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 53
('10', 52, 1, 2, 109393) I hope it 1 is in a fair way to disappear from the horizon of Transvaal politics.
('10', 52, 1, 3, 109475) The vast majority of Transvaal Indians are sick to death of the agitation carried on by some of their extreme representatives, and have quietly submitted to the law.
('10', 52, 1, 4, 109641) I have had repeated conversations with Lord Crewe and other important leaders interested in this matter, and I think it will be possible now to find a solution of this vexed question which all reasonable men will consider right and fair.
('10', 52, 1, 5, 109879) And there the matter rests at present.
('10', 52, 1, 6, 109918) There is some ground, there fore, for hoping that a settlement will be arrived at.
('10', 52, 1, 7, 110001) Lord Ampthill has worked wonderfully in the matter, but if the negotiations are protracted, it is now a question, in view of General Smuts’ return to South Africa, whether Mr. Hajee Habib and I should stay here or whether our place is now in South Africa and, if necessary, in the Transvaal gaol.
('10', 52, 1, 8, 110298) As to the Natal deputation, Mr. Abdul Caadir and friends are moving heaven and earth.
('10', 52, 1, 9, 110384) They are circulating the statement broadcast.
('10', 52, 1, 10, 110430) They have seen Lord Crewe and they are seeing, this week, Lord Morley and Colonel Seely.
('10', 52, 1, 11, 110519) They have also been in correspondence with the Aga Khan, who is in Paris undergoing medical treatment.
('10', 52, 1, 12, 110622) Sir Muncherji is also in constant touch.
('10', 52, 1, 13, 110663) A copy of their letter to the Indian public shows the remedy they are now concentrating their energy upon.
('10', 52, 1, 14, 110770) They have sent you the statement.
('10', 52, 1, 15, 110804) A letter has also been officially addressed to the Viceroy, asking him to adopt the remedy of suspending Indian immigration to Natal unless relief is granted.
('10', 52, 1, 16, 110963) They are most anxious to pay their respects personally to you, especially as they have been spec ially instructed to meet you and be guided by your advice .
('10', 52, 1, 17, 111120) I would, there fore, thank you to let me have an idea as to when you are likely to return.
('10', 52, 1, 18, 111211) I hope there has been no further hindrance to the cure you have been undergoing and that you will return thoroughly invigorated.
('10', 52, 1, 19, 111340) I may mention that a public meeting will be held tomorrow in Bombay to protest against the Transvaal legislation.
('10', 52, 2, 20, 111454) I remain,
('10', 52, 3, 21, 111464) Yours sincerely, JUSTICE AMEER ALI, C. I. E. HOTEL SCHWEIZERHOF VULPERA TARASP [SWITZERLAND]

('10', 53, 1, 2, 111681) 38. LETTER TO SWAMI SHANKERANAND
('10', 53, 2, 3, 111714) [LONDON,] August 30, 1909
('10', 53, 3, 4, 111740) DEAR SWAMIJI, Received your letter.
('10', 53, 3, 5, 111776) I had read your speech earlier about Curzon Wyllie delivered at the Depot Road.
('10', 53, 3, 6, 111856) I also read your letter on education.
('10', 53, 3, 7, 111894) I am grieved at reading all the three.
('10', 53, 3, 8, 111933) Your letter to me shows your views on Islam and the other two items show your behaviour towards the people of that faith.
('10', 53, 3, 9, 112055) I do not say anything about your views on Islam.
('10', 53, 3, 10, 112104) But your sarcastic remarks about Islam are, so far as I know, against the spirit of Hinduism.
('10', 53, 3, 11, 112198) But even these I do not mind.
('10', 53, 3, 12, 112228) What has particularly been painful to me is your expedient and immoral behaviour while making those remarks.
('10', 53, 3, 13, 112337) In saying that the British are the defenders of the Hindu religion, you have shown our utter helplessness.
('10', 53, 3, 14, 112444) If I myself am not able to protect my religion, how can a person of another faith do it ?
('10', 53, 3, 15, 112534) Your ideas on education I consider as only causing a split between the Hindus and the Mussalmans.
('10', 53, 3, 16, 112632) If it is necessary to keep so much distance between the Hindus and the Mussalmans, then, Hindustan deserves to remain slave.
('10', 53, 3, 17, 112757) How, then, can one find fault with the foreigner ?
('10', 53, 3, 18, 112808) And if that distance is insisted upon, Hinduism would just perish.
('10', 53, 3, 19, 112875) Fortu nately, Hinduism is sound and stable.
('10', 53, 3, 20, 112919) I have firm faith that a religion that has maintained itself for thousands of years will not perish even at the hands of our priests.
('10', 53, 3, 21, 113053) What shall I write to you?
('10', 53, 3, 22, 113080) I have respect for your knowledge; but I am pained at your behaviour.
('10', 53, 3, 23, 113150) [From Gujarati]
('10', 53, 4, 24, 113166) Gandhiji na Patro and Gandhiji ni Sadhna

('10', 54, 9, 15, 113879) [LONDON,] September 1, 1909
('10', 54, 10, 16, 113907) MY LORD, I am exceedingly obliged to Your Lordship for your letter of the 31st ultimo.
('10', 54, 10, 17, 113994) If General Smuts’ decision 1 be final, it is unfortunate.
('10', 54, 10, 18, 114052) But I fear that it will not be possible for me to recede from the position as to the question of “right”.
('10', 54, 10, 19, 114158) In my opinion, nothing will be gained by his making the residence of a limited number of educated Indian immigrants permanent, if the “right” be not recognized.
('10', 54, 10, 20, 114319) No Indian need enter the Transvaal if only the theoretical “right” remain inviolate.
('10', 54, 10, 21, 114404) The origin of number six lies in Mr. Cartwright’s anxiety that I should give some tangible proof of the community’s declaration that, behind the question of the status of educated Indians, there was no intention to flood the Transvaal with British Indians.
