('10', 61, 1, 2, 126311) a cutting giving General Smuts’ statement to Reuter, before he sailed from Southampton.
('10', 61, 1, 3, 126399) It, however, now appears that what he wants to do is to repeal the Act and to give permanent certificates of residence to a limited number of educated Indians; thus, he does not want to recognise the “right” of entry.
('10', 61, 1, 4, 126617) I am rather glad if he does this and makes a public declaration.
('10', 61, 1, 5, 126682) The issue again narrows down to the one and only point, namely, the status of educated Indians and the self respect of India.
('10', 61, 1, 6, 126808) We then approach England and India on a clear cut proposition, and ask the Indians in the Transvaal also to continue the battle until that point is decided.
('10', 61, 1, 7, 126965) You will see from my letter to Lord Ampthill how I view it.
('10', 61, 1, 8, 127025) I almost feel, before we return to South Africa, we may visit India and then pay another visit to London and retrace our steps.
('10', 61, 1, 9, 127153) I know, if General Smuts makes the public declaration in accordance with Lord Ampthill’s letter, the fight here will be most difficult.
('10', 61, 1, 10, 127289) However, that does not dismay me, though I question very much whether any useful purpose will be served by public meetings if any could be held, and canvassing of Members of Parliament, until further suffering has been gone through.
('10', 61, 1, 11, 127522) I would far rather be in gaol than carry on what may prove to be almost a useless agitation.
('10', 61, 1, 12, 127615) There may be in this dcsire to avoid it a touch of laziness; I hope not.
('10', 61, 1, 13, 127688) I do not wish to shirk having to see people and address meetings, in so far as that may be necessary, but whenever I have a quiet moment to myself, I do continually ask myself as to whether I should be doing right in remaining here for the purpose of canvassing.
('10', 61, 1, 14, 127951) Wherever your meeting is held, I hope you will have succeeded in getting Mr. Armstrong and other Anglo Indians to attend it.
('10', 61, 1, 15, 128076) I hope you have been sending the Gujarati and English cuttings to Johannesburg also.
('10', 61, 1, 16, 128161) In order not to disappoint people there, I have been, by way of double precaution, sending, to them the cuttings received by you.
('10', 61, 1, 17, 128291) You do not mind my not replying to your cables immediately, when you do not get one from me as early as you may expect it.
('10', 61, 1, 18, 128414) Please under stand that there is good reason for my not having replied.
('10', 61, 1, 19, 128486) For instance, you have asked me whether there is any hope.
('10', 61, 1, 20, 128545) I am delaying the reply, as I am waiting for a call from Lord Crewe.
('10', 61, 1, 21, 128614) I should then be able, somewhat definitely, to tell you whether there is or not.
('10', 61, 1, 22, 128695) Just now, I should say there is none.
('10', 61, 2, 23, 128733) Yours sincerely,

('10', 62, 1, 2, 128852) 47. DEPUTATION NOTES [–X ]
('10', 62, 2, 3, 128879) [After September 3, 1909] I am tired of reporting every time that I have no news to give about a settlement.
('10', 62, 2, 4, 128988) But that is what I must say again.
('10', 62, 2, 5, 129023) I know, of course, that those who are perfect satyagrahis will not weary of reading this, for they are not concerned whether or not a settlement is reached.
('10', 62, 2, 6, 129180) They stand victorious in any case.
('10', 62, 2, 7, 129215) However, I am really in a position to give a little more information this time.
('10', 62, 2, 8, 129295) We have been told that General Smuts will at least repeal the Act.
('10', 62, 2, 9, 129362) But as regards the issue of educated Indians, he will grant permits for permanent residence to a limited number as a matter of favour.
('10', 62, 2, 10, 129497) They will have the same rights as those who have been registered.
('10', 62, 2, 11, 129563) But I see no advantage in this.
('10', 62, 2, 12, 129595) They may not call us “dead”, but use the expression “passed away”; yet, we shall be dead all the same.
('10', 62, 2, 13, 129698) It is against the quick and living that we have to pit our strength.
('10', 62, 2, 14, 129767) We must therefore continue the fight.
('10', 62, 2, 15, 129805) I have no definite news, though.
('10', 62, 2, 16, 129838) We shall know the truth in a few days.
('10', 62, 2, 17, 129877) I do not think there will be any formal negotiations for a settlement this time.
('10', 62, 2, 18, 129958) In due time, our demands will be conceded, and then alone shall we be in a position to hang up our weapons.
('10', 62, 2, 19, 130066) If, as I have suggested above, the Act is now repealed and permanent permits for six men are offered, that will give further impetus to the fight.
('10', 62, 2, 20, 130213) Its real nature will come to be better understood.
('10', 62, 2, 21, 130264) Everyone will then realize that we have been fighting not for [the admission of] a particular number [of educated men], but for India’s honour.There must be legal equality with the whites; it will not matter then if, in practice, not even a single Indian is able to get in.
('10', 62, 2, 22, 130538) We can bear that.
('10', 62, 2, 23, 130556) But it would not serve our purpose even if permits are issued to 50 men, so long as the law itself is tainted.
('10', 62, 2, 24, 130667) We are not fighting for ourselves, but for others.
('10', 62, 2, 25, 130718) It is not a fight on behalf of the educated or the highly educated, but for India’s honour, for our self respect, for the fulfilment of our pledge.
('10', 62, 2, 26, 130866) The more we suffer in this cause, the happier we shall be.
('10', 62, 2, 27, 130925) Those who fight in this spirit are true satyagrahis—men with soulforce.
('10', 62, 2, 28, 130997) I want to see every Indian join this beautiful, sublime struggle.
('10', 62, 2, 29, 131063) Readers must have noticed that the deputation has been acting all the time behind the scenes.
('10', 62, 2, 30, 131157) They should know all the same that
('10', 63, 0, 1, 131192) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 63, 1, 2, 131233) nothing that needs to be done will be left undone.
('10', 63, 1, 3, 131284) Our object is to get things done through the good offices of the Imperial Government.
('10', 63, 1, 4, 131370) So long as that is happening, nothing else needs to be done here (in England).
('10', 63, 1, 5, 131449) In attempting anything more, we may only damage the cause.
('10', 63, 1, 6, 131508) When the Imperial Government washes its hands of the business, we shall have to act publicly.
('10', 63, 1, 7, 131602) Eight weeks have passed in negotiations.
('10', 63, 1, 8, 131643) A little more time may yet elapse.
('10', 63, 1, 9, 131678) We shall then work publicly as and when necessary.
('10', 63, 1, 10, 131729) This is a time consuming process.
('10', 63, 1, 11, 131763) We shall need more time than we had supposed, but there is no escape.
('10', 63, 1, 12, 131833) Moreover, when the Imperial Government declares its helplessness after having tried to help us, our work here will become extremely difficult.
('10', 63, 1, 13, 131976) Not before we have gone through the ordeal of a bitter, intense and strenuous fight shall we be able to slay what Mr. Dawad Mahomed has termed an elephant.
('10', 63, 1, 14, 132132) The more I observe things, the more I realize that deputations, petitions, etc., are all in vain if there are no real sanctions behind them.
('10', 63, 1, 15, 132273) I see from experience that it is better to be in gaol than to have to seek interviews.
('10', 63, 1, 16, 132360) Mirabai has sung: Prepare not your draught from the twice bitter neem, Shunning the sweetness of the sugar and the sugarcane; Give not your love to the glow worm, Turning away from the light of sun and moon.
('10', 63, 1, 17, 132568) This saintly lady has told us that anyone who devotes himself entirely to love of God will find everything else bitter like neem juice and lustreless like the glow worm’s glitter.
('10', 63, 1, 18, 132748) Likewise, anyone who has had experience of satyagraha—soul force, who has found its spell irresistible, will have no pleasure in petitions and deputations.
('10', 63, 1, 19, 132904) ‘Why, then,’ the reader must ask me, ‘did you leave the happiness of gaol life to join the deputation?’ I have said in an earlier letter 1 that the deputation is a confession of the community’s weakness.
('10', 63, 1, 20, 133108) It became something of a duty to come [ here] on behalf of the weak.
('10', 63, 1, 21, 133177) But I can say from experience that the community can put us and other Indians to the best use by allowing us to be in gaol.
('10', 63, 1, 22, 133301) Those who lead a deputation cannot make a more skilfully drafted petition than the one that satyagrahis make by the fact of their being in gaol.
('10', 63, 1, 23, 133446) Men have now lost faith in such activities.
('10', 63, 1, 24, 133490) Personally,I make bold to say that, if
('10', 63, 2, 25, 133529) 1 Vide “Deputation’s Voyage [ I]”, Afterr 23 6 1909

('10', 64, 1, 3, 133730) In spite of these views of mine, I feel that, should there be no settlement after all, we should leave for India and, after doing everything necessary there, return to England to take any further steps that may be called for, and then go back to the Transvaal.
('10', 64, 1, 4, 133991) For the moment, however, these are mere castles in the air.

('10', 64, 1, 18, 135227) The reason which the Government gave for not permitting the meeting was that, since the Union was an accomplished fact, a Government officer like the Sheriff should not hold a [protest] meeting.

('10', 66, 1, 2, 137758) THIS CRAZY CIVILIZATION
('10', 66, 2, 3, 137782) London has gone mad over Mr. Bleriot 1 who flew in the air in an aeroplane and Dr. Cook who claims to have reached the North Pole.
('10', 66, 2, 4, 137913) Newspapers report their achievements in great detail.
('10', 66, 2, 5, 137967) People, it appears, throw away thousands of pounds after such things.
('10', 66, 2, 6, 138037) Personally, I am un able to see what miracles they have achieved.
('10', 66, 2, 7, 138103) No one points out what good it will do to mankind if planes fly in the air.
('10', 66, 2, 8, 138179) People go crazy over every impostor making a novel claim.
('10', 66, 2, 9, 138237) To me at least it appears that life would grow intolerable if there were to be too many planes in the air.
('10', 66, 2, 10, 138344) We have trains running underground; there are telegraph wires already hanging over us, and outside, on the roads, there is the deafening noise of trains.
('10', 66, 2, 11, 138498) If you now have planes flying in the air, take it that people will be done to death.
('10', 66, 2, 12, 138583) Looking at this land, I at any rate have grown disillusioned with Western civilization.
('10', 66, 2, 13, 138671) The people whom you meet on the way seem half crazy.
('10', 66, 2, 14, 138724) They spend their days in luxury or in making a bare living and retire at night thoroughly exhausted.
('10', 66, 2, 15, 138825) In this state of affairs, I cannot understand when they can devote themselves to prayers.
('10', 66, 2, 16, 138915) Suppose Dr. Cook has, in fact, been to the North Pole, what then?
('10', 66, 2, 17, 138981) People will not, on that account, get the slightest relief from their sufferings.
('10', 66, 2, 18, 139063) While Western civilization is still young, we find things have come to such a pass that, unless its whole machinery is thrown over board, people will destroy themselves like so many moths.
('10', 66, 2, 19, 139252) Even today we can see that there are more and more cases of suicide every day.
('10', 66, 2, 20, 139331) There are reasons why it may be advisable for people to come to England on some business or for education, but, generally speaking, I am definitely of the view that it is altogether undesirable for anyone to come or live here.
('10', 66, 2, 21, 139558) We shall consider this point at greater length some other time.
('10', 66, 3, 22, 139622) JOSEPH ROYEPPEN
('10', 66, 4, 23, 139638) I have already reported his departure on Saturday.
('10', 66, 4, 24, 139689) 2 I see indications that he will have no option but to go to gaol.
('10', 66, 4, 25, 139756) I hope he will do so.

('10', 67, 3, 4, 140056) SIR, Lord Ampthill informs Mr. Hajee Habib and me that the Earl of Crewe will presently ask us either to wait on His Lordship or depute some one we could see, and with whom we could discuss the Transvaal Indian question.
('10', 67, 4, 5, 140277) I am aware that His Lordship is very busy with many matters of State.
('10', 67, 4, 6, 140347) May I, however, remind you that Mr. Hajee Habib and I have been now in the metropolis for over eight weeks, and that great pressure is being put upon us from those who have sent us here to give the result of our mission?
('10', 67, 4, 7, 140568) I need hardly mention that we have purposely avoided all public activity, in order not to prejudice the negotiations that His Lord ship has been pleased to carry on with the Transvaal Ministers, with a view to bringing the struggle to an end.
('10', 67, 4, 8, 140811) My colleague and I will be obliged if you will place this letter before His Lordship, and let us know when our presence will be required.

('10', 76, 10, 15, 158014) The cablegram is but an indication of what my countrymen have to undergo in the Transvaal in their self imposed suffering.
('10', 76, 10, 16, 158137) But my colleague and I can have no reason for complaining.

('10', 76, 10, 19, 158432) In it he made the following remark:
('10', 76, 11, 20, 158468) The vast majority of Transvaal Indians are sick to death of the agitation carried on by some of their extreme representatives, and have quietly submitted to the law.
('10', 76, 11, 21, 158634) We have treated it as a rhetorical expression, and have allowed it

('10', 78, 11, 21, 161741) 1 Vide “Letter to Private Secretary to Lord Crewe”, 20 7 1909 2 Lord Ampthill wrote back on September 11 : “I cannot think that you will have to wait much longer for your answer from Lord Crewe and I should be very much surprised as well as pained if he declined to give you another hearing.
('10', 78, 11, 22, 162033) If you have not received an answer by the time this reaches you, you could with perfect propriety send a reminder pointing out that your time is valuable and that you are anxious to arrange for your return to South Africa.” 3 The English text of the letter is reproduced here from Indian Opinion, 9 10 1909, with some changes needed to bring it into conformity with the Gujarati translation.
('10', 79, 0, 1, 162425) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 79, 1, 2, 162466) and circulated in connection with the grievances of British Indians in the Colony of Natal.
('10', 79, 1, 3, 162558) In order to concentrate public attention on only the most pressing of them, we have excluded mention of many that do not call for immediate redress.
('10', 79, 1, 4, 162707) The position of Natal among the other South African Colonies is somewhat peculiar.
('10', 79, 1, 5, 162790) Natal introduced indentured Indian labour when its prosperity hung in the balance.
('10', 79, 1, 6, 162873) Now she wants to avoid some of its natural consequences.
('10', 79, 1, 7, 162930) In other words, she wants all the advantages that this form of labour gives her without having in its midst a non indentured and free Indian population.
('10', 79, 1, 8, 163083) Hence, first, its desire to starve out Indian merchants and traders by depriving them of their licences to trade.
('10', 79, 1, 9, 163197) The officers appointed to grant these licences or their renewals or transfers from place to place, or from person to person, have absolute discretion to grant or refuse.
('10', 79, 1, 10, 163367) This discretion has been used detrimentally to Indians.
('10', 79, 1, 11, 163423) Hence, the right of appeal to the Supreme Court should be granted.
('10', 79, 1, 12, 163490) Secondly, its desire to drive out of Natal those Indians who have finished their indentures by imposing a prohibitive annual tax upon them, their wives and their children.
('10', 79, 1, 13, 163662) Thirdly, its desire to keep them in a state of perpetual ignorance by depriving Indians of what little facility they had for education.
('10', 79, 1, 14, 163798) In the course of a Press letter, it is not possible to give an adequate idea of our grievances.
('10', 79, 1, 15, 163894) Domiciled Indians cannot even bring with them their children over a certain age or their female relatives who are dependent upon them.
('10', 79, 1, 16, 164029) You will thus see that the Indian community in Natal is attacked from three dangerous positions.
('10', 79, 1, 17, 164126) We have, therefore, come to the centre of the Empire in order to obtain justice, and although Natal is a self governing Colony, and will now form part of the Union of South Africa, it is the duty of the Imperial Government to protect acquired rights.
('10', 79, 1, 18, 164377) It ought not to fail in that duty.
('10', 79, 1, 19, 164412) We have no voice in the making of Natal laws.
('10', 79, 1, 20, 164458) Our remedy therefore is, and must continue to be, by means of Imperial protection.
('10', 79, 1, 21, 164541) Indeed, so far as that Colony is concerned, the Imperial Government have a very tangible remedy, and that is to withdraw from Natal the assistance she receives from India in the shape of indentured labour, until she has granted justice to those Indians who are suffering from the above mentioned threefold disabilities.
('10', 80, 0, 1, 164861) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 81
('10', 80, 1, 2, 164903) We trust that the Press of the United Kingdom will come to the rescue and insist upon the Imperial Government doing its duty.
('10', 80, 2, 3, 165029) ABDUL CAADIR AMOD BHAYAT H. M. BADAT M. C. ANGLIA
('10', 80, 3, 4, 165079) DID THEY REACH NORTH POLE?
('10', 80, 4, 5, 165106) A childish argument has been going on between two American whites whether the North Pole has, in fact, been discovered or not, and if it has, then, by whom.
('10', 80, 4, 6, 165263) One of them is Dr. Peary and the other, Dr. Cook.
('10', 80, 4, 7, 165313) Both of them claim to have stood on the North Pole.
('10', 80, 4, 8, 165365) Dr. Peary challenges Dr. Cook’s claim, and the latter that of the former.
('10', 80, 4, 9, 165439) Men have almost lost their heads over this argument.
('10', 80, 4, 10, 165492) Newspapers are full of the controversy.
('10', 80, 4, 11, 165532) Reports about it and reports of football and cricket fill all the space in them.
('10', 80, 4, 12, 165613) It is beyond my understanding what good the discovery of the North Pole has done the world; but such things are regarded as important sign posts of contemporary civilization.
('10', 80, 4, 13, 165788) What exactly is their importance they alone can say who claim to understand these matters.
('10', 80, 4, 14, 165879) I for one regard all these things as symptoms of mental derangement.
('10', 80, 4, 15, 165948) That one should just fritter away one’s time for want of a proper occupation, or, out of greed, cast about for ways of getting rich at any cost—I would not want even an enemy to be reduced to such a plight.

('10', 80, 5, 21, 166480) They invade his leisure and his residence.

('10', 80, 5, 25, 166655) All this is absurd.
('10', 80, 5, 26, 166675) Being women, they escape punishment for their misconduct.
('10', 80, 5, 27, 166733) The British people respect women, so that no one lays hands on them.
('10', 80, 5, 28, 166802) Being aware of this, the women take undue advantage of it.
('10', 80, 5, 29, 166861) That will not, of course, secure them the franchise.

('10', 83, 4, 9, 171942) Lord Ampthill, who has taken a deep interest in the sufferings of British Indians in the Transvaal, and has assisted us so very greatly, informs my colleague and me that, whilst General Smuts is prepared now to grant permanent certificates of residence to a limited number of educated and cultured British Indians, he will not recognize the right of such Indians to emigrate to the Transvaal, be it on ever so limited a scale.
('10', 83, 4, 10, 172369) The Indian struggle has been undertaken on the question of ‘right’.
('10', 83, 4, 11, 172437) Whilst it is necessary for the domiciled Indians of the Transvaal to receive fresh immigrants from India possessing educa tional attainments,in the opinion of the British Indian community, such a facility is not of so great an importance as the theoretical right of a British Indian, under a general immigration test, to emigrate to the Trans vaal.
('10', 83, 4, 12, 172786) But for the passing of another separate Asiatic Act, namely, Act 36 of 1908, mere repeal of Act 2 of 1907 would have been sufficient to guard the theoretical right above referred to, and thus to save the honour of India, but today the existence of that Act 36 of 1908 renders it neces sary to mention the question of educated Indians separately, and slightly to amend the existing law of the Transvaal.
('10', 83, 4, 13, 173189) It is in order to show the fundamental distinction between what General Smuts is now prepared to offer, and what has been and is still demanded by British Indians in the Transvaal, that I have offered, as I do again on behalf of my colleague and myself, to wait on His Lordship if he can spare the time.

('10', 87, 1, 2, 180034) 66. SUBSTANCE OF INTERVIEW WITH LORD CREWE 1
('10', 87, 2, 3, 180079) [LONDON, September 16, 1909] PRESENT : LORD CREWE, HAJEE HABIB AND GANDHI
('10', 87, 3, 4, 180153) LORD CREWE COMMENCED BY SAYING: I suppose Lord Ampthill has been in touch with you, and has told you everything.
('10', 87, 3, 5, 180266) I asked you to see me in order to tell you that there has been delay in the negotiations, because the Colonial Ministers had many other things to do.
('10', 87, 3, 6, 180416) Both Colonel Seely and I had several interviews with General Smuts.
('10', 87, 3, 7, 180484) He was reasonable and anxious to see a settlement.
('10', 87, 3, 8, 180535) He proposes to repeal the Act but he was disinclined to accept Lord Ampthill’s amendment.
('10', 87, 3, 9, 180625) He, however, recognised that a limited number of British Indians should have permanent residential certificates, and, to that end, he said that he was willing to amend the existing legislation.
('10', 87, 3, 10, 180819) He said that he did not like the fictitious equality.
('10', 87, 3, 11, 180873) Can you not accept the substantial thing that General Smuts is willing to give?
('10', 87, 4, 12, 180953) GANDHI : I am afraid that it is impossible for the British Indian community to be satisfied with what General Smuts is willing to give; it still leaves the racial taint on the Statute book.
('10', 87, 5, 13, 181143) LORD CREWE INTERVENED : But do you not think that the Australian policy of excluding by imposing ridiculous tests is not a satisfactory mode of dealing with the question?
('10', 87, 6, 14, 181314) GANDHI : I admit that it is unsatisfactory, but the fictitious equality is the lesser of the two evils.
('10', 87, 6, 15, 181418) And after all, is not the British Constitution itself founded on many fictions?
('10', 87, 6, 16, 181498) I have myself been nurtured in those traditions.
('10', 87, 6, 17, 181547) As a students I learnt the value of this kind of fiction.
('10', 87, 6, 18, 181605) Indeed, after mature consideration, I have come to the conclusion that there is a very reasonable basis for these so called fictions and if General Smuts is really anxious to see a settlement, and wishes to live under the British flag, why will he deliberately interfere with the British Constitution, especially when what he wants can be had without departing from it?
('10', 87, 6, 19, 181975) I should like to draw Your Lordship’s
('10', 87, 7, 20, 182013) 1 After the interview, Gandhiji himself wrote down its substance; vide “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”, 16 9 1909. For Lord Crewe’s minute on the interview, vide Appendix Lord Crewe’s Minute”.
('10', 88, 0, 1, 182201) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 89
('10', 88, 1, 2, 182243) attention to the fact that the Immigration Act of the Colony was not a Crown Colony measure, that it is General Smuts’ own production and he has undou btedly relied on fiction there.
('10', 88, 1, 3, 182426) The Act bristles with adventitious clauses.
('10', 88, 2, 4, 182470) LORD CREWE (intervening) : I share your views very largely.
('10', 88, 2, 5, 182530) I think that what you say is quite just and proper, but General Smuts is not an Englishman and, therefore, does not like the idea even of theoretical equality.
('10', 88, 3, 6, 182690) GANDHI : If that is the case, it is all the greater reason for us to press for the removal of the racial taint from the Statute book, and in offering this opposition, we think that we are rendering an Imperial service.
('10', 88, 3, 7, 182909) As Your Lordship must have noticed, the struggle has been in its later stages entirely idealistic.
('10', 88, 3, 8, 183008) We have no personal interests to serve, and I for one should feel very reluctant to impose so much suffering on my countrymen and advise them to continue the struggle, if it were only for the admission of a few cultured Indians, however desirable such admission may be for the well being of the community.
('10', 88, 3, 9, 183314) If I am not taking up your time unduly, I should like to give you the origin of the limitation in number.
('10', 88, 3, 10, 183420) Mr. Cartwright, the editor of The Transvaal Leader, a friend of the Boers, as also a friend always of unrepresented classes and a special friend of mine, told me that the club talk was that, behind the theoretical equality, I had some ulterior motives, and that I had not really accepted the policy of virtual exclusion of Asiatics, and it was in order to enable Mr. Cartwright to satisfy those friends of his who talked to him at the clubs, I told him that, if that were so, he could announce to his friends that I would be prepared to advise the Indian community to accept a very rigid educational test, so rigid as to admit of only, say, six highly educated Indians into the country per year.
('10', 88, 3, 11, 184116) You will, therefore, see that from the commencement of the struggle, we have never placed any importance on the admission of Indians, but that we have all along fought for legal equality.
('10', 88, 4, 12, 184304) LORD CREWE : But do not you think that General Smuts would find it difficult perhaps with his own people to get Lord Ampthill’s amendment accepted?
('10', 88, 5, 13, 184452) GANDHI : I venture to think not.
('10', 88, 5, 14, 184485) I do not think that he could have any difficulty with the Progressive Party.
('10', 88, 5, 15, 184562) I can picture before my mind’s eye Sir George Farrar, as we were discussing at the meeting of the Executive Council, after the burning of the certificates,
('10', 89, 0, 1, 184718) 90 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 89, 1, 2, 184759) this very ques tion, pleading with General Smuts to point a way out of the difficulty, and it was because General Smuts said he could not amend the Immigra tion Act that the question of the status of educated Indians remained unsolved.
('10', 89, 1, 3, 184995) The people in the Colonies undoubtedly want to see the exclusion of Asiatics generally, in order to avoid competition.
('10', 89, 1, 4, 185114) This policy having been accepted, I cannot conceive their offering objection to theoretical equality.
('10', 89, 2, 5, 185216) MR. HAJEE HABIB: As a matter of fact, we have received cables from Bombay from the party controlled by Professor Gokhale and Sir Pherozeshah Mehta to the effect that we had gone further than we ought to have in offering to accept the second amendment, and that the matter was exciting a very great deal of commotion in India.
('10', 89, 3, 6, 185542) GANDHI : We had to naturally cable what has been going on here, and from the letter received from Mr. Polak, I gather that the racial insult is being very keenly resented in India, so that it could not be said that only the Transvaal Indians were offering opposition.
('10', 89, 4, 7, 185810) LORD CREWE : I quite agree, and I see the force of what you are saying, and let me assure you that, keenly as I feel the justification of the demands of the local Indians in the Transvaal, I placed the matter before General Smuts as an Imperial question.
('10', 89, 4, 8, 186065) I am myself most anxious to see a settlement, but it occurs to me that General Smuts may also feel—though I do not wish to say that he has said to me any such thing—that if theoretical equality were kept up, it might be used for fresh agitation in order to increase the demands.
('10', 89, 5, 9, 186344) GANDHI : I can only say in reply to any such fear that it will be open, whenever the Ministers in the Transvaal thought that we were departing from our understanding, to pass more restrictive legislation.
('10', 89, 5, 10, 186549) At the same time, I do not for one moment wish to suggest that, if our demands were granted, that will be the end of all agitation in the Transvaal.
('10', 89, 5, 11, 186698) There are peculiar difficulties under which we are labouring and they may call forth fresh efforts.
('10', 89, 6, 12, 186798) LORD CREWE : I quite recognise that.
('10', 89, 6, 13, 186835) There can be no finality in such matters.
('10', 89, 6, 14, 186877) All I say is, that for a certain number of years at least, there should be some rest if the question is settled to your satisfaction.
('10', 89, 7, 15, 187011) GANDHI : I am prepared to go a step further.
('10', 89, 7, 16, 187056) When I talked of fresh agitation, I referred to other difficulties than those of the question of the status of educated Indians.
('10', 89, 7, 17, 187185) As to the question of immigration, we are prepared to give a written undertaking that, our demands being satisfied, we should not raise any further agitation.
('10', 90, 0, 1, 187344) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 91
('10', 90, 1, 2, 187386) go so far as to say that, if there were any such unreasonable agitation, I should be prepared to become a passive resister against my own countrymen, even as I was just after the compromise.
('10', 90, 2, 3, 187577) LORD CREWE : Yes, I think that is quite reasonable and I shall now tell General Smuts what has happened at this meeting, and hope that there will be a settlement, but I do not hold out much hope.
('10', 90, 2, 4, 187773) General Smuts may find it difficult to accept your proposition.
('10', 90, 2, 5, 187837) If he does, will it perhaps not be as well to wait for the Union Parliament?
('10', 90, 3, 6, 187914) GANDHI: May I make the position a little clearer?
('10', 90, 3, 7, 187964) Passive resistance in the meanwhile will have to continue, and that prolongs the agony for another six months, and if my reading of the amendment introduced at Your Lordship’s instance in the South Africa Act is correct, I feel that the Union Parliament will have no jurisdiction to amend the Immigration Act, because by itself it imposes no racial disqualification.
('10', 90, 3, 8, 188331) The amend ment is aimed at the legislation which itself contains racial disabilities.
('10', 90, 4, 9, 188417) LORD CREWE : That is true, only I feel that the Union Parliament will not like to see such suffering prolonged, and I can assure you that even General Smuts does not like the prolongation of the struggle, and it is for that reason that I think that the Union Parliament may intervene and bring about a proper solution, but it is difficult to know what view the Union Parliament will take.
('10', 90, 5, 10, 188806) GANDHI : If we cannot get relief now, I know that we will have to wait, but we are prepared to wait indefinitely.
('10', 90, 5, 11, 188920) If the negotiations are not successful, I shall go back feeling that we have not suffered enough and that therefore we ought to continue our sufferings.
('10', 90, 6, 12, 189073) LORD CREWE : Very well, I will then discuss the question with General Smuts.
('10', 90, 7, 13, 189150) GANDHI : As Your Lordship is aware, we have been here quite two months.
('10', 90, 7, 14, 189222) Will it not be better to cable to General Smuts, so that we may know the result in good time?
('10', 90, 8, 15, 189316) LORD CREWE : I thought a dispatch would be better, but perhaps it will be as well to cable, I know you have had to remain here for a long time.

('10', 91, 1, 2, 189554) 67. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 91, 2, 3, 189582) [LONDON,] September 16, 1909
('10', 91, 3, 4, 189611) MY LORD, Mr. Hajee Habib and I have just waited on Lord Crewe.
('10', 91, 3, 5, 189674) His Lordship was very sympathetic.
('10', 91, 3, 6, 189709) I think that he understands the question thoroughly, and I noticed too that every point I thought I had made, Lord Crewe interposed by saying he had heard it from you.
('10', 91, 3, 7, 189877) I believe he feels too that there is a great deal to be said on behalf of our standpoint as to theoretical equality.

('10', 96, 1, 2, 200855) 69. DEPUTATION NOTES [ XII ]
('10', 96, 2, 3, 200884) [After September 16, 1909 ] This time I cannot merely say that we are where we were.
('10', 96, 2, 4, 200969) We had an interview with Lord Crewe on the 16th.
('10', 96, 2, 5, 201018) He said that General Smuts was agreeable to the repeal of the Act and to the provision for permanent residence permits to the educated, but that he cannot reconcile himself to the idea that educated men should be able to enter as a matter of right after passing the test.
('10', 96, 2, 6, 201290) We have, therefore, replied that, so long as the right is not conceded, the struggle will certainly continue.
('10', 96, 2, 7, 201400) India’s honour cannot be upheld if that right is not secured.
('10', 96, 2, 8, 201462) The struggle was not intended to defend merely the rights of the Transvaal Indians as individuals but also India’s honour.
('10', 96, 2, 9, 201585) Once equal rights were conceded under the law, it would not matter if they were not allowed to be availed of.
('10', 96, 2, 10, 201695) It would be possible to deal with such a situation.
('10', 96, 2, 11, 201747) But denying the right under the law itself amounted to an attack on India’s honour.
('10', 96, 2, 12, 201831) After a long discussion, Lord Crewe admitted that we had no ulterior motive in our fight and wanted to maintain a theoretical right.
('10', 96, 2, 13, 201964) He has agreed to send a cablegram to General Smuts.
('10', 96, 2, 14, 202016) Let us wait for the reply.
('10', 96, 2, 15, 202043) What more can we hope for than this?
('10', 96, 2, 16, 202080) We have told Lord Crewe frankly that, should General Smuts refuse to accede to our demand ultimately, we would conclude that we have not as yet had our full measure of suffering.
('10', 96, 2, 17, 202259) We were always prepared [we told him] for suffering.
('10', 96, 2, 18, 202312) In the course of this discussion, we also referred to the agitation in India.
('10', 96, 2, 19, 202390) It appears that Mr. Polak’s vigorous efforts in India are a source of great strength [to our cause].
('10', 96, 2, 20, 202491) A very fine cable report of the Bombay mass meeting appeared in the local newspapers.
('10', 96, 2, 21, 202577) It said that the meeting demanded that the recruitment of indentured labour for Natal should be stopped.
('10', 96, 2, 22, 202682) People’s feelings were roused to a high pitch by Mr. Polak’s speech.
('10', 96, 2, 23, 202751) They were also very much put out by the news of Nagappen’s death.
('10', 96, 2, 24, 202817) Moreover, a fund has been started in aid of those who have been deported.
('10', 96, 2, 25, 202891) To be sure, it was a very successful meeting.
('10', 96, 2, 26, 202937) The cables about the arrests of the Chinese in Johannesburg, the refusal [by the authorities] to provide special facilities regarding food during Ramzan and the criticism of Mr. Vernon, also, make welcome reading.
('10', 96, 2, 27, 203151) There is no doubt that the more we suffer, the tougher we
('10', 97, 0, 1, 203209) 98 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 97, 1, 2, 203250) grow and the stronger becomes our cause.
('10', 97, 1, 3, 203291) If Lord Crewe has been striving so hard, it is only because of our voluntary submission to suffering.
('10', 97, 1, 4, 203393) Lord Crewe also said that, if General Smuts did not concede [our demands], we should wait for the Union Parliament.
('10', 97, 1, 5, 203509) This means that we should continue with our struggle even while we are waiting for that Parliament to meet.
('10', 97, 1, 6, 203617) If the fight is abandoned, the fate of Indians all over South Africa will be sealed, and we shall have, in the words of Mr. Rustomjee, cut off India’s nose with our own hands and proved ourselves cowards.
('10', 97, 1, 7, 203822) But I have not the slightest hesitation in believing that the Indians who are courageously holding out at present are men who will fight on till death.
('10', 97, 1, 8, 203974) I earnestly hope that our friends who have been released will be only too ready to welcome imprisonment whenever the Government chooses to arrest them.
('10', 97, 1, 9, 204126) It is my hope that, by the time this letter reaches there, Mr. Dawad Mahomed will have been installed in gaol again.
('10', 97, 1, 10, 204243) It is better, in my view, to die in prison than to enjoy good health outside.
('10', 97, 1, 11, 204321) Death in prison will uphold our honour and will serve the cause of India.
('10', 97, 1, 12, 204395) This is the time not to grieve over anyone’s suffering, but rather to offer congratulations on it.
('10', 97, 1, 13, 204494) In a land where innocent men are reduced to slavery and sentenced to imprisonment, all good men should take pleasure in serving such sentences.
('10', 97, 1, 14, 204638) Let every brave Indian allow this idea to take hold of his mind.
('10', 97, 1, 15, 204703) I have stated before now that, if General Smuts’ reply proves disappointing, we should, after spending some time here in holding pub lic meetings, etc., hasten to South Africa and get lodged in gaol.
('10', 97, 1, 16, 204903) The only thing that remains yet to be considered is whether or not to go to India.
('10', 97, 1, 17, 204986) For myself, I am unable to reach any defininte decision on this point.

('10', 98, 1, 2, 205142) 70. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('10', 98, 2, 3, 205171) [LONDON,] September 17, 1909
('10', 98, 3, 4, 205200) MANILAL, I was extremely glad to read your letter of the 21st [ultimo] about Mr. West.
('10', 98, 3, 5, 205287) I read the letter twice.
('10', 98, 3, 6, 205312) I felt proud of you and thanked God that I had such a son.
('10', 98, 3, 7, 205371) I wish you to remain such for ever.
('10', 98, 3, 8, 205407) To do good to others and serve them without any sense of egoism—this is real educa tion.
('10', 98, 3, 9, 205496) You will realize this more and more as you grow up.
('10', 98, 3, 10, 205548) What better way of life can there be than serving the sick?
('10', 98, 3, 11, 205608) Most of religion is covered by it.
('10', 98, 3, 12, 205643) We have to keep a detached mind about the chicken soup, etc., given to Mr. West.
('10', 98, 3, 13, 205724) You know my ideas in the matter.
('10', 98, 3, 14, 205757) I would have preferred Ba’s passing away without the soup; 1 but would not have allowed it to be given to her without her consent.
('10', 98, 3, 15, 205888) The body should not be dearer than the soul.
('10', 98, 3, 16, 205933) He who knows the soul, and also knows that it is different from the body, will not try to protect his body by committing violence.
('10', 98, 3, 17, 206064) All this is very difficult indeed; but he who has imbibed very noble ideas easily understands it and acts accordingly.
('10', 98, 3, 18, 206183) The belief that the soul can do good or evil only when it is encased in a body is quite mistaken and terrible sins have been and are being committed owing to it.
('10', 98, 3, 19, 206345) I want you to be free from it.
('10', 98, 3, 20, 206376) There is no such law that the soul can be known only at an advanced age.
('10', 98, 3, 21, 206449) Many old men pass away without knowing the soul, while persons like the late Raichandbhai have been able to realize the self even at the age of 8. Mistakes are made and sins committed despite such knowledge; but these can be eliminated after very careful thought.
('10', 98, 3, 22, 206713) The body has been given to us for curbing it.
('10', 98, 3, 23, 206759) About the settlement nothing definite can be said.
('10', 98, 3, 24, 206810) You will know more about it from my letter 2 to Chhaganbhai.
('10', 98, 3, 25, 206871) The above is written as the occasion offered itself.
('10', 98, 3, 26, 206924) Please share it with the others.
('10', 98, 3, 27, 206957) Blessings from MOHANDAS

('10', 99, 9, 17, 207947) DEAR SIR, The Transvaal deputation have received the following cablegram from Johannesburg :
('10', 99, 10, 18, 208040) Meeting held yesterday enthusiastic, determined continue, resolutions congratulating released, reaffirming complete confidence delegates, efforts greatly appreciated, afresh pledging their support, protesting Vernon’s statement which until Government repudiates Asiatics interpret disclosure Government policy.

('10', 99, 11, 20, 208402) refused.
('10', 99, 11, 21, 208411) I draw your particular attention to the last paragraph of the cablegram, which shows that the Transvaal Government have deeply hurt the religious susceptibilities of British Indian Mohammedans who have settled in the Transvaal, who have felt called upon, on religious
('10', 100, 0, 1, 208679) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 101
('10', 100, 1, 2, 208722) and conscientious grounds, to disregard what is known as the Asiatic Act and to suffer imprisonment for their so doing.
('10', 100, 1, 3, 208842) That under the British flag, which is supposed to respect all religions, Mohammedan passive resisters should be prevented from performing a religious observance of the highest importance is a very serious matter.
('10', 100, 1, 4, 209055) I hope that the League will take prompt action.
('10', 100, 1, 5, 209103) I may point out that last year, at Volksrust, facilities were given to passive resisters during the month of Ramzan.
('10', 100, 2, 6, 209220) I remain, etc.,

('10', 100, 4, 8, 209291) 73. LONDON
('10', 100, 5, 9, 209302) [Before September 18, 1909 ] NATAL DEPUTATION
('10', 100, 6, 10, 209348) The Natal gentlemen met Mr. Ali Imam, Bar at Law, of the All India Muslim League.
('10', 100, 6, 11, 209430) He has promised to help.
('10', 100, 6, 12, 209455) Next week Mr. Amir Imam will also be apprised of the situation in the Transvaal.
('10', 100, 6, 13, 209536) Mr. Justice Ameer Ali, who had gone for a change of climate, has now returned.
('10', 100, 6, 14, 209615) He too has promised every help.
('10', 100, 6, 15, 209647) The deputation has received from Lord Crewe the written reply which it had requested.
('10', 100, 6, 16, 209733) He says : The Imperial Government can only make a recommendation to the Natal Government but cannot effectively intervene in regard to the disabilities which flow from the existing legislation and which can be removed only by an amendment of such legislation.
('10', 100, 6, 17, 209993) In case further disabilities are sought to be imposed through fresh legislation, the Imperial Government can disallow such legislation.
('10', 100, 6, 18, 210129) Its sympathies are with the Indian community in the hardships which it experiences in Natal and, in the past, it has also made representations to the Natal Government about major grievances such as the denial of the right of appeal under the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('10', 100, 6, 19, 210394) Moreover, Royal assent was withheld from the Bills which had been passed for curtailing [Indian] trade.
('10', 100, 6, 20, 210498) As to the future, the Imperial Government hopes that the Union Parliament, which has been vested with powers of legislation regarding Indians and Coloured people, will follow a more liberal policy and give
('10', 101, 0, 1, 210704) 102 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 101, 1, 2, 210746) relief of the Indian community.
('10', 101, 1, 3, 210778) This is a very disappointing reply.
('10', 101, 1, 4, 210814) It contains no promise to write again to the Natal Government.
('10', 101, 1, 5, 210877) The powers of the Union Parliament relate to legislation exclusively affecting the Coloured people, but the Dealers’ Licenses Act applies nominally to everyone, so that most probably the Natal Government alone can amend it.
('10', 101, 1, 6, 211101) The hope of action by the Union Parliament is, therefore, a mere bait.
('10', 101, 1, 7, 211172) Besides, the reply says nothing about the demand for stopping the import of indentured Indian labour.

('10', 105, 1, 2, 217515) 77. LONDON 1
('10', 105, 2, 3, 217528) [After September 18, 1909 ] CIVILIZATION OR BARBARISM?
('10', 105, 3, 4, 217583) For some days now newspapers here have been writing about food.
('10', 105, 3, 5, 217647) They point out that almost all processed foods are adulterated, some of them to the extent of 33 per cent.
('10', 105, 3, 6, 217754) Sometimes the adulterant is of a harmful nature.
('10', 105, 3, 7, 217803) Big factories preparing items like jelly engage expert chemists who are expected to give to inferior products the appearance of quality goods.
('10', 105, 3, 8, 217946) This is done through suitable methods of chemical mixing which save costs.
('10', 105, 3, 9, 218021) The conclusion to be drawn is that the producers have their eyes only on profit and never care what harm they do to people.
('10', 105, 3, 10, 218145) These very men then donate a part of their ill gotten wealth to public causes and so win respect for themselves.
('10', 105, 3, 11, 218258) They earn reputation as good and virtuous men.
('10', 105, 3, 12, 218305) In this civilization, therefore, immorality presents itself as morality.
('10', 105, 3, 13, 218378) There is no doubt that most of the processed foods rely on the use of animal fat.
('10', 105, 3, 14, 218460) For instance, it is used in cleansing or polishing rice in England.
('10', 105, 3, 15, 218528) This is a frightful thing, but true all the same.
('10', 105, 3, 16, 218578) It offends the religious susceptibilities of both Hindus and Muslims.
('10', 105, 3, 17, 218648) Therefore, the only way out is not to use anything manufactured in the West.
('10', 105, 3, 18, 218725) In any case, processed foods must never be used.
('10', 105, 3, 19, 218774) BRAVE JAPANESE SOLDIER
('10', 105, 4, 20, 218797) The newspapers here have reported the death of a brave Japanese, Marquess Ito 2 , as the result of a revolver shot by a Korean.
('10', 105, 4, 21, 218925) Korea is situated near Japan.
('10', 105, 4, 22, 218955) The Japanese hold power in Korea as the British do in Egypt and India, enjoying the same rights and privileges.
('10', 105, 4, 23, 219067) Of course, Japan is not in Korea to oblige her.
('10', 105, 4, 24, 219115) But the Koreans are known to be a weak people.
('10', 105, 4, 25, 219162) Were the country to pass under the rule of the Russians or the Chinese, that would pose a threat to Japan, and so Japan herself grabbed it.
('10', 105, 4, 26, 219302) The Korean people were in

('10', 106, 1, 26, 221725) WHITE’S VIEWS ON INDIAN AWAKENING
('10', 106, 2, 27, 221759) Mr. G. K. Chesterton is one of the great writers here.
('10', 106, 2, 28, 221814) He is an Englishman of a liberal temper.
('10', 106, 2, 29, 221855) Such is the perfection of his style that his writings are read by millions with great avidity.
('10', 106, 2, 30, 221950) To The Illustrated London News of September 18 he has contributed an article on Indian awakening, which is worth studying.
('10', 106, 2, 31, 222073) I too believe that what he has said is reasonable.
('10', 106, 2, 32, 222124) I give below the substance of that part of it which is of special interest : 1
('10', 106, 3, 33, 222203) 1 The translation has been collated with the original article.
('10', 107, 0, 1, 222266) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 107, 1, 2, 222308) When young Indians talk of independence for India, I get a feeling that they do not understand what they are talking about.
('10', 107, 1, 3, 222432) I admit that they who demand swarajya are fine fellows; most young idealists are fine fellows.
('10', 107, 1, 4, 222527) I do not doubt that many of our officials are stupid and oppressive.
('10', 107, 1, 5, 222596) Most of such officials are stupid and oppressive.
('10', 107, 1, 6, 222646) But when I see the actual papers and know the views of Indian nationalists, I get bored and feel dubious about them.
('10', 107, 1, 7, 222763) What they want is not very Indian and not very national.
('10', 107, 1, 8, 222820) They talk about Herbert Spencer’s 1 philosophy and other similar matters.
('10', 107, 1, 9, 222894) What is the good of the Indian national spirit if they cannot protect themselves from Herbert Spencer?
('10', 107, 1, 10, 222997) I am not fond of the philosophy of Buddhism, but it is not so shallow as Spencer’s philosophy.
('10', 107, 1, 11, 223092) It has some noble ideals, unlike the latter.
('10', 107, 1, 12, 223137) One of their papers is called The Indian Sociologist.
('10', 107, 1, 13, 223191) Do the Indian youths want to pollute their ancient villages and poison their kindly homes by introducing Spencer’s philosophy into them?
('10', 107, 1, 14, 223328) There is a great difference between a people asking for its own ancient life and a people asking for things that have been whollyinvented by somebody else.
('10', 107, 1, 15, 223484) There is a difference between a conquered people demanding its own institutions and the same people demanding the institutions of the conqueror.
('10', 107, 1, 16, 223629) Suppose an Indian said: “I wish India had always been free from white men and all their works.
('10', 107, 1, 17, 223724) Everything has its own faults and we prefer our own.
('10', 107, 1, 18, 223777) Had we our own institutions, there would have been dynastic wars; but I prefer dying in battle to dying in hospital.
('10', 107, 1, 19, 223894) There would have been despotism; but I prefer one king whom I hardly even see to a hundred kings regulating my diet and my children.
('10', 107, 1, 20, 224027) There would have been pestilence; but I would sooner die of the plague than live like a dead man, in constant fear of the plague.
('10', 107, 1, 21, 224157) There would have been religious differences dangerous to public peace; but I think religion more important than peace.
('10', 107, 1, 22, 224276) Life is very short; a man must live somehow and die somewhere; the amount of bodily comfort a peasant gets under your way of living is not so much more than mine.
('10', 107, 1, 23, 224439) If you do not like our way of living, we never asked you to do.
('10', 107, 1, 24, 224503) Go, and leave us with it.”
('10', 107, 2, 25, 224530) 1 (1820 1903); English philosopher; author of Principles of Psychology, Synthetic Philosophy and Principles of Sociology
('10', 108, 0, 1, 224651) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 109
('10', 108, 1, 2, 224694) Suppose an Indian said that, I should call him an Indian nationalist.
('10', 108, 1, 3, 224764) He would be an authentic Indian, and I think it would be very hard to answer him.
('10', 108, 1, 4, 224846) But the Indian nationalists whose works I have read go on saying: “Give me a ballot box.
('10', 108, 1, 5, 224935) Give us power, give me the judge’s wig.
('10', 108, 1, 6, 224975) I have a natural right to be Prime Minister.
('10', 108, 1, 7, 225020) I have a right to introduce a Budget.
('10', 108, 1, 8, 225058) My soul is starved if I am excluded from the editorship of the Daily Mail,” or words to that effect.
('10', 108, 1, 9, 225159) Now this is not so difficult to answer.
('10', 108, 1, 10, 225199) Even the most sympathetic person may say in reply: “What you say is very fine, my good Indian, but it is we who invented all these things.
('10', 108, 1, 11, 225338) If they are so good as you make out, you owe it to us that you have ever heard of them.
('10', 108, 1, 12, 225426) If they are indeed natural rights, you would never even have thought of your natural rights but for us.” If voting is such a very important thing (which I am inclined rather to doubt myself) then, certainly we have some of the authority that belongs to founders.
('10', 108, 1, 13, 225689) When Indians take a haughty tone in demanding a vote, I imagine to myself the situation reversed.
('10', 108, 1, 14, 225787) It seems to me very much as if I were to go into Tibet and demand of the Lama that I should be treated as a Mahatma.
('10', 108, 1, 15, 225904) The Lama would in that case reply : “Our religion is either true or false; it is either worth having or not worth having.
('10', 108, 1, 16, 226026) If you know better than we do, you do not want our religion.
('10', 108, 1, 17, 226087) But if you think that our way of life is good, please remember that it is we who discovered and studied it, and we know whether a man is a Mahatma or not.
('10', 108, 1, 18, 226242) If you want one of our peculiar privileges, you must accept our peculiar discipline and pass our peculiar standards, to get it.” Perhaps you think that in writing this I am opposing Indian nationalism.
('10', 108, 1, 19, 226444) But that will be a mistake; I am only letting my mind play round the subject.
('10', 108, 1, 20, 226522) This is desirable when there is a con flict between two complete civilizations.
('10', 108, 1, 21, 226602) I also admit the existence of natural rights.
('10', 108, 1, 22, 226648) The right of a people to express itself, to be itself in action, is a genuine right.
('10', 108, 1, 23, 226733) Indians have a right to be and to live as Indians.
('10', 108, 1, 24, 226784) But Herbert Spencer is not Indian; his philosophy is not Indian philosophy; all this clatter about the science of education and other things is not Indian.
('10', 108, 1, 25, 226940) I often wish it were not English either .
('10', 108, 1, 26, 226982) But this is our first difficulty, that the Indian nationalist is not national.
('10', 108, 1, 27, 227061) Indians must reflect over these views of Mr. Chesterton and
('10', 109, 0, 1, 227121) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 109, 1, 2, 227163) consider what they should rightly demand.
('10', 109, 1, 3, 227205) What is the way to make the Indian people happy?
('10', 109, 1, 4, 227254) May it not be that we seek to advance our own interests in the name of the Indian people?
('10', 109, 1, 5, 227344) Or, that we have been endeavouring to destroy what the Indian people have carefully nurtured through thousands of years?
('10', 109, 1, 6, 227465) I, for one, was led by Mr. Chesterton’s article to all these reflections and I place them before readers of Indian Opinion.

('10', 109, 2, 8, 227630) 78. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES 1
('10', 109, 3, 9, 227675) [LONDON,] September 20, 1909
('10', 109, 4, 10, 227704) SIR, A letter was received addressed to my colleague, Mr. Amod Bayat, in his absence, from the Natal Immigration Restriction Department in connection with his application for a temporary visiting pass for a priest to take charge of the Mosque in Pietermaritzburg and of a Madressa.
('10', 109, 4, 11, 227986) This application was made on behalf of and in the name of the whole of the Mohammedan congregation in Pietermaritzburg I beg to enclose herewith copy of the letter above referred to.
('10', 109, 4, 12, 228169) I venture to think that the Earl of Crewe will be able to enter into the feelings of British Indian Mohammedans who, for the purpose of earning an honest livelihood, have settled in that Colony.
('10', 109, 4, 13, 228364) My colleagues and I consider the letter of the Immigration Restriction Department to be highly offensive to our feelings as men, as British subjects and last but not least, as Mohammedans.
('10', 109, 4, 14, 228553) A special assurance was given to the Immigration Officer that this priest was required solely for religious purposes and that he would not in any way compete in trade or any other business.
('10', 109, 5, 15, 228743) 1 Though the letter bears the signature of M. C. Anglia, there is evidence that the draft was Gandhiji’s.
('10', 109, 5, 16, 228849) In his letter of October 14, 1909, Polak wrote : “Your letter (through one of the Natal delegates) re: the PM Burg Moulvi is strong and excellent— but pardon me if I say the construction is wretched.
('10', 109, 5, 17, 229049) They say lawyers write bad grammar.
('10', 109, 5, 18, 229085) I hope I don’t catch the complaint from you!
('10', 109, 5, 19, 229130) I am appending the letter to my forthcoming book.
('10', 109, 5, 20, 229180) It seems to be intended for publication, and no secrets are divulged .
('10', 109, 5, 21, 229251) ” Polak reproduced the letter as Appendix D to his pamphlet : A Tregedy of Empire.
('10', 109, 5, 22, 229334) Vide also “Letter to Ameer Ali”, 27 9 1909.
('10', 110, 0, 1, 229378) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 111
('10', 110, 1, 2, 229421) That the community should have to make Herculean efforts to have a simple application like the above granted, and that it should be granted in a manner so offensive to it, and that in a matter in no way touching the economic policy of the Colony, only shows under what trying, humiliating and difficult circumstances British Indians have to exist in Natal.
('10', 110, 1, 3, 229778) Why a visiting pass should be granted for only a quarter, renewable quarterly and should carry with it a penalty of twenty shillings each time that it is renewed, passes comprehension.
('10', 110, 1, 4, 229963) A policy such as this, in the humble opinion of the deputation, can only be considered as wantonly cruel.
('10', 110, 1, 5, 230069) It puts an undue strain upon the patience of the Indian community and, whilst the deputation is still here, I venture to request very serious and earnest consideration by the Earl of Crewe of the anomalous position British Indians occupy in Natal.
('10', 110, 1, 6, 230317) We consider that a position such as this, intolerable as it is, cannot and ought not to be prolonged with safety to the Empire to which it has hitherto been the pride of British Indians to belong.
('10', 110, 1, 7, 230514) We would be unjust to ourselves, to the trust that is reposed in us by the community and to the Empire, if we did not assure His Lordship that the humiliating treatment in Natal is corroding the hearts of British Indians, and it is difficult for us to imagine all the consequences that may follow, when it has reached, as it may any day reach, the breaking point.
('10', 110, 1, 8, 230878) I have written with the approval of my co delegates somewhat strongly, but on more strongly than the occasion requires.

('10', 111, 1, 2, 231101) 79. LETTER TO PRIVATE SECRETARY TO LORD CREWE

('10', 118, 1, 2, 246902) A Moulvi was required for the Mosque in Pietermaritzburg, the capital of Natal.
('10', 118, 1, 3, 246982) The Maulvi was to combine also the work of a Madressa teacher.
('10', 118, 1, 4, 247045) This Moulvi was to replace the retiring one.
('10', 118, 1, 5, 247090) According to the law of Natal, an intending immigrant must have a knowledge of one of the European languages.
('10', 118, 1, 6, 247200) This Moulvi did not possess such a knowledge.
('10', 118, 1, 7, 247246) The congregation of the Mosques, therefore, applied to the Government to grant to the Moulvi not the right of immigration, that is, permanent residence, but a certificate enabling him to reside in the Colony for three years.
('10', 118, 1, 8, 247471) The applicants undertook to give security that the Moulvi, during his residence in Natal, would not carry on any commercial business and that the would leave Natal at the end of the period.
('10', 118, 1, 9, 247661) After a great deal of waiting, the Government replied that they would grant permission on condition that the certificate was renewed every three months, and that each renewal bore a stamp fee of £1. Mr. Anglia will show you the letter in question, and you will see from its tenor how insulting it is.
('10', 118, 1, 10, 247962) In my opinion, we as self respecting men cannot accept the offensive terms.
('10', 118, 1, 11, 248038) The stipulation as to quarterly renewals bearing a fee of £1 is, in my opinion, an impudent exaction.
('10', 118, 2, 12, 248140) I remain, etc.,

('10', 119, 7, 16, 249931) SIR, Your footnote in the issue of the 9th instant to the letter of Mr. Jehangir Bomanjee Petit, regretting among other things your description of Mr. Henry S. L. Polak as a paid agent, encourages me to address this letter to you.
('10', 119, 7, 17, 250162) You say, “We have alluded to Mr. Polak as a paid agent and we
('10', 119, 8, 18, 250224) 1 The letter was apparently not published in The Advocats of India.
('10', 119, 8, 19, 250292) J. B. Petit, however, had it published in the columns of Gujarati, 7 11 1909, under the caption “The Advocate of India and Mr. Polak”, along with the following covering letter : “You will remember that some weeks ago The Advocate of India sought to discredit Mr. Polak’s activity in this country on behalf of our suffering brethren in the Transvaal by representing him as a near ‘paid agent’.

('10', 120, 1, 9, 252249) For over four years he received not a farthing from the funds of the British Indian community because he needed nothing.
('10', 120, 1, 10, 252370) During all that time he was working for the community.

('10', 120, 1, 13, 252989) You do not know, nor do the Bombay public, that ever since his marriage, Mr. Polak has given very little of his time to his wife who, in order the better to enable her husband to perform his self imposed duty, has reconciled herself to a life of almost indefinitely prolonged separation.
('10', 120, 1, 14, 253277) I imagine that the term “paid agent” means an agent who names a price adequate to the work he does, and does the work well enough no doubt, in many cases, but does it nevertheless for the money he receives and not for the love of it.

('10', 122, 2, 3, 255313) [LONDON,] September 29, 1909 MY DEAR HENRY, At last I have decided about Dr. Mehta’s offer of a scholarship for Manilal, of which I wrote to you, I think, some time ago.
('10', 122, 2, 4, 255483) I told you, then, that I asked Dr. Mehta to let me use this scholarship for any other person belonging to Phoenix whom I chose.
('10', 122, 2, 5, 255611) He accepted my proposal, but when he made the offer, I know he made it simply because he felt that he would like to undertake the education of at least one of my sons.
('10', 122, 2, 6, 255779) Today, however, he is almost as good a passive resister as you and I, and he agrees with me entirely that he should defray the cost of educating some other Phoenixite.
('10', 122, 2, 7, 255947) I decided upon Chhaganlal, and I have already written 1 to him by the outgoing mail this week.
('10', 122, 2, 8, 256042) I wrote to him last week a letter5 2 embodying my suggestions, but that letter was sent to Phoenix.
('10', 122, 2, 9, 256142) I subsequently learned that he was to have left for India on the 15th.
('10', 122, 2, 10, 256213) By the time this reaches you, he will probably, therefore, be with you.
('10', 122, 2, 11, 256285) I will not go into all the reasoning that has led me to the following conclusions.
('10', 122, 2, 12, 256368) After having remained with you there for some time, he should come to London, say to reach here at the latest about the end of March.
('10', 122, 2, 13, 256502) He should join one of the Inns of Court.
('10', 122, 2, 14, 256543) The question whether he should actually be called to the Bar or not to be decided later (the odds are that, by that time, we would not want him to be called to the Bar at all).
('10', 122, 2, 15, 256720) Simultaneously with his legal studies, he should join an English class in one of the institutions here.
('10', 122, 2, 16, 256824) He should, before embarking, take a definite and formal vow of poverty.
('10', 122, 2, 17, 256896) He should also take the vow that he will not use the learning acquired here as a means of livelihood, the latter being always found from Phoenix and that he should dedicate his life to a realization of the Phoenix, ideals.
('10', 122, 2, 18, 257119) He should stay in some vegetarian family (I am finding out information about all available vegetarian families in and about London).
('10', 122, 2, 19, 257252) He should live, if necessary, in a house in one of the suburbs and there do his own cooking and everything.
('10', 122, 2, 20, 257360) If he feels confidence in himself at the end of the year, we should send one or more from phoenix at a time for training in London.
('10', 122, 2, 21, 257492) These will be able to live with him in house, and he having formed a desirable circle

('10', 128, 3, 24, 271809) 91. LETTER TO LEO TOLSTOY
('10', 128, 4, 25, 271835) LONDON, October 1, 1909
('10', 128, 5, 26, 271859) SIR, I take the liberty of inviting your attention to what has been going on in the Transvaal (South Africa) for nearly three years.
('10', 128, 5, 27, 271992) There is in that Colony a British Indian population of nearly 13,000. These Indians have, for several years, laboured under various legal disabilities.
('10', 128, 5, 28, 272144) The prejudice against colour and in some respects
('10', 128, 6, 29, 272194) 1 Some words are missing here.
('10', 129, 0, 1, 272225) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 129, 1, 2, 272267) against Asiatics is intense in that Colony.
('10', 129, 1, 3, 272311) It is largely due, so far as Asiatics are concerned, to trade jealousy.
('10', 129, 1, 4, 272383) The climax was reached three years ago, with a law 1 which I and many others considered to be degrad ing and calculated to unman those to whom it was applicable.
('10', 129, 1, 5, 272545) I felt that submission to a law of this nature was inconsistent with the spirit of true religion.
('10', 129, 1, 6, 272643) I and some of my friends were and still are firm believers in the doctrine of non resistance to evil.
('10', 129, 1, 7, 272745) I had the privilege of studying your writings also, which left a deep impression on my mind.
('10', 129, 1, 8, 272838) British Indians, before whom the position was fully explained, accepted the advice that we should not submit to the legislation, but that we should suffer imprisonment, or whatever other penalties the law may impose for its breach.
('10', 129, 1, 9, 273070) The result has been that nearly one half of the Indian popula tion, that was unable to stand the heat of the struggle, to suffer the hard ships of imprisonment, have withdrawn from the Transvaal rather than submit to [the] law which they have considered degrading.
('10', 129, 1, 10, 273335) Of the other half, nearly 2,500 have for conscience’s sake allowed themselves to be imprisoned, some as many as five times.
('10', 129, 1, 11, 273459) The imprisonments have varied from four days to six months, in the majority of cases with hard labour.
('10', 129, 1, 12, 273562) Many have been financially ruined.
('10', 129, 1, 13, 273597) At present there are over a hundred passive resisters in the Transvaal gaols.
('10', 129, 1, 14, 273675) Some of these have been very poor men, earning their livelihood from day to day.
('10', 129, 1, 15, 273756) The result has been that their wives and children have had to be supported out of public con tributions, also largely raised from passive resisters.
('10', 129, 1, 16, 273905) This has put a severe strain upon British Indians, but, in my opinion, they have risen to the occasion.
('10', 129, 1, 17, 274009) The struggle still continues and one does not know when the end will come.
('10', 129, 1, 18, 274084) This, however, some of us at least have seen most clearly, that passive resistance will and can succeed where brute force must fail.
('10', 129, 1, 19, 274217) We also notice that, in so far as the struggle has been prolong ed, it has been due largely to our weakness and, hence, to a belief having been engendered in the mind of the Government that we would not be able to stand continued suffering.
('10', 129, 1, 20, 274458) Together with a friend, I have come here to see the Imperial authorities and to place before them the position, with a view to seeking redress.
('10', 129, 1, 21, 274602) Passive resisters have recognized that they should have nothing to do with pleading with the Government, but the deputation has come at the instance of the weaker members of the community, and it therefore represents their weakness rather than
('10', 129, 2, 22, 274846) 1 The Transvaal Asiatic Law Amendment Ordinance.

('10', 130, 1, 2, 274938) their strength.
('10', 130, 1, 3, 274954) But, in the course of my observation here, I have felt that if a gene ral competition for an eassy on the Ethics and Efficacy of Passive Resis tance were invited, it would popularise the movement and make people think.

('10', 137, 3, 7, 291829) SYED ALI IMAM
('10', 137, 4, 8, 291843) A dinner was given on October 1 in honour of Mr. Syed Ali Imam, president of the Bihar [branch of the] All India Muslim League.
('10', 137, 4, 9, 291971) It must have been attended by about a hundred men.
('10', 137, 4, 10, 292022) Dr. Abdool Majid was in the chair.
('10', 137, 4, 11, 292057) The Reception Committee comprised both Hindus and Muslims.
('10', 137, 4, 12, 292116) Mr. Verma and Mr. Jaffer were the secretaries.
('10', 137, 4, 13, 292163) Among the gentlemen present were Sir Henry Cotton, Dr. Rutherford, Mr. Upton, Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree, Mr. Nawab Saheb Syed Hussain Bilgrami, Major Syed Hussain, Mr. Ritch, Mr. [J. H.] Polak, Mr. Bipin Chandra Pal, Mr. Khaparde, Mr. Parikh, Mr. Chhotalal Parekh and others.
('10', 137, 4, 14, 292439) Mr. Ali Imam said in his speech that India could remain with England, not under it.
('10', 137, 4, 15, 292523) Indians must have the same rights [as the British].
('10', 137, 4, 16, 292575) They must make a success of what Lord Morley had granted and then demand more.
('10', 137, 4, 17, 292654) Hindus, Muslims and Parsis must learn to live as one nation.
('10', 137, 4, 18, 292715) In Turkey, Muslims, Jews and Christians lived in amity, and that was why they commanded respect.
('10', 137, 4, 19, 292812) In every part [of India] where Hindus were in a majority and the Muslims in a minority, the former should help the latter to gain special rights, and vice versa.
('10', 137, 4, 20, 292974) If this were done, there would be no Hindu Muslim problem.
('10', 137, 4, 21, 293033) There were many reforms to be carried out in India.
('10', 137, 4, 22, 293085) We must ensure the spread of education and respect for women’s rights.
('10', 137, 4, 23, 293156) We must not be backward where we have to act on our own.
('10', 137, 4, 24, 293213) His prayer for good health was received by the gathering with applause.
('10', 137, 4, 25, 293285) He was followed by Sir Henry Cotton who said in a short speech that it was for the Indians to win their own rights.
('10', 137, 4, 26, 293401) Then Sir Muncherji Bhownaggree spoke.
('10', 137, 4, 27, 293439) He appealed for good wishes for [the success of] the Transvaal and Natal deputations.
('10', 137, 4, 28, 293525) Sir Muncherji pointed out in his speech that the problem in South Africa was a very serious one.
('10', 137, 4, 29, 293622) It had brought two deputations which they ought to help.
('10', 137, 4, 30, 293679) Our fellow countrymen were passing through hard times in South Africa.
('10', 137, 4, 31, 293750) This appeal was also received with great enthusiasm.
('10', 137, 4, 32, 293803) Mr. Gandhi then replied.
('10', 137, 4, 33, 293828) He said that it was in South Africa
('10', 138, 0, 1, 293864) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 139
('10', 138, 1, 2, 293907) that the Indian nation was being formed.
('10', 138, 1, 3, 293948) A nation, he said, could come into being only when people made sacrifices for the sake of freedom.
('10', 138, 1, 4, 294047) Moreover, the Hindu Muslim problem just did not arise in South Africa.
('10', 138, 1, 5, 294118) There it was almost as good as solved.
('10', 138, 1, 6, 294157) Mr. Imam was quite right when he said that the minorities should have special rights.
('10', 138, 1, 7, 294243) That was the only way to bring about Hindu Muslim unity.
('10', 138, 1, 8, 294300) The Transvaal Indians, [he said], were fighting—not for self interest—but for India’s honour.
('10', 138, 1, 9, 294394) It was for that that Parsee Rustomjee was undergoing imprisonment.
('10', 138, 1, 10, 294461) Some Sikhs had also gone to gaol.
('10', 138, 1, 11, 294495) People would thus continue to go to gaol so long as men like Mr. Ali Imam were not free to enter to Transvaal as of right, and they would win that right.
('10', 138, 1, 12, 294649) In Natal they want to ruin the traders, exact an annual tax of £3 from poor Indians and prevent the boys from being educated.
('10', 138, 1, 13, 294775) It was the duty of every Indian to fight such tyranny.

('10', 138, 1, 15, 294881) It was his duty to press for justice and, if he failed, to resign [his membership].
('10', 138, 1, 16, 294965) Indians of the younger generation should examine the meaning of this problem.
('10', 138, 1, 17, 295043) If they did, there would be a solution in no time.
('10', 138, 1, 18, 295094) Speaking next, Major Syed Hussain said that Hindus and Muslims should sit for dinner at the same table in India, just as they did in an English hotel.
('10', 138, 1, 19, 295245) Mr. Bipin Chandra Pal said in his speech that Hindus and Muslims could be and must be united.
('10', 138, 1, 20, 295339) It was an excellent thing, [he said,] that Mr. Ali Imam was honoured by both Hindus and Muslims.
('10', 138, 1, 21, 295436) Hindus would, of course, remain Hindus and Muslims Muslims, but they should be more proud of being Indians.
('10', 138, 1, 22, 295544) Speaking again, Mr. Ali Imam said that it was exactly because the South African problem was a very serious one that he had not referred to it in his speech.
('10', 138, 1, 23, 295701) It was very much present in his mind and he would not forget it.
('10', 138, 1, 24, 295766) He would, of course, do everything he could for the removal of Indians’ disabilities.
('10', 138, 1, 25, 295852) Dr. Rutherford said that Mr. Gandhi’s speech had inspired him with a new spirit.
('10', 138, 1, 26, 295933) Indians were putting up a good fight in the Transvaal.
('10', 138, 1, 27, 295988) Their example should be followed by everyone.
('10', 138, 1, 28, 296034) He would, on his part, render every possible assistance.
('10', 138, 1, 29, 296091) Mr. Upton, a Member of Parliament, also spoke in a similar strain.
('10', 138, 1, 30, 296158) He was followed by Mr. Parikh, and the gathering then dispersed.

('10', 140, 2, 4, 298375) 94. LETTER TO KHUSHALCHAND GANDHI
('10', 140, 3, 5, 298409) LONDON, October 3, 1909
('10', 140, 4, 6, 298433) RESPECTED KHUSHALBHAI, Once Chi.
('10', 140, 4, 7, 298466) Chhaganlal had asked for your permission to let Narandas also be sacrificed for Phoenix.
('10', 140, 4, 8, 298555) It was, however, not granted at that time.
('10', 140, 4, 9, 298598) I remember that I, too, had written in that regard.
('10', 140, 4, 10, 298650) The thing is again being considered here.
('10', 140, 4, 11, 298692) There would be nothing wrong, if you spare Narandas; it will be to his good.
('10', 140, 4, 12, 298769) It is quite natural to want to have all your sons near you in your old age; nevertheless, it is also infatuation.
('10', 140, 4, 13, 298883) If, by staying away from you, they can do spiritual good to themselves and if one of them stays with you, why can the others not stay away?
('10', 140, 4, 14, 299023) It is pure selfishness to keep one’s sons always by one’s side.
('10', 140, 4, 15, 299087) Our religion preaches selflessness at all times.
('10', 140, 4, 16, 299136) Therefore, when an occasion arises for them to follow the path of selflessness, it is but proper, as I see it, to let them go.
('10', 140, 4, 17, 299263) If you can persuade yourself to accept this view, I would request you to permit Chi.
('10', 140, 4, 18, 299348) Narandas [to join Phoenix].
('10', 140, 4, 19, 299376) Of course, the first thing to be considered in this connection is whether or not Narandas himself is inclined to do so.
('10', 140, 4, 20, 299496) My request holds good only if he is.
('10', 140, 4, 21, 299533) I do not recall if Narandas is married or not.
('10', 140, 4, 22, 299580) If he is not married and not even betrothed, he will be, in my opinion, able to do much better work.
('10', 140, 4, 23, 299681) I have given deep thought to this matter; and I have lived and am living accordingly.
('10', 140, 4, 24, 299767) I shall not go deeper into it here.
('10', 140, 4, 25, 299803) I am only putting my ideas before you; for I think and take for granted that among all the brothers you are the one who understands me to some extent.
('10', 140, 4, 26, 299954) Chhaganlal will tell you more.
('10', 140, 4, 27, 299985) Please do what you think proper after hearing him.
('10', 140, 4, 28, 300036) Respects from MOHANDAS From the Gujarati original in Gandhiji’s hand : C. W. 4899 Courtesy: Naran das Gandhi
