('10', 143, 4, 5, 304618) 96. SPEECH AT GUJARATI MEETING 2
('10', 143, 5, 6, 304651) [LONDON, October 5, 1909] These days a new idea is in the air in India.
('10', 143, 5, 7, 304723) Hindus, Muslims, Parsis—all are filled with the spirit of “my country” and “our country”.
('10', 143, 5, 8, 304813) We shall not on this occasion go into the political aspects of the matter.
('10', 143, 5, 9, 304888) Thinking of it from the point of view of language, it requires little effort to see that we must cultivate pride in our language before we can speak of “our country” with genuine feeling.
('10', 143, 5, 10, 305076) Turning to recent examples, we find that one strong reason why the Boers enjoy swarajya today is that they and their children mostly use their own language.
('10', 143, 5, 11, 305233) General Botha uses the Boer language even when talking to Lord Crewe.
('10', 143, 5, 12, 305303) His knowledge of English can be considered to be much superior to ours, but he uses the language of his motherland as a point of honour and also with the object of setting an example.
('10', 143, 5, 13, 305487) We come across many other instances of the kind, but there is no need to cite them here.
('10', 143, 5, 14, 305576) Personally, therefore, I think it a welcome development that everyone in India, young or old, is beginning to turn his attention to his own language.
('10', 143, 5, 15, 305726) We find a desire being expressed that the people of India should have one single language.
('10', 143, 5, 16, 305817) That may, perhaps, happen in future.
('10', 143, 5, 17, 305854) Everyone will admit that such a language must be an Indian language.
('10', 143, 5, 18, 305923) But that stage is yet to come.
('10', 143, 5, 19, 305954) As the basis of my pride as an Indian, I must have pride in myself as a Gujarati.
('10', 143, 5, 20, 306036) Otherwise we shall be left without any moorings.
('10', 143, 5, 21, 306085) The leaders in every province
('10', 143, 6, 22, 306115) 1 Gandhiji substituted a second draft for this, vide enclosure to “Letter to Lord Ampthill”,6 10 1909 The communication finally sent, however, was different; vide “Letter to Under Secretary for Colonies”, 8 10 1909 2 Speaking at a meeting of Gujaratis held in London on October 5, to extend support to the third Gujarati Literary Conference which was to be held at Rajkot, Gandhiji moved the following resolution : “This meeting sends its congratulations to the third session of the Gujarati Literary Conference which is being held at Rajkot during the current month, and wishes it success.” In Indian Opinion the report of the speech appeared under the heading “Some thoughts on Gujarati”.
('10', 143, 6, 23, 306806) For a report of the meeting, vide Appendix “Gujarati Meeting in London”.
('10', 144, 0, 1, 306879) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 145
('10', 144, 1, 2, 306922) have no option but to learn the language of some other province.
('10', 144, 1, 3, 306987) A Gujarati can learn Bengali, Marathi, Tamil, Hindi, etc., with great ease; there is nothing difficult in that.
('10', 144, 1, 4, 307099) If only we make on Indian languages half the effort that we waste on English, thanks to certain notions of ours, the situation will change altogether.
('10', 144, 1, 5, 307250) India’s uplift is, to a very considerable extent, bound up with this.
('10', 144, 1, 6, 307320) I had been under the sway of Macaulay’s ideas on Indian education.
('10', 144, 1, 7, 307387) Others, too, are.
('10', 144, 1, 8, 307405) I have now been disillusioned.
('10', 144, 1, 9, 307436) I wish that others should be.
('10', 144, 1, 10, 307466) This is not the occasion, [however,] to dilate on this point.
('10', 144, 1, 11, 307528) If this argument is correct, we may proceed to consider the case of Gujarati.
('10', 144, 1, 12, 307606) One cannot help saying that the fact of Gujaratis using English among themselves is an indication of their degraded state.
('10', 144, 1, 13, 307729) This practice has impoverished the mother tongue.
('10', 144, 1, 14, 307779) We ourselves despise it and, as a result, lose our self respect.
('10', 144, 1, 15, 307844) When I think that I cannot express myself well in Gujarati but can do so in English, I tremble.
('10', 144, 1, 16, 307940) What good can we expect a man to do to his country when he has grown indifferent to his own language?
('10', 144, 1, 17, 308042) We cannot even dream of the possibility of the great people of Gujarat ever forgetting their own language and adopting another.
('10', 144, 1, 18, 308170) If that is so, it will not be an exaggeration to say that those who give up that language are traitors to the country, that is, to their own people.
('10', 144, 1, 19, 308319) It will not be incorrect to say that a language reflects the image of the people.
('10', 144, 1, 20, 308401) It is, therefore, a very good sign that Gujarati, Bengali, Urdu and Marathi conferences are beginning to be held.
('10', 144, 1, 21, 308515) This fact should give much food for thought to Indians abroad.
('10', 144, 1, 22, 308578) They carry a heavy responsibility.
('10', 144, 1, 23, 308613) They will be the leaders of the people.
('10', 144, 1, 24, 308653) It will be a sin on their part if they themselves grow indifferent to their respective languages.
('10', 144, 1, 25, 308751) I have come across men highly educated in English, writing or saying that they know English better than Gujarati.
('10', 144, 1, 26, 308865) This is a matter of shame for us.
('10', 144, 1, 27, 308899) What they say is in fact not true.
('10', 144, 1, 28, 308934) I have no hesitation in saying that those who make such a claim cannot really write or speak correct English.
('10', 144, 1, 29, 309044) That is but natural.
('10', 144, 1, 30, 309065) I admit that some thoughts can be expressed with [greater] ease in English, but that, too, is a matter of shame for us.
('10', 144, 1, 31, 309185) Generally speaking, however, it cannot be claimed that we are quite familiar with the idiom and grammar of the English language.
('10', 144, 1, 32, 309314) On the other hand, the grammar and the idiom of Gujarati are generally familiar to every Indian as a matter of course.
('10', 144, 1, 33, 309433) We shall never use in Gujarati the present tense in place of the past.
('10', 144, 1, 34, 309504) But we shall come across errors in the use of tenses in English even in
('10', 145, 0, 1, 309576) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 145, 1, 2, 309618) the writings of Indians who have been very well educated.
('10', 145, 1, 3, 309676) Errors is the use of idioms are endless.
('10', 145, 1, 4, 309717) It does happen that we [sometimes] do not pronounce Gujarati correctly, that we do not distinctly enunciate syllables with more than one sound.
('10', 145, 1, 5, 309861) This is a fault easy to point out, but it cannot be said for that reason that we know less Gujarati.
('10', 145, 1, 6, 309962) I also hear it said that students who come [here] to learn English must have practice in English and, if so, they cannot bother themselves with Gujarati.
('10', 145, 1, 7, 310116) This is a fallacious notion.
('10', 145, 1, 8, 310145) If Gujaratis talk Gujarati among themselves, their proficiency in English will not suffer.
('10', 145, 1, 9, 310236) It may possibly improve, for in that case they will hear only Englishmen’s English and the ear will be so trained as to be able to detect unidiomatic English immediately.
('10', 145, 1, 10, 310407) Moreover, Indian students in England are not so engrossed in their studies that they cannot spare time for reading Gujarati books.
('10', 145, 1, 11, 310538) If any student aspires, at the end of his studies, to serve the motherland, to take part in public life, he must find some time for the mother tongue.
('10', 145, 1, 12, 310689) If English is learnt at the cost of the mother tongue, the purpose of learning English, service of the motherland, will be lost.
('10', 145, 1, 13, 310818) Such a result will only go to prove that there is no use in learning English.
('10', 145, 1, 14, 310896) If an operation is likely to lead to the patient’s death, everyone will admit that it had better not be undertaken.
('10', 145, 1, 15, 311012) Furthermore, Gujarati is not a language of little worth.
('10', 145, 1, 16, 311069) No limits can be placed to the growth of a language that has been served by poets like Narasinh Mehta 1, Akha Bhagat 2 and Dayaram 3 and which they have found it possible to develop, a language spoken by followers of three great religions of the world—Hinduism, Islam and Zoroastrianism.
('10', 145, 1, 17, 311357) The same thought can sometime be expressed in Gujarati in three different ways.
('10', 145, 1, 18, 311437) He whom the Parsis call Khuda, Muslims Allah Tala, Hindus Ishvar, is referred to in English by a single word, God.
('10', 145, 1, 19, 311552) The Gujarati which a Muslim writes, will reflect traces of Arabic and the Persian of Sheikh Saadi 4 ; the Parsi’s Gujarati will reveal the influence of Zoroaster’s Zend and the Gujarati of a Hindu that of Sanskrit.

('10', 147, 3, 5, 314477) As nothing can be lost by sending a letter as per draft, it is not of much moment whether that letter or the letter as per draft 1 sent yesterday, is forwarded.
('10', 147, 3, 6, 314638) But the more I think [of] the matter, the more I feel that we will not get any further satisfaction at the present moment, and that the ambiguity is deliberate and diplomatic, and, therefore, it does not admit of being cleared up.

('10', 155, 5, 10, 332497) introduce legislation on the lines proposed by Mr. Smuts.
('10', 155, 5, 11, 332555) I do not know whether the legislation proposed by Mr. Smuts is on the basis suggested by me at the interview of the 16th ultimo, or whether it is on the basis proposed by Mr. Smuts before he embarked for South Africa.
('10', 155, 5, 12, 332773) There is a fundamental difference between the proposal submitted by me and what Mr. Smuts prepared to give.
('10', 155, 5, 13, 332881) It will be admitted it is of the greatest importance to my colleague and me to know the exact position taken up by Mr. Smuts after His Lordship’s cable, which evidently was sent after the interview in question.
('10', 155, 5, 14, 333092) We recognise that the negotiations will now take some time before the final result is known.
('10', 155, 5, 15, 333185) We are, however, desirous not to indefinitely prolong our stay in this country.
('10', 155, 5, 16, 333265) My colleague and I, therefore, feel that it is time for us to inform public opinion before our departure.
('10', 155, 5, 17, 333371) In wanting to do so, we have no desire to embarrass the Earl of Crewe.
('10', 155, 5, 18, 333442) Indeed, we are grateful to His Lordship for the efforts he has made, and will still make, in order to bring about a satisfactory settlement.
('10', 155, 5, 19, 333583) In tak ing up public activity we only wish to strengthen His Lordship’s hands, and to be able to render a satisfactory account of our mission to our countrymen in South Africa.
('10', 155, 5, 20, 333760) We propose to interview those leaders of public opinion who are likely to be interested in our troubles; if possible to address meetings of representative men; to circulate a short statement in the Press, etc., and, if we receive advice from the European and the Indian Committees at Johannesburg, and if time permits, to pay a visit to India, and to give to the Indian public an account of our mission here.
('10', 155, 5, 21, 334169) I assume that the Earl of Crewe has no objection to our making
('10', 156, 0, 1, 334232) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 157
('10', 156, 1, 2, 334275) public the net result of the negotiations, so far as they have progressed.
('10', 156, 1, 3, 334350) May I request an early reply?
('10', 156, 2, 4, 334380) I remain, etc., M. K. GANDHI

('10', 157, 4, 5, 335932) 103. LETTER TO “GUJARATI PUNCH”
('10', 157, 5, 6, 335964) [LONDON,] October 8, 1909
('10', 157, 6, 7, 335990) TO THE EDITOR GUJARATI PUNCH [BOMBAY]
('10', 157, 7, 8, 336028) SIR, You have requested me to write something for the Special Diwali Number.
('10', 157, 7, 9, 336105) My life is taken up at present by one single thing—the life and death struggle for the fulfilment of the pledge taken by the Indians living in the Transvaal in South Africa.
('10', 157, 7, 10, 336279) The pledge was taken by thousands of poor Indians—Hindus, Muslims, Parsis, Pubjabis, Bengalis, Madrasis, Gujaratis and others—to uphold India’s honour.
('10', 157, 7, 11, 336431) A tiny country like the Transvaal refuses entry even to a person like the Dada 2 of India, a country as vast as the ocean.
('10', 157, 7, 12, 336554) The few Indians here, illiterate traders, hawkers and labourers, cannot, will not, bear this insult.
('10', 157, 7, 13, 336655) To obliterate it, to uphold their religion, be it Hinduism or Islam or Zoroastrianism (for every religion teaches us that failure to honour a pledge taken is a violation of one’s religion), 2,580 persons out of a total Indian population of 13,000 in the Transvaal have already suffered imprisonment.
('10', 157, 7, 14, 336955) Even now many of them are in gaol, and many will go to gaol in future.
('10', 157, 7, 15, 337026) I must say that the gaol here is a terrible place.
('10', 157, 7, 16, 337077) We do not get there the food that we are used to, and are classified with the Kaffirs.
('10', 157, 7, 17, 337164) Many strong minded Indian women, the so called weaker sex, bear separation from their husbands in order that the latter may carry on the fight.
('10', 157, 7, 18, 337308) Some of them, along with their children, go starving.
('10', 157, 7, 19, 337362) Many of those who suffer thus are Gujaratis, for Hindus and Muslims from Gujarat are in a majority [among the Indians] in this land.
('10', 157, 8, 20, 337495) 1 Vide “Statement of Transvaal Indian Case”, 16 7 1909.
('10', 157, 9, 21, 337551) 2 Dadabhai Naoroji
('10', 158, 0, 1, 337570) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 159
('10', 158, 1, 2, 337613) If this letter is published, the readers of the Gujarati Punch must ask themselves on this festival of Diwali what they propose to do for the Transvaal Indians.
('10', 158, 1, 3, 337774) There will be a Diwali, or Id, or Pateti for them only when they return from the battle field 1 victorious.
('10', 158, 2, 4, 337882) Yours etc.,
('10', 158, 3, 5, 337894) MOHANDAS KARAMCHAND GANDHI [From Gujarati]
('10', 158, 4, 6, 337937) Egypt no Uddharak athawa Mustafa Kamel Pasha nu Jivan Charitra tatha Bija Lekho
('10', 158, 5, 7, 338017) 104. SPEECH AT EMERSON CLUB 2
('10', 158, 6, 8, 338047) [LONDON, October 8, 1909] War with all its glorification of brute force is essentially a degrading thing.
('10', 158, 6, 9, 338153) It demoralizes those who are trained for it.
('10', 158, 6, 10, 338198) It brutalizes men of naturally gentle character.
('10', 158, 6, 11, 338247) It outrages every beautiful canon of morality.
('10', 158, 6, 12, 338294) Its path of glory is foul with the passions of lust, and red with the blood of murder.
('10', 158, 6, 13, 338381) This is not the pathway to our goal.
('10', 158, 6, 14, 338418) The grandest aid to development of strong, pure, beautiful character which is our aim, is the endurance of suffering.
('10', 158, 6, 15, 338536) Self restraint, unselfishness, patience, gentleness, these are the flowers which spring beneath the feet of those who accept, but refuse to impose, suffering, and the grim prisons of Johannesburg, Pretoria, Heidelberg and Volksrust are like the four gateways to this garden of God.
('10', 158, 6, 16, 338818) Indian Opinion, 12 2 1910

('10', 159, 1, 2, 339370) 105. DEPUTATION NOTES [–XV]
('10', 159, 2, 3, 339398) [After October 8, 1909] This time I am in a position to give some more news, but I am afraid it is not very cheering.
('10', 159, 2, 4, 339516) Lord Crewe has written to say that he has no further information to give “for the present”, and that something will be known after General Smuts has had a discussion with the other members of his Cabinet.
('10', 159, 2, 5, 339721) There is no information as to what General Smuts will propose to the Cabinet.
('10', 159, 2, 6, 339799) If the proposal follows Lord Crewe’s cable, that will mean our demand.
('10', 159, 2, 7, 339870) If he proposes what is in his mind, that will mean the repeal of the Act and admission of a limited number of educated men as a matter of favour but on a permanent basis.
('10', 159, 2, 8, 340041) If it is this latter proposal which he is thinking of presenting for consideration, we can be sure it will lead to nothing.
('10', 159, 2, 9, 340165) It will be all right if he presents our demand.
('10', 159, 2, 10, 340213) But this letter has a deeper significance which must be grasped by every Indian.
('10', 159, 2, 11, 340294) It is this, that General Smuts wants to gain time by putting forward this excuse, so that in the interval he can break the spirit of the satyagrahis.
('10', 159, 2, 12, 340444) He would like to concede our demand only if his efforts failed.
('10', 159, 2, 13, 340508) The satyagrahis should understand this underlying motive of his and keep up the highest spirit.
('10', 159, 2, 14, 340604) They cannot afford to keep silent or to show any weakness.
('10', 159, 2, 15, 340663) This reply of Lord Crewe’s proves that it is not in England that we shall find the means for the solution [of our problems]; we have it in our own hands.
('10', 159, 2, 16, 340817) If we have failed to gain our demands so far, it is because we have not employed that means, our soul force, in full measure.
('10', 159, 2, 17, 340943) It is not enough that people have gone to gaol.
('10', 159, 2, 18, 340991) I have often said that we should have no mental reservations.
('10', 159, 2, 19, 341053) We should place no limit on our self sacrifice.
('10', 159, 2, 20, 341101) Rather, we must be prepared to bear every hardship that we may encounter.
('10', 159, 2, 21, 341175) If we do not, we shall lose the fight.
('10', 159, 2, 22, 341214) One should not feel as though going to gaol once, or maybe ten times, was all that one could do.
('10', 159, 2, 23, 341311) We ought to be ready to welcome any suffering, whether imprisonment or death.
('10', 159, 2, 24, 341389) I hope, therefore, that all the saytyagrahis will remain perfectly steadfast and fill the gaols.
('10', 159, 2, 25, 341486) Every Indian must remember that all over India they are singing praises of the epic struggle in the Transvaal.
('10', 159, 2, 26, 341597) Polak has been rousing India with his speeches.
('10', 159, 2, 27, 341645) The newspapers are full of our struggle.
('10', 160, 0, 1, 341686) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 161
('10', 160, 1, 2, 341729) hope that Indians will bear in mind all this and not retreat even an inch—nor show weakness.
('10', 160, 1, 3, 341822) In England, too, they say the same thing, that the Transvaal Indians have put up a most wonderful show, that they are men who will not accept defeat.
('10', 160, 1, 4, 341972) Let it be remem bered that they are fighting the battle for the whole of South Africa.
('10', 160, 1, 5, 342059) Lord Crewe’s letter referred to above shows that the deputation can no longer continue to work merely in private.
('10', 160, 1, 6, 342173) It is necessary now to come out in the open.
('10', 160, 1, 7, 342218) We have, accordingly, requested Lord Crewe’s permission to place the entire matter before the public.
('10', 160, 1, 8, 342320) 1 That will be done when the permission is received.
('10', 160, 1, 9, 342373) Thereafter, we shall place the facts before the members of the House of Commons, if they agree to give us a hearing.
('10', 160, 1, 10, 342490) We shall have the matter discussed in newspapers and also hold such meetings as may be possible.
('10', 160, 1, 11, 342587) A very important question facing us is whether or not we should both pay a flying visit to India.
('10', 160, 1, 12, 342685) On this point, our advisers are of the view that it will be the right thing to do.
('10', 160, 1, 13, 342768) There are reasons to believe that it will be profitable to pay such a visit.
('10', 160, 1, 14, 342845) My own view is that it is in the Transvaal that our main work lies, and even there—in its gaols.
('10', 160, 1, 15, 342942) There is but one consideration against this.
('10', 160, 1, 16, 342987) Our coming here this time was an admission of weakness; [we came] in the hope that an early solution could be found.
('10', 160, 1, 17, 343104) The very reasons which brought us here will justify our going to India.
('10', 160, 1, 18, 343176) However, there are many other considerations.
('10', 160, 1, 19, 343222) A visit to India will delay our return to South Africa.
('10', 160, 1, 20, 343278) As I said above, the work in India will take up much time.
('10', 160, 1, 21, 343337) We can leave for India after October 30. We shall need about a month there, and another for the journey.
('10', 160, 1, 22, 343442) By that time, it will be December, and we can return from here at the end of that month.
('10', 160, 1, 23, 343531) If there is no solution, even after all this, we shall be where we were.
('10', 160, 1, 24, 343604) The simplest course, instead, appears to be to drop the idea of a visit to India.
('10', 160, 1, 25, 343686) However, it is necessary that the suggestion which has been discussed here should be placed before everyone.
('10', 160, 1, 26, 343795) Besides, this extension will involve some expenditure.
('10', 160, 1, 27, 343850) Personally, I cannot express definite view.
('10', 160, 1, 28, 343894) If I am asked to state my own view simply as a satyagrahi, I would say that we should immediately return to the Transvaal.

('10', 161, 6, 25, 345779) Afterwards, a number of questions were answered.
('10', 161, 6, 26, 345828) The Transvaal problem was raised and everyone was moved by the tale of our sufferings.
('10', 161, 6, 27, 345915) There was a speech by Mr. Pal, in which he argued that soul force should be backed by physical force.
('10', 161, 6, 28, 346017) Mr. Gandhi replied that, in that case it would not deserve the name of soul

('10', 162, 2, 4, 346303) SUFFRAGETTE FUNCTION
('10', 162, 3, 5, 346324) On the 7th there was a very big gathering of suffragettes in a large hall called Albert Hall.
('10', 162, 3, 6, 346418) It was attended by hundreds of women.
('10', 162, 3, 7, 346456) There were speeches by Mrs. Pankhurst and others.
('10', 162, 3, 8, 346506) Enthusiasm ran so high that a sum of about £3,000 in cash was received on the spot in aid of the struggle.
('10', 162, 3, 9, 346613) About four of them paid £250 each.
('10', 162, 3, 10, 346648) In all, the women have collected £51,000 by now.
('10', 162, 3, 11, 346697) Their journal has a weekly circulation of about 50,000. They appeared determined to fight till death.

('10', 162, 3, 22, 347370) We may be sure that no good will come out of it.

('10', 163, 2, 3, 348003) [LONDON,] 2
('10', 163, 3, 4, 348015) October 12, 1909
('10', 163, 4, 5, 348032) MANILAL, The service you are rendering to Mr. West and others is the best study for you.
('10', 163, 4, 6, 348121) He who does his duty is all the while studying.
('10', 163, 4, 7, 348169) You say that you had to leave your studies; but it is not so.
('10', 163, 4, 8, 348231) You are certainly studying when you are serving.
('10', 163, 4, 9, 348280) It would be correct to say that you had to give up reading books.
('10', 163, 4, 10, 348346) There is no harm in thus leaving studies.
('10', 163, 4, 11, 348388) One can get academic education later on, one cannot say that one will get an opportunity of serving others later on.
('10', 163, 4, 12, 348505) 3 Let this be inscribed in your heart that, since your mind is pure, you will not fall ill while serving others.
('10', 163, 4, 13, 348618) And even if you fall ill, I will not worry.
('10', 163, 4, 14, 348662) You and I, all of us, will achieve perfection only by being moulded in this manner.
('10', 163, 4, 15, 348746) Learning to live a good life is in itself education.
('10', 163, 4, 16, 348799) All else is useless.
('10', 163, 5, 17, 348820) Blessings from

('10', 163, 7, 19, 348878) 108. SPEECH AT HAMPSTEAD 4
('10', 163, 8, 20, 348905) [LONDON, October 13, 1909]
('10', 163, 9, 21, 348932) Mr. Gandhi said that the question of East and West presented a vast and complex problem.
('10', 163, 9, 22, 349021) He had had 18 years’ experience of contact between East and West and had endeavoured to study the question, and he felt that he might give an audience such as the present one the results of his observations.
('10', 163, 9, 23, 349229) As he thought of the subject,
('10', 163, 10, 24, 349259) 1 The first part of the letter seems to have been omitted in Gandhiji na Patro, the Gujarati collection from which it has been taken.
('10', 163, 10, 25, 349393) 2 The place of writing given in the source is “Johannesburg” which is evidently wrong as Gandhiji was, at the time, in England.
('10', 163, 10, 26, 349521) 3 Some words have been omitted here.
('10', 163, 10, 27, 349558) 4 Gandhiji spoke on “East and West” at a meeting held under the auspices of the Hampstead Peace and Arbitration Society at the Friends’ Meeting House.
('10', 163, 10, 28, 349709) C. E. Maurice presided.
('10', 164, 0, 1, 349733) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 165
('10', 164, 1, 2, 349776) his heart sank within him.
('10', 164, 1, 3, 349803) He would have to say many things which would seem repugnant to his audience, and use hard words.
('10', 164, 1, 4, 349900) He would also have to speak against a system under which he had been brought up.
('10', 164, 1, 5, 349981) He hoped they would bear with him if he hurt their feelings.
('10', 164, 1, 6, 350042) He would have to break many idols which he and his countrymen had worshipped, and which his audience may have worshipped.
('10', 164, 1, 7, 350164) He then referred to the lines in Kipling’s poem, that “East is East and West is West and never the twain shall meet”, and said he considered that doctrine to be a doctrine of despair, and inconsistent with the evolution of humanity.
('10', 164, 1, 8, 350397) He felt it utterly impossible to accept a doctrine of that nature.
('10', 164, 1, 9, 350464) Another English poet, Tennyson, had in his “Vision” clearly foretold the union between East and West and it was because he (the lecturer) believed in that vision that he had cast in his lot with the people of South Africa, who were living there in very great difficulties.
('10', 164, 1, 10, 350737) It was because he thought it possible for the two peoples to live together in perfect equality that he found himself in South Africa.
('10', 164, 1, 11, 350871) If he had believed in Kipling’s doctrine, he would never have lived there.
('10', 164, 1, 12, 350946) There had been individual instances of English and Indian people living together under the same rule without a jarring note, and what was true of individuals could be made true of nations.
('10', 164, 1, 13, 351135) To a certain extent it was true that there was no meeting place between civilizations.
('10', 164, 1, 14, 351222) The barriers between the Japanese and the Europeans were daily vanishing, because the Japanese assimilated Western civilization.
('10', 164, 1, 15, 351351) It seemed to him that the chief characteristic of modern civilization [was that it] worshipped the body more than the spirit, and gave everything for the glorifying of the body.
('10', 164, 1, 16, 351529) Their railways, telegraphs and telephones, did they tend to help them forward to a moral elevation?
('10', 164, 1, 17, 351629) When he cast his eyes upon India, what was represented there today under British rule?
('10', 164, 1, 18, 351716) Modern civilization ruled India.
('10', 164, 1, 19, 351749) What had it done?
('10', 164, 1, 20, 351767) He hoped he would not shock his hearers when he said that civilization had done no good to India.
('10', 164, 1, 21, 351865) There was there a network of railways and telegraphs and telephones; we had given them a Calcutta, a Madras, a Bombay, a Lahore and a Benares—these were symbols of slavery rather than of freedom.
('10', 164, 1, 22, 352061) He noticed that these modern travelling facilities had reduced their holy places to unholy places.
('10', 164, 1, 23, 352160) He could picture to himself Benares of old, before there was a mad rush of civilization, and he had seen the Benares of today with his own eyes, an unholy city.
('10', 164, 1, 24, 352321) He saw the same thing here as in India.
('10', 164, 1, 25, 352361) The mad activity had unhinged us and, although he was living under the system, it seemed to him desirable that he should speak to them in that strain.
('10', 164, 1, 26, 352512) He knew it was impossible for the two peoples in India to live together until the British changed their ways.
('10', 164, 1, 27, 352622) We had offended the religious susceptibilities of the Hindus by sport in their sacred places.
('10', 164, 1, 28, 352716) Unless this mad rush was changed, a calamity must come.
('10', 164, 1, 29, 352772) One way would be for them to adopt modern civilization; but far be it from him to say that they should ever do so.
('10', 164, 1, 30, 352887) India would then be the football of the world, and the two nations would be flying at each other.
('10', 164, 1, 31, 352985) India was not yet lost, but had been immersed in lethargy.
('10', 164, 1, 32, 353044) There were many things which could not be understood, for which we must be patient;
('10', 165, 0, 1, 353128) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 165, 1, 2, 353170) but one thing was certain, and that was that, so long as this mad rush lasted, with its glorification of the body, the soul within, which was imperishable, must languish.
('10', 165, 1, 3, 353341) India, 22 10 1909
('10', 165, 2, 4, 353359) 109. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 165, 3, 5, 353388) [LONDON,] October 14, 1909
('10', 165, 4, 6, 353415) MY LORD, A cablegram has just been received from Johannesburg, which says :
('10', 165, 5, 7, 353491) Smuts tells newspapers he awaits Secretary State’s answer regarding his proposals.
('10', 165, 5, 8, 353574) My interpretation of this cable is that the proposals referred to in Lord Crewe’s letter to which I have sent a reply are Mr. Smuts’ original proposals, and that he is waiting to know whether, if those proposals are carried out, passive resistance will cease.
('10', 165, 5, 9, 353834) There is no reply yet from Lord Crewe.
('10', 165, 5, 10, 353873) 1 It is evident to me that, if Lord Crewe and Lord Morley were to do their duty, this is just the psychological moment.
('10', 165, 5, 11, 353993) When Mr. Smuts made his statement to Reuter’s agent at Southampton before embarking for South Africa, he spoke light heartedly and confidently, thinking that there was no fight left in the passive resisters.
('10', 165, 5, 12, 354201) It is evident that he has been disillusioned on reaching Pretoria, and he, therefore, wants to know whether we here are prepared to advise acceptance of his proposals and cessation of passive resistance.
('10', 165, 5, 13, 354405) Cessation, unless the theoretical right is granted, is impossible.
('10', 165, 5, 14, 354472) Mr. Doke, in a letter to me, says that passive resisters have never been so strong as they were when his letter left South Africa.
('10', 165, 6, 15, 354603) Your Lordship’s obedient servant,

('10', 166, 3, 11, 355381) However, we have to work as if they have fallen through.

('10', 166, 3, 21, 356644) It is now problematical whether, even if a reply is received this week from him, I can finish the work of education before the 30th inst.
('10', 166, 3, 22, 356782) As you will be seeing practically the whole of India—a privilege I have myself not yet been able to enjoy—I think I should jot down the definite conclusions to which I
('10', 166, 4, 23, 356950) 1 This was held on October 11. 2 (1845 1914); Viceroy and Governor General of India, 1905 10
('10', 167, 0, 1, 357043) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 167, 1, 2, 357085) have almost arrived after more matured observations made here.
('10', 167, 2, 3, 357148) The thing was brewing in my mind, but there was no certain clear light.
('10', 167, 2, 4, 357220) The heart and brain became more active after I accepted the invita tion of the Peace and Arbitration Society to speak to them on “East and West.” 2 It came off last night.
('10', 167, 2, 5, 357392) I think this meeting was a splendid succ ess; they were earnest folk, but some insolent questions were put on the South African situation.
('10', 167, 2, 6, 357531) You will be surprised to learn that even in Ham pstead there were men enough to stand up for the tragedy in South Africa,and to talk all the claptrap about the Indian trader being a canker, and what not.
('10', 167, 2, 7, 357735) A dear old lady got up and said that I had uttered disloyal sentiments and, just as we have to deal with idolaters in South Africa who would think of and cling to form and superficiality as in the case of finger impressions, so had I last night in the Friends’ Meeting House.
('10', 167, 2, 8, 358011) My main purpose was, in all the questions that were addressed to me, forgotten, and details were warmly taken up and discussed.
('10', 167, 2, 9, 358139) The following are the conclusions : (1) There is no impassable barrier between East and West.
('10', 167, 2, 10, 358233) (2) There is no such thing as Western or European civilization, but there is a modern civilization, which is purely material.
('10', 167, 2, 11, 358359) (3) The people of Europe, before they were touched by modern civilization, had much in common with the people of the East; anyhow, the people of India and, even today, Europeans who are not touched by modern civilization are far better able to mix with the Indians than the offspring of that civilization.
('10', 167, 2, 12, 358665) (4) It is not the British people who are ruling India, but it is modern civilization, through its railways, telegraphs, telephones, and almost every invention which has been claimed to be a triumph of civilization.
('10', 167, 2, 13, 358880) (5) Bombay, Calcutta and the other chief cities of India are the real plague spots.
('10', 167, 2, 14, 358964) (6) If British rule was replaced tomorrow by Indian rule based on modern methods, India would be no better, except that she would be able then to retain some of the money that is drained away to England, but, then, Indians would only become a second or fifth
('10', 167, 3, 15, 359223) 1 In the office copy from the Sabarmati Sangrahalaya, two pages are missing here.
('10', 167, 3, 16, 359305) These have been supplied from a handwritten copy in the Gokhale papers with the Servants of India Society, Poona and collated with the part of the letter given in M. K. Gandhi and the South African Indian Problem by Dr. P. J. Mehta.
('10', 167, 3, 17, 359538) 2 Vide “Speech at Hampstead”,13 10 1909.
('10', 168, 0, 1, 359579) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 169
('10', 168, 1, 2, 359622) edition of Europe or America.
('10', 168, 1, 3, 359652) (7) East and West can only and really meet when the West has thrown overboard modern civilization, almost in its entirety.
('10', 168, 1, 4, 359775) They can also seemingly meet when East has also adopted modern civilization.
('10', 168, 1, 5, 359852) But that meeting would be an armed truce, even as it is between, say, Germany and England, both of which nations are living in the Hall of Death in order to avoid being devoured, the one by the other.
('10', 168, 1, 6, 360053) (8) It is simply impertinence for any man or any body of men to begin or contemplate reform of the whole world.
('10', 168, 1, 7, 360165) To attempt to do so by means of highly artificial and speedy locomotion is to attempt the impossible.
('10', 168, 1, 8, 360267) (9) Increase of material comforts, it may be generally laid down, does not in any way whatsoever conduce to moral growth.
('10', 168, 1, 9, 360389) (10) Medical science is the concentrated essence of Black Magic.
('10', 168, 1, 10, 360454) Quackery is infinitely preferable to what passes for high medical skill.
('10', 168, 1, 11, 360527) (11) Hospitals are the instruments that the Devil has been using for his own purpose, in order to keep his hold on his kingdom.
('10', 168, 1, 12, 360655) They perpetuate vice, misery and degradation, and real slavery.
('10', 168, 1, 13, 360719) (12) I was entirely off the track when I considered that I should receive a medical training.
('10', 168, 1, 14, 360813) It would be sinful for me in any way what soever to take part in the abominations that go on in the hospitals.
('10', 168, 1, 15, 360924) If there were no hospitals for venereal diseases, or even for consumptives, we should have less consumption, and less sexual vice amongst us.
('10', 168, 1, 16, 361066) (13) India’s salvation consists in unlearning what she has learnt during the past fifty years.
('10', 168, 1, 17, 361161) The railways, telegraphs, hospitals, lawyers, doctors, and such like have all to go, and the so called upper classes have to learn to live conscientiously and religiously and deliberately the simple peasant life, knowing it to be a life giving true happiness.
('10', 168, 1, 18, 361421) (14) Indians should wear no machine made clothing, whether it comes out of European mills or Indian mills.
('10', 168, 1, 19, 361528) (15) England can help India to do this, and then she will have justified her hold of India.
('10', 168, 1, 20, 361620) There seem to be many in England today who think likewise.
('10', 168, 1, 21, 361679) (16) There was true wisdom in the sages of old having so regulated society as to limit the material condition of the people: the
('10', 169, 0, 1, 361808) 170 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 169, 1, 2, 361850) rude plough of perhaps five thousand years ago is the plough of the husbandman today.
('10', 169, 1, 3, 361936) Therein lies salvation.
('10', 169, 1, 4, 361960) People live long, under such conditions, in comparative peace much greater than Europe has enjoyed after having taken up modern activity, and I feel that every enlightened man, certainly every Englishman, may, if he chooses, learn this truth and act according to it.
('10', 169, 1, 5, 362227) There is much more than I can write upon today, but the above is enough food for reflection.
('10', 169, 1, 6, 362320) You will be able to check me when you find me to be wrong.
('10', 169, 1, 7, 362379) You will notice, too, that it is the true spirit of passive resistance that has brought me to the above almost definite conclusions.
('10', 169, 1, 8, 362512) As a passive resister, I am unconcerned whether such a gigantic reformation, shall I call it, can be brought about among people who derive their satisfaction from the present mad rush.
('10', 169, 1, 9, 362697) If I realize the truth of it, I should rejoice in following it, and, therefore, I could not wait until the whole body of people had commenced.
('10', 169, 1, 10, 362840) All of us who think likewise have to take the necessary step; and the rest, if we are in the right, must follow.
('10', 169, 1, 11, 362953) The theory is there : our practice will have to approach it as much as possible.
('10', 169, 1, 12, 363034) Living in the midst of the rush, we may not be able to shake ourselves free from all taint.
('10', 169, 1, 13, 363126) Every time I get into a railway car, use a motor bus, I know that I am doing violence to my sense of what is right.
('10', 169, 1, 14, 363242) I do not fear the logical result on that basis.
('10', 169, 1, 15, 363290) The visiting of England is bad, and any communication between South Africa and India by means of Ocean’s grey hounds is also bad, and so on.
('10', 169, 1, 16, 363431) You and I can, and may, outgrow those things in our present bodies, but the chief thing is to put our theory right.
('10', 169, 1, 17, 363547) You will be seeing there all sorts and conditions of men.
('10', 169, 1, 18, 363605) I, therefore, feel that I should no longer withhold from you what I call the progressive step I have taken mentally.
('10', 169, 1, 19, 363722) If you agree with me, it will be your duty to tell the revolutionaries and everybody else that the freedom they want, or they think they want, is not to be obtained by killing people or doing violence, but by setting themselves right, and by becoming and remaining truly Indian.
('10', 169, 1, 20, 364001) Then the British rulers will be servants and not masters.
('10', 169, 1, 21, 364059) They will be trustees and not tyrants, and they will live in perfect peace with the whole of the inhabitants of India.
('10', 169, 1, 22, 364178) The future, therefore, lies not with the British race, but with the Indians themselves, and if they have sufficient self abnega tion and abstemiousness, they can make themselves free this very mo ment, and when we have arrived in India at the simplicity which is still ours largely and which was ours entirely until a few years ago, it will still be
('10', 170, 0, 1, 364528) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 171
('10', 170, 1, 2, 364571) possible for the best Indians and the best Europeans to see one another throughout the length and breadth of India and act as the leaven.
('10', 170, 1, 3, 364709) When there was no rapid locomotion, traders and preachers went on foot, from one end of the country to the other, braving all the dangers, not for pleasure, not for recreating their health, (though all that followed from their tramps,) but for the sake of humanity.
('10', 170, 1, 4, 364975) Then were Benares and other places of pilgrimage holy cities, whereas today they are an abomination.
('10', 170, 1, 5, 365076) You will recollect you used to rate me for talking to my children in Gujarati.
('10', 170, 1, 6, 365155) I now feel more and more convinced that I was absolutely right in refusing to talk to them in English.
('10', 170, 1, 7, 365258) Fancy a Gujarati writing to another Gujarati in English, which as you would properly say, he mispronounces and writes ungrammatically.
('10', 170, 1, 8, 365393) I should certainly never commit the ludicrous blunders in writing in Gujarati that I do in writing or speaking in English.
('10', 170, 1, 9, 365516) I think that, when I speak in English to an Indian or a foreigner, I in a measure unlearn the language.
('10', 170, 1, 10, 365620) If I want to learn it well and if I want to attune my ear to it, I can only do so by talking to an Englishman, and by listening to an Englishman speaking.
('10', 170, 1, 11, 365775) Now I think I have given you a terrible dose, I hope you will be able to digest it.
('10', 170, 1, 12, 365859) It is very likely that you with your great imagination and sound common sense have perhaps, in your varied experience there, probably come to the conclusions independently of me.
('10', 170, 1, 13, 366038) After all, they are not new but they have only now assumed such a concrete form and taken a violent possession of me.
('10', 170, 1, 14, 366156) I have just received the following cablegram from Johanne sburg :
('10', 170, 2, 15, 366222) Smuts tells newspapers he awaits Secretary State’s answer regarding his proposals.
('10', 170, 2, 16, 366305) London Committee continues for present.
('10', 170, 2, 17, 366345) This cablegram means that the question is being somewhat agitated in Johannesburg and that Smuts is no longer sanguine about smashing passive resistance.
('10', 170, 2, 18, 366499) It shows, too, if Lord Crewe made a supreme effort, he could bring about a settlement.
('10', 170, 2, 19, 366586) However, we can but fight on.
('10', 170, 2, 20, 366616) So the London Committee continues.
('10', 170, 2, 21, 366651) This does not alter the situation, and it eases Ritch’s position.
('10', 170, 2, 22, 366717) Poor Mrs. Ritch will have to undergo another and further operation.
('10', 170, 2, 23, 366785) She may not even survive it.
('10', 170, 2, 24, 366814) It will be a great relief to her if the living death turns into real death.

('10', 171, 5, 10, 367375) 111. DEPUTATION NOTES [–XVI]
('10', 171, 6, 11, 367404) [October 15, 1909] The last week was rather bad.
('10', 171, 6, 12, 367453) First, we saw a cable report in The Times that the talk about a settlement had no truth in it.
('10', 171, 6, 13, 367548) Mr. Smuts [it said] had a talk with Lord Crewe, but the Government had no intention of conceding the Indian demand.
('10', 171, 6, 14, 367664) There was another private cable which reported that Mr. Smuts was awaiting Lord Crewe’s reply.
('10', 171, 6, 15, 367759) There was a reply from Lord Crewe today (Friday) 1 in which he says that what General Smuts offered was what he had earlier suggested, namely, repeal of the Act and amendment [of the Immigrants’ Restriction Act] so as to permit the admission of selected educated Indians on a permanent basis.
('10', 171, 6, 16, 368052) Lord Crewe states, moreover, that it was for us to decide whether we should carry on any public agitation here.
('10', 171, 6, 17, 368164) He asks us to consider what effect such agitation would have on General Smuts.
('10', 171, 6, 18, 368243) That is the situation here.
('10', 171, 6, 19, 368271) It needs rather careful consideration now as to what is best for us to do.
('10', 171, 6, 20, 368346) If Mr. Smuts is really thinking of con ceding our demands, a public agitation here will prove embarrassing to him.
('10', 171, 6, 21, 368461) If not, such agitation would be the right course.
('10', 171, 6, 22, 368511) It is not easy to express any definite view immediately.
('10', 171, 6, 23, 368568) Indifference to consequences is justified in pure satyagraha, but one must pause to think when dealing with a mixed lot of men, some strong and some weak.
('10', 171, 6, 24, 368723) We have now to await the reactions of Lord Ampthill and other gentlemen.
('10', 171, 6, 25, 368796) Before this letter is published, some decisive step will have been taken here.
('10', 171, 6, 26, 368875) The biggest issue involved in this is that concerning India.
('10', 171, 6, 27, 368936) But, personally, I feel that as the struggle
('10', 171, 7, 28, 368981) 1 October 15; vide “Letter to Under Secretary for Colonies”, 19 10 1909.
('10', 172, 0, 1, 369054) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 173
('10', 172, 1, 2, 369097) develops, the correct step will suggest itself at each stage.
('10', 172, 1, 3, 369159) Meanwhile, everyone will need patience and courage and will have to go through extreme suffering 1. The one great man in Russia is Count Tolstoy.
('10', 172, 1, 4, 369305) I had addressed a letter 2 to him in connection with the struggle and other related matters.
('10', 172, 1, 5, 369398) I quote below a paragraph from his reply : 3
('10', 172, 2, 6, 369443) I have just received your most interesting letter, which has given me great pleasure.
('10', 172, 2, 7, 369529) God help our dear brothers and co workers in the Transvaal!
('10', 172, 2, 8, 369589) That same struggle of the tender against the harsh, of meekness and love against pride and violence, is every year making itself more and more felt here among us also, especially in one of the very sharpest of the conflicts of the religious law with the worldly laws—in refusals of military service.
('10', 172, 2, 9, 369889) Such refusals are becoming ever more and more frequent.
('10', 172, 3, 10, 369945) I greet you fraternally, and am glad to have intercourse with you.
('10', 172, 3, 11, 370012) This great man has now attained the age of 80. In Europe, at least, one will not find his equal in purity of character and godliness.
('10', 172, 3, 12, 370146) He has been a soldier, has enjoyed authority over hundreds of thousands of men, has spent millions in enjoyment, and has known a life of luxury.
('10', 172, 3, 13, 370291) He has no equal among European writers.
('10', 172, 3, 14, 370331) In spite of all this, he has chosen to live like a fakir at present.
('10', 172, 3, 15, 370400) He offers uncompromising opposition to oppressive laws in Russia and exhorts others to do the same.
('10', 172, 3, 16, 370500) But he never employs physical force and forbids others to employ it.
('10', 172, 3, 17, 370569) He relies entirely on spiritual force.
('10', 172, 3, 18, 370608) Moreover, his books are read all over the world.
('10', 172, 3, 19, 370657) We come across a number of men in this land who base their conduct on his principles.
('10', 172, 3, 20, 370743) He places his trust in God alone.
('10', 172, 3, 21, 370777) And so, on me at least, his words have had a highly cheering effect, and I hope that every Indian will welcome them and allow them to guide his conduct.
('10', 172, 3, 22, 370930) It is a matter of deep satisfaction that we have the support of such a great and holy man.
('10', 172, 3, 23, 371021) His letter shows us convincingly that soul force—satya graha— is our only resort.
('10', 172, 3, 24, 371103) Deputations and the like are all vain efforts.

('10', 173, 1, 2, 371488) 112. LETTER TO “SOUTH AFRICA” 1
('10', 173, 2, 3, 371520) [LONDON, Before October 16, 1909]
('10', 173, 3, 4, 371554) SIR, Your Johannesburg correspondent, in his weekly letter published by you in the current issue of your journal, has done a serious injustice to the British Indian community in the Transvaal, by mis stating facts in connection with the Nagappen case.
('10', 173, 3, 5, 371806) Moreover, your correspondent has omitted to state in his letter, that many men besides British Indians who have read the evidence laid before the Commissioner 2 , have refused to accept the Commissioner’s finding, and that Mr. Benson 3 , who represented the British Indian Association at the inquiry, has exposed the weakness of the finding in a three column letter published in the Transvaal Press.
('10', 173, 3, 6, 372206) That letter still remains unanswered.
('10', 173, 3, 7, 372244) And after all, what is Major Dixon’s finding?
('10', 173, 3, 8, 372290) He does leave it an open question as to whether the deceased had two blankets or not.
('10', 173, 3, 9, 372376) He admits that the deceased did not have rice supplied to him.
('10', 173, 3, 10, 372439) It is very charitable on the part of your correspondent to suggest that, if no rice were supplied, water certainly was, and that amply.
('10', 173, 3, 11, 372575) My countrymen, however, consider that even an ample supply of water is not a substitute for rice, nor has the Commissioner, as your correspondent suggested, found that poor Nagappen was healthier when in custody.
('10', 173, 3, 12, 372788) Any layman, and I should imagine even a medical man, would consider, as certainly did Dr. Godfrey 4, that partial starvation and insufficiency of clothing, in the very rigorous winter on the high veldt of the Transvaal, apart from anything else, would be quite sufficient to induce pneumonia from which this poor passive resister died within six days after his
('10', 173, 4, 13, 373149) 1 This appeared under the caption : “South Africa Again Corrected” along with the dispatch to which Gandhiji replied.
('10', 173, 4, 14, 373267) Vide Appendix Dispatch in “south Africa”..

('10', 173, 6, 16, 373882) 4 Dr. W. Godfrey had attended on Nagappen during his last illness and later certified that the primary cause of his death was acute double pneumonia and that it had been “accelerated by the conduct of the gaol officials, if all is true”.

('10', 174, 1, 2, 374163) discharge.

('10', 175, 1, 2, 375733) 115. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES
('10', 175, 2, 3, 375777) [LONDON,] October 19, 1909
('10', 175, 3, 4, 375804) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter 1 of the 15th instant.
('10', 175, 3, 5, 375888) The letter leaves my colleague and me in a state of great uncertainty.
('10', 175, 3, 6, 375959) The Earl of Crewe was pleased to tell Mr. Hajee Habib and me when we waited on His Lordship on the 16th ultimo that he agreed that the proposal submitted by me was reasonable, and that he would place it before Mr. Smuts for his acceptance.
('10', 175, 3, 7, 376199) The letter under reply does not say whether the proposal was placed before Mr. Smuts and, if it was, what his decision was in respect of it.
('10', 175, 3, 8, 376340) His Lordship will, I have no doubt, appreciate the fact that, in order not to prejudice the negotiations that have been carried on, we have remained, so far as the public are concerned, entirely inactive, and we should consider it our duty to do so, so long as the negotiations are carried on on the basis of the proposal submitted by me.
('10', 175, 3, 9, 376679) The great and prolonged suffering British Indians in the Transvaal are undergoing can only end with the security of the theoretical right of British Indians of culture being attained in accordance with my submission.
('10', 175, 3, 10, 376896) If, therefore, Mr. Smuts intends only to place his own original proposal made at the time of his departure for South Africa before the Transvaal Ministers and the Transvaal Parliament, it is respectfully submitted that, so far as British Indians are concerned, nothing is to be gained by a policy of inactivity.
('10', 175, 3, 11, 377208) I feel sure that His Lordship will agree that we should know the exact position under the negotiations, in order that we may thereby guide our conduct and, so far as it lies within our power, facilitate them.
('10', 175, 3, 12, 377417) May I, therefore, request fuller information on the subject of the negotiations at an early date?
('10', 175, 4, 13, 377515) 1 This was in reply to Gandhiji’s letter of October 8 and ran as follows : “.
('10', 175, 4, 14, 377593) the proposals referred to in the letter from this Department of the 4th instant as a possible basis of legislation with regard to the British Indian question in the Transvaal were those made by Mr. Smuts before his departure, not those made by you at the interview on the 16th ultimo.
('10', 175, 4, 15, 377878) “I am to add that the question of the action to be taken by you in connection with the controversy can only be one for your own decision.
('10', 175, 4, 16, 378016) You will, however, no doubt bear in mind the effect which your proposed course may have on the attitude of the Transvaal Government and Parliament towards Mr. Smuts’ proposals, and will consider whether it is not preferable to await a declaration of their policy in the matter before taking further action.”
('10', 176, 0, 1, 378324) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 177
('10', 176, 1, 2, 378367) I may add that a cablegram received from Johannesburg states that to a newspaper reporter Mr. Smuts said that he was waiting for a reply from the Earl of Crewe before he made any public statement regarding his proposals on the question.
('10', 176, 1, 3, 378604) This cablegram adds to our difficulty as to the course we should adopt, so long as we are uniformed as to the action which His Lordship proposed to take when the interview of the 16th ultimo was granted.
('10', 176, 2, 4, 378808) I have, etc., M. K. GANDHI Colonial Office Records : 291/142; also, from a photostat of the typewritten office copy : S. N. 5136
('10', 176, 3, 5, 378937) 116. LETTER TO LORD AMPTHILL [LONDON,] October 19, 1909
('10', 176, 4, 6, 378993) MY LORD, I have to thank you very much for your letter of the 18th instant, and for your very kind and excellent advice.
('10', 176, 5, 7, 379114) I have now sent a letter to lord Crewe, 2 copy of which I enclose herewith, and which I think embodies all the points of your letter.
('10', 176, 5, 8, 379248) I hope it will meet with your Lordship’s approval.
('10', 176, 5, 9, 379299) I remain, etc.,
('10', 176, 6, 10, 379315) From the typewritten office copy : S. N. 5137
('10', 176, 7, 11, 379361) 1 Lord Ampthill had written : “It was, of course, to be expected that the Colonial Office should wish you to remain quiet and it is difficult to judge how far their advice is disinterested or otherwise.
('10', 176, 7, 12, 379564) They tell you that it is General Smuts’ own proposals which are under consideration but they do not tell you whether Lord Crewe has taken any steps to show the Transvaal Government that, from your point of view, these proposals are altogether inadequate.
('10', 176, 7, 13, 379819) If I were in your position, I should point this out to the Colonial Office either by letter or by personal interview before I did anything else and say that, while you are naturally unwilling to embarrass any negotiations which are being made on your behalf, you require some assurance that your latest representations are not being ignored.
('10', 176, 7, 14, 380161) I would tell them quite plainly, but, of course, in appropriately guarded language, that you cannot allow an unsatisfactory ‘compromise’ to be negotiated while you are kept out of the discussion and then to be told, when it is all over and you are obliged to protest, that you are ‘raising new questions’.
('10', 176, 7, 15, 380467) I think that they have given you an opening for a representation of this sort which you will well know how to express in a tactful and diplomatic manner.
('10', 176, 7, 16, 380621) It must be exasperating for you to be put off and kept waiting in this way, and I only hope that the Colonial Office is going straight and not trading on the patience and self restraint of which you have given such conspicuous proof.” 2 Vide the preceding item.

('10', 177, 1, 2, 380925) 117. LONDON
('10', 177, 2, 3, 380937) [Before October 20, 1909]
('10', 177, 3, 4, 380963) NATAL DEPUTATION
('10', 177, 4, 5, 380980) So far as I can see, there is nothing for this deputation to do now.
('10', 177, 4, 6, 381049) Mr. Anglia and Hajee Habib are on a brief visit to Paris.
('10', 177, 4, 7, 381107) They are likely to return in a day or so.
('10', 177, 5, 8, 381149) ALI IMAM
('10', 177, 6, 9, 381158) Mr. Ali Imam has been mixing a great deal among all the Indians here.
('10', 177, 6, 10, 381228) He had asked several Indians to tea today, on the eve of his departure.
('10', 177, 6, 11, 381300) A good many of them attended.
('10', 177, 6, 12, 381330) Mr. Ali Imam will leave for India on the 20th.
('10', 177, 6, 13, 381377) He has promised to give every help to our cause from there.
('10', 177, 6, 14, 381437) He has been appointed public prosecutor in Patna.
('10', 177, 7, 15, 381487) SUFFRAGETTES’ COURAGE
('10', 177, 8, 16, 381509) I have written and spoken strongly in the past against the use of physical force by the suffragettes—women who are demanding votes.
('10', 177, 8, 17, 381641) But we must show all honour to them, at any rate, for the courage they display and the suffering they go through.
('10', 177, 8, 18, 381755) Some of them, very delicate women, were recently arrested and sentenced to impris onment.
('10', 177, 8, 19, 381845) They refused to take any food, so that those among them who were very weak were let off after being starved for a few days.
('10', 177, 8, 20, 381969) The rest are still in gaol and refuse to take food; they are, therefore, being forcibly fed with the help of a tube put through the throat.
('10', 177, 8, 21, 382109) These women have created such a terror that no member of the Cabinet can attend any function in peace.
('10', 177, 8, 22, 382212) The suffragettes’ spies follow every member wherever he goes and make a nuisance of themselves.
('10', 177, 8, 23, 382308) They even pelt him with stones.
('10', 177, 8, 24, 382340) A mere handful, the women have created a terror as though a great war was on.
('10', 177, 8, 25, 382418) Mr. Lloyd George is a member of the Cabinet.
('10', 177, 8, 26, 382463) He addressed a meeting in Newcastle.
('10', 177, 8, 27, 382500) But so great was the fear of the suffragettes that the strictest arrangements had to be made for maintaining order.
('10', 177, 8, 28, 382616) Writing on it, The Times says : In Mr. Lloyd George’s meeting were to be witnessed strong iron bars, mounted police and crowds.
('10', 177, 8, 29, 382744) There was a time not very long ago when no tickets were required for admission to such meet ings and
('10', 178, 0, 1, 382845) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 179
('10', 178, 1, 2, 382888) when one or two constables sufficed to maintain order.
('10', 178, 1, 3, 382943) But the suffragettes have changed all that.
('10', 178, 1, 4, 382987) Wherever a member of the Cabinet addresses a meeting, the local authorities have to close the main traffic routes and requisition police and mounted guards in large numbers from neighbour ing towns.
('10', 178, 1, 5, 383186) Everyone who wants to attend the meeting has to show his ticket while he is yet one or two streets away from the venue, and he reaches it at last after passing through narrow lanes.
('10', 178, 1, 6, 383368) If, on the way, anyone suspects him he may even be required to give his name.
('10', 178, 1, 7, 383446) All this is a very expensive business.
('10', 178, 1, 8, 383485) Such is the women’s spirit.
('10', 178, 1, 9, 383513) They do not allow themselves a moment’s rest.
('10', 178, 1, 10, 383559) To the hundreds of thousands of women who oppose them, they merely say : “You do not know your interests.
('10', 178, 1, 11, 383665) We shall fight for you.
('10', 178, 1, 12, 383689) That you will not help makes no difference to us.” They have also written to the Government to say that, if it agreed to grant the franchise to women who were qualified for it, those who were in gaol would serve their terms of imprisonment quietly and would not even demand voting rights for themselves.
('10', 178, 1, 13, 383993) Such brave women will never be defeated.
('10', 178, 1, 14, 384034) It is obvious that they have no interest of their own to serve.
('10', 178, 1, 15, 384098) They fear nothing—neither rough treatment nor monetary loss nor being called immodest by the people.
('10', 178, 1, 16, 384199) There is no short cut to rights in this world.
('10', 178, 1, 17, 384246) These very women, by their disorderly behaviour, bring disgrace to a struggle so fine as theirs, Their misdeeds will recoil on themselves in the end.
('10', 178, 1, 18, 384396) 1 The people here yield to physical force, they worship it.
('10', 178, 1, 19, 384456) Hence the women will certainly get the vote.
('10', 178, 1, 20, 384501) But after that they will practise the same kind of tyranny that they are opposing now, so that the masses will remain where they are.
('10', 178, 1, 21, 384635) If they had based their fight on pure satyagraha, they could have changed conditions all over England and the change would have had repercussions throughout the world.
('10', 178, 1, 22, 384803) The use of physical force will ultimately lead to selfishness.
('10', 178, 1, 23, 384866) Taking a warning from their example, we must learn to avoid the use of physical force, but emulate their capacity for suffering.
('10', 178, 1, 24, 384995) We may also observe that the British will not concede any rights even to the women in their country without putting them to the test.
('10', 178, 1, 25, 385129) BLOW FOR A BLOW I have come across two very beautiful poems in the Gujarati of Bombay.
('10', 178, 1, 26, 385216) In one of them poet has, without meaning it, given a vivid
('10', 178, 2, 27, 385275) 1 The original has “The heart will pay for the misdeeds of the hands”, a Gujarati saying.
('10', 179, 0, 1, 385365) 180 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 179, 1, 2, 385407) description of satyagraha.
('10', 179, 1, 3, 385434) The poem is as follows : The lamp not burning, On what will the moth throw itself and be burnt?
('10', 179, 1, 4, 385530) Seeking to burn us, You burn yourself first.
('10', 179, 1, 5, 385575) The union of soul and body, The same in you as in me, Unless you wound yourself, Us you cannot hurt.
('10', 179, 1, 6, 385676) So soon as I owned myself your lover, You stood declared my beloved; A name I’ve bestowed on you, And will cease only when I perish.
('10', 179, 1, 7, 385809) Such airs you give yourself today, Your eyes stern and proud; These your arrows Will turn back upon you, myself unharmed.
('10', 179, 1, 8, 385931) You live, if I live; if I die, Tell yourself you die too; Can a tree exist without seed?
('10', 179, 1, 9, 386020) The fruit, whereon will it grow?
('10', 179, 1, 10, 386053) Where is the king if there are no subjects?
('10', 179, 1, 11, 386097) Would he rule over wood and stone?
('10', 179, 1, 12, 386132) Your being is wrapped up in mine Aiming a blow at me, You shall only hurt yourself.
('10', 179, 1, 13, 386216) —Diwano 1
('10', 179, 2, 14, 386226) This is a very interesting gazal.
('10', 179, 2, 15, 386260) 2 It is addressed by an Indian to an Englishman.
('10', 179, 2, 16, 386309) “Your arrows will turn back upon you, myself unharmed.” This contains the divine law of satyagraha.
('10', 179, 2, 17, 386409) So long as the victim does not resist, the aggressor will only injure himself.
('10', 179, 2, 18, 386488) If we attempt to strike merely at the air, the hand will come down with a jerk.
('10', 179, 2, 19, 386568) When force is employed only by one party, it will spend itself
('10', 179, 3, 20, 386631) 1 Literally, the mad on 2 A poetic composition in the style of lyrics
('10', 180, 0, 1, 386701) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 181
('10', 180, 1, 2, 386744) for want of resistance.
('10', 180, 1, 3, 386768) That is the reason why every religion has held that, if all human beings were to become good, even the poisonous and predatory creatures would disappear from the world.
('10', 180, 1, 4, 386937) This may be taken to be a scientific law.
('10', 180, 1, 5, 386979) If so, it is all success for me so long as I refuse to meet force with force.
('10', 180, 1, 6, 387057) The man who sought my life will, in the end, meet death himself.
('10', 180, 1, 7, 387122) In the same way, “Where is the king if there are no subjects, would he rule over wood and stone” means that, if the subjects refuse to recognize the authority of the king, the latter will have nothing to do.
('10', 180, 1, 8, 387330) The subjects may resort to satyagraha and tell him : “We shall not submit to your orders, no matter whether you imprison or kill us.” There has never been, and will never be, a king in this world who can rule by imprisoning a whole people.
('10', 180, 1, 9, 387570) The king will lose the game, even if he imprisons only a few who defy him.
('10', 180, 1, 10, 387645) If all defy him, he just cannot imprison there.
('10', 180, 1, 11, 387693) The soul of the man who has embraced imprisonment continues its work till, in the end, others too defy [the king] in like manner.
('10', 180, 1, 12, 387823) All the verses of the poem quoted above deserve careful thinking over.
('10', 180, 2, 13, 387894) “FAKIRS WE”
('10', 180, 3, 14, 387906) In the same issue, I find another poem—Fakirs We—which also, being quite interesting, I give here : Fakirs we’ve made of ourselves For the motherland’s sake; We’ve kindled the flame of love To burn us for India’s sake.
('10', 180, 3, 15, 388125) We have quit the idols we worshipped, Flung our books in dust; The precious begging bowl We’ve taken up for India’s sake.
('10', 180, 3, 16, 388247) The angel’s words and the priest’s We’ve put away from us, Turned away from pleasures sweet as nectar For draughts of bitterest poison.
('10', 180, 3, 17, 388383) The tomes of Vedas and Puranas Down the stream we’ve let them float; Little do we reck of God, For India alone is all our care.
('10', 181, 0, 1, 388511) 182 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 181, 1, 2, 388553) Through every vein of our being Is coursing a wild intoxication; Why do you seek, you men of medicine, To cure us of that?
('10', 181, 1, 3, 388676) In soft living you spend your days, ’Tis your way of life; Ours, the bad habit, The burden of loyalty to bear.
('10', 181, 1, 4, 388787) Such is the strange gladness Of the madness in our drunken hearts; ’Tis for India And India alone that we live.
('10', 181, 1, 5, 388899) —Bulbul 1
('10', 181, 2, 6, 388909) This poem is certainly not as good as the first one, but the idea is good.
('10', 181, 2, 7, 388984) The words are well arranged.
('10', 181, 2, 8, 389013) Its fervent sentiment should appeal to a satyagrahi.
('10', 181, 2, 9, 389066) Without it—without the voluntary poverty of the fakir that it speaks of—it is difficult to be a satyagrahi.
('10', 181, 2, 10, 389174) One must kindle the flame of the Invisible for the service of India.
('10', 181, 2, 11, 389243) Then alone shall we be able to discharge the debt we owe to India for having been born in it.
('10', 181, 2, 12, 389337) When the words, “Tis for India and for India alone that we live” proceed from the depth of our heart, God will hear us.
('10', 181, 2, 13, 389457) He sees the heart.
('10', 181, 2, 14, 389476) He cannot be taken in by words.
('10', 181, 2, 15, 389508) This is a game to be played in right earnest.
('10', 181, 2, 16, 389554) A mere actor has no place in it.
('10', 181, 3, 17, 389587) INDIAN LANGUAGES
('10', 181, 4, 18, 389604) Reading these Gujarati poems, one realizes that it will not be easy to express such thoughts in English words of equal sweetness; for the two words, “satyagraha” and “fakir”, will evoke no response in an Englishman’s heart.
('10', 181, 4, 19, 389828) Why should we not cultivate a language that is so beautiful?
('10', 181, 4, 20, 389889) India will be aroused when we touch all the Indian languages with the spirit of patriotism.
('10', 181, 4, 21, 389981) Mr. Lloyd George, about whom I have already written, was born in Wales, a principality in Great Britain.
('10', 181, 4, 22, 390086) It has a dialect of its own and Mr. Lloyd George is taking steps to ensure that Welsh children do not forget their language.
('10', 181, 4, 23, 390211) How much more need is there for Indians to preserve their languages than

('10', 183, 9, 21, 392795) 121. DEPUTATION NOTES [–XVII]
('10', 183, 10, 22, 392825) [October 22, 1909] I have now got fed up.
('10', 183, 10, 23, 392867) I think the reader, too, must have grown tired of reading uncertain news.
('10', 183, 10, 24, 392941) There is no certain information yet from Lord Crewe and correspondence is going on.
('10', 183, 10, 25, 393025) So long as he has not washed his hands of the matter entirely, it appears advisable not to give out anything to the public.
('10', 183, 10, 26, 393149) That is also Lord Ampthill’s advice.
('10', 183, 11, 27, 393186) 1 In 1906; vide “Indian Stretcher Bearer corps”, Before 19 7 1906. 2 Vide “London”,23 7 1909
('10', 184, 0, 1, 393279) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 185
('10', 184, 1, 2, 393322) Just now a cable 1 has been received from Johannesburg, saying that 21 persons were tried and sentenced to three months.
('10', 184, 1, 3, 393443) They include Mr. Aswat and Mr. Thambi Naidoo.
('10', 184, 1, 4, 393489) Moreover, Mr. Sorabji, Mr. Joshi and Mr. Medh have been deported.
('10', 184, 1, 5, 393555) I congratulate all these friends and pray to God to bestow on them the utmost strength of spirit.
('10', 184, 1, 6, 393653) According to me, such strength is the only real deputation.
('10', 184, 1, 7, 393713) It is strength which holds the real key.
('10', 184, 1, 8, 393754) When I think of Mr. Aswat’s and Mr. Sorabji’s health, I even tremble a little, but take heart again because I know that gaol going is the best course, whatever the state of one’s health.
('10', 184, 1, 9, 393941) At this juncture, I wish to see Mr. Dawad Mahomed in the Transvaal.
('10', 184, 1, 10, 394009) Soldiers cannot afford to wait on their health.
('10', 184, 1, 11, 394057) I am convinced that, even when in poor health, we are in duty bound to suffer imprison ment for the sake of the motherland.
('10', 184, 1, 12, 394181) I think many Indians press Mr. Dawad Mahomed, out of their regard for him, that he should plunge himself into the fight only after he is restored to health.
('10', 184, 1, 13, 394338) I would request him not to heed any such advice, and I would urge those who give such advice that they should not, in the interest of the community, hold back Mr. Dawad Mahomed even for an hour longer.
('10', 184, 1, 14, 394540) The women who are fighting here go to gaol and give no thought to their health.
('10', 184, 1, 15, 394620) Moreover, they take no food after going to gaol.
('10', 184, 1, 16, 394669) Going to the front necessarily means risking one’s head.

('10', 187, 3, 4, 399572) There was a famous man in Spain, Ferrer by name, who worked to spread education among the people.

('10', 187, 3, 10, 399973) This has created a stir among a large number of whites in Europe.

('10', 197, 4, 14, 420827) 132. LETTER TO G. A. NATESAN 1
('10', 197, 5, 15, 420858) [LONDON, After October 29, 1909]
('10', 197, 6, 16, 420891) DEAR SIR, You have cabled me for a message to the forthcoming Congress.
('10', 197, 6, 17, 420963) I do not know that I am at all competent to send any message.
('10', 197, 6, 18, 421025) Simple courtesy, however, demands that I should say something in reply to your cable.
('10', 197, 6, 19, 421111) At the present moment, I am unable to think of anything but the task immediately before me, namely, the struggle that is going on in the Transvaal.
('10', 197, 6, 20, 421259) I hope our countrymen throughout India realise that it is national in its aim in that it has been undertaken to save India’s honour.
('10', 197, 6, 21, 421392) I may be wrong, but I have not hesitated publicly to remark that it is the greatest struggle of modern times, because it is the purest as well in its goal as in its methods.
('10', 197, 6, 22, 421566) Our countrymen in the Transvaal are fighting for the right of cultured Indians to enter the Transvaal in common with Europeans.
('10', 197, 6, 23, 421694) In this the fighters have no
('10', 197, 7, 24, 421723) 1 This was published in the December issue of Indian Review.
('10', 197, 7, 25, 421784) Evidently, Gandhiji had simultaneously sent a copy to Indian Opinion which published it under the heading : “Message to Indian National Congress”.
('10', 197, 7, 26, 421931) Vide also “Letter to H. S. L. Polak”,29 10 1909.
('10', 198, 0, 1, 421980) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 199
('10', 198, 1, 2, 422023) personal interest to serve, nor is there any material gain to accrue to anybody after the above mentioned right (which has, for the first time in Colonial Legislation, been taken away) is restored.
('10', 198, 1, 3, 422221) The sons of Hindustan, who are in the Transvaal, are showing that they are capable of fighting for an ideal pure and simple.
('10', 198, 1, 4, 422346) The methods adopted in order to secure relief are also equally pure and equally simple.
('10', 198, 1, 5, 422434) Violence in any shape or form is entirely eschewed.
('10', 198, 1, 6, 422486) They believe that self suffering is the only true and effective means to procure lasting reforms.
('10', 198, 1, 7, 422584) They endeavour to meet and conquer hatred by love.
('10', 198, 1, 8, 422635) They oppose the brute or physical force by soul force.
('10', 198, 1, 9, 422690) They hold that loyalty to an earthly Sovereign or an earthly constitution is subordinate to loyalty to God and His constitution.
('10', 198, 1, 10, 422819) In inter preting God’s constitution through their conscience, they admit that they may possibly be wrong.
('10', 198, 1, 11, 422925) Hence, in resisting or disregarding those man made laws which they consider to be inconsistent with the eternal laws of God, they accept with resignation the penalties provided by the former, and trust to the working of time and to the best in human nature to make good their position.
('10', 198, 1, 12, 423211) If they are wrong, they alone suffer, and the estab lished order of things continues.
('10', 198, 1, 13, 423297) In the process, over 2,500 Indians, or nearly one half of the resident Indian population, or one fifth of the pos sible Indian population of the Transvaal, have suffered imprisonment, car rying with it terrible hardships.
('10', 198, 1, 14, 423519) Some of them have gone to gaol again and again.
('10', 198, 1, 15, 423567) Many families have been impoverished.
('10', 198, 1, 16, 423605) Several merchants have accepted privation rather than surrender their manhood.
('10', 198, 1, 17, 423684) Incidentally, the Hindu Mahomedan problem has been solved in South Africa.
('10', 198, 1, 18, 423759) We rea lise there that the one cannot do without the other.
('10', 198, 1, 19, 423819) Mahomedans, Parsees and Hindus, or taking them provincially, Bengalees, Madrasees, Punjabis, Afghanistanees, and Bombayites, have fought shoulder to shoulder.
('10', 198, 1, 20, 423978) I venture to suggest that a struggle such as this is worthy of occupying the best, if not, indeed, the exclusive attention of the Congress.
('10', 198, 1, 21, 424118) If it be not impertinent, I would like to distinguish between this and the other items on the programme of the Congress.
('10', 198, 1, 22, 424239) The opposition to the laws or the policy with which the other items deal does not involve any material suffering : the Congress activity consists in a mental attitude without corresponding action.
('10', 198, 1, 23, 424436) In the Transvaal case, the law and the policy it enunciates being wrong, we disregard it, and there fore consciously and deliberately suffer material and physical injury; ac tion follows and corresponds to our mental
('10', 199, 0, 1, 424653) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 199, 1, 2, 424695) attitude.
('10', 199, 1, 3, 424705) If the view here sub mitted be correct, it will be allowed that, in asking for the best place in the Congress programme for the Transvaal question, I have not been un reasonable.
('10', 199, 1, 4, 424884) May I also suggest that, in pondering over and concentrating our attention upon passive resistance such as has been described above, we would perchance find out that for the many ills we suffer from in India passive resistance is an infallible panacea.
('10', 199, 1, 5, 425137) It is worthy of careful study, and I am sure it will be found that it is the only weapon that is suited to the genius of our people and our land, which is the nursery of the most ancient religions and has very little to learn from modern civilization—a civilization based on violence of the blackest type, largely a negation of the Divine in man, and which is rushing headlong to its own ruin.

('10', 200, 1, 2, 427176) inform you of what I have seen.
('10', 200, 1, 3, 427208) I have made it a point to see Indians here of every shade of opinion.
('10', 200, 1, 4, 427278) Opposed as I am to violence in any shape or form, I have endeavoured specially to come into contact with the so called extremists who may be better described as the party of violence.
('10', 200, 1, 5, 427462) This I have done in order if possible to convince them of the error of their ways.
('10', 200, 1, 6, 427545) I have noticed that some of the members of this party are earnest spirits, possessing a high degree of morality, great intellectual ability and lofty self sacrifice.
('10', 200, 1, 7, 427711) They wield an undoubted influence on the young Indians here.
('10', 200, 1, 8, 427772) They are certainly unsparing in their efforts to impress upon the latter their convictions.
('10', 200, 1, 9, 427864) One of them came to me with a view to convince me that I was wrong in my methods and that nothing but the use of violence, covert or open or both, was likely to bring about redress of the wrongs they consider they suffer.
('10', 200, 1, 10, 428086) An awakening of the national consciousness is unmistakable.
('10', 200, 1, 11, 428146) But among the majority it is in a crude shape and there is not a corresponding spirit of self sacrifice.
