('10', 200, 1, 25, 429211) India suffers additionally only in so far as it is exp loited in the interest of foreign capitalists.
('10', 200, 1, 26, 429313) The true remedy lies, in my humble opinion, in England discarding modern civilization which is en souled by this spirit of selfishness and materialism, is vain and purpose less and is a negation of the spirit of Christianity.

('10', 202, 1, 2, 432144) 134. SPEECH AT NEW REFORM CLUB 1
('10', 202, 2, 3, 432177) [LONDON, October 30, 1909]
('10', 202, 3, 4, 432204) The fight (he said) was for freedom of conscience, for mental independence and independence of action, not for the mechanical right of voting.
('10', 202, 3, 5, 432347) British Indians first emigrated to the Transvaal in 1883, and from the first, their very vertues were set down as vices by those who could not realize how difficult it was for Indians to live in such a country.
('10', 202, 4, 6, 432558) They had heard from Lord Lansdowne that the war was undertaken as much for the British Indians as for other Outlanders, but after the war was over, the former were in a much worse position.
('10', 202, 4, 7, 432748) They could only trade or hold land in Locations reserved for them, they had no burgher rights and no right to walk on the footpath, and it could be imagined how they were therefore treated by the people of the Transvaal when they were so degraded in the eyes of the law.
('10', 202, 4, 8, 433019) Many statesmen allowed themselves to be betrayed into the hands of a few agitators, rivals in trade of the British Indians, and the new Registration Law of 1906 was used for oppressing British Indians.
('10', 202, 4, 9, 433221) It was impossible for those who had the slightest sense of self respect to accept that legislation.
('10', 202, 4, 10, 433321) Deputations were repulsed, as was the request for a judicial enquiry.
('10', 202, 4, 11, 433391) British Indians had been thrown into gaol and classed in treatment with the black men being forced to live upon the same dietery, with the consequence that they were practically starved.
('10', 202, 4, 12, 433578) For the sake of the national honour they became passive resisters.
('10', 202, 4, 13, 433645) It might be years before they could make themselves heard, but that would only be because they had not suffered enough.
('10', 202, 4, 14, 433765) They had justice on their side, and Hindus, Mahomedans and Tamils, by working together in the cause, had solved a great racial problem.

('10', 203, 1, 2, 434115) 135. SPEECH AT MEETING OF INDIANS 1
('10', 203, 2, 3, 434151) [LONDON, November 2, 1909]
('10', 203, 3, 4, 434178) Mr. Gandhi, in the course of his remarks, stated that in the Transvaal would be solved the question, so far as the whole of South Africa was concerned, of the status of British Indians, and that it had a far reaching effect in India also, and as the struggle in the Transvaal was for preserving the national honour, every Indian was bound to do his utmost to help the cause.
('10', 203, 3, 5, 434553) He felt that if Indian volunteers came forward to do propaganda work in London and surrounding districts a great deal could be done to inform public opinion, which was ultimately bound to react on the Transvaal.
('10', 203, 3, 6, 434765) The volunteers should set apart consistently with their ordinary occupations a certain amount of time for paying house to house visits and getting subscriptions from one farthing upward to relieve the distress amongst passive resisters and their families, and signatures to a document 2 expressing sympathy with the struggles of the passive resisters, encouraging them and trusting that the authorities will grant relief.
('10', 203, 4, 7, 435187) Indian Opinion, 4 12 1909

('10', 206, 4, 16, 441437) 139. LETTER TO THE PRESS
('10', 206, 5, 17, 441462) LONDON, November 5, 1909
('10', 206, 6, 18, 441487) SIR, The Transvaal British Indian deputation arrived in London on the 10th day of July last.
('10', 206, 6, 19, 441580) The enclosed statement 4 of the British Indian case in that Colony was prepared immediately after the arrival in London of that deputation, but it was not issued as delicate negotiations with a view to arriving at a quiet settlement were in progress.
('10', 206, 6, 20, 441831) We have now learnt that these have proved abortive and that the position remains unchanged.
('10', 206, 6, 21, 441923) It has therefore become necessary for us to inform the public as to how the matter stands and what the struggle of the British Indians in the Transvaal means.
('10', 206, 6, 22, 442082) The ex Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal during its adminis tration as a Crown Colony, writing in a magazine in South Africa in the month of February last, thus correctly summed up the question :
('10', 206, 7, 23, 442280) The position of the Indian leaders is that they will tolerate no law which does
('10', 206, 8, 24, 442360) 1 No report of this speech is available.
('10', 206, 8, 25, 442401) 2 Vide “Deputation’s Last Letter”, After 6 11 1909. 3 Vide “Speech at Farewell Meeting”,12 11 1909. 4 Vide “Statement of Transvaal Indian Case”, 16 7 1909.
('10', 207, 0, 1, 442557) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 207, 1, 2, 442599) not put them on an equality with Europeans in regard to restriction on immigration.
('10', 207, 1, 3, 442683) They are willing to see the number of Asiatics limited by administrative action.
('10', 207, 1, 4, 442764) They insist on equality in the terms of the law itself.
('10', 207, 1, 5, 442820) That is still the position.
('10', 207, 1, 6, 442848) Mr. Smuts, the present Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal, offers to repeal the Registration Law around which the struggle has been raging for the last three years, and to concede to a limited number of British Indians, other than former residents of the Transvaal, certificates of per manent residence.
('10', 207, 1, 7, 443153) Were the object aimed at by the British Indians the ad mission into the Colony of a few more of their brethren, this concession would be material, but the object they have had in view in agitating for the repeal of the Law being to secure legal or theoretical equality in respect of immigration, their purpose is by the proposed maintenance of the legal disability not advanced a step.
('10', 207, 1, 8, 443539) We are not aware whether the above modification of the present law proposed by Mr. Smuts will take place irrespective of the continuance of the passive resistance at present being offered by the British Indians of the Transvaal, but we are in a position to state that the proposed concession will not satisfy passive resisters.
('10', 207, 1, 9, 443867) The struggle of the Indian community of that Colony was undertaken in order to obtain the removal of the stigma cast upon the whole of India by this legislation, which imports a racial and colour bar into the Immigration Laws of a British Colony for the first time in the history of Colonial legislation.
('10', 207, 1, 10, 444172) The principle so laid down, that British Indians may not enter the Transvaal because they are British Indians, is a radical departure from traditional policy, is un British and intolerable, and if that principle is accepted even tacitly by British Indians, we consider that they will be untrue to themselves, to the land of their birth, and to the Empire to which they belong.
('10', 207, 1, 11, 444549) Nor is it the passive resisters in the Transvaal who in a matter of this kind have alone to be considered.
('10', 207, 1, 12, 444656) The whole of India is now awakened to a sense of the insult that the Transvaal legislation offers to her, and we feel that the people here at the heart of the Empire cannot remain unmoved by this departure, so unprecedented and so vital, from Imperial traditions.
('10', 207, 1, 13, 444920) Mr. Smuts’ proposal brings out the issue in the clearest manner possible.
('10', 207, 1, 14, 444994) If we were fighting not for a principle but for loaves and fishes, he would be prepared to throw them at us in the shape of residential permits for the small number of cultured British Indians that may be required for our wants, but because we insist upon the removal of the implied racial taint from the legislation of the
('10', 208, 0, 1, 445318) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 209
('10', 208, 1, 2, 445361) Colony, he is not prepared to yield an inch.
('10', 208, 1, 3, 445406) He would give us the husk without the kernel.
('10', 208, 1, 4, 445452) He declines to remove the badge of inferiority, but is ready to change the present rough looking symbol for a nicely polished one.
('10', 208, 1, 5, 445583) British Indians, however, decline to be deluded.
('10', 208, 1, 6, 445632) They may yield everything, occupy any position, but the badge must be removed first.
('10', 208, 1, 7, 445717) We, therefore, trust that the public will not be misled by the specious concessions that are being offered into the belief that British Indians, because they do not accept them, are unreasonable in their demands, that they are uncompromising, and that, therefore, they do not deserve the sympathy and support of a common sense and practical public.
('10', 208, 1, 8, 446066) In the final reply received by us from Lord Crewe the following is the position that is taken up :
('10', 208, 2, 9, 446165) His Lordship explained to you that Mr. Smuts was unable to accept the claim that Asiatics should be placed in a position of equality with Europeans in respect of right of entry or otherwise.
('10', 208, 2, 10, 446356) Herein lies the crux.
('10', 208, 2, 11, 446378) Legal equality in respect of the right of entry, even though never a man does enter, is what British Indians have been fighting for and, according to the reports we have received from the Transvaal, is what some of them, at least, will die for.
('10', 208, 2, 12, 446623) The only possible justification for holding together the different communities of the Empire under the same Sovereignty is the fact of elementary equality, and it is because the Transvaal legislation cuts at the very root of this principle that British Indians have offered a stubborn resistance.
('10', 208, 2, 13, 446920) It would be contrary to fact to argue that no relief can be had in this matter because the Transvaal is a self governing Colony, and because now South Africa has got its Union.
('10', 208, 2, 14, 447097) The difficulty of the situation is due to a mistake committed at the centre of the Empire.
('10', 208, 2, 15, 447188) The Imperial Go vernment are party to the crime against the Imperial Constitution.
('10', 208, 2, 16, 447271) They sanctioned when they need not have, and when it was their duty not to have sanctioned, the legislation in question.
('10', 208, 2, 17, 447392) They are now undoubtedly most anxious to settle this troublesome matter.
('10', 208, 2, 18, 447465) Lord Crewe has endeavo ured to bring about a satisfactory result, but he is too late.
('10', 208, 2, 19, 447551) Mr. Smuts, perhaps very properly, has reminded His Lordship of the fact that the legislation in question had received Imperial sanction, and that he should or could not now be called upon to retrace his steps, because the British Indians in the Transvaal had undertaken to disregard the legislation, and to suffer the penalties of such disregard.
('10', 208, 2, 20, 447898) His position as a politician and as an
('10', 209, 0, 1, 447937) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 209, 1, 2, 447979) aspirant to high office in “a white South Africa” is unquestionable, but neither the British public nor the Indian public are interested in his position, nor are they party to this crime of the Imperial Government.
('10', 209, 1, 3, 448194) We may add that, during the last four months, arrests and imprison ments have gone on unabated.
('10', 209, 1, 4, 448290) The leaders of the community continue to go to prison.
('10', 209, 1, 5, 448345) The severity of the prison regulations is maintained.
('10', 209, 1, 6, 448399) The prison diet has been altered for the worse.
('10', 209, 1, 7, 448447) Prominent medical men of Johannesburg have certified that the present dietary scale for Indian prisoners is deficient.
('10', 209, 1, 8, 448566) The authorities, unlike their action during last year, have ignored the religious scruples of Mahomedan prisoners, and have refused to give facilities for observing the sacred annual fast which millions of Mahomedans scrupulously undergo from year to year.
('10', 209, 1, 9, 448823) Sixty passive resisters recently came out of the Pretoria Gaol emaciated and weak.
('10', 209, 1, 10, 448906) Their message to us is that, starved as they were, they are ready to be re arrested as soon as the Government wish to lay their hands on them.
('10', 209, 1, 11, 449049) The Acting Chairman of the British Indian Association has only just been arrested and sentenced to be imprisoned for three months with hard labour.
('10', 209, 1, 12, 449197) This is his third term.
('10', 209, 1, 13, 449221) He is a Mahomedan.
('10', 209, 1, 14, 449240) A brave Parsee, a well educated man, was deported to Natal.
('10', 209, 1, 15, 449300) He re entered, and is now undergoing six months’ imprisonment with hard labour.
('10', 209, 1, 16, 449380) He is in gaol for the fifth time.
('10', 209, 1, 17, 449414) A young Indian, an ex Volunteer sergeant, has also gone to gaol for the third time on the same terms as the Parsee.
('10', 209, 1, 18, 449530) Wives of imprisoned British Indians and their children either take up baskets of fruit, hawk about and earn their living in order to support themselves, or are being supported from contributions.
('10', 209, 1, 19, 449726) Mr. Smuts, when he re embarked for South Africa, said that he had arrived at an understanding with Lord Crewe that would satisfy the large body of British Indians who were heartily sick of the agitation.
('10', 209, 1, 20, 449930) His prophecy has been totally disproved by what has happened since.
('10', 209, 2, 21, 449998) We remain, etc.,
('10', 209, 3, 22, 450015) M. K. GANDHI HAJEE HABIB
('10', 210, 0, 1, 450040) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 211
('10', 210, 1, 2, 450083) [ENCLOSURE]
('10', 210, 2, 3, 450095) SUMMARY OF STATEMENT
('10', 210, 3, 4, 450116) The British Indians in the Transvaal have been suffering for the past two years and six months untold suffering in order to secure : Repeal of a Transvaal law called the Asiatic Registration Act (2 of 1907) which its authors claim to be a measure merely for effecting the identification of the British Indians entitled to remain in the Colony, but which is regarded by the British Indians themselves as most objectionable, because, in reality— (1) The Act wounds their religious susceptibilities and degrades them in many ways; and (2) Read together with another law of a later date (called the Immigration Act), it constitutes an impassable barrier to the immigration of Indians, however highly cultured, on the score of their race and colour.
('10', 210, 3, 5, 450861) The desired relief can easily be granted by repealing the Registration Act and slightly amending the Immigration Act, without in any way endangering the colonial policy of preventing an influx of British Indians.
('10', 210, 3, 6, 451074) The practical effect of such repeal and amendment would be the removal of the racial insult, and would at the most involve the entry of the few Indian new comers necessary for the spiritual and intellectual needs of the resident community.
('10', 210, 3, 7, 451314) The Indians at present actually residing in the Transvaal number about 5,000. The population of Indians domiciled in the Transvaal is about 13,000. The difference means that nearly 8,000 Indians have been driven away, for the time being, from the Transvaal, being too weak to undergo the physical suffering of gaol life.
('10', 210, 3, 8, 451635) Over 2,500 British Indians have passed through the Transvaal gaols, all but 150 having been imprisoned with hard labour.
('10', 210, 3, 9, 451756) Sentences have ranged from four days’ to six months’ hard labour.
('10', 210, 3, 10, 451822) Hundreds of British Indians have been ruined in the struggle.
('10', 210, 3, 11, 451884) Several families have been supported from public subscriptions, the wage earners being in the Transvaal gaols.
('10', 210, 3, 12, 451995) Indians both young and old have suffered and are still suffering imprisonment.
('10', 210, 3, 13, 452074) Many leaders are at present in the gaols, including the Mahomedan Chairman of the British Indian Association and a Parsee gentleman who is renowned
('10', 211, 0, 1, 452222) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 211, 1, 2, 452264) for his philanthropy throughout South Africa.
('10', 211, 1, 3, 452310) Fathers and sons have been in gaol at the same time.
('10', 211, 1, 4, 452363) About sixty Indians have been deported to India, where they were Ianded penniless and friendless.
('10', 211, 1, 5, 452461) A band of noble Europeans in the Transvaal, headed by Mr. Wm.
('10', 211, 1, 6, 452523) Hosken, M. L. A. of the Transvaal, have formed themselves into a committee for securing justice.
('10', 211, 1, 7, 452620) Hindoos and Mahomedans, Parsees and Sikhs are fighting shoulder to shoulder.
('10', 211, 1, 8, 452697) The struggle to day is being continued to maintain the honour of the three hundred millions of their fellow countrymen, and is absolutely selfless.
('10', 211, 1, 9, 452845) The sufferers have no personal interest to serve.
('10', 211, 1, 10, 452895) The Indians contend that General Smuts, the Colonial Secretary of the Transvaal, is under promise to repeal the Asiatic Registration Act of 1907. If that Act had been repealed, the question of educated Indians would have been automatically adjusted, because, without it, the Immi gration Law above referred to would not have prevented the entry of highly educated Indians.
('10', 211, 1, 11, 453268) General Smuts contends that, whilst he discussed the question of repeal of the Act with Mr. Gandhi, he does not remember having made a definite promise.
('10', 211, 1, 12, 453421) Mr. Gandhi has made an affidavit swear ing that such a promise was made and has produced documentary evidence in support of his contention.
('10', 211, 1, 13, 453561) General Smuts holds that the Indian deman ds are in effect satisfied in that he wishes to treat the Registration Act as a dead letter and is prepared to admit educated Indians on sufferance and on temporary permits, which may be extended from time to time.
('10', 211, 1, 14, 453818) Indians hold that they are under a solemn obligation to secure repeal of the Act above mentioned, and that, if it is a dead letter, it can be of no use to the Government.
('10', 211, 1, 15, 453989) They further contend that the admission of educated Indians on sufferance is useless because the struggle is not so much to secure the admission of a few individuals as to conserve national honour.
('10', 211, 1, 16, 454187) It is the unnecessary legal racial disability which makes the situation so degrading, and affords an obiding source of irritation to the whole Indian nation.
('10', 211, 1, 17, 454345) This legislation is the first of its kind in the history of the Colonies.
('10', 211, 1, 18, 454419) No other self governing Colony possesses legislation containing the racial taint, described by Lord Morley as the “bar sinister”.
('10', 211, 1, 19, 454549) British Indians do not desire an indiscriminate influx of their countrymen into the Transvaal.
('10', 211, 1, 20, 454644) They submit that, by a judicious administration of the Immigration Act, all but a few—say six highly
('10', 212, 0, 1, 454745) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 213
('10', 212, 1, 2, 454788) educated Indians per year—may be prevented from entering the Colony.
('10', 212, 1, 3, 454857) The Cape, Australia and other Colonies have solved the question of Asiatic immigration without resort to racial legislation.
('10', 212, 2, 4, 454982) From a photostat of the printed copy : S. N. 5180
('10', 212, 3, 5, 455032) 140. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES
('10', 212, 4, 6, 455076) [LONDON,] November 6, 1909
('10', 212, 5, 7, 455103) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, numbered 34519/1909. 1 It is a matter for very deep regret that the Earl of Crewe is unable to hold out any hopes of obtaining recognition of theoretical equality as to immigration such as is claimed by British Indians in the Transvaal, and as has hitherto been accepted throughout the Colonies, and which alone, it is respectfully submitted, can justify the holding together of different peoples of the world under the same sovereignty.
('10', 212, 5, 8, 455626) There remains nothing for my colleague and me to do but to place the position before the public and to return to the Transvaal.
('10', 212, 5, 9, 455754) In view, however, of the Imperial importance of the question, my colleague and I respectfully trust that His Lordship will still use his influence in order to secure the removal of the offensive colour bar in the immigration laws of the Transvaal.
('10', 212, 6, 10, 456002) I have, etc.,
('10', 212, 7, 11, 456016) M. K. GANDHI

('10', 213, 1, 2, 456462) 141. LETTER TO TRANSVAAL BRITISH INDIANS 1
('10', 213, 2, 3, 456505) [LONDON, November 6, 1909]
('10', 213, 3, 4, 456532) We of the United Kingdom have learnt, through those who are working here on your behalf, about your sorrows and trials under the British flag.
('10', 213, 3, 5, 456675) That you are fighting for the honour of your race and your motherland commands our admiration.
('10', 213, 3, 6, 456770) In our opinion, the Transvaal Government has no right to debar British subjects who may be of a different race or a different colour to themselves from entering that Colony because of colour or race.
('10', 213, 3, 7, 456970) We hold it to be contrary to the traditions of the Empire to which you and we belong.
('10', 213, 3, 8, 457056) We appreciate the moderation of your position in that, whilst you naturally insist upon your national honour being preserved untarnished, you do not oppose the desire of the Colonists in the Transvaal to regulate and restrict immigration from India under general and non racial legislation, and on economic grounds which to the Colonists appear to be just.
('10', 213, 4, 9, 457413) The Method you have adopted for seeking redress appeals to us who believe in religion as the guiding force of life.
('10', 213, 4, 10, 457529) In making your position good, and in convincing the authorities of the justice of your cause and of the earnestness of your demand, you have not resorted to methods of violence and physical force, but you have heroically suffered in your own persons by refusing to accept a law which you rightly consider to be repugnant to your conscience and by submitting to the penalties provided by it for non submission.
('10', 213, 4, 11, 457939) 2,500 of you have already been imprisoned—mostly with hard labour, and for long terms up to six months.
('10', 213, 4, 12, 458043) Some of you have become impoverished.
('10', 213, 4, 13, 458081) Wives have patiently borne separation from their husbands, and have also been reduced almost to starvation.
('10', 213, 4, 14, 458189) Your merchants have allowed their goods to be sold, and have allowed their creditors to take away their stock.
('10', 213, 4, 15, 458300) In undergoing such suffering you are showing the true spirit of the great teachers of the different
('10', 214, 0, 1, 458400) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 215
('10', 214, 1, 2, 458443) religions of the world.
('10', 214, 1, 3, 458467) We sympathise with you.
('10', 214, 1, 4, 458491) We mean that our whole life shall testify how earnestly we desire for you strength and courage to continue your struggle, and, as a tangible expression of our sympathy for you, we subscribe our names herein below, and pay whatever we feel impelled to give towards the relief of your distress.
('10', 214, 1, 5, 458784) We hope that the authorities, as well in the Transvaal as in London, will open their eyes and give immediate relief.

('10', 214, 3, 7, 458928) 142. DEPUTATION’S LAST LETTER 1
('10', 214, 4, 8, 458960) [After November 6, 1909 ]
('10', 214, 5, 9, 458986) LORD CREWE’S REPLY
('10', 214, 6, 10, 459005) Everything now is as clear as daylight.
('10', 214, 6, 11, 459045) Lord Crewe has given a plain reply.
('10', 214, 6, 12, 459081) Says he.
('10', 214, 7, 13, 459090) I am to inform you that the proposals in question were those put before you by His Lordship on the 16th of September as having been made by Mr. Smuts, viz., the repal of Act 2 of 1907 and the admission of six educated Asiatics each year on certificates of permanent right of residence, which would involve, in your own view, a real step in advance and would, so far as their practical effect is concerned, provide a solution of the present difficulty.
('10', 214, 7, 14, 459542) They were not, nor were they connected with, those made by yourself, and involving a theoretical claim for which His Lordship is not able to hold out any hope of obtaining recognition.
('10', 214, 7, 15, 459727) Indeed, at the interview on the 16th of September, His Lordship explained to you that Mr. Smuts was unable to accept the claim that Asiatics should be placed in a position of equality with Europeans in respect of right of entry or otherwise.

('10', 215, 0, 1, 460465) 216 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 215, 1, 2, 460507) COMMENTS
('10', 215, 2, 3, 460516) It is now necessary for every Indian to understand what the struggle is about and how important are the issues involved.
('10', 215, 2, 4, 460637) We are carrying a burden on behalf of the whole of India.
('10', 215, 2, 5, 460695) It is but our duty to do so.
('10', 215, 2, 6, 460724) Mr. Smuts is prepared to offer us whatever we want if only we concede that we are not the equals of whites.
('10', 215, 2, 7, 460832) He clings to the position that we shall not have equality under the law.
('10', 215, 2, 8, 460905) He has struck at the root of British principles and the principles of humanity.
('10', 215, 2, 9, 460985) We have taken the blow on ourselves in order to defend those principles.
('10', 215, 2, 10, 461058) Were the blow to strike at the root, the British Empire will cease to have any meaning, and it will be slavery for Indians to stay on in the Transvaal or South Africa.
('10', 215, 2, 11, 461226) No one can enslave us against our will.
('10', 215, 2, 12, 461266) If we do not recognize the principles of the man [who may attempt to enslave us] and refuse to carry out his orders, we cease to be slaves.
('10', 215, 2, 13, 461406) In former times, they used force to impose slavery; now they use blandishments.
('10', 215, 2, 14, 461486) In olden days, one might say, things were better, since all the evil was there on the surface for everyone to see, with the result that people were repelled by it.
('10', 215, 2, 15, 461650) When the slaves could no longer bear their sufferings, they ran away or killed themselves.
('10', 215, 2, 16, 461741) Now that they seek to confer slavery upon us through baits, we readily accept it, not even knowing that it is slavery.
('10', 215, 2, 17, 461860) We are fighting the battle of satyagraha in South Africa in order to save ourselves from such a plight.
('10', 215, 2, 18, 461964) The Government know, and we ought to—if we do not know already—that, if we once compel it to give up its effort [to enslave us], the rest will be easy enough for us.
('10', 215, 2, 19, 462130) We are carrying on a fight for the franchise that really matters.
('10', 215, 2, 20, 462196) We are demonstrating that we have the potentialities of nationhood in us, the spirit that people aspiring to be a nation must possess.
('10', 215, 2, 21, 462331) Moreover, we are not fighting against the Transvaal [Government] only, but also against the Imperial Government, for the latter has assented to the law 1 in question.
('10', 215, 2, 22, 462498) “You will get all that you want if you give up the claim to legal equality;” in other words, “Sign a bond of slavery and you will be treated well.” Or, we may explain this by imagining Germany saying to the British : “Come under our rule and we shall treat you well.” In reply, the British will say : “We do not care to be treated well by you.
('10', 215, 2, 23, 462842) We are happy defending our freedom, whatever the suffering we may have to go
('10', 215, 3, 24, 462919) 1 The Asiatic Registration Act No.
('10', 215, 3, 25, 462954) 2 of 1907
('10', 216, 0, 1, 462964) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 217
('10', 216, 1, 2, 463007) through.” That is exactly the kind of reply that we have been giving for the last three years, and which, I hope, we shall for ever continue to give.
('10', 216, 1, 3, 463157) Many embraced poverty in the course of the fight for legal equality in respect of right of entry, and we are prepared to lay down our lives in it.
('10', 216, 1, 4, 463304) I take it that the brave ones who have taken up arms will never retreat.
('10', 216, 1, 5, 463377) Let every Indian tell himself over and over again that the remedy for this situation is in our own hands, not in those of the Imperial Government or of the Transvaal Government.
('10', 216, 1, 6, 463555) It is our duty to make formal representations to them and reason with them.
('10', 216, 1, 7, 463631) But it should not be forgotten that no pressure other than that of our own strength will avail us.
('10', 216, 1, 8, 463730) FEELINGS
('10', 216, 2, 9, 463739) The cable report in the newspapers about the imprisonment of my son, Harilal, coming as it did at the same time as Lord Crewe’s letter, certainly made me very happy.
('10', 216, 2, 10, 463905) When so many Indians were re arrested, I was not in the least happy that my son and I should be free.
('10', 216, 2, 11, 464007) And just then appeared the cable report.
('10', 216, 2, 12, 464048) Miss Polak, who understands my feelings on this matter, congratulated me as she gave me the news.
('10', 216, 2, 13, 464146) Though I know that the boy, poor child, will suffer, I welcome the news all the same.
('10', 216, 2, 14, 464232) It will do him good to suffer, and me too; he will be doing a service to the community.
('10', 216, 2, 15, 464320) It is the command of God [that one should suffer].
('10', 216, 2, 16, 464371) Nagappen, you too were a mere child, and sacrificed your life for the sake of the motherland.
('10', 216, 2, 17, 464465) I regard your sacrifice as a blessing on your family.
('10', 216, 2, 18, 464519) I believe that, though dead, you are immortal.
('10', 216, 2, 19, 464566) Why, then, should I be upset by my son’s imprisonment?
('10', 216, 2, 20, 464621) His associates have returned to gaol.
('10', 216, 2, 21, 464659) None of them stands to gain anything by doing so, and yet they have submitted to the hardships of gaol.
('10', 216, 2, 22, 464763) I refuse to believe that this suffering will not be rewarded with happiness and that the law will not be repealed on our terms.
('10', 216, 2, 23, 464891) I hope that no Indian will be timid enough to entertain such a belief.
('10', 216, 2, 24, 464962) TO SOUTH AFRICAN INDIANS
('10', 216, 3, 25, 464987) I say to all the Indians in South Africa that this struggle is not confined to the Transvaal, that it is on behalf of them all and that they should extend every encouragement to those who are fighting.
('10', 216, 3, 26, 465189) To Mr. Abdul Caadir and Mr. Amod Bhayat, who have seen for themselves how matters stand here, I say that their duty requires them to instil the highest spirit in the people.
('10', 216, 3, 27, 465363) Everyone can, and will, I

('10', 217, 3, 10, 466039) MEETING OF LONDON INDIANS

('10', 217, 4, 12, 466122) Between 40 and 50 Indians were present.

('10', 217, 4, 21, 466675) It is likely to take root and, if all the volunteers put their heart into the work, they may achieve a big result.

('10', 218, 2, 4, 467747) There is also an idea that we may start a small journal here in England itself for the duration of the struggle.
('10', 218, 2, 5, 467860) It should give a digest of all the news received from South Africa and India and should be put on sale at a number of places.
('10', 218, 2, 6, 467986) The intention is to start the journal only if some whites here offer to finance it.

('10', 219, 2, 3, 469672) [Before November 8, 1909 ] SUFFRAGETTES
('10', 219, 3, 4, 469712) The campaign that women have been carrying on for the franchise can prove most useful to us, or so I think at least.
('10', 219, 3, 5, 469829) It has importance both for South Africa and India.
('10', 219, 3, 6, 469880) They do much that deserves to be copied, and much that should be avoided.
('10', 219, 3, 7, 469954) Like us, they believe that they are being denied their rights, and that they are treated as inferior [to men].
('10', 219, 3, 8, 470065) Their struggle has been going on for quite some time.
('10', 219, 3, 9, 470119) They, too, have two parties, one moderate and the other extremist.
('10', 219, 3, 10, 470186) The difference between them and us is that they are not satyagrahis, but believe in brute force.
('10', 219, 3, 11, 470283) Their courage, their unity, their readiness to bear pecuniary losses, their intelligence—all these deserve to be admired and emulated.
('10', 219, 3, 12, 470418) They throw stones and injure others, forgetting all sense of propriety, and these ways of theirs deserve to be shunned.
('10', 219, 3, 13, 470538) Three such incidents occurred only recently.
('10', 219, 3, 14, 470583) A suffragette in Manchester Gaol was being forcibly fed.
('10', 219, 3, 15, 470640) She, therefore, resorted to a stratagem which made it impossible to open the door [of her cell].
('10', 219, 3, 16, 470737) Thereupon, the authorities sprayed her with a water hose.
('10', 219, 3, 17, 470795) Still, she did not open the door.
('10', 219, 3, 18, 470829) This lady had real courage, indeed, but used it to a wrong end.
('10', 219, 3, 19, 470893) Those who come forward to suffer are not justified in behaving as she did.
('10', 219, 3, 20, 470968) Her object was to secure her release from gaol, and she achieved it.
('10', 219, 3, 21, 471037) But the women won no rights [thereby].
('10', 219, 3, 22, 471076) When it came to be known that she was sprayed with a water hose, she was ordered to be released.
('10', 219, 3, 23, 471173) In a certain locality here, election of a member to the House of Commons was going on.
('10', 219, 3, 24, 471260) Two women went there with the intention of spoiling election papers.
('10', 219, 3, 25, 471329) 1 They had with them some liquid with which they could burn paper.
('10', 219, 3, 26, 471396) Having managed somehow to enter the election booth, they squirted the liquid all round.
('10', 219, 3, 27, 471484) Not many papers were spoiled, but one of the women caused a serious injury to an officer’s eye.
('10', 219, 3, 28, 471580) This was a very base thing to do.
('10', 219, 3, 29, 471614) It is being condemned by everyone.
('10', 219, 3, 30, 471649) And yet, her Association has accepted
('10', 219, 4, 31, 471687) 1 Reports of these two incidents appeared in the Gujarati columns of Indian Opinion, 6 11 1909.
('10', 220, 0, 1, 471783) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 221
('10', 220, 1, 2, 471826) responsibility for what she did.
('10', 220, 1, 3, 471859) The women are now being prosecuted.
('10', 220, 1, 4, 471895) At a third place, the broke the door panes of the physician who used to carry out forcible feeding.
('10', 220, 1, 5, 471995) This was done merely with the object of damaging the physician’s property.

('10', 220, 1, 9, 472273) Courage should be put to a worthy use.
('10', 220, 1, 10, 472312) I came to know only recently that the suffragettes publish four journals— three weeklies and one monthly.

('10', 220, 1, 12, 472663) There are meetings of the Association branches at one place or another all through the week.

('10', 220, 1, 14, 472848) This is surely no ordinary spirit.
('10', 220, 2, 15, 472883) The storm over the budget raged for six months in the House of Commons.
('10', 220, 2, 16, 472955) It has now passed the Budget Bill, which will go to the House of Lords on Monday.
('10', 220, 2, 17, 473037) The Bill is expected to meet with fierce opposition there.

('10', 220, 2, 19, 473165) In that case, there will be new elections in January.
('10', 220, 2, 20, 473219) Many people hold that even if that happens, the Liberal Party will win.
('10', 220, 2, 21, 473291) For the present, the British people are intensely preoccupied with this question.
('10', 220, 2, 22, 473373) They can think of nothing else, for it is a fierce strife that is going on between the commoners and the nobility.
('10', 220, 2, 23, 473488) Each side reviles the other and doubts its bona fides.
('10', 220, 2, 24, 473543) The only thing they have desisted from, so far, is actual physical fighting and that, too, not because they think it bad but because neither side expects to profit by it.
('10', 220, 2, 25, 473714) They are not likely [however] to invite help from a third party to settle their quarrel.
('10', 220, 2, 26, 473803) That much is certain.

('10', 223, 1, 2, 477452) friend—an Englishman, who is at present in South Africa, in connection with my life, in so far as it has a bearing on the struggle with which I am so connected, and to which my life is dedicated.
('10', 223, 1, 3, 477648) As I am very anxious to engage your active interest and sympathy, I thought that it would not be considered by you as out of the way for me to send you the book.
('10', 223, 1, 4, 477810) In my opinion, this struggle of the Indians in the Transvaal is the greatest of modern times, inasmuch as it has been idealised both as to the goal as also the methods adopted to reach the goal.
('10', 223, 1, 5, 478005) I am not aware of a struggle in which the participators are not to derive any personal advantage at the end of it, and in which 50 per cent.
('10', 223, 1, 6, 478146) of the persons affected have undergone great suffering and trial for the sake of a principle.
('10', 223, 1, 7, 478240) It has not been possible for me to advertise the struggle as much as I should like.
('10', 223, 1, 8, 478324) You command, possibly, the widest public today.
('10', 223, 1, 9, 478372) If you are satisfied as to the facts you will find set forth in Mr. Doke’s book, and if you consider that the conclusions I have arrived at are justified by the facts, may I ask you to use your influence in any manner you think fit to popularise the movement?
('10', 223, 1, 10, 478632) If it succeeds, it well be not only a triumph of religion, love and truth over irreligion, hatred and falsehood, but it is highly likely to serve as an example to the millions in India and to people in other parts of the world, who may be down trodden and will certainly go a great way towards breaking up the party of violence, at least in India.
('10', 223, 1, 11, 478980) If we hold out to the end, as I think we would, I entertain not the slightest doubt as to its ultimate success; and your encouragement in the way suggested by you can only strengthen us in our resolve.
('10', 223, 1, 12, 479182) The negotiations that are going on for a settlement of the question have practically fallen through, and together with my colleague I return to South Africa this week, and invite imprisonment.
('10', 223, 1, 13, 479375) I may add that my son has happily joined me in the struggle and is now undergoing imprisonment with hard labour for six months.
('10', 223, 1, 14, 479503) This is his fourth imprisonment in the course of the struggle.
('10', 223, 1, 15, 479566) If you would be so good as to reply to this letter, may I ask you to address your reply to me at Johannesburg, S.A., Box 6522. Hoping that this will find you in good health.
('10', 223, 2, 16, 479740) I remain, etc.,
('10', 223, 3, 17, 479756) M. K. GANDHI

('10', 225, 1, 2, 481425) 150. INTERVIEW TO “THE DAILY EXPRESS” 1
('10', 225, 2, 3, 481465) [LONDON, November 10, 1909 ] General Smuts took a step forward when he said he would repeal the obnoxious Asiatic Act and, so far as the status of educated Indians arising from the Act is concerned said he was prepared to grant certificates of permanent residence to a limited number of Indians.
('10', 225, 2, 4, 481761) This is satisfactory as far as it goes, but it leaves untouched the principle for which and for which alone we have been fighting.
('10', 225, 2, 5, 481892) That principle is for legal equality so far as immigration is concerned.
('10', 225, 2, 6, 481965) General Smuts’ offer is not enough to stop passive resistance on our part.
('10', 225, 2, 7, 482040) Mr. Hajee Habib and myself are returning at once to Johann esburg.
('10', 225, 2, 8, 482107) The next step probably is that both of us will be arrested at the Transvaal frontier, but the campaign will continue with unabated vigour.
('10', 225, 2, 9, 482246) Hitherto we have refrained from asking for funds in India or elsewhere outside South Africa, but the severe strain upon our resources and the number of ruined families whom we have to support now make this essential.
('10', 225, 2, 10, 482463) We have organised a band of Indian and English volunteers who, immediately on our departure from this country, will commence house to house visits both in London and in the provinces, asking for signatures for a memorandum to the authorities of the Transvaal and in London.
('10', 225, 2, 11, 482737) India, 12 11 1909
('10', 225, 3, 12, 482755) 151. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE LONDON, November 11, 1909
('10', 225, 4, 13, 482810) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE,
('10', 225, 5, 14, 482834) Although I have your kind message through Mr. Polak that I should not address you as Professor 2 , my reverence for you will not enable me to adopt a more familiar style.
('10', 225, 6, 15, 483005) 1 This report of the interview was reproduced in India from The Daily Express, 10 11 1909. 2 In his letter of September 10, Polak had informed Gandhiji that Gokhale thought it “too formal and he and you know each other too well for these formalities.”
('10', 226, 0, 1, 483257) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 227
('10', 226, 1, 2, 483300) In his last letter, Mr. Polak tells me that overwork and anxiety have ruined your health and that your plain spokenness has endangered your life 1 .
('10', 226, 1, 3, 483449) I venture to suggest that you should come to the Transvaal and join us.
('10', 226, 1, 4, 483521) I claim that the Transvaal struggle is national in every sense of the term.
('10', 226, 1, 5, 483597) It deserves the highest encourag ement.
('10', 226, 1, 6, 483637) I have considered it to be the greatest struggle of modern time.
('10', 226, 1, 7, 483702) That it will succeed in the end I have not the slightest doubt.
('10', 226, 1, 8, 483766) But an early success will break up the violence movement in India.
('10', 226, 1, 9, 483833) I have moved very freely among our countrymen here and I notice extreme bitterness against you.
('10', 226, 1, 10, 483929) Most consider that violence is the only method for securing any reform.
('10', 226, 1, 11, 484001) In the Transvaal, we are trying to show that violence is futile and that the proper method is self suffering.
('10', 226, 1, 12, 484111) i.e., passive resistance.
('10', 226, 1, 13, 484137) If, therefore, you came to the Transvaal, publicly declaring that it was your intention to share our sorrows and, therefore, to cross the Transvaal border as a citizen of the Empire, you would give it a world wide significance, the struggle will soon end and your countrymen will know you better.
('10', 226, 1, 14, 484434) The last consi deration may not weigh with you.
('10', 226, 1, 15, 484482) But it does with me for the sake of themselves.
('10', 226, 1, 16, 484530) If you would come, and If you are left untouched and I am free, I should deem it a great privilege to nurse you.
('10', 226, 1, 17, 484643) If you are arrested and imprisoned, I should be delighted.
('10', 226, 1, 18, 484702) I may be wrong, but I do feel that it is a step worth taking for the sake of India.
('10', 226, 1, 19, 484786) Feeling so strongly, I would be pardoned for suggesting that the Transvaal quest ion should have a prominent place on the Congress platform and nothing can be so effective as for you to say that you would join the struggle.
('10', 226, 1, 20, 485010) I have written this letter in the midst of interruptions.
('10', 226, 1, 21, 485068) I have not therefore been able to explain all I should like to.
('10', 226, 1, 22, 485132) I would only [add] that my reverence for you has prompted this suggestion.
('10', 226, 1, 23, 485207) I would see you reach perfection among your countrymen in S. A., where you would not be misunderstood and where you would be mentioned as nowhere else.
('10', 226, 1, 24, 485359) Will you kindly send your reply to me at Johannesburg, Box 6522?

('10', 227, 1, 2, 485859) 152. LETTER TO H. S. L. POLAK
('10', 227, 2, 3, 485889) [LONDON,] November 11, 1909
('10', 227, 3, 4, 485917) MY DEAR HENRY, I should like to write a very long letter to you, but I do not know how to.
('10', 227, 3, 5, 486008) I am full of information of the greatest importance but I cannot give it to you in a presentable form during the time at my disposal.
('10', 227, 3, 6, 486142) The first thing, however, I want to deal with is Maud’s condition.
('10', 227, 3, 7, 486209) I had only once joked with her, asking whether she wanted to go to South Africa, and the joke proceeded from a remark made by Hajee Habib, but it is evident that she has been very seriously thinking about it.
('10', 227, 3, 8, 486418) Last evening she could not restrain herself, and told me she wanted to go to South Africa very badly and work for the cause.
('10', 227, 3, 9, 486543) I was not surprised, and yet this is not quite accurate, because I was taken aback a little, as I have felt she was permanently fixed up at the place where she is, not that I am at all in love with it, but it appeared to me to be the best in the circumstances.
('10', 227, 3, 10, 486804) She is very sweet natured.
('10', 227, 3, 11, 486831) I think she is capable of great self sacrifice, and she is willing to work, but I do not know how far the Phoenix life would suit her.
('10', 227, 3, 12, 486966) Personally, I feel that, if she wants to go to South Africa merely to earn her living, it is hardly worthwhile; but if she wants to work for an ideal, she must have the strength and courage to do it.
('10', 227, 3, 13, 487166) I have told her all I could about things.
('10', 227, 3, 14, 487208) I have told her as well as I could about the jarring notes there, and I have told her, too, that there is no money in it.
('10', 227, 3, 15, 487330) I have further told her how Millie herself finds it difficult to reconcile herself to life at Phoenix.
('10', 227, 3, 16, 487433) She is in possession of all the information that I can give her.
('10', 227, 3, 17, 487498) I have further told her that I am not in a position to give a definite opinion, that first of all she must secure Pater’s and Mater’s consent, and then Sally’s.
('10', 227, 3, 18, 487659) After she has the approval of the three, she sould place her position before you, and finally depend upon Millie’s advice.
('10', 227, 3, 19, 487782) I have told her, too, that however much she may regard my view, and like it, I consider myself incompetent to enter into all a woman’s feelings, and when she has accessible to her Millie’s loving assistance and advice, she cannot do better than rely upon her judgment.
('10', 227, 3, 20, 488051) She tells me that she wants to be able to send home £4 per month.
('10', 227, 3, 21, 488117) I have told her that this is not impossible, but that the chief thing to consider is whether she will be able to appreciate and
('10', 228, 0, 1, 488245) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 229
('10', 228, 1, 2, 488288) love the Phoenix life.
('10', 228, 1, 3, 488311) I have told her, too, that there is no definite work that can be assigned to her—that it may be anything, from what is considered the meanest household duties, to teaching, and moulding the characters of the children at Phoenix.
('10', 228, 1, 4, 488540) Now, I think, I have told you everything.
('10', 228, 1, 5, 488582) She will be writing you fully.
('10', 228, 1, 6, 488613) You know her much better than I do, and you will be able to guide her in the path you think best for her moral well being.
('10', 228, 1, 7, 488736) The other household matters that I would like to discuss with you must wait, unless I get the time between now and reaching Madeira, but my programme for the voyage is so full that domestic matters which are not urgent are likely to be crowded out.
('10', 228, 1, 8, 488985) Maud is writing to you very fully, and she has promised to show me her letter, and if I have any further suggestions, after I have read the letter, I will write again.
('10', 228, 1, 9, 489153) Millie is coming here from Westcliffe on Friday, and I shall fully discuss it with her, as also with Pater and Mater, if I get an opportunity of seeing them.
('10', 228, 1, 10, 489311) Millie will sleep at the Hotel, so I am looking forward to a long and quiet chat with her.
('10', 228, 1, 11, 489402) Naturally we are much nearer each other now than we were ever before, having seen more of each other than in Johannesburg, where I rarely met her apart.
('10', 228, 1, 12, 489555) Waldo and Brownie are looking superb.
('10', 228, 1, 13, 489593) I still retain the opinion that it is difficult, if not impossible, to match Waldo in beauty, and he is daily becoming more and more wilful !
('10', 228, 1, 14, 489735) He is certainly very original, and you will appreciate the fact when I tell you that Simmonds completes his happiness.
('10', 228, 1, 15, 489854) Sally, who is sitting by me, just reminds me that I should not finish this letter without telling you something about Brownie; that he is outgrowing his superficial ugliness, and that he has begun to speak is stale news, but probably you do not know that the first name he learnt to pronounce was Sally’s.
('10', 228, 1, 16, 490160) Sally may be a good worker in her office; she claims to be an estimable suffragette, not to be beaten by mere man; I can certainly certify to her being at her best when she is with Waldo and Brownie.
('10', 228, 1, 17, 490360) When one meets a woman who is at her best with children, you know what an opinion I have of her.
('10', 228, 1, 18, 490457) Since dictating this letter, I have seen Sally.
('10', 228, 1, 19, 490505) Just fancy Sally saying she is also anxious to go to Phoenix and that she would simply love the life.
('10', 228, 1, 20, 490607) I wonder if the taint (?) of simplicity runs through the family and if it only requires a little nursing to bring it all out.
('10', 228, 1, 21, 490733) She says that is was she who suggested to Maud that Maud should go out, but she also adds that they do not want to desert the parents, and so she recognises that one or the other should stay.
('10', 228, 1, 22, 490925) I do not know how to take all this.
('10', 228, 1, 23, 490961) I am afraid that I am very largely, responsible for
('10', 229, 0, 1, 491013) 230 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 229, 1, 2, 491055) their enthusiasm.
('10', 229, 1, 3, 491073) I have spoken in such glowing terms about the charm of simplicity and all that, that they have pictured Phoenix as a Paradise.
('10', 229, 1, 4, 491200) Simmonds cautions me against any hasty advice or hasty step.
('10', 229, 1, 5, 491261) His caution I appreciate very greatly, and I therefore pass it on to you.
('10', 229, 1, 6, 491335) I have no intention of advising the girls to take the plunge.
('10', 229, 1, 7, 491397) As I mentioned in another letter, I should like to write at very great length, and yet this is being dictated after one o’clock a.m.
('10', 229, 1, 8, 491530) and there is a vast amount of humdrum work to go through before Saturday.

('10', 229, 3, 10, 491665) 153. LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES
('10', 229, 4, 11, 491709) [LONDON,] November 11, 1909
('10', 229, 5, 12, 491737) SIR, I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 9th instant, enclosing a copy of a despatch from the Governor of the Transvaal, together with a minute from the Transvaal Ministers regarding the treatment of British Indian prisoners.
('10', 229, 5, 13, 491994) I note in the minute from the Prime Minister’s Office, Pretoria, to the Deputy Governor, that there is a categorical denial of every complaint made.
('10', 229, 5, 14, 492143) I venture, however, to submit for His Lordship’s consideration the fact that, from my own personal observations made at the different prisons of the Transvaal, the complaints received by me and passed on to the Colonial Office appear to me, in the main, to be substantial.
('10', 229, 5, 15, 492416) As to the death of the late Nagappen, the magistrate’s finding has been challenged by the Indian community, 1 as also by the European Committee presided over by Mr. Hosken, and that a
('10', 229, 6, 16, 492600) 1 E. I. Aswat, Acting Chairman of the British Indian Association, in a letter to the Rand Daily Mail, had expressed surprise at the judgment of the Commission and felt that “sufficient weight has not been attached to some portions of the evidence”.
('10', 229, 6, 17, 492849) The Secretary of State for the Colonies received on September 30 a communication from the British Indian Committee at Pretoria, saying that Government had been requested to reopen the enquiry.
('10', 229, 6, 18, 493042) An official of the Colonial Office recorded in a minute dated October 1: “I am afraid this is a bad business.
('10', 229, 6, 19, 493152) The Government enquiry into Nagappen’s death is a complete white washing and is accordingly heartily endorsed by the Ministers .
('10', 229, 6, 20, 493281) but the evidence, it is pretty clear, hardly supports the conclusions .
('10', 230, 0, 1, 493353) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 231
('10', 230, 1, 2, 493396) reopening of the enquiry was asked for and refused.
('10', 230, 1, 3, 493448) 1 Moreover, I invite His Lordship’s attention to the fact that the allegation that the deceased was not supplied with rice was sustained.
('10', 230, 1, 4, 493586) That the magistrate left it an open question as to whether he had two blankets or not, that the deceased was taken from Johannesburg to a camp in a rigorous winter, and was called upon to do rough work, are undisputed facts.
('10', 230, 1, 5, 493811) As to the diet scale, His Lordship is already in possession of the exhaustive report of the independent medical men of Johannesburg bearing out the Indian allegation that this scale is deficient.
('10', 230, 1, 6, 494007) With regard to the prisoner Mahomed Khan, I have already stated in my letter 2 of the 16th August that there might be some exaggeration, but I venture to trust that I shall be pardoned for saying that the denials of the officials concerned of the truth of the complaints are hardly sufficient answer.
('10', 230, 1, 7, 494308) It was open, as it is now, to the Government, if they wish, to invite Mr. Mahomed Khan to corroborate or withdraw his complaints.
('10', 230, 1, 8, 494438) The later developments, in the shape of a refusal to allow Indian prisoners to receive religious consolation, and to permit Mahomedans during the sacred months of Ramzan to receive facilities for observing their fast, hardly bear out the statement that Indian prisoners are treated humanely, and that there is no desire on the part of the prison officials to treat them harshly because they are passive resisters.
('10', 230, 1, 9, 494852) It is likely that Indian prisoners are now invariably housed in cells by themselves, but it is within my own knowledge that, up to the month of May, Indian prisoners have been housed in the self same cells as the Natives.
('10', 230, 2, 10, 495074) I have, etc.,

('10', 231, 1, 2, 495490) 154. LETTER TO “DAILY TELEGRAPH”
('10', 231, 2, 3, 495523) [LONDON,] November 11, 1909 THE EDITOR DAILY TELEGRAPH
('10', 231, 3, 4, 495578) DEAR SIR, I am sorry that you could not spare a few minutes to grant me an interview.
('10', 231, 3, 5, 495664) I received the message that I was to write to you.
('10', 231, 3, 6, 495715) The position to date in connection with the Transvaal British Indian question is given in the statement issued to the Press, 1 a copy of which I trust you have seen.
('10', 231, 3, 7, 495881) The reason why I wished to have a personal interview with you was to place before you the gravity of the Transvaal Indian question.
('10', 231, 3, 8, 496013) As you will notice from the supplementary statement, the question is not now that of saving the Transvaal from an Asiatic influx; it purely and simply resolves itself into the question whether, so far as immigration is concerned, highly cultured Indians may be placed on an equality with the European immigrants, as they were before the legislation against which passive resistance has been offered and as they are now throughout the British Colonies.
('10', 231, 3, 9, 496465) Thus, for the first time in the history of Colonial legislation, in the words of Mr. Chamberlain, “an affront” has been put upon the millions in India.
('10', 231, 3, 10, 496617) In our struggle, therefore, I venture to think that we have a right to expect the Press of the United Kingdom to support us, and I hope that you will see your way to give due publicity to the movement, and favour it with your advocacy, regard being had to the fact that nearly fifty per cent, of the present Indian population of the Transvaal have passed through its goals, and that one young Indian 2
('10', 231, 4, 11, 497019) has succumbed to pneumonia, caught by him, according to the testimony of witnesses, whilst he was in goal.
('10', 231, 5, 12, 497126) I remain, etc.,

('10', 232, 7, 13, 498444) 156. LETTER TO THE INDIAN PRESS1
('10', 232, 8, 14, 498477) [LONDON, November 12, 1909 ]
('10', 232, 9, 15, 498506) SIR, I venture to trust that you will give as wide publicity as possible to the statement 2 that my colleague, Mr. Hajee Habib, and I have issued in connection with the British Indian struggle in the Transvaal.
('10', 232, 9, 16, 498717) Although it is raging in the Transvaal, the fact that it is a matter of vital importance to the whole of India is so clear that he who runs may
('10', 232, 10, 17, 498861) 1 Vide “Trial of Naidoo and Others”, 16 6 1909 and also “Johannesburg Letter”, Before 21 6 1909. 2 This was published under the title: “The Indian Struggle in the Transvaal”.
('10', 232, 10, 18, 499036) Vide also “Letter to the Press”, 5 11 1909.
('10', 233, 0, 1, 499080) 234 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 233, 1, 2, 499122) read, and the Transvaal Government have made that issue clear by emphatically declaring that, although they would give us the incidence that would flow from the granting of the principle we are fighting for, they are not prepared to meet us on the question of the principle itself, and so the struggle must go on.
('10', 233, 1, 3, 499436) The principle we are fighting for cannot be better described than in the words of the Transvaal Government itself.
('10', 233, 1, 4, 499551) Lord Crewe says in his reply to the Transvaal British Indian deputation:
('10', 233, 2, 5, 499624) His Lordship explained to you that Mr. Smuts was unable to accept the claim that Asiatics should be placed in a position of equality with Europeans in respect of right of entry or otherwise.
('10', 233, 2, 6, 499815) The phrase “or otherwise” may, for the time being, be dismissed from consideration.
('10', 233, 2, 7, 499899) All that we have asked for is equality in the eye of the law with Europeans in respect of the right of entry.
('10', 233, 2, 8, 500009) It should be remembered that we are fighting for the restoration of this equality, which we enjoyed before the legislation in question was passed, as well during the Boer regime as after the British occupation, that is, up to the close of the, year 1906. The doctrine laid down by the Transvaal Government, and assented to by the Imperial Government cuts at the foundation of the Empire.
('10', 233, 2, 9, 500397) In the words of Lord Ampthill, 1 who has made the cause his own:
('10', 233, 3, 10, 500462) It is a matter which touches the honour of our race and affects the unity of the Empire as a whole; it, therefore, concerns every part of the Empire.
('10', 233, 3, 11, 500612) Moreover, it is certain that any departure from principle, which may be sanctioned or ignored at the heart of the Empire, will operate as a mischievous example to other places inside and out, and then only by some rude shock to the whole system will the arrest of moral decay be possible.
('10', 233, 3, 12, 500901) Further on His Lordship states:
('10', 233, 4, 13, 500933) Theory can be modified in practice to suit the exigencies of time and place, but if theory is cast to the winds, there is no means of steering practice.
('10', 233, 4, 14, 501086) I cannot place our position in clearer terms.
('10', 233, 4, 15, 501132) If the doctrine of the Transvaal Government be true, the people of India cease to be partners in the Empire, and it is in order to resist this dangerous, immoral and pestilent doctrine that we in the Transvaal are fighting.
('10', 233, 4, 16, 501356) How is India, including Anglo India, to help in this national struggle?
('10', 233, 4, 17, 501428) It should be remembered that we have taken practical steps for seeking redress, that is, we are suffering in our own persons by

('10', 234, 3, 10, 502544) 157. SPEECH AT FAREWELL MEETING 1
('10', 234, 4, 11, 502578) [LONDON, November 12, 1909 ]
('10', 234, 5, 12, 502607) Mr. Gandhi said he was thankful to Mr. Meyer for having called the meeting and given his colleague and him an opportunity of making a statement with reference to the very difficult position of the British Indians in the Transvaal.
('10', 234, 5, 13, 502838) He thought the caution Mr. Meyer had uttered with reference to what they had been doing in the Transvaal was a very proper caution; 2 they did not come before the public of England for an endorsement of every step they had taken in the struggle, but to receive their generous support, their sympathy and their encouragement, in the arduous struggle in
('10', 234, 6, 14, 503190) 1 A meeting to bid farewell to Gandhiji and Hajee Habib on the eve of their departure for South Africa was held at Westminster Palace Hotel.

('10', 234, 7, 19, 503702) Meyer had observed : “He thought their presence there did not endorse in every particular all Mr. Gandhi’s works and acts in the long and arduous agitation he had been conducting.
('10', 234, 7, 20, 503882) If a man made no mistakes, he made nothing.
('10', 234, 7, 21, 503926) No man had not had to regret some word or act which might have been said or performed better, but, on the whole, their presence at that meeting was their endorsement of a struggle of a singularly pure character and unselfish methods, and he felt they represented a very large number of men who were watching this conflict with interest and who felt that they could not but contribute their influence to it.”
('10', 235, 0, 1, 504334) 236 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 235, 1, 2, 504376) which they were engaged.
('10', 235, 1, 3, 504401) The question upon which he would venture to occupy their attention for a few minutes was, in his humble opinion, a question of the most solemn importance, not only to the British Indians of the Transvaal, who were engaged in that struggle, but to the whole of the British Empire.
('10', 235, 1, 4, 504681) It was perfectly true that a certain offer had been made in connection with the struggle, and Mr. Meyer had placed the position quite correctly before them in stating that they declined to accept the offer that had been made because it did not touch the principle for which they were fighting.
('10', 235, 1, 5, 504975) There were in South Africa nearly 150,000 British Indians who had been settled there for close upon forty years, if not longer.
('10', 235, 1, 6, 505103) The immigration of British Indians commenced with the system of Indentured Labour in Natal.
('10', 235, 1, 7, 505195) This was followed by the advent of free British Indians who paid their own passage and these free British Indians it was who had excited the trade jealousy of their rivals in commerce; hence the present British Indian problem in South Africa.
('10', 235, 1, 8, 505438) The position they occupied in that country was a very difficult and a very delicate position.
('10', 235, 1, 9, 505532) It was also exceedingly precarious.
('10', 235, 1, 10, 505568) In Natal, at the Cape, in the Orange Free State, and in the Transvaal, there existed legislation which hurt their feelings, which hurt their self respect, and which deprived them of many avenues of earning an honest livelihood.
('10', 235, 1, 11, 505796) In the Transvaal particularly, the position had become exceedingly acute.
('10', 235, 1, 12, 505870) Before the War, they could not hold landed property.
('10', 235, 1, 13, 505923) They had, of course, no Burgher rights.
('10', 235, 1, 14, 505963) They could live only in Locations, They might not walk on the footpaths nor ride on tram cars.
('10', 235, 1, 15, 506058) With regard to the living in Locations, that difficulty had now been removed, although this was not because of the good will of the Government, but because a flaw was discovered in the laws of the country.
('10', 235, 1, 16, 506264) All the other restrictions, it would be seen, vitally affected the position of British Indians in the Transvaal, as also throughout South Africa.
('10', 235, 1, 17, 506410) Hitherto, that is up to the year 1906, they had been able to put up with these restrictions.
('10', 235, 1, 18, 506503) They had had to suffer all these disabilities.
('10', 235, 1, 19, 506550) They had memorialised the Government, they had gone to the British Agent.
('10', 235, 1, 20, 506624) His friend and co delegate, Mr. Hajee Habib, could tell them that, during his stay in Pretoria as a merchant of some standing, he had been times without number to the British Agent before the last War, for relief, but very little had been granted.
('10', 235, 1, 21, 506872) Still there had been the British Agent to fall back upon, who had given them some sympathy and had sometimes obtained a measure of redress, but they had not felt called upon to go beyond taking these steps.
('10', 235, 1, 22, 507079) When, however, in 1906, the law about which he had to address them was passed, he felt that that was the coping stone of an edifice that was erected in order to degrade them and to drive them out of South Africa.
('10', 235, 1, 23, 507292) That legislation, as he had elsewhere said, was conceived in distrust, it was born in an atmosphere of criminality, and it was nurtured in arrogant high handedness.
('10', 235, 1, 24, 507457) When that legislation was brought in, all kinds of charges were brought against his community, and had since been disproved, and it constituted an attack on their conscience and, he would say, upon their religion also in the truest and highest
('10', 236, 0, 1, 507701) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 237
('10', 236, 1, 2, 507744) sense of the word, for it took away from them their manhood.
('10', 236, 1, 3, 507805) They felt it was utterly impossible to accept legislation of that character.
('10', 236, 1, 4, 507882) They again approached the Government.
('10', 236, 1, 5, 507920) He would here add also that the object of that legislation was not only to degrade them, but was, together with the legislation that had been foreshadowed by the gentleman who had introduced that legislation, to put a barrier upon British Indian immigration into the Transvaal.
('10', 236, 1, 6, 508198) This legislation was to be undertaken for the first time in the history of Colonial legislation.
('10', 236, 1, 7, 508295) His communityrealised what all this meant.
('10', 236, 1, 8, 508338) It was an attempt of the Transvaal Government to introduce into the Statute book of the Colony the principle that British Indians might not enter the Transvaal because they were British Indians.
('10', 236, 1, 9, 508533) They felt that very keenly.
('10', 236, 1, 10, 508561) They felt that it was
('10', 236, 2, 11, 508583) degrading to the national spirit and their manhood to accept such legislation and to remain in the Colony, and be satisfied simply with having petitioned and memorialised the Government in a matter of such very serious import, and it was for that reason that, when all attempts to secure justice and the removal of this bar sinister had failed, his friend and colleague, Mr. Hajee Habib, had administered an oath in a Johannesburg theatre to all assembled at a mass meeting 1 of British Indians—a meeting of nearly two thousand—not to submit to any legislation of such sinister import, and that meeting had risen as one man and had declared solemnly that, if that legislation were sanctioned by the Imperial Government, they would not accept it but would suffer the penalties for breaking it.
('10', 236, 2, 12, 509376) Here, they would see, was no personal interest to serve.
('10', 236, 2, 13, 509433) So long as it was a personal matter, so long as it touched their pockets only, they had put up with the disabilities under which they worked, but when it constituted a reflection on their national honour, when it meant they were not to be considered equal to Europeans even with respect to immigration, and saw that the very foundations upon which the British Constitution is built were being endangered by the Transvaal Colony, they felt that it was time for them to act more vigorously and they had before them two alternatives.
('10', 236, 2, 14, 509964) One was to meet violence with violence.
('10', 236, 2, 15, 510004) They rejected that doctrine.
('10', 236, 2, 16, 510033) What was the other alternative?
('10', 236, 2, 17, 510065) It was decided by the leaders of the community that they would not adopt any violent method, but that they would not accept this legislation and, instead, would suffer in their own persons the penalties provided.
('10', 236, 2, 18, 510278) This method had been called, for want of a better phrase, Passive Resistance.
('10', 236, 2, 19, 510356) He did not know how he could define the meaning he would like to attach to this term.
('10', 236, 2, 20, 510442) He had been wondering how he could make their attitude clear to his audience, but an incident from the Bible occurred to him—a chapter in the life of Daniel, and he would say that the British Indians in the Transvaal had been doing what Daniel did when he was called upon to accept the laws of the Medes and the Persians, He regretted to have to say that the Imperial
('10', 236, 3, 21, 510810) 1 Vide “The Mass Meeting”, 11 9 1906 and “Johannesburg Letter”, 22 9 1906.

('10', 237, 1, 2, 510927) Government were party to this crime.
('10', 237, 1, 3, 510964) They need not have accepted this legislation.
('10', 237, 1, 4, 511010) They might have known that this legislation would deeply wound the susceptibilities of British Indians, and render it impossible for them to accept it while retaining their self respect, and they might have stayed the hand of the Transvaal administration.
('10', 237, 1, 5, 511266) They might have at least hesitated before they set their hand to such a document, but under the exigencies of party politics they had yielded.
('10', 237, 1, 6, 511409) He could not suggest under what other motives they had lent their countenance to such a law.
('10', 237, 1, 7, 511502) They (Indians) felt that acceptance was impossible, and so they became passive resisters.
('10', 237, 1, 8, 511592) In effect they said to the Transvaal Government : “We will fill your gaols and suffer all the penalties you will put us to, but it is impossible for us to accept this law.” He must pause and ask himself what was the meaning of the British Constitution.
('10', 237, 1, 9, 511845) Did it not confer equality upon the different members of the Empire comprised in the British Constitution?
('10', 237, 1, 10, 511952) He could understand that.
('10', 237, 1, 11, 511978) He could consent to remain a subject of an Empire based upon this principle, but, in the light of his experience, he must declare it was utterly impossible for him to give his allegiance to an Empire in which he was not to be treated, even in theory, as an equal of any other member of that Empire.
('10', 237, 1, 12, 512277) If he was to be treated as an inferior, then he would never aspire to a position of equality.
('10', 237, 1, 13, 512371) He might be content to be a member of an Empire in which he participated to the extent even of a one per cent.
('10', 237, 1, 14, 512482) share, but if he was to be merely a slave, then the Empire had absolutely no meaning for him.
('10', 237, 1, 15, 512576) The term “British subject” then became meaningless to him, and it was this effect of that legislation that he would like to impress upon the meeting, and which they had been feeling for the last three years.
('10', 237, 1, 16, 512784) This legislation of the Colony of the Transvaal was cutting at the root of the British Empire, and in resisting the doctrine implied by such legislation, they had been rendering a service not only to British India but to the British Empire.
('10', 237, 1, 17, 513025) They were undoubtedly offering passive resistance not only to the Transvaal Government but to the Imperial Government, and he hoped that meeting would tell him in no uncertain voice that they were doing rightly in doing so (“hear, hear,” and applause).
('10', 237, 1, 18, 513278) They felt they could not do less and deserve to be members of the British Empire— they would not deserve to be partners in the Empire and, unless there was partnership there could not be Empire.
('10', 237, 1, 19, 513473) He had therefore not hesitated to say that this struggle was one of the greatest of modern times, and this was so because of the great principle at stake, because of the pure ideal for which they were fighting and, lastly, because of the pure methods they had adopted in endeavouring to attain that ideal.
('10', 237, 1, 20, 513779) What was the offer that had now been made?
('10', 237, 1, 21, 513822) It was that this legislation should be repealed, but the condition it was sought to impose was that British Indians shall not in future enter the Transvaal on terms of equality in the eye of the law with Europeans.
('10', 237, 1, 22, 514037) The Transvaal Government were quite willing to stant British Indians the incidence that would flow from this change of legislation, nacrely, that a few British Indians would be able on sufferance to enter the Transvaal.
('10', 237, 1, 23, 514257) They (British Indians)
('10', 238, 0, 1, 514280) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 239
('10', 238, 1, 2, 514323) were not satisfied with that.
('10', 238, 1, 3, 514353) As an illustration, let them suppose a matter telling his slave : “You may sit at the table with me, and live with me : you may enjoy all these privileges, but on this condition, that this bond of slavery shall always exist between us.” Could they suppose the slave would be satisfied?
('10', 238, 1, 4, 514639) Could the slave be satisfied even with the highest place at that table, whilst the taint of slavery existed?
('10', 238, 1, 5, 514748) Was it not clear that acquiescence was impossible so long as that bar remained—so long as the taint of slavery was unremoved?
('10', 238, 1, 6, 514874) They could not accept as sufficient what was now offered by the Colonial Government; hence, they had come to appeal to the British public for their sympathy and support in this struggle.
('10', 238, 1, 7, 515061) He realised that it was impossible for the Imperial Government to force by arms the hands of the Transvaal Government, and they as passive resisters could not even ask them to appeal to force.
('10', 238, 1, 8, 515254) They themselves used no force.
('10', 238, 1, 9, 515285) they asked nobody to use physical violence in their behalf, but they did think that the British public should know what that struggle meant, should learn that 50 per cent of the resident community had already been in the gaols, should know also that one young man had already died of pneumonia contracted in the gaols, that fathers and sons had together gone to gaol, that mothers had taken up baskets and sold fruit in the streets in order to support themselves and their children whilst their husbands were in gaol, that many families had been pauperised and had had to be supported out of contributions.
('10', 238, 1, 10, 515892) If they, at that meeting, thought that the ideals that had led the passive resisters cheerfully to experience these sufferings appealed to them, they should send that little community of passive resisters their encouragement and sympathy and a word of cheer.
('10', 238, 1, 11, 516151) They might at least show the Imperial Government that they would be no party to this crime against Imperial conscience.
('10', 238, 1, 12, 516271) They in the Transvaal knew that they must not rely upon sympathy in England but upon their own strength, and he (Mr. Gandhi) felt that they had that strength.
('10', 238, 1, 13, 516430) He felt that, so long as a single passive resister was left alive, he would continue the struggle.
('10', 238, 1, 14, 516529) He had just received a cable from Johannesburg which told him that they were determined to continue to the end.
('10', 238, 1, 15, 516641) This was a message sent not only from the British Indian Association, but included the small band of European workers who had formed a Committee under Mr. William Hosken, a Member of the Legislative Assembly, and he would ask his hearers to imitate that European Committee and to give them all the encouragement they could, and so hasten the end of their sufferings.
