('10', 239, 3, 4, 517526) The letter 2 translated below calls for an explanation.
('10', 239, 3, 5, 517582) Count Tolstoy is a Russian nobleman.
('10', 239, 3, 6, 517619) He has had his full share of life’s pleasures, and was once a valiant soldier.
('10', 239, 3, 7, 517698) He has no equal among European writers.
('10', 239, 3, 8, 517738) After much experience and study, he has come to the conclusion that the political policies generally followed in the world are quite wrong.
('10', 239, 3, 9, 517878) The chief reason for that, according to him, is that we are vengeful, a habit unworthy of us and contrary to the tenets of all religions.
('10', 239, 3, 10, 518016) He believes that to return injury for injury does harm both to ourselves and our enemy.
('10', 239, 3, 11, 518104) According to him, we should not retaliate against anyone who may injure us, but reward him with love instead.
('10', 239, 3, 12, 518214) He is uncompromising in his loyalty to the principle of returning good for evil.
('10', 239, 3, 13, 518295) He does not mean by this that those who suffer must seek no redress.
('10', 239, 3, 14, 518364) He believes rather that we invite suffering on ourselves through our own fault.
('10', 239, 3, 15, 518444) An oppressor’s efforts will be in vain if we refuse to submit to his tyranny.
('10', 239, 3, 16, 518522) Generally, no one will kick me for the mere fun of it.
('10', 239, 3, 17, 518577) There must be some deeper reason for his doing so.
('10', 239, 3, 18, 518628) He will kick me to bend me to his will if I have been opposing him.
('10', 239, 3, 19, 518696) If, in spite of the kicks, I refuse to carry out his orders, he will stop kicking me.
('10', 239, 3, 20, 518782) It would make no difference to me whether he did so or not.
('10', 239, 3, 21, 518842) What matters to me is the fact that his order is unjust.
('10', 239, 3, 22, 518899) Slavery consists in submitting to an unjust order, not in suffering ourselves to be kicked.
('10', 239, 3, 23, 518991) Real courage and humanity consist in not returning a kick for a kick.
('10', 239, 3, 24, 519061) This is the core of Tolstoy’s teaching.

('10', 244, 3, 7, 529016) 4 I discussed things with as many of my countrymen as I could.
('10', 244, 3, 8, 529079) I met, too, as many Englishmen as it was
('10', 244, 4, 9, 529120) 1 This was originally written in Gujarati during Gandhiji’s return journey from England on the Kildonan Castle and published in Indian Opinion, the first twelve chapters on 11 12 1909 and the rest on 18 12 1909. Issued as a booklet in January 1910, it was proscribed in India by the Government of Bombay on March 24, 1910; vide “Our Publications”, (7 5 1910).
('10', 244, 4, 10, 529480) This hastened Gandhiji’s decision to publish the English translation; vide “Preface to Hind Swaraj”, (20 3 1910).
('10', 244, 4, 11, 529594) This was issued by the International Printing Press, Phoenix, with a foreword by Gandhiji dated March 20, 1910 and also the English translation of the Gujarati foreword dated November 22, 1909, reproduced here.
('10', 244, 4, 12, 529805) The text adopted here is that of the Revised New Edition published in 1939 by the Navajivan Press, Ahmedabad.
('10', 244, 4, 13, 529915) Their first edition appeared in 1938 with a preface by Mahadev Desai, who also wrote (in the Harijan, 10 9 1938) an article on the Hind Swaraj Special Number of The Aryan Path (September 1938).
('10', 244, 4, 14, 530109) This article of Desai’s and a message from Gandhiji dated July 14, 1938 were included in the 1939 edition, the proofs of which had been, as Mahadev Desai states in his introductory lines dated December 11, 1938, “revised by numerous friends”.
('10', 244, 4, 15, 530352) Gandhiji discusses Hind Swaraj in the article “The Unbridgeable Gulf”, Harijan, 14 10 1939. Ganesh & Co., Madras, brought out the first Indian edition in 1919 with Gandhiji’s foreword dated May 28, 1919. Their fourth edition came out in 1921 with Gandhiji’s article “Hind Swaraj or Indian Home Rule” in Young India, 26 1 1921. Their sixth edition was issued in 1924. In the same year appeared an American edition by H. T. Mazumdar with the title Sermon on the Sea.
('10', 244, 4, 16, 530817) The second Gujarati edition was issued in May 1914, in South Africa, with a new Preface by Gandhiji, published in Indian Opinion, 29 4 1914. The Navajivan Press published in September 1923 a facsimile edition of the Gujarati original in Gandhiji’s hand.

('10', 316, 1, 2, 705267) 162. LETTER TO MANILAL GANDHI
('10', 316, 2, 3, 705297) UNION CASTLE LINE, R. M. S. KILDONAN CASTLE, November 24, 1909
('10', 316, 3, 4, 705360) MANILAL 1, It is 9.30 p.m.
('10', 316, 3, 5, 705387) It is five days’ voyage hence to Cape Town.
('10', 316, 3, 6, 705431) As I am tired of writing with the right hand, I write this to you with the left.
('10', 316, 3, 7, 705512) As I may have to go to gaol straight on landing, I write now.
('10', 316, 3, 8, 705574) I take it that you at any rate will rejoice at my going to gaol, for you have understanding.
('10', 316, 3, 9, 705667) The secret of the struggle lies in going to gaol cheerfully, and being happy while there.
('10', 316, 3, 10, 705757) It was good you asked the question about Phoenix.
('10', 316, 3, 11, 705807) First of all, we shall have to consider how we can realize the self and how serve our country.
('10', 316, 3, 12, 705902) After we do this, we can explain what Phoenix is.
('10', 316, 3, 13, 705952) For realizing the self, the first essential thing is to cultivate a strong moral sense.
('10', 316, 3, 14, 706040) Morality means the acquisition of virtues such as fearlessness, truth, brahmacharya [celibacy] and so on.
('10', 316, 3, 15, 706146) Service is automatically rendered to the country in this process of cultivating morality.
('10', 316, 3, 16, 706236) Phoenix is of great help in this process.
('10', 316, 3, 17, 706278) I believe that it is very difficult to preserve morality in cities where people live in congestion and there are many temptations.
('10', 316, 3, 18, 706409) That is why the wise have recommended solitary places like Phoenix.
('10', 316, 3, 19, 706477) Experience is the real school.
('10', 316, 3, 20, 706508) The experience you have had in Phoenix you could not have got elsewhere.
('10', 316, 3, 21, 706581) Thoughts about realizing the self, again, could only occur to you there.
('10', 316, 3, 22, 706654) The very fact that you have asked me such a profound question when you are a mere child shows your merit.
('10', 316, 3, 23, 706760) The credit of your having been able to nurse Mr. West 2 and others also goes to Phoenix.
('10', 316, 3, 24, 706849) As most of the people in Phoenix are just beginners, you may find faults all round you.
('10', 316, 3, 25, 706937) They may be there.
('10', 316, 3, 26, 706956) Phoenix is not perfect but we wish it to become so.
('10', 316, 3, 27, 707008) The Phoenix School has nothing to do with what I have said above.
('10', 316, 3, 28, 707074) The school is a means to achieve our end.
('10', 316, 3, 29, 707116) If it breaks down, we shall know that we are not yet fit for that kind of work.
('10', 316, 3, 30, 707196) I understand
('10', 316, 4, 31, 707209) 1 Gandhiji’s second son 2 Manager, International Printing Press, Phoenix; during his illness, Manilal attended on him; vide “Letter to Manilal Gandhi”, 12 10 1909.

('10', 317, 1, 2, 707415) your eagerness to study.
('10', 317, 1, 3, 707440) My advice to you is to have patience.
('10', 317, 1, 4, 707478) Concerning you, I have been thinking in various ways.
('10', 317, 1, 5, 707532) I shall explain this to you when we meet.
('10', 317, 1, 6, 707574) Meanwhile have faith in Bapu.
('10', 317, 1, 7, 707604) Ask me if there is anything you have not understood.
('10', 317, 1, 8, 707657) It is all right that Mr. West has given you a pocket book.
('10', 317, 1, 9, 707716) You have not served him for the sake of a gift.
('10', 317, 1, 10, 707764) He has not given you the book as a reward but as a memento.
('10', 317, 1, 11, 707824) I am anxious about Deva 1. Please look after him.

('10', 317, 6, 15, 707974) 163. LAST NOTE ON DEPUTATION 2
('10', 317, 8, 16, 708005) KILDONAN CASTLE, November 25, 1909
('10', 317, 9, 17, 708040) This is my last note on the Deputation.
('10', 317, 9, 18, 708080) I should like to request every Indian to go through it carefully.
('10', 317, 9, 19, 708146) It is my hope that when this note is published in Indian Opinion, we, both the brothers 4, will have been lodged in gaol or will soon be.
('10', 317, 10, 20, 708284) POLAK’S WORK
('10', 317, 11, 21, 708297) It appears that the more General Smuts sets himself against us, the greater the support we get from India.
('10', 317, 11, 22, 708404) But four months is too short a period in which to rouse a people.
('10', 317, 11, 23, 708470) Even four years will not be enough.
('10', 317, 11, 24, 708506) What then is the secret of the success of Mr. Polak’s mission?
('10', 317, 11, 25, 708569) 5 The Transvaal satyagrahis, of course.
('10', 317, 11, 26, 708609) Mr. Polak’s effort has

('10', 317, 14, 29, 708791) 4 Gandhiji and Hajee Habib.
('10', 317, 14, 30, 708819) When the deputation was on its way to England, fellow passengers on the ship got the impression, from the friendly relations between the two, that they were brothers.

('10', 318, 1, 2, 709188) been welcomed on all sides, not because he is Mr. Polak, but because he is our spokesman telling the story of our grievances, because it is for India that we have been suffering and because India has come to realize the justice of our cause.
('10', 318, 2, 3, 709430) PROTEST IN ENGLAND
('10', 318, 3, 4, 709449) What about England?
('10', 318, 3, 5, 709469) I cannot explain how deep a root the movement initiated in England is likely to strike.
('10', 318, 3, 6, 709557) After the Deputation of 1906, the [South Africa British Indian] Committee was formed.
('10', 318, 3, 7, 709643) We have often spoken of the invaluable work done by the Committee.
('10', 318, 3, 8, 709710) Lord Ampthill 1 and Sir Muncherji 2 are unremitting in their efforts, in the faith that we shall hold out till the end.
('10', 318, 3, 9, 709830) But the movement 3 that has now started is far more important than the work of the Committee.
('10', 318, 3, 10, 709924) Its object is to take our cause right to the individual Englishman and see that every Indian in England becomes fully acquainted [with the situation].
('10', 318, 3, 11, 710075) We are not making this effort because we depend on the support of the British people.
('10', 318, 3, 12, 710161) Every human being can help our cause.
('10', 318, 3, 13, 710199) The object of our effort is to give world wide publicity to the justice of our cause and the injustice of the Transvaal [Government]’s stand.
('10', 318, 3, 14, 710341) We bring the matter to the notice of the British people because of the connection that exists between them and us.
('10', 318, 3, 15, 710456) On being acquainted with the facts, they tell us that what we have been doing is right.
('10', 318, 3, 16, 710544) They send money in aid of our cause.
('10', 318, 3, 17, 710581) This conveys the suggestion of our being their equals.
('10', 318, 3, 18, 710636) They do not write to us with an air of condescension, but as our brothers and sisters.
('10', 318, 3, 19, 710723) This is a new idea.
('10', 318, 3, 20, 710743) They do their duty [by us].
('10', 318, 3, 21, 710771) Let us assume that about a hundred thousand signatures and as many pence will be collected.
('10', 318, 3, 22, 710863) The significance of this cannot be easily grasped by everyone.
('10', 318, 3, 23, 710926) A hundred thousand pence will make £416. That is not a small amount.
('10', 318, 3, 24, 710995) But it is not the amount that matters.
('10', 318, 3, 25, 711034) The collection of 100,000 signatures is no child’s play.
('10', 318, 3, 26, 711091) About 40 Indians and Englishmen have volunteered to go round for the purpose.
('10', 318, 3, 27, 711169) It will require a great effort on the part of all these persons to collect such a large number of signatures.
('10', 318, 3, 28, 711279) Besides, it is not a small thing that 100,000 persons encourage us to go ahead with our fight.
('10', 318, 3, 29, 711374) Why should these men work?
('10', 318, 3, 30, 711401) Only because we make sacrifices.
('10', 318, 3, 31, 711434) Does anyone
('10', 318, 4, 32, 711446) 1 Chairman of the Committee; former Governor of Madras; vide”Deeds Better Than Words”, 26 10 1906. 2 Bhownaggree (1851 1933), Indian barrister settled in England, Member of Parliament; “Mr. Brodrick and British Indians in the Transvaal”, 2 7 1905. 3 Vide “Speech at Meeting of Indians”, 2 11 1909.
('10', 319, 0, 1, 711744) 320 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 319, 1, 2, 711786) believe that we could get a single person to work so much for us merely by babbling something about wanting rights for ourselves ?
('10', 319, 1, 3, 711917) Having carried on the fight so far, what will the Transvaal Indians do now?
('10', 319, 1, 4, 711993) If they want to uphold the honour of the people of India, they will meet death rather than give up the fight.
('10', 319, 1, 5, 712103) They will not keep looking at one another, but go on with the fight.
('10', 319, 1, 6, 712172) Everyone will want to be a Nagappen 1. They will not be unnerved, but happy rather that the struggle is lengthening out, for, as days pass, people realize that we are not just being theatrical, and they also grow better acquainted with the nature of our struggle.
('10', 319, 1, 7, 712436) That is the miracle that suffering works.
('10', 319, 1, 8, 712478) As, one after another, the brave Moor soldiers threw themselves on the French guns and fell dead, 2 the French gunmen at last refused to fire on them and embraced the survivors.
('10', 319, 1, 9, 712656) So great is the respect that courage inspires.
('10', 319, 1, 10, 712703) The Moors could make the impression that they did because they were reckless of their lives.
('10', 319, 1, 11, 712796) Had they known how to fire a gun, they could not have succeeded so well.
('10', 319, 1, 12, 712869) But they knew how to die.
('10', 319, 1, 13, 712895) Through their deeds they told the gunmen: “We are not frightened by your guns.
('10', 319, 1, 14, 712974) Our country and our religion are dearer to us than our lives.
('10', 319, 1, 15, 713036) Therefore, keep your guns to yourselves.
('10', 319, 1, 16, 713077) You cannot bend us.
('10', 319, 1, 17, 713097) You may seize our lands, if you can, after our death.
('10', 319, 1, 18, 713151) Do not think, you can take them while we live.” These Moors have not in fact died, but live on.
('10', 319, 1, 19, 713247) For generations their people will recall the story of their courage and the whole world, too, will cite their example.
('10', 319, 1, 20, 713366) The same is true of the Transvaal Indians.
('10', 319, 1, 21, 713409) Let them all speak out with one voice that they are prepared to lay down their lives to fulfil their pledge; and then be as good as their word.
('10', 319, 1, 22, 713553) During [these] four months, many Indians held out courageously and have acquitted themselves well.
('10', 319, 1, 23, 713652) But there were also many who betrayed weakness.
('10', 319, 1, 24, 713700) We are paying the price of that weakness.
('10', 319, 1, 25, 713742) The struggle is getting prolonged.
('10', 319, 1, 26, 713777) What does it matter, though: the more it is protracted, the more severely are the soldiers tested.
('10', 319, 1, 27, 713876) We cannot expect everyone to display the same courage.
('10', 319, 1, 28, 713931) Were it to be otherwise, there would be no need for a fight.
('10', 319, 1, 29, 713992) All the same, the following things need to be done.
('10', 319, 1, 30, 714044) (1) Everyone who possibly can should keep up courage and fight till death.
('10', 319, 2, 31, 714119) 1 A satyagrahi, who died a martyr; vide “Statement of Transvaal Indian Case”.
('10', 319, 2, 32, 714197) 16 7 1909. 2 Vide “Cape Town Indians”, 31 8 1907.
('10', 320, 0, 1, 714247) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 321
('10', 320, 1, 2, 714290) (2) Those who cannot should cheer the others who continue fighting rather than attempt to dispirit them, or hold their tongue and not come in the way of anyone attempting to do something good.
('10', 320, 1, 3, 714483) (3) Those who cannot take part [in the struggle] as in (1) above should help with money.
('10', 320, 1, 4, 714572) This is how all wars are fought.
('10', 320, 1, 5, 714605) Everyone does not march to the front.
('10', 320, 1, 6, 714643) The others [who remain behind] cheer those on the front, nurse them [when wounded] and help with their money.
('10', 320, 1, 7, 714753) (4) Everyone must bring home to General Smuts the determination of the Indian community not to rest till it had won its demands.
('10', 320, 1, 8, 714882) These are the duties of the Transvaal Indians.
('10', 320, 1, 9, 714929) Indians all over South Africa [however] must know that it is because of the struggle that they have been spared.
('10', 320, 1, 10, 715042) It is this fight which safeguards their interests.
('10', 320, 1, 11, 715093) If it has become difficult to pass laws [against them] elsewhere, that is because the Transvaal has been fighting.
('10', 320, 1, 12, 715208) Indians must bear in mind that they will call down disgrace on the community if they do not act as suggested above.
('10', 320, 1, 13, 715324) Even a child can see that we must win the fight.
('10', 320, 1, 14, 715373) They offer to repeal the Act and to permit entry of sixIndians, but refuse equal rights of entry [with the whites] under the law.
('10', 320, 1, 15, 715503) The explanation for this hurdle has also been provided by General Smuts: it is that there are only a few Indians who carry on the fight.
('10', 320, 1, 16, 715640) The rest have grown sick of it.
('10', 320, 1, 17, 715672) If this is true, it is obvious that we shall get nothing.

('10', 321, 2, 6, 716848) OUR DEMAND
('10', 321, 3, 7, 716859) The demand we have made through Lord Ampthill is this: the law must provide for equal rights of entry to all.
('10', 321, 3, 8, 716969) We are also agreeable to the Governor being empowered under the law to regulate the number of immigrants belonging to any community.
('10', 321, 3, 9, 717102) But the law must be the same for all.
('10', 321, 4, 10, 717140) GENERAL SMUTS’ OFFER General Smuts has shown himself prepared to give permits of permanent residence to Indians, and also to repeal the obnoxious Act 3. But he is not prepared to grant equal rights under the immigration law.
('10', 321, 4, 11, 717365) There must be [he says] a separate law making special provision for the Asiatics.
('10', 321, 4, 12, 717447) Lord Crewe 4 has stated emphatically that General Smuts is not prepared to concede equal rights even in theory.
('10', 321, 4, 13, 717559) It all boils down to this: he is prepared to give us the very thing [we want], but only as a gift rather than as a right.
('10', 321, 4, 14, 717681) He insists that in the law itself there must be a distinction between the whites and the Coloured people.
('10', 321, 4, 15, 717787) We argue that we have not been fighting for numbers, but for equal rights [even if only in theory].

('10', 323, 2, 4, 720442) Although the cause they represent is passing through a dark hour, I am not discouraged.
('10', 323, 2, 5, 720530) In the history of the human race, it has been darkest before the dawn.
('10', 323, 2, 6, 720601) Never did the cause of the Negro seem more hopeless than during the years that preceded the abolition of slavery.
('10', 323, 2, 7, 720715) The Saviour of the world deemed Himself lost in the moment that brought our redemption.
('10', 323, 2, 8, 720803) And so I join you in spirit in wishing Godspeed to Messrs Gandhi and Hajee Habib.

('10', 323, 4, 10, 720913) I hear that they have not obtained the small measure of justice which they came to this country to ask.

('10', 324, 1, 2, 722780) allow their friends to depart without showing them their goodwill.
('10', 324, 1, 3, 722847) He thought their presence there did not endorse in every particular all Mr. Gandhi’s words and acts or suggest that he had made no mistakes.
('10', 324, 1, 4, 722988) Human beings would not be human beings if they did not make mistakes.
('10', 324, 1, 5, 723058) But, on the whole, their presence at that meeting was their endorsement of the Indian struggle.
('10', 324, 1, 6, 723154) The question touched not only the Transvaal or India, but the British Empire as a whole.
('10', 324, 1, 7, 723243) Mr. Gandhi had informed them, he said, that there was an offer from General Smuts to repeal the Act of 1907, but it was subject to a condition which was unacceptable.
('10', 324, 1, 8, 723410) Mr. Gandhi did not resist legislation in general, but only legislation which cast a slur upon Indians.
('10', 324, 1, 9, 723513) Mr. Gandhi said: I am thankful to Mr. Meyer for having called this meeting and I welcome the opportunity given to my colleague and me.
('10', 324, 1, 10, 723648) We do not expect this gathering to endorse every step that we have taken.
('10', 324, 1, 11, 723722) We only want you to declare that our demand is a reasonable one and request your support for it.
('10', 324, 1, 12, 723819) The issue on which we have been fighting concerns not only the Transvaal but the whole of the British Empire.
('10', 324, 1, 13, 723929) The offer which the Transvaal Government has made is not acceptable because it does not meet our object.
('10', 324, 1, 14, 724034) There are in South Africa nearly 150,000 Indians.
('10', 324, 1, 15, 724084) The immigration of Indians commenced with the system of indentured labour in Natal.
('10', 324, 1, 16, 724168) This was followed by the advent of free Indians who, being traders, excited the jealousy of white traders; hence the present Indian problem in South Africa.
('10', 324, 1, 17, 724325) The position we occupy in that country is a very difficult and a very delicate one.
('10', 324, 1, 18, 724409) In Natal, at the Cape, in the Orange Free State and in the Transvaal, there exists legislation which hurts our feelings.
('10', 324, 1, 19, 724530) In the Transvaal the position is particularly difficult.
('10', 324, 1, 20, 724587) Before the war, we could not hold landed property, had no voting rights, might not walk on the foot paths nor ride on tram cars.
('10', 324, 1, 21, 724716) All these laws are still in force.
('10', 324, 1, 22, 724751) Up to the year 1906, however, we put up with these restrictions.
('10', 324, 1, 23, 724816) We memorialized the Government.
('10', 324, 1, 24, 724848) My friend, Mr. Hajee Habib, used to approach the British Agent for relief.
('10', 324, 1, 25, 724923) He sometimes obtained a measure of redress.
('10', 324, 1, 26, 724967) We did not, however, go beyond taking these steps.
('10', 324, 1, 27, 725018) But the law which was passed in 1906 fell in a different category.
('10', 324, 1, 28, 725085) It was conceived in an atmosphere of criminality.
('10', 324, 1, 29, 725135) It was degrading to the people who were settled there.
('10', 324, 1, 30, 725190) They also intended to
('10', 325, 0, 1, 725212) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 325, 1, 2, 725254) pass another law to put a barrier upon Indian immigration.
('10', 325, 1, 3, 725313) Never before had such laws been passed in a British Colony.
('10', 325, 1, 4, 725373) They were an attack on us as a community.
('10', 325, 1, 5, 725415) We felt therefore that petitions would not be enough.
('10', 325, 1, 6, 725469) We held a meeting in a theatre, at which Mr. Hajee Habib administered an oath to everyone not to submit to any such law if it came to be passed but suffer the penalties for breaking it.
('10', 325, 1, 7, 725655) 1 We had no personal interest to serve by this.
('10', 325, 1, 8, 725703) So long as it was a matter of our own interests, we had kept patient.
('10', 325, 1, 9, 725773) But when we saw that it constituted an attack on us as a community, that the very foundations of the British Empire were endangered, we resolved to keep quiet no longer.
('10', 325, 1, 10, 725943) We had two alternatives before us.
('10', 325, 1, 11, 725978) One was to meet violence with violence.
('10', 325, 1, 12, 726018) We rejected that alternative.
('10', 325, 1, 13, 726048) The other was to refuse submission to this legislation.
('10', 325, 1, 14, 726104) We adopted this course.
('10', 325, 1, 15, 726128) We acted as Daniel had done when he refused to obey the laws of men which he did not approve of.
('10', 325, 1, 16, 726225) 2 The Imperial Government, too, were a party to this crime.
('10', 325, 1, 17, 726285) They knew that this legislation would hurt our susceptibilities.
('10', 325, 1, 18, 726350) They might have withheld their consent to the Transvaal measure, but they did not.
('10', 325, 1, 19, 726433) What is the meaning of the British Constitution ?
('10', 325, 1, 20, 726483) It is supposed to confer equal rights on all subjects.
('10', 325, 1, 21, 726538) I could consent to remain a subject of an Empire with such a constitution.
('10', 325, 1, 22, 726613) But I have found from experience that we cannot have equal rights even in theory.
('10', 325, 1, 23, 726695) I am obliged to say that I cannot consent to remain a subject in such an Empire.
('10', 325, 1, 24, 726776) It does not matter to what extent I am allowed to participate in it; if, however, I am to be treated as a mere slave and not as a partner, that is a position I cannot accept.
('10', 325, 1, 25, 726951) This legislation cuts at the root of the British Empire and resisting it we have been rendering a service not only to India but to the whole Empire.
('10', 325, 1, 26, 727100) We have been offering passive resistance against the Imperial Government as well, and I hope that this meeting will tell us that we are right in doing so.
('10', 325, 1, 27, 727255) We cannot do less and deserve to be partners in the Empire, and unless there is partnership, there cannot be Empire.
('10', 325, 1, 28, 727372) That is why I have said that this struggle is one of the greatest of modern times.
('10', 325, 1, 29, 727455) We are fighting with no selfish motive, and the weapon we employ is self sacrifice.
('10', 325, 1, 30, 727539) What we ask is equality in the eyes of law, which Smuts refuses to grant.
('10', 325, 1, 31, 727613) As an illustration, let us suppose a master telling his slave: “You may sit at the table with me, but on this

('10', 326, 1, 2, 727879) condition, that this bond of slavery will always exist between us.” Will the slave acquiesce in such an arrangement, if he wants to be free?
('10', 326, 1, 3, 728020) What he must do is to tear off the bond of slavery.
('10', 326, 1, 4, 728072) That is our position.

('10', 332, 3, 13, 741910) 167. LETTER TO RAMDAS GANDHI
('10', 332, 4, 14, 741939) UNION CASTLE LINE, R. M. S. KILDONAN CASTLE, Wednesday [November 27, 1909]
('10', 332, 5, 15, 742014) RAMDAS 1, I write this letter to you as I do not know when we shall meet.
('10', 332, 5, 16, 742088) Do not be angry with me if I have not brought anything for you.
('10', 332, 5, 17, 742152) There was nothing I liked.
('10', 332, 5, 18, 742179) What could I do if nothing European appealed to me?
('10', 332, 5, 19, 742231) I like everything Indian.
('10', 332, 5, 20, 742257) The people of Europe are good, but their way of life is not good.
('10', 332, 5, 21, 742323) I shall explain [this] to you in detail when we meet.

('10', 334, 1, 2, 744453) 170. INTERVIEW TO “CAPE ARGUS” 1
('10', 334, 2, 3, 744486) [CAPE TOWN, November 30, 1909]
('10', 334, 3, 4, 744517) Dr. Abdurahman 2, this morning, introduced Mr. Gandhi and [Mr.] Habib, who left South Africa in June last as a deputation to England on behalf of the Indian Passive Resisters.
('10', 334, 3, 5, 744693) They arrived this morning, and continue their journey today to the Transvaal, if they are not stopped at Vereeniging.
('10', 334, 4, 6, 744811) Mr. Gandhi .
('10', 334, 4, 7, 744824) has a youthful appearance; but he is over 40 years of age, and has a son who has four times been in prison as a Passive Resister.
('10', 334, 4, 8, 744954) Mr. Gandhi himself has been in prison for the same reason.
('10', 334, 4, 9, 745013) [GANDHIJI:] Passive resistance has gone on for three years, and now the issue is the clearest possible between the Transvaal Government and the British Indians.
('10', 334, 4, 10, 745174) We have been fighting throughout this time for legal or theoretical equality with reference to the future emigration from India.
('10', 334, 4, 11, 745303) We entirely recognise the Transvaal standpoint that there should be a very rigid test of all emigrants from India, but we have always held that the manner of bringing about this position should be not offensive to the whole of India, as now, and should not be a departure from such legislation in other colonies.
('10', 334, 4, 12, 745616) The Transvaal legislation is the first of its kind.
('10', 334, 4, 13, 745668) Indians are excluded from the Transvaal as Indians—that is, on the ground of race or colour, whereas in other colonies, even in Australia, exclusion is brought about by severe education tests.
('10', 334, 4, 14, 745861) This test is made severe, or it is relaxed, in accordance with the instructions issued by the administrator in charge of the Immigration Department.
('10', 334, 4, 15, 746010) Against this, we have nothing to say, but I feel that equality in theory should be preserved intact, otherwise the terms ‘British Constitution’ and ‘British subject’ become perfectly meaningless.
('10', 334, 4, 16, 746206) I have yet been able to find no one who has studied the question, who has anything to say against this attitude taken up by us.
('10', 334, 4, 17, 746334) The question to be considered is the retention on the Statute book, deliberately, of this unreasonable inequality.
('10', 334, 4, 18, 746449) I say nothing with reference to the internal legislation in the Transvaal, bad as it is, but talk of the fundamental point I have drawn attention to.
('10', 334, 4, 19, 746599) l could point out, too, that the struggle has been entirely idealised, in that those
('10', 334, 5, 20, 746684) 1 This was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 11 12 1909.
('10', 334, 6, 21, 746737) 2 President of the African Political Organisation and member of the Cape Town Municipality.
('10', 335, 0, 1, 746829) 336 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 335, 1, 2, 746871) engaged in it have no personal interest to serve, merely fighting for a principle.
('10', 335, 1, 3, 746954) The method adopted also is idealised, as we seek to bring about relief through personal suffering by disregard of the law, which we hold to be against our conscience and our self respect.
('10', 335, 1, 4, 747142) We suffer, that is the penalty; hence over 2,500 Indians have suffered imprisonment in the Transvaal, some of them even four times.
('10', 335, 1, 5, 747274) Among this number are merchants, hawkers and servants, men representative of all the different religions, and today we have received a cablegram from Professor Gokhale, who is a member of the Viceregal Council, Calcutta, stating that one of the millionaires of India, Mr. R. J. Tata, has given 25,000 rupees (£1,630) to the funds of the passive resisters.
('10', 335, 1, 6, 747630) Hitherto we have not appealed for funds outside of South Africa, but since the prolongation of the struggle has reduced so many Indian families to poverty, we find it necessary to accept assistance from outside South Africa.
('10', 335, 1, 7, 747855) In England many Englishmen and Indians volunteered to collect subscriptions and to sign a letter 1 addressed to the passive resisters, encouraging them to continue the fight.
('10', 335, 2, 8, 748030) We went to England in no spirit of defiance, but in order to take advantage of the presence there of so many Colonial statesmen.
('10', 335, 2, 9, 748159) I feel certain that when the people in South Africa realise the ideal nature of the struggle, though their own ideal is not to encourage the wholesale importation of Indians from India, they will be unwilling to inflict the serious suffering that has been going on.
('10', 335, 2, 10, 748425) 1 think that the South African statesmen should welcome the method adopted by us to gain relief, because we do not inflict suffering on others.
('10', 335, 2, 11, 748569) Although [the result of] our visit to England was negligible, yet I feel satisfied that the English people now realise the exact nature of this struggle and are persuaded that we are moved by a sense of duty.
('10', 335, 3, 12, 748778) As regards the effect in India, meetings have been held throughout the chief towns of India, in which all the different classes combined in support of the passive resisters, and I notice that one 4 the retiring Indian members of Lord Morley’s Council has stated that no question has so agitated India as this concerning the Transvaal
('10', 335, 4, 13, 749112) 1 Vide “Letter to Transvaal British Indians”, 6 11 1909
('10', 335, 5, 14, 749168) 2 This paragraph was not reproduced in Indian Opinion.

('10', 336, 1, 2, 749344) treatment of the Indians.
('10', 336, 2, 3, 749370) Question: Will the education test be accepted ?
('10', 336, 2, 4, 749418) [GANDHIJI:] Yes, the Emigration Officer would have a discretionary power as to the test to be applied, and it would be open to him to make a severe test as regards Indians, and so reject those who were not able to meet it.
('10', 336, 2, 5, 749641) This is done in Australia and other colonies.
('10', 336, 2, 6, 749687) I see no difficulty about it.

('10', 336, 4, 10, 749954) 171. FRAGMENT OF A LETTER 2
('10', 336, 5, 11, 749982) December 1, 1909
('10', 336, 6, 12, 749999) I never realize any distinction between a Hindu and a Mahomedan.
('10', 336, 6, 13, 750064) To my mind, both are sons of Mother India.
('10', 336, 6, 14, 750107) I know that Hindus are in a numerical majority, and that they are believed to be more advanced in knowledge and education.
('10', 336, 6, 15, 750230) Accordingly they should be glad to give way so much the More to their Mahomedan brethren.
('10', 336, 6, 16, 750320) As a man of truth, I honestly believe that Hindus should yield to the Mahomedans what the latter desire, and that they should rejoice in so doing.
('10', 336, 6, 17, 750467) We can expect unity only if such mutual large heartedness is displayed.
('10', 336, 6, 18, 750539) When the Hindus and Mahomedans act towards each other as blood brothers, then only we can hope for the dawn of India.

('10', 337, 9, 20, 752427) The people of England and India were waking up to the fact that the struggle was just.
('10', 337, 9, 21, 752514) They were realising the detrimental nature of the Transvaal’s action.

('10', 339, 4, 9, 755823) 176. REPLY TO “ THE STAR” 1
('10', 339, 5, 10, 755851) [JOHANNESBURG,] December 3, 1909
('10', 339, 6, 11, 755884) SIR, I must again, with your kind permission, worry you and your readers with the struggle in which my countrymen have now been engaged for the last three years.
('10', 339, 6, 12, 756046) I must confess that, even in London, I could see no sign of the majority of my compatriots here having been tired of the struggle, as you are.
('10', 339, 6, 13, 756189) They have certainly felt the strain.
('10', 339, 6, 14, 756226) Some have undoubtedly succumbed, and, before we are through, more may succumb; but the demonstration at the station last evening 2 could not have failed to show even a superficial observer that practically the whole of the Indian community is at the back of it, and that those who have, through weakness or through other causes, accepted the law no less keenly resent it than active passive resisters.
('10', 339, 6, 15, 756628) I am, however, more anxious to engage the attention of your readers on the merits than on the question of the strength or weakness of passive resistance.
('10', 339, 6, 16, 756782) In spite of your quotation from Macbeth, 3 I venture to repeat what I have said—that the theory of equality may be restored in our legislation as to immigration, which may be deliberately departed from in administration, and yet I would deny the
('10', 339, 7, 17, 757028) 1 The Star’s leading article, “Mr. Gandhi’s Return” dated 2 12 1909, was reproduced it part in Indian Opinion, 11 12 1909, along with this reply.
('10', 339, 8, 18, 757174) 2 At the Park Station, vide “Interview to Reuter”, 2 12 1909.
('10', 339, 9, 19, 757236) 3 “Be these juggling fiends no more believed That palter with us in a double sense; That keep the word of promise to our ear And break it to our hope.”
('10', 340, 0, 1, 757388) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 341
('10', 340, 1, 2, 757431) charge of having “paltered with” anybody “in a double sense”.
('10', 340, 1, 3, 757493) It will not do to dismiss a great principle of the British Constitution by loosely using the words “administrative chicanery”, “dishonesty”, etc.
('10', 340, 1, 4, 757639) In theory, the Indian Civil Service is open to all British subjects; in practice, it is open to the people of India in a most restricted sense.
('10', 340, 1, 5, 757783) This departure from theory is unfortunate, but it is neither dishonest nor fraudulent, because the thing is done openly, and, rightly or wrongly, as an administrative necessity.
('10', 340, 1, 6, 757961) Australia, Natal, and many other Colonies have legislation such as British Indians have submitted to the Transvaal Government for acceptance; and it is not possible to charge all these Colonies with questionable practices because they use their education test very effectively to keep out British Indians.
('10', 340, 1, 7, 758267) Their legislation contains no national insult, and who can deny that it is a great thing to keep the Statute Books of the Colony free from the taint of prejudice?
('10', 340, 1, 8, 758430) If administration is differential, it will simply be a concession to prejudice, as also the well defined policy of the white inhabitants of South Africa.
('10', 340, 1, 9, 758584) But, in the latest amendment submitted through Lord Ampthill, there is even no room left for the charge of dishonesty.
('10', 340, 1, 10, 758703) The law will clearly state that the Governor in Council will have the power to limit the number of immigrants belonging to any class or race, in spite of their having passed the education test.
('10', 340, 1, 11, 758897) I do believe that, if the people in South Africa, and particularly in the Transvaal, really understood the question, they would ask our Government to grant the concession my countrymen have been fighting for.
('10', 340, 1, 12, 759106) Meanwhile, the Government are making the lot of passive resisters well nigh intolerable.
('10', 340, 1, 13, 759195) One of the greatest Indians in South Africa is, in spite of his weak constitution, being deprived at Diepkloof of the special food which was issued to him by the Medical Officer at Volksrust and at Houtpoort.
('10', 340, 1, 14, 759404) He has been compelled to uncover his head, although he has a religious objection to doing so, an objection that was respected during his three incarcerations.
('10', 340, 1, 15, 759563) He was not only hand cuffed but chained on his arrival from Johannesburg; but, if I know Mr. Rustomjee well, I know that nothing in the world will daunt his brave spirit.
('10', 340, 1, 16, 759734) Another Indian 1, an ex sergeant, has been called upon to empty slop pails.
('10', 340, 1, 17, 759810) 2 He has scruples.
('10', 340, 1, 18, 759829) Such scruples have been hitherto, within my own knowledge, very largely respected.
('10', 340, 2, 19, 759912) 1 U. M. Shelat; vide “Indian Stretcher Bearer Corps”, Before 19 7 1906.
('10', 340, 3, 20, 759984) 2 Vide “Speech at Johannesburg Mass Meeting”,5 12 1909

('10', 341, 1, 2, 760081) has been, for his disobedience so called, put on spare diet and confined in a solitary cell.

('10', 341, 1, 4, 760242) In conclusion, I would like to express the appreciation of my colleague, Mr. Hajee Habib, and myself of the Government’s courtesy in allowing us to cross the border unchallenged.

('10', 342, 0, 1, 761624) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 343
('10', 342, 1, 2, 761667) 178. SPEECH AT JOHANNESBURG MASS MEETING 1
('10', 342, 2, 3, 761710) [December 5, 1909]
('10', 342, 3, 4, 761729) Mr. Gandhi said that it gave Mr. Hajee Habib and himself the greatest satisfaction to see his countrymen in such large numbers face to face again.
('10', 342, 3, 5, 761876) Their presence and their welcome at Park Station gave the lie direct to the charge that interest in the struggle had waned.
('10', 342, 3, 6, 762000) The speaker offered thanks to the Transvaal Government for their having allowed Mr. Hajee Habib and himself to cross the border unchallenged.
('10', 342, 3, 7, 762142) It showed that the struggle could be carried on with dignity and without unnecessary bitterness, and yet the proceedings of the past five months showed that there was a great deal of bitterness as also irritation.
('10', 342, 3, 8, 762356) He recalled the death of the gallant young Nagappan, who gave his life for the struggle.
('10', 342, 3, 9, 762445) A thousand MajorDixons 2 could not remove the impression from his mind that he had died a martyr’s death.
('10', 342, 3, 10, 762551) The great philanthropist Mr. Rustomjee was in gaol, and he was shattered in health.
('10', 342, 3, 11, 762635) The illustrious Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeer was also suffering imprisonment, and so were the stout hearted Mr. Sorabji and other brave Indians.
('10', 342, 3, 12, 762777) Mr. Shelat was suffering solitary imprisonment and was put upon spare diet, because he refused to carry slop pails.
('10', 342, 3, 13, 762893) These things could not but cause great bitterness and irritation.
('10', 342, 3, 14, 762959) It had been said that the community had weakened.
('10', 342, 3, 15, 763009) It was perfectly true that some had fallen.
('10', 342, 3, 16, 763053) It was not their fault.
('10', 342, 3, 17, 763077) It was not in human nature to expect capacity for prolonged suffering on the part of many.
('10', 342, 4, 18, 763168) The state in which they were living was described by General Smuts as that of war; and, in every war, the honours of battle were reserved for the few, and every community was represented, after all, by the fewest possible.
('10', 342, 4, 19, 763391) In the gaol at Diepkloof, every action of the community was represented by its best men.
('10', 342, 5, 20, 763480) 1 The meeting, attended by more than 1,500 Indians including representatives from Boksburg, Germiston, Krugersdorp, Heidelberg and other Rand towns and a number of Chinese friends as also Messrs Vogl and Kallenbach, was held at 4 p.m.
('10', 342, 5, 21, 763715) on the grounds of the Hamidia Mosque, Johannesburg, to welcome the Delegates on their return from England.
('10', 342, 5, 22, 763822) Telegrams were received from several of the country districts.
('10', 342, 5, 23, 763885) A. M. Cachalia, Chairman of the British Indian Association, presided and observed: “The sending of the Delegations to England and India has resulted in giving our struggle world wide status.” A report also appeared in Rand Daily Mail, 6 12 1909.

('10', 343, 0, 1, 764455) 344 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 343, 1, 2, 764497) was, therefore, every reason for hope, and the speaker hoped that Indians would follow the worthy example of their leaders.
('10', 343, 1, 3, 764621) As a matter of fact, the deputations to England and to India were against the real spirit of passive resistance, which relied entirely upon selfsuffering, but there was weakness, too.
('10', 343, 1, 4, 764805) It, therefore, became necessary to supplement the effort by sending deputations.
('10', 343, 1, 5, 764886) They had returned from England without any final result, and yet they had not returned disappointed.
('10', 343, 1, 6, 764987) The authorities now knew the exact nature of the struggle.
('10', 343, 1, 7, 765046) There was no one in England who had anything to say against it.
('10', 343, 1, 8, 765110) Lord Ampthill had supported them with his whole heart.
('10', 343, 1, 9, 765165) Everyone knew that they were fighting for legal and theoretical equality as to immigration.
('10', 343, 1, 10, 765257) It was recognised that the struggle was not on behalf of a handful of Indian residents in the Transvaal.
('10', 343, 1, 11, 765362) It was on behalf of the whole of India, indeed, on behalf of the whole Empire.
('10', 343, 1, 12, 765441) Its honour was entrusted to them, and it would be well for the Colonists to understand the seriousness of the struggle.
('10', 343, 1, 13, 765561) They could not question the demand of the Indian community for a restoration of that equality it had enjoyed before the War and up to 1906, when the Colonial policy of restricting immigration from India was accepted and carried out.
('10', 343, 1, 14, 765794) It was the duty of Indians to resent a national wrong.
('10', 343, 1, 15, 765849) When they were told that they could not enter the country because they were Indians, the implied insult became intolerable.
('10', 343, 1, 16, 765973) It was a life and death struggle.
('10', 343, 1, 17, 766007) His (the speaker’s) life and he believed that of many of his countrymen was dedicated to fighting against the policy underlying the legislation they were protesting against.
('10', 343, 1, 18, 766181) The formation of a band of volunteers for doing house to house work, for collecting subscription, 1 and for reaching the heart of democracy in the United Kingdom was a very important result of their mission.
('10', 343, 1, 19, 766389) The movement might be far reaching in its effects.
('10', 343, 1, 20, 766440) Many earnest English men and women and Indians had joined it.
('10', 343, 1, 21, 766502) The magnificent efforts that were being made by the self sacrificing Mr. Polak had borne ample fruit.
('10', 343, 1, 22, 766604) It had resulted in the magnificent donation of Mr. Ratanji Jamshedji Tata.
('10', 343, 1, 23, 766679) A struggle such as this might well be prolonged.
('10', 343, 1, 24, 766728) Prolongation meant greater dis cipline, if it also meant greater hardship, but the goal to be achieved was worth all the sacrifice, and the speaker hoped that Asiatics would continue the struggle to the end.
('10', 343, 2, 25, 766936) He appealed to the Transvaal Government, as also the Colonists, to consider the issue.
('10', 343, 2, 26, 767023) The Colonists should, in his opinion, exercise their imagination and their Imperial instinct, and concede the demands of the Asiatic communities.
('10', 343, 2, 27, 767169) He hoped that they did not wish to tell the millions of India that they were to be considered as inferior beings, no matter what their status might be.
('10', 343, 2, 28, 767321) The doctrine of inequality as regards immigration was laid down for the first time in the colony of the Transvaal.
('10', 343, 2, 29, 767436) It was not yet too late to retrace the step.
('10', 343, 2, 30, 767481) If the desired alteration in the legislation was made, it would be a simple graceful act of justice.
('10', 343, 2, 31, 767582) But he feared that if the Transvaal proceeded in its present policy, it would shake the very foundations of the Empire.
('10', 343, 3, 32, 767702) 1 Vide “Speech at Meeting of Indians”, 2 11 1909.

('10', 344, 5, 12, 768743) A community which has in it heroes like Mr. Bawazeer, Mr. Rustomjee, Mr. Naidoo 4 and Mr. Sorabji cannot surely be said to have accepted defeat.

('10', 344, 5, 15, 769027) Even a child can see that there would have been a settlement by now if those who gave in had not done so.

('10', 345, 1, 2, 770381) that our struggle is a pure one, that it is not dictated by self interest and that all our methods have been above reproach.
('10', 345, 1, 3, 770506) Likewise, Lord Ampthill and other British leaders too understand all these things.
('10', 345, 1, 4, 770589) We did not come across a single Englishman or Indian who said that our fight was not justified.
('10', 345, 1, 5, 770685) This is no mean achievement.
('10', 345, 1, 6, 770714) We can go ahead now.
('10', 345, 2, 7, 770735) For a time, it also appeared likely that there would be a settlement.
('10', 345, 2, 8, 770805) [General Smuts] offered to repeal the Act and to make provision for the issue of certificates of permanent residence to educated Indians, at discretion.
('10', 345, 2, 9, 770958) We could not accept this.
('10', 345, 2, 10, 770984) It is not a favour that we want, but [recognition of] a right.
('10', 345, 2, 11, 771047) If we have an inferior status under the law, it makes no difference to us that we may be allowed to come in.
('10', 345, 2, 12, 771156) The offer was an appeal to our self interest.
('10', 345, 2, 13, 771202) It was not free from the insult implied in the denial of the right of entry to us on the ground that we are Indians.
('10', 345, 2, 14, 771319) So long as this stigma is not removed, our pledge will remain unfulfilled.
('10', 345, 2, 15, 771394) Therefore, we have no option but to carry on this fight for the sake of our people and our religion.
('10', 345, 2, 16, 771495) We demand that the law must grant equal rights of entry to Europeans and Indians.
('10', 345, 2, 17, 771577) It can empower the Governor to frame regulations to provide that, even from among those who had passed the test, only a fixed number from each community would be allowed to enter.
('10', 345, 2, 18, 771757) This would ensure legal equality and uphold our honour.
('10', 345, 2, 19, 771813) But we failed to get this, I believe, because of our weakness here.
('10', 345, 2, 20, 771881) It should also be remembered by every Indian that more than this we shall never get.

('10', 345, 2, 22, 772024) And get it we shall.
('10', 345, 3, 23, 772045) Everyone knows the fruit of Mr. Polak’s fine efforts in India.
('10', 345, 3, 24, 772108) They have resulted in Mr. Tata’s donation of Rs. 25,000. In England, English ladies and gentlemen as also Indians have enlisted themselves as volunteers and go round from house to house.
('10', 345, 4, 25, 772295) Thus our struggle has gained world wide publicity.
('10', 345, 4, 26, 772346) We have stepped into the limelight.
('10', 345, 4, 27, 772382) It would be a great shame to give up the fight now.
('10', 345, 4, 28, 772434) People have come to feel confident that the Transvaal Indians will never betray weakness of purpose.
('10', 345, 4, 29, 772535) To turn away from the task now will bring disgrace to the Indian community.
('10', 345, 5, 30, 772611) It must also be realized that the status of Indians in South Africa depends to a large extent on this struggle.
('10', 345, 5, 31, 772723) It is because of the struggle that new laws have not been passed, the Licenses Act in Natal has been amended and legislation in Rhodesia was disallowed.
('10', 345, 5, 32, 772876) If we continue, it will be difficult to make laws against us when the Union Parliament comes into being.
('10', 345, 5, 33, 772981) This is as much as to say that our interests also are involved.
('10', 345, 6, 34, 773045) That the struggle is drawing out is to our advantage, rather than otherwise.
('10', 345, 6, 35, 773122) India is being awakened thereby, we are being educated and are learning to do public work.
('10', 345, 6, 36, 773213) It is, therefore, my earnest request to the community that those who are strong must remain strong, that those who have fallen must openly admit their weakness and

('10', 346, 2, 7, 773790) 180. RESOLUTIONS AT JOHANNESBURG MASS MEETING 2
('10', 346, 3, 8, 773838) December 5, 1909
('10', 346, 4, 9, 773855) 1. This meeting of British Indians hereby welcomes Messrs Hajee Habib and Gandhi, and, after having heard their statements, endorses their action, and congratulates them upon having carried out their mission with courage, patience and moderation.
('10', 346, 4, 10, 774102) 2. This meeting of British Indians hereby respectfully tenders its thanks to Lord Ampthill and his fellow members of the South Africa British Indian Committee for having guided the delegates and given them the benefit of their mature experience.
('10', 346, 4, 11, 774348) 3. This meeting of British Indians declares its intention to carry on the struggle by means of self suffering in the shape of imprisonment and otherwise until the legal and theoretical equality as to immigration of British Indians of culture with the other immigrants is restored.
('10', 346, 4, 12, 774629) 4. This meeting of British Indians of the Transvaal appeals to the Government and the European Colonists to consider the bearings of the struggle on the Empire as a whole, and in view of the fact that under the British Indian demand the Colonial ideal of rigorously controlling immigration from India is preserved intact, to see that the terrible sufferings of the community are ended by justice being done.
('10', 346, 4, 13, 775037) 5. This meeting of British Indians of the Transvaal appeals to the Imperial and the Indian Governments to use their friendly efforts for securing a settlement of the long standing grievance of the community, regard being especially had to the fact that the grievance is national and a further prolongation of it is calculated to injure the prestige of the British Empire.

('10', 348, 1, 2, 776992) 182. LETTER TO G. K. GOKHALE
('10', 348, 2, 3, 777021) JOHANNESBURG, December 6, 1909
('10', 348, 3, 4, 777052) DEAR PROFESSOR GOKHALE, As soon as we arrived at Cape Town, your cablegram announcing the magnificent donation from Mr. Tata was received, and now I have your inquiry from Poona as to our requirements.
('10', 348, 3, 5, 777254) I have just cabled as follows:
('10', 348, 4, 6, 777285) PRESENT REQUIREMENT THOUSAND POUNDS.
('10', 348, 4, 7, 777322) EXPECT IM 
('10', 348, 5, 8, 777333) PRISONMENT BEFORE END MONTH.
('10', 348, 5, 9, 777362) MUCH MORE REQUIRED
('10', 348, 6, 10, 777381) What I observe is that the expenses are necessarily great, and our resources in South Africa are exhausted.
('10', 348, 6, 11, 777489) There are enough Indians in the Transvaal alone who could still carry on the struggle, if they would, without outside help, but they are not now inclined to help.
('10', 348, 6, 12, 777652) They think that they have given enough.
('10', 348, 6, 13, 777692) These are the weaker members of the community.
('10', 348, 6, 14, 777739) The strongest have ruined themselves pecuniarily, and they simply go to gaol as often as the Government arrest them.
('10', 348, 6, 15, 777856) Their families have also to be supported.
('10', 348, 6, 16, 777898) When this struggle commenced, I bore the whole of the expenses of the office, as also the rent of offices, which were really for my practice, but, for the last two years, I have done very little legal work.
('10', 348, 6, 17, 778105) I have also found the expenses for running Indian Opinion, which is by no means yet self supporting.
('10', 348, 6, 18, 778206) These are the current expenses: Office here £50 Office London £40 Indian Opinion £50 Distressed families £25 These I apprehend will be the minimum monthly expenses.
('10', 348, 6, 19, 778371) Almost all connected with Indian Opinion are working practically under a vow of poverty, including the Europeans, but, as the paying subscribers are very few, it is necessary to give help.
('10', 348, 6, 20, 778560) I feel that, if contributions do arrive from India, we should continue the above expenses.
('10', 348, 6, 21, 778651) If they do not, it is my intention to cut down much of the expense of Indian Opinion, thus depriving the struggle of one of its greatest supports, and to close down the London office.
('10', 348, 6, 22, 778835) The active passive resisters who are likely to remain staunch to the last we count as one hundred.
('10', 348, 6, 23, 778934) These will force themselves on the attention of the
('10', 349, 0, 1, 778986) 350 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 349, 1, 2, 779028) authorities.
('10', 349, 1, 3, 779041) The bulk of the community will help by attending meetings, making protests, and also by contributing something.
('10', 349, 1, 4, 779153) This would enable the passive resisters to support their dependents.
('10', 349, 1, 5, 779222) To reduce the struggle to this extent means an indefinite prolongation, but, as it has been undertaken very largely as a matter of discipline, those of us who understand it would not at all be disappointed, and are prepared for life long suffering.
('10', 349, 1, 6, 779471) I cannot blame our countrymen in the Transvaal or in South Africa for not paying as liberally as they have hitherto.
('10', 349, 1, 7, 779588) The struggle has cost already, I think, no less than £10,000. In this I include the expenses of all sub committees, which are not found in the advertised accounts of the Central Association, but I exclude the enormous losses that individuals have suffered.
('10', 349, 1, 8, 779845) It is no wonder then if many now lose heart and decline to give even pecuniary help.
('10', 349, 1, 9, 779930) As, however, the national importance of the struggle is now being recognised in India, I feel that we might receive pecuniary support, and that openly.
('10', 349, 1, 10, 780082) I am anxious to make as much of it as possible.
('10', 349, 1, 11, 780130) I have now placed practically the whole of the situation before you.
('10', 349, 1, 12, 780199) Some of the bravest Indians representing all races are at present in Diepkloof Gaol.
('10', 349, 1, 13, 780284) The foremost among them I count Mr. Rustomjee, who has now finished over nine months of continuous imprisonment.
('10', 349, 1, 14, 780397) He is very much shattered in health.
('10', 349, 1, 15, 780434) I paid him a visit yesterday; he is resolved upon dying in gaol if need be.
('10', 349, 1, 16, 780510) Another is a cultured Mahomedan priest, Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeer.
('10', 349, 1, 17, 780577) The third is a Mahomedan merchant of standing, Mr. Ebrahim Aswat from the Surat District.
('10', 349, 1, 18, 780667) The fourth is an undergraduate and Jain, Mr. Nanalal Shah.
('10', 349, 1, 19, 780726) The fifth is a Brahmin from Ahmedabad, Mr. Umiashanker Shelat.
('10', 349, 1, 20, 780789) He has refused to carry slop pails, and is now confined in a solitary cell.
('10', 349, 1, 21, 780865) But perhaps the bravest and the staunchest of all is the indomitable Thambi Naidoo.
('10', 349, 1, 22, 780949) I do not know any Indian who knows the spirit of the struggle so well as he does.
('10', 349, 1, 23, 781031) He was born in Mauritius, but is more Indian than most of us.
('10', 349, 1, 24, 781093) He has sacrificed himself entirely, and has sent me a defiant message, saying that, even though I may yield and accept anything less than Lord Ampthill’s amendment, he alone will offer resistance and die in the Transvaal gaols.
('10', 349, 1, 25, 781321) I may perhaps add to this list another young man, Mr. Sorabji.
('10', 349, 1, 26, 781384) He left a lucrative post in order to lay the foundation of the second stage of the struggle and claim entry as an educated Indian.
('10', 349, 1, 27, 781515) He came light heartedly not knowing what was in store for him, but for the last
('10', 350, 0, 1, 781595) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 351
('10', 350, 1, 2, 781638) eighteen months he has been practically in gaol.
('10', 350, 1, 3, 781687) I could continue to multiply the names.
('10', 350, 1, 4, 781727) In all, there are about thirty Indian passive resisters in the gaols at present; many more would certainly claim the honours if the Government would give them.
('10', 350, 1, 5, 781887) The possibilities of a struggle such as this it is very difficult to measure.
('10', 350, 1, 6, 781965) I hope that the Motherland will come to the rescue, and assist us as far as possible.
('10', 350, 1, 7, 782051) The moral effect of continued pecuniary assistance from India will also be very great.
('10', 350, 1, 8, 782138) I hope that my letter 1 from London has duly reached you, and that it has received your consideration.
('10', 350, 2, 9, 782241) I remain,
('10', 350, 3, 10, 782251) Yours sincerely,
('10', 350, 4, 11, 782268) M. K. GANDHI [PS.] I propose to utilise the funds just received £1673 from you towards liquidating debts already incurred mostly for Indian Opinion.
('10', 350, 4, 12, 782417) You shall have full account of disbursements.

('10', 350, 6, 14, 782565) 183. EXTRACT FROM LETTER 2
('10', 350, 7, 15, 782592) [JOHANNESBURG, December 6, 1909]
('10', 350, 8, 16, 782625) I paid a visit to Mr. Rustomjee yesterday.
('10', 350, 8, 17, 782668) He is very much broken down; he does not receive the medical food that was prescribed for him at Volksrust.
('10', 350, 8, 18, 782776) The Parsees—I mean the orthodox Parsees—never take off their caps, but Mr. Rustomjee has now been compelled to remove his cap, although he was allowed to keep it on at Volksrust and Houtpoort.
('10', 350, 8, 19, 782969) He is put on stone breaking.
('10', 350, 8, 20, 782998) Mr. Rustomjee is also suffering from a constitutional disease; his eye sight is affected; he was a most pitiable and piteous sight.
('10', 350, 8, 21, 783130) I am applying for permission for a doctor to see him.

('10', 351, 0, 1, 783478) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 351, 1, 2, 783520) 184. TATA’S GIFT
('10', 351, 2, 3, 783537) That India has been roused is evident from the generous gift of Mr. Ratanji Jamshedji Tata.
('10', 351, 2, 4, 783629) By his big donation of Rs. 25,000 he has given a powerful impetus to our movement.
('10', 351, 2, 5, 783712) He will probably be followed by other Indians.
('10', 351, 2, 6, 783759) Parsis are known the world over for their generous gifts.
('10', 351, 2, 7, 783817) Mr. Tata has been true to that spirit of generosity.
('10', 351, 2, 8, 783870) In South Africa hardly any Indian can equal Mr. Rustomjee’s performance.
('10', 351, 2, 9, 783943) We have had many generousdonations from him.
('10', 351, 2, 10, 783988) For us, therefore, Mr. Tata’s gift is no matter for surprise.
('10', 351, 2, 11, 784050) Mr. Tata has laid the entire community under obligation.
('10', 351, 2, 12, 784107) What is the way to repay it?
('10', 351, 2, 13, 784136) Our courage must increase tenfold after what has happened.
('10', 351, 2, 14, 784195) The money has been given in the faith that we shall carry on the struggle to the bitter end.
('10', 351, 2, 15, 784288) It is up to us to prove that we are worthy of such confidence.
('10', 351, 2, 16, 784351) It would be some satisfaction if the fight were continued for the sake at any rate of Mr. Tata’s gift, not so much because of the amount itself as for the implication which the donation carries, and the impression that it will make on the world.
('10', 351, 2, 17, 784597) If Mr. Tata’s gift is a matter for satisfaction, it also calls for a warning.
('10', 351, 2, 18, 784675) In this world a gift can rarely be turned to good account.
('10', 351, 2, 19, 784734) Only a few know how to put to good use money got as a gift.
('10', 351, 2, 20, 784794) Such money makes people weak willed and selfish.
('10', 351, 2, 21, 784843) Our fight is based on self help and is intended to bring about our own regeneration.
('10', 351, 2, 22, 784928) Therefore, should Mr. Tata’s gift lead people to relax their efforts, it may do more harm than good.
('10', 351, 2, 23, 785029) We would urge the Indian community not to slacken in its duty in South Africa, regardless of this gift.
('10', 351, 3, 24, 785133) [From Gujarati]
('10', 351, 4, 25, 785149) Indian Opinion, 11 12 1909
('10', 351, 5, 26, 785176) 185. NATAL LICENSING ACT
('10', 351, 6, 27, 785201) The Natal Parliament has amended the Dealers’ Licenses Act.
('10', 351, 6, 28, 785261) The Indian community was keen on provision for appeal, and its desire has been partly satisfied.
('10', 351, 6, 29, 785358) If an officer refuses to renew an existing licence, an appeal will now be allowed to the Supreme Court.
('10', 351, 6, 30, 785462) This is a matter for some satisfaction.
('10', 351, 6, 31, 785502) There used to be rank injustice sometimes, which will now cease.
('10', 351, 6, 32, 785567) The amendment does not apply to
('10', 352, 0, 1, 785599) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 353
('10', 352, 1, 2, 785642) new licences, but we do not think this is much of a difficulty.
('10', 352, 1, 3, 785706) With some effort we may possibly secure that too.
('10', 352, 1, 4, 785756) Every Indian must note how the change came about.
('10', 352, 1, 5, 785806) There are two main reasons.
('10', 352, 1, 6, 785834) One, to arrest the agitation for ending the system of indenture.
('10', 352, 1, 7, 785899) Two, fear of satyagraha in Natal.
('10', 352, 1, 8, 785933) Thirdly, there is also reason to believe that the change came about a little earlier than it might otherwise have done because of the Natal Deputation.
('10', 352, 1, 9, 786085) But we especially draw the attention of the Indian community to the first reason.
('10', 352, 1, 10, 786167) The amendment is a kind of a sop.
('10', 352, 1, 11, 786201) The Government will now expect the business community to abandon its agitation for stopping the import of indentured labour.
('10', 352, 1, 12, 786326) We hope the community will do nothing of the kind.
('10', 352, 1, 13, 786377) If it does, it will have proved remiss in its duty.
('10', 352, 1, 14, 786429) According to us, indenture is an evil thing [in itself].
('10', 352, 1, 15, 786486) But there is also the £3 poll tax on the indentured labourers.
('10', 352, 1, 16, 786549) There must be an agitation for its removal.
('10', 352, 1, 17, 786593) The Natal Government wants that the terms of indenture should expire in India.
('10', 352, 1, 18, 786672) The [Natal] Mercury has pointed out clearly that had it not been for the difficulty of licences the Imperial Government would certainly have agreed to the change regarding the expiry of the term of indenture in India.
('10', 352, 1, 19, 786890) It is our earnest request that the Indian community should not neglect its duty in this matter.
('10', 352, 1, 20, 786986) It will be evident to every Indian that this gain is the result of satyagraha.
('10', 352, 1, 21, 787065) Those who see this will realize that satyagraha can meet every situation.
('10', 352, 1, 22, 787139) The problem of Indian education is also a very serious one.
('10', 352, 1, 23, 787199) It demands the utmost attention from the community.
('10', 352, 1, 24, 787251) We therefore hope that the community will not sink into lethargy in the belief that nothing further now remains to be done.
('10', 352, 2, 25, 787375) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 11 12 1909

('10', 354, 4, 4, 788996) THE EDITOR INDIAN OPINION
('10', 354, 5, 5, 789022) SIR, I hope that I shall find myself lodged in gaol before this letter appears in print.
('10', 354, 6, 6, 789111) My second son (Manilal) lives with me.
('10', 354, 6, 7, 789150) For some time past I had been thinking of asking him to join the struggle.
('10', 354, 6, 8, 789225) He was insistent.
('10', 354, 6, 9, 789243) It appeared to me, on deep reflection, that it would be right to bring him in.
('10', 354, 6, 10, 789322) I believe that to go to gaol or suffer similar hardships with a pure motive for the sake of the motherland is the truest kind of education.
('10', 354, 6, 11, 789462) Since I look upon gaol as a kind of palace, how can I deny the privilege of being there to those whom I hold dear?
('10', 354, 6, 12, 789577) My son has attained the age (17) 2 when he can think for himself.
('10', 354, 6, 13, 789643) 3 For my part, I should like to tell all Indian parents and all Indian youths that success will attend those who have joined the struggle.
('10', 354, 6, 14, 789782) It is they that do the fighting, who profit most from it.
('10', 354, 6, 15, 789840) To those who are in gaol now I make this request, that they should make up their minds to return to gaol the moment they are released, without so much as pausing for breath.
('10', 354, 6, 16, 790014) An exception may be made only inthe case of Mr. Rustomjee.
('10', 354, 6, 17, 790073) If he is not arrested [on his release], he would do well to go to Durban for a month.
('10', 354, 6, 18, 790159) But as soon as a month is over, it will be his duty, so at least it appears to me, to return [to the Transvaal], whatever the state of his health.
('10', 354, 6, 19, 790306) Those who are outside should think of possible ways of getting into gaol.
('10', 354, 6, 20, 790380) Failing everything else, it will be easy enough for them to fill the gaols in January or February.
('10', 354, 6, 21, 790479) Whether or not others fill them, it is obviously the duty of those

('10', 358, 1, 2, 796654) 192. LETTER TO A. H. WEST
('10', 358, 2, 3, 796680) Friday Night [December 24, 1909]
('10', 358, 3, 4, 796713) MY DEAR WEST, Both your letter and Joseph’s 1 to the Mercury are very good.
('10', 358, 3, 5, 796789) I should like to keep them for Natesan 2 if I may.
('10', 358, 3, 6, 796840) If there is not sufficient to pay wages, I, being the manager of the Trust 3, must make provision.
('10', 358, 3, 7, 796939) In any case, the whole estate is liable for wages.
('10', 358, 3, 8, 796990) Such is the legal position.
('10', 358, 3, 9, 797018) The moral position is this: We do not make two ends meet; I fail to find money; we close down the Press, try other means; if we do not succeed and if we do not want to die on the land in the attempt to make it pay, we disperse or those who are dissatisfied will disperse.
('10', 358, 3, 10, 797290) What do owners do, when they find their enterprise not paying?
('10', 358, 3, 11, 797353) Settlers are virtually owners.
('10', 358, 3, 12, 797384) Yes, it is possible for the majority to sell the land.
('10', 358, 3, 13, 797439) I think we ought to leave the door open.
('10', 358, 3, 14, 797480) You will remember I once remarked that Indian Opinion.
('10', 358, 3, 15, 797535) only may be taken over by the settlers, or some of them.
('10', 358, 3, 16, 797592) Hence the clause 4. Throughout I have presumed that the majority of us at least may be expected to carry out the ideals.
('10', 358, 3, 17, 797713) The settlers will be those who will sign the list of settlers to be appended to the Trust.
('10', 358, 3, 18, 797804) The wives and children are not ‘Settlers, in the sense of the Trust.
('10', 358, 3, 19, 797873) Polak and Harilal who have joined the scheme are.
('10', 358, 3, 20, 797923) Miss Schlesin can be one.
('10', 358, 3, 21, 797949) Mr. Doke and Miss Smith are not.
('10', 358, 3, 22, 797982) The earnings will pay for all they can.
('10', 358, 3, 23, 798022) For the present we only contemplate a deficit.
('10', 358, 3, 24, 798069) The scope has been changed in that the settlers are paid according to needs and not according to income or ability.
('10', 358, 3, 25, 798185) I shall still await your concrete suggestions for amendment or alteration or addition.
('10', 358, 4, 26, 798272) Yours sincerely,
('10', 358, 5, 27, 798289) M. K. GANDHI From a photostat of the original in Gandhiji’s hand C. W. 4411

('10', 359, 4, 13, 799507) 194. LETTER TO MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('10', 359, 5, 14, 799542) Sunday, December 26, 1909
('10', 359, 6, 15, 799568) MY DEAR MILLIE, I am writing this in Mr.Kallenbach’s tent.
('10', 359, 6, 16, 799627) It has been raining for the last two days.
('10', 359, 6, 17, 799670) The tent is soaking wet, water dropping here and there.
('10', 359, 6, 18, 799726) The wind is howling about me.
('10', 359, 6, 19, 799756) Manilal is with us.
('10', 359, 6, 20, 799776) He is a good boy.
('10', 359, 6, 21, 799794) I notice that he is over particular about his dress.
('10', 359, 6, 22, 799847) He devoted nearly a[n] hour to ironing his suit.
('10', 359, 6, 23, 799896) He is pining to go to goal.
('10', 359, 6, 24, 799924) I see you address me Brother in inverted commas and underlined thrice.
('10', 359, 6, 25, 799995) We may well call ourselves brother and sister.
('10', 359, 6, 26, 800042) Our conduct certainly justifies it.
('10', 359, 6, 27, 800078) But will you give me a sister’s confidence?
('10', 359, 6, 28, 800122) If you say ‘yes’, I shall try to be ‘brother’ to you.
('10', 359, 6, 29, 800176) No real increase in my family can be cause of sorrow to me.
('10', 359, 6, 30, 800236) Henry wants me to send you £ 17 now.
('10', 359, 6, 31, 800273) His previous letter said £ 16. I think I wrote to you from ‘on board’ that I should like to be able to send you more.
('10', 359, 6, 32, 800391) Now it is done by Henry which is the same thing.
('10', 359, 6, 33, 800440) Henry wonders how you will take his prolonged stay in India.
('10', 359, 6, 34, 800501) And yet he is there in his element.
('10', 359, 6, 35, 800537) After a certain stage, my presence is a hindrance to friends’ growth.
('10', 359, 6, 36, 800607) Henry is doing much better independently of me.
('10', 359, 6, 37, 800655) He has succeeded in captivating Dr.Mehta who wants me to print his address on industrialism and its evils for free
('10', 360, 0, 1, 800770) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 361
('10', 360, 1, 2, 800813) distribution.
('10', 360, 1, 3, 800827) Your letter is full of epigrams in your best style.
('10', 360, 1, 4, 800879) You could hardly be so sweet as you are if you never needed a friend’s help and consolation.
('10', 360, 1, 5, 800972) Though a brother could never replace a husband, I tried during my stay in London to replace Henry so far as I could.
('10', 360, 1, 6, 801089) It was no more a wrench to you to separate from me than it was to me to separate from you.
('10', 360, 1, 7, 801180) We certainly came nearer each other in London than ever before.
('10', 360, 1, 8, 801244) It was natural.
('10', 360, 1, 9, 801260) You may well envy Maud and yet you cannot.
('10', 360, 1, 10, 801303) Maud is a different type.
('10', 360, 1, 11, 801329) Friends can make or mar her.
('10', 360, 1, 12, 801358) You can be helped by friends and never marred.
('10', 360, 1, 13, 801405) A trusting nature like Maud’s is beautiful.
('10', 360, 1, 14, 801449) It can under good auspices develop into a very strong nature.
('10', 360, 1, 15, 801511) Her progress can be rapid but so can her retrogression.
('10', 360, 1, 16, 801567) With you retrogression is impossible.
('10', 360, 1, 17, 801605) And progress, shall I say, slow if not even difficult.
('10', 360, 1, 18, 801660) You would be justified.
('10', 360, 1, 19, 801684) I know, in saying the same of me.
('10', 360, 1, 20, 801718) We are both strong natures.
('10', 360, 1, 21, 801746) We may be nearest each other but never identical.
('10', 360, 1, 22, 801796) I was tempted to analyse Henry.
('10', 360, 1, 23, 801828) But I must not speculate any further.
('10', 360, 1, 24, 801866) Your wonderful letter before me has given rise to these thoughts.
('10', 360, 1, 25, 801932) That is the beauty of epigrams.
('10', 360, 1, 26, 801964) You could say so much on each.
('10', 360, 1, 27, 801995) You are right in assuming that Lord Morley’s reforms may be a piece of bone thrown to a hungry dog.
('10', 360, 1, 28, 802095) And yet it is open to those who will be the leaders in the new Assembly to make much out of them.
('10', 360, 1, 29, 802193) Lord Morley can do little for India unless Indians themselves are prepared to do something for themselves.
('10', 360, 1, 30, 802300) Just now assassination is the order of the day.
('10', 360, 1, 31, 802348) Lord Morely can stop it but he is too blind to see the way.
('10', 360, 1, 32, 802408) I should like to be able to throw myself into the work but I cannot, and have no desire to force the pace.
('10', 360, 1, 33, 802515) I am glad Waldo and Baby are getting on.
('10', 360, 1, 34, 802556) I hope Celia and Amy are keeping well.
('10', 360, 1, 35, 802595) Of myself, you will learn from elsewhere.
('10', 360, 1, 36, 802637) With love,
('10', 360, 2, 37, 802648) Yours sincerely, YOUR ‘BROTHER’

('10', 361, 3, 7, 803056) 2 Reasonable medical expenses of all should come out of the business.
('10', 361, 3, 8, 803126) What is reasonable should be decided in each case separately in consultation with the patient.
('10', 361, 3, 9, 803221) The scheme is based on mutual trust and we must expect everyone not to wilfully fall ill or to wilfully ask us to incur expenses.
('10', 361, 3, 10, 803351) If I do not want a doctor, I cannot impose the idea on others.
('10', 361, 3, 11, 803414) In coming to this conclusion, I fancy that the ordinary law of human life is health and not sickness.

('10', 364, 3, 4, 809023) 197. LETTER TO MILLIE GRAHAM POLAK
('10', 364, 4, 5, 809058) JOHANNESBURG, December 31, 1909
('10', 364, 5, 6, 809090) MY DEAR MILLIE, Nowadays I come to the office between 7 and 8. I have a quiet half hour just now which I wish to devote to writing to you.
('10', 364, 5, 7, 809229) You are dearer to me than my widowed sister Gokuldas’ mother, whom as you know I worship, though in thoughts a gulf divides us.
('10', 364, 5, 8, 809357) You are dearer because there is so much in common between us and because I have entered so much into your and Henry’s lives I hope for our common good and the good of humanity.
('10', 364, 5, 9, 809534) Your brief letter haunts me.
('10', 364, 5, 10, 809563) It fills me with sorrow and admiration for you.
('10', 364, 5, 11, 809611) You have written it in love, grief and resignation.
('10', 364, 5, 12, 809663) I wish you had sent me the other letter also that you wrote.
('10', 364, 5, 13, 809724) No, no, my dear sister, you are not going to live away from Henry for ever.
('10', 364, 5, 14, 809800) Your wondrous imagination has carried you much further, I am sure, than Henry could ever intend you to go.
('10', 364, 5, 15, 809907) How I wish I was close by you to comfort you and show how wrong you were.
('10', 364, 5, 16, 809981) In reply to that letter of mine which you read, Henry wrote to me and told me he was writing to you.
('10', 364, 5, 17, 810082) I wish you had sent his letter to me.
('10', 364, 5, 18, 810120) You have cut a deep wound in my heart by telling me that your brief letter is to be the last for many weeks.
('10', 364, 5, 19, 810229) You will not treat your only (am I) adopted brother in that fashion?
('10', 364, 5, 20, 810298) If I am your brother, you must 2 let me share your sorrows.
('10', 364, 5, 21, 810358) You are Henry’s better half.
('10', 364, 5, 22, 810387) No path can be considered right for him along which he cannot carry you.
('10', 364, 5, 23, 810460) Will you not have sufficient faith in him to know for certain that he is incapable of creating a gulf between you and himself?
('10', 364, 5, 24, 810587) I ask you to trust me neve 3 to carry Henry
('10', 364, 6, 25, 810631) 1 The court ordered, after hearing McIntyre’s arguments, this time, that the defendants be deported, the deportation to take effect after the decision in the appeal to the Supreme Court.
('10', 364, 6, 26, 810818) 2 Words supplied in italics here and elsewhere in the text of a letter (other than those italicised as per editorial style) are underlined in the original, evidently for emphasis.

('10', 365, 1, 2, 811040) along any route without your approval.
('10', 365, 1, 3, 811079) A gift given or a sacrifice made grudgingly and not cheerfully is no gift or sacrifice.
('10', 365, 1, 4, 811167) You have often given me the privilege of analysing you to yourself.
('10', 365, 1, 5, 811235) You have heroically sacrificed yourself on the altar of duty.
('10', 365, 1, 6, 811297) But you have done so in bitterness not always free from resentment.
