('10', 365, 5, 25, 812461) 198. MR. SHELAT’S DISCHARGE
('10', 365, 6, 26, 812489) After having served six months, imprisonment, Mr. Shelat was discharged from Diepkloof Gaol on the 24th December, reduced in weight from 139 pounds to 110, looking weak and emaciated.
('10', 365, 6, 27, 812673) The readers of this journal will remember that Mr. Shelat was confined to a solitary cell and placed on reduced diet for having refused to carry
('10', 366, 0, 1, 812818) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 367
('10', 366, 1, 2, 812861) slop pails.
('10', 366, 1, 3, 812873) 1 We consider that passive resisters should not hesitate to do the meanest work in the Transvaal prisons.
('10', 366, 1, 4, 812979) But Mr. Shelat—a Brahmin —made the matter a point of conscience.
('10', 366, 1, 5, 813044) We can but treat his objection, therefore, with respect.
('10', 366, 1, 6, 813101) He was first punished with twenty four hours’ solitary confinement with spare diet for disobeying the order.
('10', 366, 1, 7, 813210) Mr. Shelat was immovable.
('10', 366, 1, 8, 813236) The next punishment was for forty eight hours; still with spare diet, but without effect.
('10', 366, 1, 9, 813326) The third sentence was increased to six days with spare diet.
('10', 366, 1, 10, 813388) Mr. Shelat was adamant.
('10', 366, 1, 11, 813412) Spare diet meant rice water twice per day.
('10', 366, 1, 12, 813455) This told on him, but Mr. Shelat was determined to die for his conscience.
('10', 366, 1, 13, 813530) He was further sentenced to 14 days’ solitary confinement and with reduced diet.
('10', 366, 1, 14, 813611) Reduced diet meant half the ordinary scale.
('10', 366, 1, 15, 813655) But even the long spell in a semi dark cell could not bend this passive resister’s spirit.
('10', 366, 1, 16, 813746) The last sentence was, therefore, twenty eight days.
('10', 366, 1, 17, 813799) This meant prolonging his six months’ sentence by nine days.
('10', 366, 1, 18, 813860) The authorities, however, discharged him without exacting the extra nine days.
('10', 366, 1, 19, 813939) This is a feat that will always remain in the annals of Passive Resistance as one of the most brilliant.
('10', 366, 1, 20, 814044) We congratulate Mr. Shelat on his pluck.
('10', 366, 1, 21, 814085) He has shown the Transvaal Government that there are some Indians who, when it is a matter of conscience with them, do not fear consequences.
('10', 366, 1, 22, 814227) Such punishment as was awarded to Mr. Shelat is reserved for criminals of a hardened type.To have inflicted it on Mr. Shelat and half starved him was wanton cruelty.
('10', 366, 1, 23, 814393) But we boldly say to those who know what the struggle means—“Never mind what suffering you have to undergo.
('10', 366, 1, 24, 814501) The more you suffer, the better it is for you and the community.”
('10', 366, 2, 25, 814567) Indian Opinion, 1 1 1910
('10', 366, 3, 26, 814592) 199. OURSELVES
('10', 366, 4, 27, 814607) With the present issue, this journal appears under a somewhat changed dress.
('10', 366, 4, 28, 814684) The size, too, has been reduced.
('10', 366, 4, 29, 814717) The Transvaal struggle has put a very severe strain on our resources.
('10', 366, 4, 30, 814787) It has now become too great for us to continue the old form and size.
('10', 366, 4, 31, 814857) It is within the knowledge of most of our readers that our publication is not a commercial concern, but our capacity for the service of the community to whose interests Indian Opinion is devoted is limited, and our limitation has necessitated the change the readers will notice
('10', 366, 5, 32, 815135) 1 Vide “Speech at Johannesburg Mass Meeting”, 5 12 1909
('10', 367, 0, 1, 815191) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 367, 1, 2, 815233) in its appearance.
('10', 367, 1, 3, 815252) We part very reluctantly by way of retrenchment with the cover whose colour was very specially selected.
('10', 367, 1, 4, 815357) Though the size has been reduced, we hope that we shall be able by means of condensation to give the same amount of information.
('10', 367, 1, 5, 815486) Our readers who are interested in the ideals we endeavour to promote can render useful service by finding subscribers for the journal which they may call their own.
('10', 367, 1, 6, 815651) It is our desire to give more varied matter as our resources increase.
('10', 367, 1, 7, 815722) It is, then, for the readers to say when they shall have a better service of news.
('10', 367, 1, 8, 815805) Indian Opinion, 1 1 1910
('10', 367, 2, 9, 815830) 200. BALANCE SHEET
('10', 367, 3, 10, 815849) Years follow one another.
('10', 367, 3, 11, 815875) At the end of each, we take stock of the community’s position.
('10', 367, 3, 12, 815938) The Transvaal satyagraha has thrown everything else into the shade.
('10', 367, 3, 13, 816006) The course of the struggle has been marked by a number of notable events.
('10', 367, 3, 14, 816080) A deputation also went to England.
('10', 367, 3, 15, 816115) Numerous have been the benefits of the struggle.
('10', 367, 3, 16, 816164) We can make the claim that the campaign has saved us from much disabling legislation in South Africa.
('10', 367, 3, 17, 816266) Several instances of this will easily occur to the reader.
('10', 367, 3, 18, 816325) The educative value of the discipline of satyagraha can never be overestimated.
('10', 367, 3, 19, 816405) Everyone can see now that carrying on this fight is in itself a kind of achievement.
('10', 367, 3, 20, 816490) The Transvaal campaign is still going on.
('10', 367, 3, 21, 816532) Quite a few Indians have weakened.
('10', 367, 3, 22, 816567) Had it not been for this fact, the struggle would have ended by now.
('10', 367, 3, 23, 816636) But the community has lost nothing by the fact that the struggle has been prolonged.
('10', 367, 3, 24, 816721) Of soul force, it may be said, the more it is employed the greater is the benefit.
('10', 367, 3, 25, 816804) Like learning, it grows through use.
('10', 367, 3, 26, 816841) The campaign has now assumed an excellent form.
('10', 367, 3, 27, 816889) In England, the volunteers have been doing very good work under the guidance of Mr. Ritch.
('10', 367, 3, 28, 816980) If the present tempo of the work is maintained for a year, consider what it will mean.
('10', 367, 3, 29, 817067) Assuming an average of £4 a week, the collection will total £208. If the signatures average 50 [a week], there will be 2,600 in all.
('10', 367, 3, 30, 817200) In fact, much more than this is likely to be achieved.
('10', 367, 3, 31, 817255) If, however, even 2,600 come to be properly informed about our struggle, it will be no small achievement.
('10', 367, 3, 32, 817361) The wider the publicity a satyagraha campaign receives the greater the admiration it wins, making its opponents feel rather crest fallen.
('10', 367, 3, 33, 817499) Mr. Polak has roused India.
('10', 367, 3, 34, 817527) As days pass, her pressure grows more vigorous.
('10', 367, 3, 35, 817575) All this shows that we stand to lose nothing because the struggle is long drawn out.
('10', 367, 3, 36, 817660) A campaign in which the
('10', 368, 0, 1, 817684) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 369
('10', 368, 1, 2, 817727) combatants have no interests of their own to serve profits them all the more by being prolonged, for they fight for the good of others, and there can be no limit to doing good to others.
('10', 368, 1, 3, 817914) From this point of view, we should not feel concerned even about those who have been suffering in gaol.
('10', 368, 1, 4, 818018) They are tested through suffering and their worth shines all the brighter.
('10', 368, 1, 5, 818093) Turning to Natal, [we find that] the condition there is pitiable.
('10', 368, 1, 6, 818159) The Natal Government has passed some laws which the community ought to oppose.
('10', 368, 1, 7, 818238) We attach little value to the minor change that has been made in the Dealers’ Act.
('10', 368, 1, 8, 818321) 1 In the matter of education, the Government has been very high handed.
('10', 368, 1, 9, 818393) Sooner or later, the Natal Indians will have no option but to take up satyagraha.
('10', 368, 1, 10, 818475) We find that the Cape Indians have been slumbering.
('10', 368, 1, 11, 818527) There has not been any new legislation to speak of in the Cape, but the community is growing weaker day by day.
('10', 368, 1, 12, 818639) Trade is no longer in Indian hands.
('10', 368, 1, 13, 818675) The community has failed to profit by the favourable conditions there; otherwise, the Cape Indians are in a position to do fine work not only in the Cape but in the whole of South Africa.
('10', 368, 1, 14, 818863) In Delagoa Bay, Indians have been gradually losing their rights.
('10', 368, 1, 15, 818928) The Portuguese authorities have been tightening the screw on them at the instance of the British.
('10', 368, 1, 16, 819026) We put it to the community that they will lose nothing by resisting the tyranny of the Government.
('10', 368, 1, 17, 819125) They must do so for the good name of the community.
('10', 368, 1, 18, 819177) Their duty, too, requires the same thing.
('10', 368, 2, 19, 819219) [From Gujarati] Indian Opinion, 1 1 1910
('10', 368, 3, 20, 819260) 201. COLLECTOR’S ASSASSINATION
('10', 368, 4, 21, 819291) There was a cable report in last week’s papers about a Collector named Jackson 2 having been assassinated near Nasik.
('10', 368, 4, 22, 819409) There are some Indians who hope to terrorize the British by such acts.
('10', 368, 4, 23, 819480) What they are doing is a grave matter.

('10', 371, 3, 8, 824690) 204. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, C. S. A. R. 1
('10', 371, 4, 9, 824736) [JOHANNESBURG, January 4, 1910] I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 2 of the 30th ultimo, in reply to my letter addressed to the Honourable the Colonial Secretary and dated the 23rd ultimo, 3 with respect to the Regulations affecting Natives and Asiatics.
('10', 371, 4, 10, 825016) Whilst my Association is grateful to you for your exhaustive, courteous and conciliatory reply, I venture to point out that the spirit of my communication has been missed.
('10', 371, 4, 11, 825188) My Association is aware of the existence of departmental regulations or instructions prior to the publication thereof in the Gazette 4. If I may venture to say so, the instructions were a result of co operation on the part of the community represented by my Association, and undoubtedly a proof of the amicable relationship that has hitherto existed between the Railway Administration and British Indians; but the legalising of these instructions gives the impression that the Administration is not satisfied with the spirit of forbearance and co operation shown by them.
('10', 371, 4, 12, 825760) My Association has never resented the separate accommodation provided in the respective classes and the affixing of the “reserved” labels.
('10', 371, 4, 13, 825899) My Association has, however, never assented to the position that the Indian community should be deprived of facilities for travelling by express trains.
('10', 371, 4, 14, 826052) As you are aware, the present bitter and exhausting Asiatic struggle going on in the Colony is due to legal inequality and
('10', 371, 5, 15, 826175) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was sent over the signature of the Chairman, British Indian Association.
('10', 371, 5, 16, 826295) 2 Reproduced in Indian Opinion, 8 1 1910; vide “The Transvaal Railway Regulation”, “The Transvaal Railway Regulations”, 8 1 1910 & “The Transvaal Railway Regulations”, 8 1 1910. 3 Vide “Substance of Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 23 12 1909.
('10', 371, 6, 17, 826537) 4 Of 17 12 1909
('10', 372, 0, 1, 826553) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 373
('10', 372, 1, 2, 826596) differentiation, andnot to departmental differentiation, which Asiatics have held to be justifiable, owing to the existence of colour prejudice in the Colony.
('10', 372, 1, 3, 826755) The Railway Board, in legalising the Regulations, have ignored the struggle, and accentuated a situation against which my Association has been fighting.
('10', 372, 1, 4, 826908) It is difficult for my Association to give an opinion as to whether legal power is required by the Administration in order to deal with the Natives, but, so far as British Indians are concerned, perhaps it will be admitted that such power is not necessary.
('10', 372, 1, 5, 827165) My Association, therefore, ventures to trust that the Regulations will be withdrawn in so far as they affect British Indians.

('10', 374, 7, 13, 831290) 206. LETTER TO J. C. GIBSON 2
('10', 374, 8, 14, 831320) JOHANNESBURG, January 6, 1910
('10', 374, 9, 15, 831350) DEAR MR. GIBSON, I enclose herewith a memorandum, showing what would finally close the bitter and exhausting Asiatic struggle that is now going on in the Colony.
('10', 374, 9, 16, 831512) It has been brought to my notice that the Indian community is being charged with two things: firstly, that British Indians have continually shifted their ground as to their demands; secondly, that the movement here is entirely engineered and controlled from India.
('10', 374, 10, 17, 831777) 1 “Transvaal Notes”, Indian Opinion, 1 1 1910, had indicated: “Mr. Jahangir Petit has cabled Mr. Gandhi £400 from Bombay.” 2 This letter and the statement were the outcome of the interview which the Rev.
('10', 374, 10, 18, 831981) Charles Phillips and J. C. Gibson had with Gandhiji on 6th January 1910, following their conversation with Lord Selborne, High Commissioner of the Transvaal.
('10', 374, 10, 19, 832139) Vide their letter dated 7 1 1910 to Lord Selborne, reproduced in Indian Opinion, 10 12 1910.
('10', 375, 0, 1, 832232) 376 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 375, 1, 2, 832274) As to the first, here are a few facts.
('10', 375, 1, 3, 832313) About the month of September, 1907, that is to say, before imprisonments had commenced and the compromise was effected, a public document 1
('10', 375, 2, 4, 832453) was addressed to the Colonial Secretary, signed by several thousand lndians, in which occurs the following sentence: “We respectfully submit that nothing short of total repeal of the Act can meet the difficult situation that has arisen.” So that repeal of the Act was the goal always aimed at.
('10', 375, 2, 5, 832747) Total repeal at the time or at any time before the passing of the second Registration Act would have restored legal equality under the Immigration Act.
('10', 375, 2, 6, 832899) When the compromise was effected 2, I contend that repeal against voluntary registration was definitely promised.
('10', 375, 2, 7, 833013) This promise was alluded to by General Smuts in his Richmond speech 3 two days after the compromise.
('10', 375, 2, 8, 833114) He stated that the Asiatics had asked for repeal, and that he had told the leaders that, until every Asiatic was registered, he would not repeal the Act.
('10', 375, 2, 9, 833268) When I was assaulted, a document 4 for publication was drawn as between Mr. Chamney and myself, to the effect that the Act would be repealed if voluntary registration was completed to the satisfaction of the authorities.
('10', 375, 2, 10, 833489) At the meeting of the Executive Council, after the burning of the certificates, a compromise became impossible because the essential point of repeal, namely, legal equality as to immigration, was not granted; and a final settlement was not arrived at in London only because of this point remaining undecided.
('10', 375, 2, 11, 833798) The following is Mr. Duncan’s 5 testimony—and Mr. Duncan ought to know what he is speaking about—to the effect that we have never shifted the ground.
('10', 375, 2, 12, 833948) Writing in the month of February last in the State 6, Mr. Duncan said:
('10', 375, 3, 13, 834019) The position of the Indian leaders is that they will tolerate no law which does not put them on an equality with Europeans in regard to restriction on immigration.
('10', 375, 3, 14, 834183) They are willing to see the number of Asiatics limited by administrative action.
('10', 375, 3, 15, 834264) They insist on equality in the terms of the law itself.
('10', 375, 3, 16, 834320) In this article, Mr. Duncan has examined the charge of shifting,
('10', 375, 4, 17, 834385) 1 Vide “Monster Petition”, before 21 9 1907.

('10', 376, 1, 4, 835020) Indeed, it is common knowledge among those who have at all understood the agitation here that the complaint was that India was not sufficiently awakened to the national importance of the struggle going on here.
('10', 376, 1, 5, 835231) Hence it was that Mr. Polak was sent.

('10', 377, 2, 8, 837718) 207. SPEECH AT DINNER TO JOSEPH ROYEPPEN AND OTHERS 1
('10', 377, 3, 9, 837772) [JOHANNESBURG, January 7, 1910]
('10', 377, 4, 10, 837804) Mr. Gandhi, in proposing the toast of “The Guests”, explained their motive in coming to the Colony—one, simply, of vindicating their national honour.
('10', 377, 4, 11, 837954) They were here to hearten their own people by going themselves through the mill of suffering.
('10', 377, 4, 12, 838048) Many of them there knew what the ordeal was, and it had, of course, yet to be seen how far the new recruits could bear it.
('10', 377, 4, 13, 838171) He would acknowledge that they could no longer boast that they numbered hundreds upon hundreds who were prepared to suffer.
('10', 377, 4, 14, 838295) Some 2,500 had gonethrough gaol, and many of these felt unable to return.
('10', 377, 4, 15, 838369) He did not blame those who broke down—such persons were to be found in every struggle.
('10', 377, 4, 16, 838456) This, however, he could say that the best of his people had simply been steeled by their suffering, and that whether the struggle lasted for months or years, it could continue until either they died or it succeeded.
('10', 377, 4, 17, 838672) Personally, he had no doubt about the result.
('10', 377, 4, 18, 838718) Whether the ordeal was longer or shorter was, in his view, comparatively unimportant.
('10', 377, 4, 19, 838804) The thing to be thankful for was that it was proved they had in their midst a considerable residue of men showing unbreakable spirit in defence of a moral principle.
('10', 377, 4, 20, 838970) Mr. Gandhi proceeded to instance the Mohammedan priest 2, “a man softly

('10', 378, 3, 9, 840719) 208. LIBERTY
('10', 378, 4, 10, 840732) Liberty consists in being able to obey our own will and conscience rather than the will and conscience of others.—Lord Hugh Cecil at the Edinburgh University Associated Societies.
('10', 378, 4, 11, 840912) It has often been said that the struggle at present going on in the Transvaal is a fight for liberty.
('10', 378, 4, 12, 841014) Judging it according to the definition quoted above, our countrymen in the Transvaal are truly fighting for liberty and that should, therefore, command universal sympathy.
('10', 378, 4, 13, 841186) Lord Hugh Cecil, in elaborating the definition he gave, said:
('10', 378, 5, 14, 841248) The true ground for maintaining liberty is that, without it, there cannot be in any true sense virtue or righteousness.
('10', 378, 5, 15, 841368) Virtue does not consist in doing right, but in choosing to do right.
('10', 378, 5, 16, 841437) This is the great distinction between the animal and man.
('10', 378, 5, 17, 841495) The Transvaal Indians are exercising the power to obey their will and conscience rather than the will of the State which is in conflict with theirs.
('10', 378, 5, 18, 841644) Any man who subordinates his will to that of the State surrenders his liberty and thus becomes a slave.

('10', 380, 2, 6, 844940) The main and only point at issue is that, whereas the regulations, before they were gazetted, were simply in the nature of departmental instructions and had not the force of law, they are today part of the laws of the Colony, and, as they lay down the principle of legal inequality, it is the duty of the Indian community of the Transvaal to combat the evil with all its might.
('10', 380, 2, 7, 845318) Separate accommodation on the Railways and kindred matters cannot be a subject of legislation, but can only be regulated by the good sense of the communities concerned and by voluntary co operation.
('10', 380, 2, 8, 845517) Immediately that state of things is changed, it becomes a usurpation of authority, which should be resisted by all lawful means.
('10', 380, 2, 9, 845646) We use the term “lawful” in the sense well known to the readers of this journal, passive resistance, in our opinion, being a strictly lawful method of seeking redress.

('10', 381, 5, 17, 847505) We gave last week translations of Reuter’s cables 1 about the Indian [National] Congress.
('10', 381, 5, 18, 847595) The discussion at the Congress on Lord Morley’s Act has made us sorry.

('10', 381, 5, 20, 847855) It is rather risky to comment on the basis of cable reports.
('10', 381, 5, 21, 847916) It would not be surprising if those who wish to divide the two communities send one sided reports; all the same, it will not be wrong if we proceed to discuss the matter on the assumption that the Reuter reports are correct.
('10', 381, 5, 22, 848141) The first error that we notice is the assumption that Lord Morley’s legislation can embitter the relations between the two
('10', 381, 6, 23, 848264) 1 According to the cable report reproduced in Indian Opinion, 1 1 1910, the President, in the course of his address, said that the grant of excessive representation to the Mahomedans on the new Provincial Councils had caused, as it was intended to cause, an estrangement between the Hindus and the Mahomedans which could not be healed for years to come.

('10', 386, 2, 5, 856855) 219. ETHICS OF HAWKING
('10', 386, 3, 6, 856878) Messrs Samuel Joseph, David Andrew and Manilal Gandhi, the new recruits who have gone to the Transvaal to join the struggle, have now for some time been going about as fruit or vegetable hawkers.
('10', 386, 3, 7, 857074) We understand that Mr. Royeppen will presently follow his companions.
('10', 386, 3, 8, 857144) This hawking is by no means fancy hawking.
('10', 386, 3, 9, 857187) It has been undertaken in right earnest and in the spirit of bona fide hawkers.
('10', 386, 3, 10, 857267) These young men go from house to house and try to sell their fruit or vegetables, as the case may be, at a small profit which goes to swell the passive resistance funds.
('10', 386, 3, 11, 857437) It is necessary to examine the reasons which have induced them to take up hawking.
('10', 386, 3, 12, 857520) When Mr. Essop Mia and Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeertook to it eighteen months ago, they did so purely to court imprisonment and set an example to the other hawkers.
('10', 386, 3, 13, 857682) This motive must always be with passive resisters in the Transvaal.
('10', 386, 3, 14, 857750) But it is not all in the present case.
('10', 386, 3, 15, 857789) The majority of free Indians throughout South Africa are either hawkers or petty traders.
('10', 386, 3, 16, 857879) Now, passive resistance is not a weapon merely to defend others but it is a weapon to use for self defence also.
('10', 386, 3, 17, 857992) It is a weapon that can be used independently of anybody else and by one individual as effectively as by many.
('10', 386, 3, 18, 858103) This power flows from the very nature of passive resistance.
('10', 386, 3, 19, 858164) The force wielded by the soul within is the mightiest among the mighty forces of nature.
('10', 386, 3, 20, 858253) Physical force is wrongly considered to be used to protect the weak.
('10', 386, 3, 21, 858322) As a matter of fact, it still further weakens the weak; it makes them dependent upon their so called defenders or protectors.
('10', 386, 3, 22, 858448) Soul force strengthens those on whose behalf it is exerted as well as those who exert it.
('10', 386, 3, 23, 858538) The Transvaal struggle is intended to teach the majority of Indians the use of this magnificent force so as to make them truly independent men.
('10', 386, 3, 24, 858682) If passive resistance had been initiated by the hawkers instead of the merchants, the former would today occupy a unique position.
('10', 386, 3, 25, 858813) As it is, many of them, being cowed down, are no longer in the struggle.
('10', 386, 3, 26, 858886) This deplorable result is due to a want of real leaders among the hawkers themselves.
('10', 386, 3, 27, 858972) They would far sooner
('10', 387, 0, 1, 858994) 388 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 387, 1, 2, 859036) listen to and understand one from among themselves than one who may be considered above them.
('10', 387, 1, 3, 859130) In order to rectify this defect in the wonderful campaign that is now going on in the Transvaal, schoolmasters and clerks are turning their attention to hawking.
('10', 387, 1, 4, 859292) Moreover, the Government probably intend to starve the new recruits out of the Transvaal.
('10', 387, 1, 5, 859382) They reply by hawking in order to earn their livelihood in that Colony.
('10', 387, 1, 6, 859454) Nor is this all.
('10', 387, 1, 7, 859471) It is at least debatable whether the profession of a clerk or book keeper is better or more respectable than that of a hawker.
('10', 387, 1, 8, 859598) A hawker is an independent man.
('10', 387, 1, 9, 859630) He has opportunity of studying human nature which a clerk slaving away for a few pounds per month can never have.
('10', 387, 1, 10, 859744) A hawker is master of his own time.
('10', 387, 1, 11, 859780) A clerk has practically no time he can call his own.
('10', 387, 1, 12, 859833) A hawker, if he chooses, has opportunity for expansion of his intellect which a clerk cannot dream of.
('10', 387, 1, 13, 859936) And what applies to the clerk applies more or less even to schoolmasters who teach for a living and not for the sake of it; and it applies certainly to the legal profession which is beset with temptations which an ordinary man would do well to avoid.
('10', 387, 1, 14, 860187) These young men, then, can do a great deal to purge the profession of hawking of its grossness and raise it to a higher level.
('10', 387, 1, 15, 860314) The hawkers are only waiting for one to rise among themselves who would lead the way to a better and purer life.
('10', 387, 1, 16, 860427) And just as they set a noble example to the professional hawkers, so they do to the clerks and schoolmasters, and, shall we say, lawyers and doctors who are weary of their vocations and who, if they could only see the way, would leave the drudgery of the desks that grinds them body and soul.
('10', 387, 1, 17, 860720) Last but not least, it seems to us that, after all, nature has intended man to earn his bread by manual labour—“by the sweat of his brow” —and intended him to dedicate his intellect not towards multiplying his material wants and surrounding himself with enervating and soul destroying luxuries, but towards uplifting his moral being—towards knowing the will of the Creator—towards serving humanity and thus truly serving himself.
('10', 387, 1, 18, 861150) If so, the profession of hawking, or, better still, simple agriculture or such other calling, must be the highest method of earning one’s livelihood.
('10', 387, 1, 19, 861300) And do not the millions do so?
('10', 387, 1, 20, 861331) No doubt many follow nature unconsciously.
('10', 387, 1, 21, 861374) It remains for those who are endowed with more than the ordinary measure of intellect to copy the millions consciously and use their intellect for uplifting their fellow labourers.
('10', 387, 1, 22, 861555) No longer will it then be
('10', 388, 0, 1, 861581) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 389
('10', 388, 1, 2, 861624) possible for the intellectuals in their conceit to look down upon the “hewers of wood and drawers of water”.
('10', 388, 1, 3, 861733) For, of such is the world made.
('10', 388, 1, 4, 861765) We, therefore, congratulate our young friends on their laudable work and hope that even after the struggle is over, they will continue to labour with their hands and feet, so far as their maintenance is concerned, and devote their talent to the service of their country both of birth and origin.
('10', 388, 1, 5, 862061) Indian Opinion, 15 1 1910
('10', 388, 2, 6, 862087) 220. HOSKEN’S MEETING

('10', 406, 2, 8, 900034) 236. INDIAN TRADERS
('10', 406, 3, 9, 900054) There is among us a story about a lazy man.
('10', 406, 3, 10, 900098) Once the house in which he lived caught fire.
('10', 406, 3, 11, 900144) They tried hard to induce the indolent fellow to do something to put out the fire or flee from the house.
('10', 406, 3, 12, 900250) He paid no heed and so was burnt to death.
('10', 406, 3, 13, 900293) That is the state [of mind] of the Indian trader; in fact, of every Indian in South Africa, but especially of the trader.
('10', 406, 3, 14, 900415) The Cape newspapers are presently carrying on a campaign against the Indian traders.
('10', 406, 3, 15, 900500) There is a clamour for measures against them through the Union Parliament which would finish them.
('10', 406, 3, 16, 900599) The demand is supported by the Advertiser in Natal and the Sunday Times of Johannesburg.
('10', 406, 3, 17, 900688) One of the newspapers 1 has published a remarkable contribution.
('10', 406, 3, 18, 900753) We give [elsewhere] a literal translation of it.

('10', 408, 3, 15, 904884) 238. PARIS HAVOC
('10', 408, 4, 16, 904901) Nature works unceasingly according to her laws, but man violates them constantly.
('10', 408, 4, 17, 904983) In different ways and at different times, Nature tells man that there is nothing in the world which is not subject to change.
('10', 408, 4, 18, 905109) It is hardly necessary to give illustrations.
('10', 408, 4, 19, 905155) As Mr. Malabari 1
('10', 408, 5, 20, 905173) says in a poem of his: “They come but to leave.” We sing in a gazal 2: “How many fairy like creatures there have been, graced with youth, how great the men who left.” And yet every extraordinary occurrence startles us and sets us thinking.
('10', 408, 5, 21, 905413) There has been one such in Paris.
('10', 408, 5, 22, 905447) The river at Paris rose in such a heavy flood that huge buildings were washed off.
('10', 408, 5, 23, 905530) A picture gallery 3 was in imminent danger.
('10', 408, 5, 24, 905574) Strongly built roads, on which millions of pounds had been spent, sagged at places.
('10', 408, 5, 25, 905658) Men were drowned.
('10', 408, 5, 26, 905676) Some who escaped drowning were buried alive.
('10', 408, 5, 27, 905721) Rats, deprived of their food, attacked children.
('10', 408, 5, 28, 905770) How did this happen?
('10', 408, 5, 29, 905791) The people of Paris had built the city to last for ever.
('10', 408, 5, 30, 905848) Nature has given a warning that even the whole of Paris may be destroyed.
('10', 408, 5, 31, 905922) It certainly would have been, had the floods subsided a day later.
('10', 408, 6, 32, 905989) 1 Behramji Malabari (1863 1912), a Parsi journalist, poet and social reformer of Bombay 2 A poetic composition of Persian origin 3 The Louvre

('10', 409, 1, 2, 906173) Of course, the people of Paris will not realize the futility of rebuilding the palatial structures.

('10', 415, 1, 2, 918769) 245. EVIDENCE BEFORE INQUIRY COMMITTEE 1
('10', 415, 2, 3, 918810) KRUGERSDORP, February 17, 1910
('10', 415, 3, 4, 918841) Mr. Gandhi said that the object of making the protest was that his clients challenged the authority of the Commissioner to make any recommendation with reference to the removal of the Location.
('10', 415, 3, 5, 919035) It was his contention that as his clients had certain legal rights, apart from other rights, the Commission ws totally uncalled for as far as the removal of the Location was concerned.
('10', 415, 3, 6, 919220) His clients had prepared a statement of the valuation of their holdings, and that statement was filed under the protest mentioned.
('10', 415, 4, 7, 919351) THE CHAIRMAN: This is not a Commission but a Committee of Inquiry.
('10', 415, 5, 8, 919418) MR. GANDHI: I have observed the distinction.
('10', 415, 6, 9, 919463) The Chairman asked, was Mr. Gandhi prepared to give a statement with regard to points on which the Committee desired information.
('10', 415, 6, 10, 919593) Mr. Gandhi said he placed himself in the hands of the Committee.
('10', 415, 6, 11, 919658) He was prepared to lead evidence, or if the Committee considered a written statement more satisfactory, he would submit one.
('10', 415, 6, 12, 919783) It had been his intention to lead some evidence that morning to rebut that given at the last sitting of the Committee.
('10', 415, 7, 13, 919902) Evidence on behalf of the Municipality was then taken.
('10', 415, 7, 14, 919957) Mr. James Munsie (Chief Sanitary Inspector) said the buildings in the Location were defective from a structural point of view .
('10', 415, 7, 15, 920085) it was impossible to repair the buildings so as to make them comply with the by laws.
('10', 415, 7, 16, 920171) The residents obtained their livelihood chiefly by hawking fruits and vegetables for which there was no proper storage.
('10', 415, 7, 17, 920291) In case of infectious diseases considerable trouble would be experienced.
('10', 415, 7, 18, 920365) (To Mr. Seehoff 3:) If the Location were under Municipal control only a certain number of residents would be allowed tin houses, and overcrowding would be prevented.

('10', 417, 4, 12, 923424) 247. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, C.S.A.R. 1
('10', 417, 5, 13, 923467) [JOHANNESBURG,] February 18, 1910
('10', 417, 7, 14, 923501) In accordance with the promise made by Mr. Gandhi and myself at the interview 2 between us on Saturday last, I beg to enclose herewith draft railway regulations.
('10', 417, 7, 15, 923663) You will notice that the draft keeps the practice hitherto observed as to the travelling of Asiatics, without making any racial distinctions and thereby offering insult.
('10', 417, 7, 16, 923833) In my humble opinion, this draft can entirely replace the regulations which have been the subject matter of this correspondence; but, if it is considered by the Railway Board that these regulations are necessary so far as the Natives are concerned, I venture to suggest that they may be repealed so far as they are applicable to Asiatics.
('10', 417, 7, 17, 924172) If the draft herewith submitted is not considered suitable, I shall be glad to receive your objections, and will endeavour to meet any such by framing another draft.
('10', 417, 7, 18, 924338) In the opinion of my Committee, the matter is rather urgent, and it is felt that the regulations should be amended without waiting for the establishment of the Union Government.
('10', 417, 7, 19, 924516) My Committee gratefully appreciates the conciliatory manner in which you have been good enough to carry on this correspondence, and for the assurance given by you that no insult is intended by the publication of the regulations.
('10', 417, 7, 20, 924745) My Committee hopes that your
('10', 417, 8, 21, 924774) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by A. M. Cachalia.
('10', 417, 8, 22, 924851) 2 Report not available
('10', 418, 0, 1, 924874) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 419
('10', 418, 1, 2, 924917) assurances and the good spirit will be carried out in practice by making the necessary amendment in the regulations.
('10', 418, 2, 3, 925034) DRAFT REGULATIONS
('10', 418, 3, 4, 925052) 1. It shall be lawful for the General Manager to set apart different compartments on trains for different races or classes, and the class or race for which the compartments are so reserved shall be able to travel only in such compartments and no other, and any person travelling in a compartment other than the one reserved for his class shall be deemed to have committed a breach of these regulations.
('10', 418, 3, 5, 925455) 2. The pointing out by a guard or any other railway official to a passenger of a reserved compartment shall be considered sufficient reservation under the foregoing regulations.
('10', 418, 3, 6, 925633) 3. It shall be competent for the guard or the conductor or any other railway official to remove passengers from one compartment to another without giving any reason therefor.
('10', 418, 3, 7, 925808) 4. It shall be competent for the station master to refuse a first or second class ticket to any passenger who may be, in his opinion, not dressed in a decent or cleanly condition.

('10', 419, 7, 9, 927485) The Masonic Hall, Jeppe Street, Johannesburg, was the scene of a brilliant mixed gathering of Europeans, Chinese and Indians on the night of the 18th instant in honour of Rev.
('10', 419, 7, 10, 927661) J. J. Doke.

('10', 419, 7, 13, 927792) Mr. Doke was on his right and Mrs. Doke on his left.

('10', 419, 8, 17, 928136) When Mr. Doke and he were comparative strangers, he (the speaker) was picked up by Mr. Doke as he was lying in a precarious condition in an office in Von Brandis Street.
('10', 419, 8, 18, 928306) When Mr. Doke asked him whether he would go to his house, he did not take many seconds before he replied in the affirmative.
('10', 419, 8, 19, 928431) 2 In his house, he was treated with every kindness and consideration.
('10', 419, 8, 20, 928501) Mr. Gandhi’s mother was dead, his widowed sister was 4,000 miles away, his wife 400 miles away.
('10', 419, 8, 21, 928597) But Mrs. Doke was both mother and sister to him.
('10', 419, 8, 22, 928646) How could he forget the figure (Mr. Doke) stealing into his room at midnight to see whether his patient was awake or asleep?
('10', 419, 8, 23, 928771) Speaking of Mr. Doke’s Asiatic work, it was not possible to refrain from speaking in praise of the work of the European Committee of which the Chairman (Mr. Hosken) was the President.
('10', 419, 8, 24, 928955) Mr. Gandhi frankly confessed that passive resistance might have broken down without the magnificent support rendered by the European Committee.
('10', 419, 8, 25, 929099) Mr. Hosken never stinted himself in rendering assistance wherever and whenever he could.
('10', 419, 8, 26, 929188) He was ever obliging.
('10', 419, 8, 27, 929210) Mr. Doke had made a thorough study of the question.
('10', 419, 8, 28, 929262) His home was ever open to distressed Asiatics.
('10', 419, 8, 29, 929309) The speaker hoped that Mr. Doke would find the opportunity of seeing Lord Crewe and Lord Morley and give them

('10', 423, 1, 2, 935071) 254. SPEECH AT DURBAN MEETING 1
('10', 423, 2, 3, 935103) February 20, 1910
('10', 423, 3, 4, 935121) A letter was received from Mr. Rustomjee while this meeting was in progress, from which it appears that he has deliberately absented himself.
('10', 423, 3, 5, 935263) Of course, there is no need to read out the letter itself to the meeting; he only wants to know from those who are assembled here, where that fine spirit has evaporated which prevailed at the meetings in which he and other friends were asked to go to the Transvaal.
('10', 423, 3, 6, 935529) He also wants to know where those men are who were to accompany him.
('10', 423, 3, 7, 935598) He says, further, that going through these motions of honouring him is like playing a joke on him and that he is not eager for such honour.
('10', 423, 3, 8, 935738) He would feel truly honoured [he says] if people went to gaol as he had done.
('10', 423, 3, 9, 935816) What we are witnessing today on the stage is the action in front of the curtain, but it is the action behind it that will determine whether or not we win.
('10', 423, 3, 10, 935971) If the gentlemen 2 who made speeches today urging support for the Transvaal and paying compliments to the satyagrahis were sincere in what they said, the end of the struggle should be at hand.
('10', 423, 3, 11, 936164) It is a very simple thing to win, if only our leaders cease their play acting.
('10', 423, 3, 12, 936243) It depends on us whether our campaign ends in four days or four years.
('10', 423, 3, 13, 936314) If it is drawing out, the fault lies with us.
('10', 423, 3, 14, 936360) Every time I went wrong in my conclusion as to the end of the struggle, I found [subsequently] that the error was in my estimate of the community’s strength.
('10', 423, 3, 15, 936518) When I was leaving for this place, Mr. Aswat, Mr. Cachalia and Mr. Bhayat urged me hard to take Dawad Sheth back with me.
('10', 423, 3, 16, 936640) Everyone is inquiring what he will do now.
('10', 423, 3, 17, 936683) I have come to take along with me Dawad Sheth, Mr. Shapurji Randeria and anyone else who may come forward.
('10', 423, 3, 18, 936790) Our own men have been telling the Government that seasoned fighters are falling off and that those who have gone to Natal are not likely to return.
('10', 423, 3, 19, 936938) If so, the fight will receive a severe set back.
('10', 423, 3, 20, 936987) I hope, therefore, that the gentlemen will come forward [again] this time.
('10', 423, 3, 21, 937062) Moreover, much has been said here about unity in the
('10', 423, 4, 22, 937115) 1 A meeting of the Natal Indian Congress was held on February 20, 1910 to honour Gandhiji and Rustomjee and to pass resolutions of protest against the £3 tax, the system of indenture and the Immigration Law Amendment Bill.
('10', 423, 4, 23, 937338) 2 Among these was Dawad Mahomed, who, as Chairman of the meeting, had spoken before Gandhiji.
('10', 424, 0, 1, 937432) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 425
('10', 424, 1, 2, 937475) community.
('10', 424, 1, 3, 937486) I wish to point out in this connection that, if there is disunity among us, the fault lies entirely with the leaders of the two communities.
('10', 424, 1, 4, 937627) If they follow up their speeches about unity with determined action, it can be achieved quite easily.
('10', 424, 1, 5, 937729) It is an error to suppose that a third party can bring them together.

('10', 424, 4, 9, 937923) 255. LETTER TO COLONIAL SECRETARY 1
('10', 424, 5, 10, 937959) [JOHANNESBURG,] February 23, 1910
('10', 424, 7, 11, 937993) I have the honour to enclose herewith a copy of a letter 2
('10', 424, 8, 12, 938052) addressed by Mr. Parsee Rustomjee to the Press about the treatment he was subjected to at the Diepkloof Gaol.
('10', 424, 8, 13, 938162) I beg to append copy of medical certificate issued by his family physician as to the state of his health upon discharge from prison:
('10', 424, 9, 14, 938295) FIRST AVENUE,
('10', 424, 10, 15, 938309) DURBAN, February 16, 1910
('10', 424, 11, 16, 938335) This is to certify that I have examined Mr Parsee Rustomjee, and, knowing him of old, I now find him very much reduced in weight and size, and that his health has greatly suffered from his late imprisonment, and that it will be some months before he will regain his former self.
('10', 424, 11, 17, 938614) I find that his heart is affected, but whether it is an organic disease or not, it is difficult to say at once on the first examination.
('10', 424, 11, 18, 938751) His eyes have also suffered from constant exposure to the sun, and are now in a state of congestion.
('10', 424, 11, 19, 938852) There is distension of the flanks of the abdominal wall, which appears to me to be due to the distension of the large bowel, and which is also responsible for the constipation he suffers from.
('10', 424, 11, 20, 939045) He is also subject to delayed and difficult micturition.
('10', 424, 11, 21, 939102) (Sgd.) R. M. NANJI, M. R. C. S., etc.
('10', 424, 11, 22, 939140) Both the certificate and the letter speak for themselves.
('10', 424, 11, 23, 939198) My Committee therefore content themselves with drawing the attention of
('10', 424, 12, 24, 939270) 1 At Pretoria; presumably drafted by Gandhiji 2 Vide Appendix II.
('10', 425, 0, 1, 939336) 426 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 425, 1, 2, 939378) the Government to the facts narrated by Mr. Rustomjee, who is one of the most respected members of the Indian community in South Africa, and a vice president of the Natal Indian Congress, and venture to trust that the civilized Government of the Transvaal will not permit a repetition of sufferings such as have been undergone by Mr. Rustomjee.
('10', 425, 1, 3, 939723) Mr. Imam Abdul Kadir Bawazeer, who has been just discharged from the Diepkloof Prison, has himself suffered very severely.
('10', 425, 1, 4, 939846) He states that once, when he was extremely feverish and when he was obliged to report himself sick, the medical officer suggested, without even examining him, that he was shirking work; but when Mr. Bawazeer indignantly repudiated the suggestion, his temperature was taken by the officer, and it was found to be 104 degrees.
('10', 425, 1, 5, 940171) This alarmed the officer and Mr. Bawazeer was placed in the prison hospital.
('10', 425, 1, 6, 940248) Mr. Bawazeer has lost 22 lbs.
('10', 425, 1, 7, 940278) in weight, and is so weak that he can walk about only with difficulty.
('10', 425, 1, 8, 940349) Mr. Bawazeer reports that most of the passive resisters have lost weight owing to insufficiency of food, and specially owing to want of ghee, and this notwithstanding the allowance of two ounces of haricot beans.
('10', 425, 1, 9, 940562) It is respectfully submitted that the persistent refusal to restore the use of a fat equivalent in the shape of ghee is interpreted by my community to mean that the Government intend to starve into submission the conscientious objectors to the anti Asiatic legislation of the Colony.
('10', 425, 1, 10, 940846) I beg once more to draw attention to the fact that the Native prisoners’ dietary allows one ounce of fat per day.
('10', 425, 1, 11, 940960) Mr. Bawazeer further reports to the Association that Mr. Joseph Royeppen, a barrister and a Cambridge graduate, was, when he was transferred to the Diepkloof Prison, taken, together with three other Indian prisoners, in a manure cart, and was compelled to walk barefoot and bareheaded for nearly two miles, and that he and his fellow prisoners were given no breakfast on the day they were transferred.
('10', 425, 1, 12, 941362) Mr. Royeppen reported the matter to the Governor, who enquired into it and, Mr. Bawazeer thinks, also gave the assurance that the mistakes above referred to would not be repeated.
('10', 425, 1, 13, 941542) My Committee, however, cannot help remarking that a system under which such grave mistakes are possible must be badly in need of revision.
('10', 425, 1, 14, 941681) My Committee hope that the various matters hereby brought to
('10', 426, 0, 1, 941742) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 427
('10', 426, 1, 2, 941785) the notice of the Government will meet with the consideration that they deserves.

('10', 427, 0, 1, 943242) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 427, 1, 2, 943284) 258. STARVATION OF PASSIVE RESISTERS
('10', 427, 2, 3, 943321) We print elsewhere 1 Mr. Smuts’ minute on the complaint of the British Indian Association of the Transvaal on the insufficiency of the revised diet scale for Indian prisoners.
('10', 427, 2, 4, 943497) The minute is remarkable for the facts it omits and those it almost mis states.
('10', 427, 2, 5, 943577) It is an instance of special pleading which seeks to justify the existing unjustifiable scale of rations.
('10', 427, 2, 6, 943683) The third paragraph states that the revision was designed to approximate the Indian scale to “Indian free diets by the introduction of ghee and curry powder”.
('10', 427, 2, 7, 943842) There is a suggestion here that no ghee was supplied before revision.
('10', 427, 2, 8, 943912) But the fact is that at Johannesburg, the Volksrust and several other gaols one ounce of ghee per day was allowed to Indian prisoners besides beans three times a week and meat once a week, and that at the other gaols one ounce of animal fat per day was allowed.
('10', 427, 2, 9, 944174) In answer chiefly to the complaint that vegetarian passive resisters could not take animal fat and that, therefore, ghee should be substituted, the Government deprived the Indian prisoners throughout the Colony of fat or ghee!
('10', 427, 2, 10, 944401) In the revised scale, there is no approach to “Indian free diets” because the latter consist of a liberal supply of bread, ghee, dholl, and tea.
('10', 427, 2, 11, 944546) No Indian eats mealie meal by choice and yet it still remains largely the food of Indian prisoners.
('10', 427, 2, 12, 944646) We are not aware of any “unbiased Indian adherents” having admitted that the revised scale is an advance on the previously obtaining scale.
('10', 427, 2, 13, 944786) Indeed, they have all said that no Indian scale could be complete without ghee.
('10', 427, 2, 14, 944866) From time immemorial, ghee has been considered to be the complement of rice.
('10', 427, 2, 15, 944943) Its other name literally translated means the complement of rice (anna poorna), as rice is notoriously known to be deficient in fat forming substance.
('10', 427, 2, 16, 945094) How can deprivation of a material part of the diet be considered by any person to be an advance?
('10', 427, 2, 17, 945191) Curry powder is purely and simply a spice and in no sense a food as ghee is.
('10', 427, 2, 18, 945268) The minute makes much of twenty five medical officers having been consulted as to the revised scale.
('10', 427, 2, 19, 945369) But it makes no mention of the fact that for the past nine months, Indian prisoners have been chiefly concentrated at Diepkloof and, that, therefore, the other medical officers had not sufficient data for observation.
('10', 427, 2, 20, 945587) The acting Medical Officer of Health may have failed to find justification for the
('10', 427, 3, 21, 945670) 1 Vide “Passive Resistance Prisoners”, Indian Opinion, 26 2 1910.
('10', 428, 0, 1, 945736) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 429
('10', 428, 1, 2, 945779) allegation as to the marked “emaciation and inanition” of passive resisters.
('10', 428, 1, 3, 945856) But Messrs Rustomjee, Bawazeer, Aswat and Shah testify differently in their own persons.
('10', 428, 1, 4, 945945) Mr. Rustomjee is undergoing special medical treatment, Mr. Bawazeer can scarcely walk, Mr. Aswat is a cripple and Mr. Shah spits blood.
('10', 428, 1, 5, 946081) They all bring the news that the absence of ghee is the greatest cause of complaint.
('10', 428, 1, 6, 946166) What weight can be attached even to a whole army of medical men testifying otherwise when the victims themselves give one an ocular demonstration of the fact of insufficiency of the scale?
('10', 428, 1, 7, 946355) It is undoubtedly a matter for thankfulness that beans are added to the scale when Indians do not take meat.
('10', 428, 1, 8, 946464) But the minute takes no note of the fact that, whilst beans are an admirable substitute for meat, they are no substitute for ghee.
('10', 428, 1, 9, 946595) We cannot, therefore, help saying that the civilized Government of the Transvaal must labour under the charge of wanton cruelty to the passive resisters so long as they callously continue to partially starve them.
('10', 428, 2, 10, 946809) Indian Opinion, 26 2 1910
('10', 428, 3, 11, 946835) 259. THE NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS
('10', 428, 4, 12, 946866) The Natal Indian Congress has, at a public meeting called for the purpose, passed a series of resolutions 1 which are important and farreaching in their results.
('10', 428, 4, 13, 947028) The most notable resolutions, to our mind, were those relating to the stoppage of indenture altogether and the carrying on of the Transvaal struggle.
('10', 428, 4, 14, 947178) Both these resolutions affirm great principles without in any way involving the self interest of the movers and seconders of the resolutions.
('10', 428, 4, 15, 947320) They, therefore, impart to the proceedings a high tone.
('10', 428, 4, 16, 947376) The resolutions may not produce any great and tangible result in the near future, but they are bound to affect the course of events both in the Transvaal and outside it.
('10', 428, 4, 17, 947546) It will certainly be admitted that both resolutions are of the highest Imperial importance.

('10', 429, 5, 14, 948679) He will not sing “God Save the King”.

('10', 429, 5, 16, 948772) The reason for this outburst of anger is natural and justifiable.
('10', 429, 5, 17, 948838) The partial disfranchisement of the Coloured people in the South Africa Act has gone deep down into the hearts of thousands of Coloured people.
('10', 429, 5, 18, 948982) For them to take part in the approaching rejoicings would undoubtedly be a mockery and a sham.
('10', 429, 5, 19, 949077) It would be hypocrisy, pure and simple.
('10', 429, 5, 20, 949117) It may be questioned whether the sentiments expressed by Dr. Abdurahman are consistent with loyalty.
('10', 429, 5, 21, 949218) The word “loyalty” is a much abused term.
('10', 429, 5, 22, 949260) It would certainly be inconsistent with the loyalty of a coward or a slave.
('10', 429, 5, 23, 949336) But we hold that a free man—an enlightened and independent man—which we think Dr. Abdurahman is, can consistently with his loyalty to the Crown, which is an ideal, refuse to associate himself with rejoicings which involve the degradation of a whole people who have deserved by common consent a better treatment.
('10', 429, 5, 24, 949648) In courageously expressing his sentiments, we think that

('10', 432, 8, 22, 955089) 266. SPEECH AT DURBAN INDIAN SOCIETY 2
('10', 432, 9, 23, 955128) February 26, 1910
('10', 432, 10, 24, 955146) An unusually interesting and representative gathering of Indians was held, under the aegis of the Durban Indians’ Society, at their hall, 104, Queen Street, Durban, on Saturday, the 26th ultimo.
('10', 432, 10, 25, 955341) The hall was packed to its utmost capacity, and the meeting was of a very orderly nature.
('10', 432, 10, 26, 955431) Deshabandhu Dawad Mahomed was voted to the chair, and amongst those present were Deshabhaktar M. K. Gandhi, Deshabandhus U. M. Shelat and Nanalal Shah, of passive resistance fame.
('10', 432, 10, 27, 955611) The Secretary, Desh.
('10', 432, 10, 28, 955632) A. D. Pillay, welcomed the veteran passive resisters.
('10', 432, 11, 29, 955686) 1 Vide “Indian Education”, 26 2 1910
('10', 432, 12, 30, 955723) 2 A brief report was published in Indian Opinion, 5 3 1910.
('10', 433, 0, 1, 955783) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 433, 1, 2, 955825) T. A. Soobramania Achary, who has decided to join the Transvaal Indian struggle, then addressed the gathering in Tamil.
('10', 433, 1, 3, 955945) Deshabhaktar M. K. Gandhi and other passive resisters were then garlanded.
('10', 433, 1, 4, 956020) Deshabhaktar M. K. Gandhi rose to reply amidst loud cheers.
('10', 433, 1, 5, 956080) He said that all the speeches had greatly impressed him.
('10', 433, 1, 6, 956137) He suggested that Mr. Naicker should join the passive resistance struggle.
('10', 433, 1, 7, 956212) He proceeded to say that the struggle was being carried on as strongly as ever, and feelings of determination were still being manifested.
('10', 433, 1, 8, 956351) Passive resistance was bound to win, for it was for a noble and righteous cause, and the Indians had resolved to endure it to a finish, though they might be tormented and tortured.
('10', 433, 1, 9, 956532) The Transvaal Government had resorted to a treacherous measure of attaching buildings, goods, bedsteads, and crockery to recover the fines, but that could not divert the Indians from their line of action, and the resolution of the Boksburg Indians, who preferred to lose all their property, and choose the gaol, was sufficient proof of their earnestness.
('10', 433, 1, 10, 956887) He read certain letters which he had received from Desh.
('10', 433, 1, 11, 956944) P. K. Naidoo, which were of public interest; and he referred to the brave stand made by him, although he was repeatedly lodged in gaol.
('10', 433, 1, 12, 957080) His action, he said, was worth emulating.
('10', 433, 1, 13, 957122) He further added that the struggle was not confined to the sterner sex alone, but the feebler sex also evinced a great deal of interest.
('10', 433, 1, 14, 957259) Their action in allowing their husbands to participate in the national struggle, which was also a struggle for equity and justice, bore evidence of the women’s valour.
('10', 433, 1, 15, 957427) These women had also endured untold privations.
('10', 433, 1, 16, 957475) He then read a telegram 1 received from India with reference to the stoppage of the Indian indentures to Natal, in which it was stated that if the Transvaal and the Natal Governments refrained from ill treating the Indians, and the indentured Indians themselves received better treatment, then indenture might be resumed.
('10', 433, 1, 17, 957797) M. K. Gandhi did not approve of the conditional suspension of the indenture, but he said that complete abolition of indenture to these Colonies was necessary.
('10', 433, 1, 18, 957956) U. M. Shelat then addressed the assembly.
('10', 433, 1, 19, 957998) Nanalal Shah followed, and gave a vivid description of the harsh treatment which he received during his gaol experience.

('10', 434, 7, 19, 959740) 268. THE INDIAN COUNCIL AND INDENTURED LABOUR
('10', 434, 8, 20, 959786) The Hon’ble Professor Gokhale and his colleagues have rendered a service to us and to India generally (as also, we are inclined to think, the Colony) by their having moved the resolution to stop indentured emigration from India to Natal.
('10', 434, 8, 21, 960024) The resolution seeks to stop indenture by way of penalty for non redress of the grievances of the free Indian population of South Africa.
('10', 434, 8, 22, 960162) We wish that Professor Gokhale had or could have taken up the highest standpoint and moved for the stoppage of indenture altogether as being inherently bad and of no real benefit to the indentured men themselves.
('10', 434, 8, 23, 960375) There is a weakness in the resolution which it would be useless not to
('10', 434, 9, 24, 960446) 1 Supplied from the report of the speech in Indian Opinion
('10', 435, 0, 1, 960505) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 435, 1, 2, 960547) acknowledge.
('10', 435, 1, 3, 960560) If indenturing be good for the indentured men themselves, those who wish to indenture should not be prevented from taking advantage of the system for the sake of benefiting the free Indian population of Natal or the sister colonies.
('10', 435, 1, 4, 960793) If, on the other hand, it is bad, no redress that may be granted to that population can be allowed to continue a state of things that is immoral or otherwise hurtful.
('10', 435, 1, 5, 960960) But we have to be thankful for small mercies in these days of compromise and expediency.
('10', 435, 1, 6, 961049) Professor Gokhale has taken the lesser step because he knows that he may not carry the Government with him in his condemnation of the system of indenture as such.
('10', 435, 1, 7, 961212) It is for us here to see to it that we accept no immoral bargains.
('10', 435, 1, 8, 961279) Whilst we would and should agitate for removal of general grievances and point out that Natal cannot receive the benefit (questionable though it is) of indentured labour from India, we must make it clear that we ask for the stoppage of indentured labour for its own sake and because we consider that it is detrimental to the moral well being of those who indenture.
('10', 435, 1, 9, 961645) Sir James Liege Hulett has been telling a reporter that in his opinion the movement in India is due to the agitation on behalf of the Indian traders.
('10', 435, 1, 10, 961795) This is perfectly true.
('10', 435, 1, 11, 961819) But the inference that it will die out because of the so called relief having been granted during the last session of the local Parliament is quite baseless.
('10', 435, 1, 12, 961977) We would appeal to Sir J. L. Hulett and his co planters that they should look at the question from a truly South African standpoint.
('10', 435, 1, 13, 962110) Is it impossible for them to realise that their interests are not necessarily the Colony’s and that the latter demand complete and immediate stoppage of indentured labour?
('10', 435, 1, 14, 962282) We are not sure that the Colony will be ruined if the tea and sugar industries were to disappear.
('10', 435, 1, 15, 962380) Indians have benefited the Colony through their cultivation of garden produce.
('10', 435, 1, 16, 962459) This will be continued by the free Indian population.
('10', 435, 1, 17, 962513) But the sooner the indentured labour supply isstopped, the better.
('10', 435, 1, 18, 962580) We would much rather that the Colony stopped this supply of its own motion than that it was done by the Government of India.
('10', 435, 1, 19, 962705) At the same time, it is necessary that no effort should be spared in India to bring about the much desired result, whether by way of penalty or otherwise.
('10', 435, 1, 20, 962860) Entire suspension of artificial emigration from India to Natal will go a long way towards solving many of the difficulties in South Africa.

('10', 443, 1, 2, 978092) 275. MR. TATHAM ON INDENTURED INDIANS
('10', 443, 2, 3, 978130) There seems to be a remarkable unanimity in Natal, save for the interested planters, that the importation of indentured labour should cease.
('10', 443, 2, 4, 978271) We reproduce this week extracts from Mr. Tatham’s speech 1 on the question.
('10', 443, 2, 5, 978347) We are not concerned with Mr. Tatham’s premises, some of which are faulty.
('10', 443, 2, 6, 978422) We do not share the view that competitive industrialism promotes the greatness of a nation, and that “the civilising influence” of the white man “adds to the sum of human happiness”.
('10', 443, 2, 7, 978605) His strictures on the spread of Mahomedanism betray gross ignorance.
('10', 443, 2, 8, 978674) With these views, however, as we have said, we are not concerned.
('10', 443, 2, 9, 978740) But we heartily agree with him that “it would be better that these industries (the sugar and tea) did not exist at all than that they should be supported by a form of labour that was going to bring ruin to the country”.
('10', 443, 2, 10, 978960) We also go further with Mr. Tatham and say, with him, that “these industries will not suffer for want of Asiatic labour”.
('10', 443, 2, 11, 979082) It was to be wished that Mr. Tatham had taken up the higher ground and condemned the system of indenture on merits and because of its inherent evil.
('10', 443, 2, 12, 979231) Be that, however, as it may, there can be no doubt that the importation of this servile labour into South Africa is doomed.
('10', 443, 2, 13, 979355) And with it must disappear the eternal Asiatic question.
('10', 443, 2, 14, 979412) There seems to be a fear lurking in the minds of some Indians that abolition of the indenture system may worsen the position of the resident Indian population.
('10', 443, 2, 15, 979572) We would venture to point out to such of our readers as entertain the fear, that they will not better the position of their countrymen by supporting a system they do not like.
('10', 443, 2, 16, 979748) We desire to live here not on sufference but as a matter of right and duty.
('10', 443, 2, 17, 979824) We must not mistake the references by some of the planter members of the Natal Legislature to the £3 tax as being unjust so far as the women are concerned for their desire to revolutionise their treatment of the Indian question as a whole.
('10', 443, 2, 18, 980064) They have repeatedly declared that they want our labour but not our competition in trade or other branches of industry.
('10', 443, 2, 19, 980184) They do not want to give civil or political equality.
('10', 443, 2, 20, 980238) As we have often said, civil or political equality is not a matter of gift.
('10', 443, 2, 21, 980314) We have to create a situation whereunder we can take it.
('10', 443, 2, 22, 980371) And it must be clear to any commonsense man that such a
('10', 443, 3, 23, 980427) 1 At a meeting of the Maritzburg Parliamentary Debating Society on 3 3 1910
('10', 444, 0, 1, 980503) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 445
('10', 444, 1, 2, 980546) state of things is impossible so long as servile labour pours into the Colony from India.
('10', 444, 2, 3, 980636) Indian Opinion, 12 3 1910
('10', 444, 3, 4, 980662) 276. INDENTURED INDIANS
('10', 444, 4, 5, 980686) The agitation in India for prohibiting the emigration of indentured Indians has occasioned much discussion here too in the newspapers.
('10', 444, 4, 6, 980821) Mr. Tatham, a Maritzburg lawyer, stated in a speech the other day that under the Union the import of Indian labour must stop.
('10', 444, 4, 7, 980947) He holds that the civilization of the West is superior to ours, and that it would not be quite right that the two should mingle with each other.
('10', 444, 4, 8, 981092) He asserts that we are not good enough to be allowed to associate with them.
('10', 444, 4, 9, 981169) He ends up with a few unworthy remarks about the Muslim faith, declaring that it would be best if there were no Indians in South Africa.
('10', 444, 4, 10, 981306) We need not pay any attention to this argument; it is [of course] necessary to know what it is.
('10', 444, 4, 11, 981402) However, we must accept the suggestion for stopping the import of indentured labour.
('10', 444, 4, 12, 981487) Every Indian should understand that the immigration of indentured Indians is neither in the interests of free Indians nor the labourers themselves.
('10', 444, 4, 13, 981635) It is short sighted to attach importance to the trade with indentured labourers and the moderate profits some of us make out of the import of foodgrains for them.
('10', 444, 4, 14, 981798) We do not—we cannot—have much trade with them.
('10', 444, 4, 15, 981845) We shall not be allowed to import goods for them and, even if all this were possible, the resulting gain should not tempt us.
('10', 444, 4, 16, 981971) Certainly, no Indian can claim that the indentured labourer is happy.
('10', 444, 4, 17, 982041) No free Indian will be ready to put himself in his position.
('10', 444, 4, 18, 982102) The severity with whichthey are treated, even prisoners never experience.
('10', 444, 4, 19, 982176) The amount of work they are required to do, prisoners are never made to do.
('10', 444, 4, 20, 982252) When, at the end of their days of slavery, they are set free, the taint of slavery remains with them for many years.
('10', 444, 4, 21, 982369) It is certainly not desirable that a single Indian should have to live in this condition.
('10', 444, 4, 22, 982459) If the immigration of indentured Indians stops, there will be an immediate improvement in the condition of the Indians now settled in South Africa.
('10', 444, 4, 23, 982607) Our present plight is entirely due to [the whites’] fear of indentured Indians.
('10', 444, 4, 24, 982687) Following the arrival of Chinese indentured labourers in the Transvaal, the Cape Chinese found themselves in trouble and a harsh law was passed.
('10', 444, 4, 25, 982832) The whites labour under the
('10', 445, 0, 1, 982860) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 445, 1, 2, 982902) apprehension that a population of indentured Indians in South Africa will lead to a swelling in the numbers of the community.
('10', 445, 1, 3, 983028) There is only one way to remove this fear.
('10', 445, 1, 4, 983071) From every point of view, therefore, the immigration of indentured Indians must stop.
('10', 445, 2, 5, 983157) [From Gujarati]
('10', 445, 3, 6, 983173) Indian Opinion, 12 3 1910
('10', 445, 4, 7, 983199) 277. INDIAN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE
('10', 445, 5, 8, 983231) This body has recently ventured on a very commendable undertaking.
('10', 445, 5, 9, 983298) The suppliers of Nestle’s milk, Needle point cigarettes and Lion matches refuse to trade with Indians, with the result that Indian traders have to depend on the whites for these items and pay fancy prices.
('10', 445, 5, 10, 983504) It is obvious that if we had any spirit in us, these three firms could not afford to slight Indians.
('10', 445, 5, 11, 983605) Even in trade one must maintain one’s prestige and dignity.
('10', 445, 5, 12, 983665) We often neglect to do this, disregarding self respect where we expect some profit.
('10', 445, 5, 13, 983749) The Durban Indian Chamber of Commerce wants now to change all this.
('10', 445, 5, 14, 983817) It has decided to save itself both from the insults of the Nestle’s milk suppliers and the financial loss.
('10', 445, 5, 15, 983924) This is how it will be done: All the milk needed by Indians will be bought from another firm and a limited liability company will be formed to obtain the necessary supplies; the company will then supply the retail traders.
('10', 445, 5, 16, 984147) All the retailers will bind themselves not to buy Nestle’s milk but to get their supplies only from this company.
('10', 445, 5, 17, 984261) Enthusiasm runs so high at the moment that shares to the value of about £1,500 have already been subscribed and the retailers have agreed not to buy Nestle’s milk.
('10', 445, 5, 18, 984425) This is a most significant step.
('10', 445, 5, 19, 984458) If it succeeds, the Nestle’s people will realize that they cannot afford to insult Indians and the latter will discover that they can stand their ground by relying on their own strength.
('10', 445, 5, 20, 984645) Success will depend on the fulfilment of the following conditions: (1) Indians must have the necessary enthusiasm and ability for such undertakings.
('10', 445, 5, 21, 984794) (2) The leaders must be honest at least in this field of
('10', 446, 0, 1, 984851) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 447
('10', 446, 1, 2, 984894) business.
('10', 446, 1, 3, 984904) It will not do for any of them to appropriate the profits themselves to the exclusion of others, or for the company to expect big returns [on the capital].
('10', 446, 1, 4, 985060) (3) There must be unity among Indian traders.
('10', 446, 1, 5, 985106) (4) The small trader will have to be large hearted.
('10', 446, 1, 6, 985158) (5) And all Indians must have a keen sense of self respect.
('10', 446, 1, 7, 985218) If this one venture succeeds, it will pave the way for many others.
('10', 446, 1, 8, 985286) We congratulate the Indian Chamber of Commerce and its office bearers on taking this step, and wish them success in their venture.
('10', 446, 1, 9, 985417) Success, though, will depend on the work of the office bearers.

('10', 447, 0, 1, 986556) 448 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('10', 447, 3, 25, 988442) The Government, in its ignorance, cannot help resorting to repression.
('10', 447, 3, 26, 988513) Mr. Gandhi’s part in the agitation and his authorship of the book on swaraj cannot remain unconnected.
('10', 447, 3, 27, 988616) Moreover, the man who is a satyagrahi in the Transvaal agitation will be one in other situations as well.
('10', 447, 3, 28, 988722) In this way, the book on swaraj may either strengthen or weaken [the Transvaal agitation].
('10', 447, 3, 29, 988813) Those who are timid will take fright and protest that they have nothing to do with swaraj, that they do not want to invite ruin on themselves.

('10', 448, 4, 12, 989779) 280. LETTER TO M. P. FANCY
('10', 448, 5, 13, 989806) Tuesday, March 16, 1910
('10', 448, 6, 14, 989830) SHETH SHRI M. P. FANCY,
('10', 448, 7, 15, 989854) You have raised a question in connection with the interview which Moulvi Saheb Ahmed Mukhtiar had with me and which he has published.
('10', 448, 7, 16, 989988) 1 You tell me that it has been a matter of controversy among some Indians and you therefore feel that I should make a statement whether the ‘interview’ has been correctly reported or not.
('10', 448, 7, 17, 990176) I had not the least intention to do this.
('10', 448, 7, 18, 990218) The community knows me; and if it does not yet do so, it is not possible for me to introduce myself to it now.
('10', 448, 7, 19, 990329) An Indian can immediately know the truth of statements attributed to me, whether they were made by me or not.
('10', 448, 7, 20, 990439) However, in response to your request I make the following reply: I am sorry to find that, in the ‘interview’ as published by the Moulvi Saheb, the statements made by me have been twisted.
('10', 448, 7, 21, 990627) At the end of our meeting he expressed his satisfaction and told me that he had received full explanation and would render every assistance to the struggle.
('10', 448, 7, 22, 990784) Yet the twist he has given to the interview is likely to harm the struggle.
('10', 448, 7, 23, 990860) I explained to him the origin of the Satyagraha Fund.
('10', 448, 7, 24, 990914) I told him
('10', 448, 8, 25, 990925) 1 Not available
('10', 449, 0, 1, 990941) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 449, 1, 2, 990983) about the letter 1 I had written from England to Prof.
('10', 449, 1, 3, 991038) Gokhale and the one 2 to Mr. Polak.
('10', 449, 1, 4, 991074) I informed the Moulvi Saheb that in these letters I had written about the debt I had incurred in connection with Indian Opinion on account of the struggle.
('10', 449, 1, 5, 991230) I explained to him how the funds came in response to those letters.
('10', 449, 1, 6, 991298) I further told him that in my letter 3
('10', 449, 2, 7, 991337) to Prof.
('10', 449, 2, 8, 991346) Gokhale I had intimated to him that the funds would be spent to clear off the debt incurred on account of Indian Opinion, to meet the expenditure on the office of the Association as well as the office in England and to maintain the families of poor satyagrahis.
('10', 449, 2, 9, 991608) I alsoinformed him of Prof.
('10', 449, 2, 10, 991636) Gokhale’s letter approving the expenditure and told him that, though Prof.
('10', 449, 2, 11, 991711) Gokhale as well as Mr. Petit had left it to me to decide how the funds were disposed of, I had no intention of spending the money solely according to my discretion.
('10', 449, 2, 12, 991876) I informed him that I consulted Mr. Cachalia and other satyagrahis in the management of the funds, that a separate account had been opened for the fund and that a statement of all the disbursements would be published at the end of the struggle; and that even now Prof.
('10', 449, 2, 13, 992145) Gokhale was kept posted about how the money was spent.
('10', 449, 2, 14, 992200) 4 And the Moulvi Saheb expressed complete satisfaction.
('10', 449, 2, 15, 992256) About travelling third class, I told the Moulvi Saheb that I did not for the present advise other Indians to travel third, but so far as I myself was concerned I had decided to travel third for the following reasons: (1) The Transvaal Railway Regulations had come into force.
('10', 449, 2, 16, 992532) (2) Money was being spent from the Satyagraha Fund.
('10', 449, 2, 17, 992584) (3) I had become poor and so had other satyagrahis.
('10', 449, 2, 18, 992636) (4) My present state of mind favoured such travelling.
('10', 449, 2, 19, 992691) (5) I shuddered to read the account of the hardships that the Kaffirs had to suffer in the third class carriages in the Cape and I wanted to experience the same hardships myself.
('10', 449, 2, 20, 992870) (6) When I was arrested in Natal in connection with the Poll Tax, I thought I could serve [the community] better if I lived like a poor Indian.

('10', 450, 1, 2, 993201) In spite of this explanation of mine, the Moulvi Saheb thought that it was a mistake on my part, similar to the one I had committed in giving finger prints, to have begun to travel third.
('10', 450, 1, 3, 993389) Upon this, I told him that I did not believe that I had committed a mistake in giving finger prints and that I had taken the right step in travelling third.
('10', 450, 1, 4, 993546) I, moreover, made it clear to him that I was not always going to travel third.
('10', 450, 1, 5, 993625) I also argued that it would be very expensive if the large number of Indians who came forward to be arrested travelled first or second.
('10', 450, 1, 6, 993761) As regards Swami Shri Shankeranand’s 1 views, I told him that I approved of what the Swami said at the Kathiawad Arya Mandal, viz., that those who wanted to stay together as equals should be equally strong.
('10', 450, 1, 7, 993968) I also liked Swamiji’s statement that if, of a group of four comrades, three were armed, the fourth also must arm himself.
('10', 450, 1, 8, 994091) But while saying this I told him that to me ‘arms’ meant satyagraha.
('10', 450, 1, 9, 994160) I said to him that I considered the sword powerless before a satyagrahi.

('10', 450, 1, 12, 994405) When, therefore, I saw the ‘interview’ published by him, I felt sorry for the community.

('10', 451, 1, 2, 994950) 281. INTERVIEW TO “THE STAR” 1
('10', 451, 2, 3, 994981) JOHANNESBURG, March 17, 1910
('10', 451, 3, 4, 995010) The Government have taken steps to arrest the Indians who came into the Transvaal with Mr. Gandhi on Sunday morning.
('10', 451, 3, 5, 995127) Two were arrested on Monday, six on Tuesday, and two yesterday, and all are under order of deportation and are being taken to Pretoria to day, from where they will be deported to Natal.
('10', 451, 3, 6, 995313) All these men are either educated Indians or pre war residents, and in spite of their right of domicile or of entry by reason of education, they will, if necessary, we understand, return to Natal when the struggle ends.
('10', 451, 4, 7, 995533) Mr. Gandhi told our representative this morning that the Indians had come to Johannesburg not to assert their personal rights, but to take part in the struggle.
('10', 451, 4, 8, 995694) They will return and be re arrested at Volksrust and imprisoned.
('10', 451, 4, 9, 995759) The balance will be arrested in a few days.
('10', 451, 4, 10, 995803) Mr. Gandhi said: “I do not know why the Government do not arrest me.
('10', 451, 4, 11, 995872) I freely admit that I am instrumental in bringing these men and introducing them into the Colony, and it has really been suggested that in bringing them into the Colony I am supposed to commit a breach of the Immigration Law in that I aid and abet prohibited immigrants to enter the Colony.
('10', 451, 4, 12, 996163) Personally I do not consider these Indians to be prohibited immigrants at all.
('10', 451, 4, 13, 996242) Our struggle principally consists in suffering, and by suffering bringing the desired relief.
('10', 451, 4, 14, 996336) In Diepkloof prison there are 100 passive resisters, including Chinese, and about 36 are now awaiting deportation.”
('10', 451, 5, 15, 996452) The Star, 17 3 1910
('10', 451, 6, 16, 996472) 1, A report of this appeared also in The Natal Mercury, 18 3 1910, and it was reproduced in Indian Opinion, 19 3 1910.
