('10', 453, 1, 2, 998252) 284. MORE CRUSADERS
('10', 453, 2, 3, 998272) Mr. Gandhi took with him to the Transvaal last week 1 quite a respectable number of crusaders.
('10', 453, 2, 4, 998367) The list we publish in our columns is thoroughly cosmopolitan and representative of most of the important provinces of India.
('10', 453, 2, 5, 998493) That many colonial born Indians are coming forward to join the struggle is a healthy sign.
('10', 453, 2, 6, 998584) Apart from the strength that these recruits give to the struggle, there is no doubt that they themselves benefit very greatly in that they receive true education in the school of suffering.
('10', 453, 2, 7, 998774) The experience that the young Indians who have proceeded to the Transvaal are now gaining will stand them in good stead in after life.
('10', 453, 2, 8, 998909) We congratulate the brave men who have deliberately gone to the Transvaal to court trouble.
('10', 453, 2, 9, 999001) It was a fitting thing that a large and representative gathering of Indians saw them off at the Station 2. The Transvaal Government again disappointed the passive resisters.
('10', 453, 2, 10, 999175) The Immigration Officer would not arrest them at the border.
('10', 453, 2, 11, 999236) We take it as a splendid certificate of honesty for passive resisters.
('10', 453, 2, 12, 999307) These men entered that Colony without giving names or signatures or finger impressions.
('10', 453, 2, 13, 999395) Their identification, therefore, consisted in their own good faith.
('10', 453, 2, 14, 999463) The Government know that these resisters have no desire to serve their own ends and remain in the Colony but that they are quite ready to quit the Colony the moment the Indian demands are granted.
('10', 453, 2, 15, 999660) Yet this non arrest at the border means a great deal of waste of money and energy to the Indian community.
('10', 453, 2, 16, 999767) This is inevitable.
('10', 453, 2, 17, 999787) The Transvaal Government intend to exhaust our resources.
('10', 453, 2, 18, 999845) And we must be prepared to meet them.
('10', 453, 2, 19, 999883) This can be done simply by going forward undaunted without caring for consequences.
('10', 453, 2, 20, 999967) A passive resister must be satisfied with the right deed.

('10', 453, 4, 22, 1000051) 1 On 11 3 1910 2 The Durban Station
('10', 454, 0, 1, 1000087) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 455
('10', 454, 1, 2, 1000130) 285. INDIAN VOTERS AT THE CAPE
('10', 454, 2, 3, 1000161) A correspondent has asked us how the Indian voters should vote at the Union Parliament elections.
('10', 454, 2, 4, 1000259) It is not an easy matter to lay down any rule.
('10', 454, 2, 5, 1000306) But it is safe to say that the Indian question will not be made a party question even if the elections take place on party lines and there is no coalition Government.
('10', 454, 2, 6, 1000473) There will be men belonging to both the parties who would generally sympathise with us.
('10', 454, 2, 7, 1000561) We would, therefore, suggest that the candidates may be asked set questions, and those who answer them favourably may receive the Indian vote, irrespective of party.
('10', 454, 2, 8, 1000727) The Indian voters should also realise that abstention should be practised without fail if no candidate be found in any constituency who would favour the Indian cause.
('10', 454, 2, 9, 1000894) The questions to be asked may be on the working of the Cape Immigration Law, the required amendment of the Dealers’ [Licenses] Act, the Transvaal struggle, and the stoppage of indentured labour in Natal.
('10', 454, 2, 10, 1001098) The last two are now properly South African questions and should engage the attention of all the public men of South Africa.
('10', 454, 2, 11, 1001223) Finally, we would suggest to the Indian voters at the Cape that they should have their own organisation which ought to be able to control the whole of the Indian vote and which should define its policy for the guidance of its members.
('10', 454, 2, 12, 1001458) The candidates will not listen to individual voters, but a body with the whole Indian vote behind it cannot but command attention.
('10', 454, 3, 13, 1001589) Indian Opinion, 19 3 1910
('10', 455, 0, 1, 1001615) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('10', 456, 1, 2, 1003216) 287. PREFACE TO “ INDIAN HOME RULE” 1
('10', 456, 2, 3, 1003254) JOHANNESBURG, March 20, 1910
('10', 456, 3, 4, 1003283) It is not without hesitation that the translation of Hind Swaraj is submitted to the public.
('10', 456, 3, 5, 1003376) A European friend 2, with whom I discussed the contents, wanted to see a translation of it and, during our spare moments, I hurriedly dictated and he took it down.
('10', 456, 3, 6, 1003540) It is not a literal translation but it is a faithful rendering of the original.
('10', 456, 3, 7, 1003620) Several English friends have read it, and whilst opinions were being invited as to the advisability of publishing the work, news was received that the original was seized in India.
('10', 456, 3, 8, 1003801) 3 This information hastened the decision to publish the translation without a moment’s delay.
('10', 456, 3, 9, 1003895) My fellow workers at the International Printing Press shared my view and, by working overtime—a labour of love,—they have enabled me to place the translation before the public in an unexpectedly short time.
('10', 456, 3, 10, 1004102) The work is being given to the public at what is practically cost price.
('10', 456, 3, 11, 1004175) But, without the financial assistance of the many Indians who promised to buy copies for themselves and for distribution, it might never have seen the light of day.
('10', 456, 3, 12, 1004340) I am quite aware of the many imperfections in the original.
('10', 456, 3, 13, 1004400) The English rendering, besides sharing these, must naturally exaggerate them, owing to my inability to convey the exact meaning of the original.
('10', 456, 3, 14, 1004545) Some of the friends who have read the translation have objected that the subject matter has been dealt with in the form of a dialogue.
('10', 456, 3, 15, 1004680) I have no answer to offer to this objection except that the Gujarati language readily lends itself to such treatment and that it is considered the best method of treating difficult subjects.
('10', 456, 3, 16, 1004871) Had I written for English readers in the first instance, the subject would have been handled in a different manner.
('10', 456, 3, 17, 1004987) Moreover, the dialogue, as it has been given, actually took place between several friends, mostly readers of Indian Opinion, and myself.
('10', 456, 3, 18, 1005124) Whilst the views expressed in Hind Swaraj are held by me, I
('10', 456, 4, 19, 1005184) 1 This appeared Indian Opinion under the captions: The Publication of “lndian Home Rule”: English Translation of the Gujarati Work: Hind Swaraj: Proscribed by the Indian Government.
('10', 456, 4, 20, 1005366) 2 Kallenbach, vide Mahadev Desai’s Preface to Hind Swaraj, 1938.
('10', 456, 5, 21, 1005431) 3 Vide “Our Publications”, 7 5 1910
('10', 457, 0, 1, 1005467) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 457, 1, 2, 1005509) have but endeavoured humbly to follow Tolstoy, Ruskin, Thoreau, Emerson and other writers, besides the masters of Indian philosophy.
('10', 457, 1, 3, 1005642) Tolstoy has been one of my teachers for a number of years.
('10', 457, 1, 4, 1005701) Those who want to see a corroboration of the views submitted in the following chapters will find it in the words of the above named masters.
('10', 457, 1, 5, 1005842) For ready reference, some of the books are mentioned in the Appendices.
('10', 457, 2, 6, 1005914) I do not know why Hind Swaraj has been seized in India.
('10', 457, 2, 7, 1005970) To me, the seizure constitutes further condemnation of the civilization represented by the British Government.
('10', 457, 2, 8, 1006081) There is in the book not a trace of approval of violence in any shape or form.
('10', 457, 2, 9, 1006160) The methods of the British Government are, undoubtedly, severely condemned.
('10', 457, 2, 10, 1006236) To do otherwise would be for me to be a traitor to Truth; to India, and to the Empire to which I own allegiance.
('10', 457, 2, 11, 1006349) My notion of loyalty does not involve acceptance of current rule or government, irrespective of its righteousness or otherwise.
('10', 457, 2, 12, 1006477) Such notion is based upon the belief—not in its present justice or morality but—in a future acceptance by Government of that standard of morality in practice which it at present vaguely and hypocritically believes in, in theory.
('10', 457, 2, 13, 1006706) But I must frankly confess that I am not so much concerned about the stability of the Empire as I am about that of the ancient civilization of India which, in my opinion, represents the best that the world has ever seen.
('10', 457, 2, 14, 1006927) The British Government in India constitutes a struggle between the Modern Civilisation, which is the Kingdom of Satan, and the Ancient Civilisation, which is the Kingdom of God.
('10', 457, 2, 15, 1007105) The one is the God of War, the other is the God of Love.
('10', 457, 2, 16, 1007162) My countrymen impute the evils of modern civilisation to the English people and, therefore, believe that the English people are bad, and not the civilisation they represent.
('10', 457, 2, 17, 1007336) My countrymen, therefore, believe that they should adopt modern civilisation and modern methods of violence to drive out the English.
('10', 457, 2, 18, 1007470) Hind Swaraj has been written in order to show that they are following a suicidal policy, and that, if they would but revert to their own glorious civilisation, either the English would adopt the latter and become Indianised or find their occupation in India gone.
('10', 457, 2, 19, 1007734) It was at first intended to publish the translation as a part of Indian Opinion, but the seizure of the original rendered such a course inadvisable.
('10', 457, 2, 20, 1007883) Indian Opinion represents the Transvaal Passive Resistance struggle and ventilates the grievances of British Indians in
('10', 457, 3, 21, 1008003) 1 Vide Appendix I to Hind Swaraj
('10', 458, 0, 1, 1008036) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 459
('10', 458, 1, 2, 1008079) South Africa generally.
('10', 458, 1, 3, 1008103) It was, therefore, thought desirable not to publish through a representative organ views which are held by me personally and which may even be considered dangerous or disloyal.
('10', 458, 1, 4, 1008280) I am naturally anxious not to compromise a great struggle by any action of mine which has noconnection with it.
('10', 458, 1, 5, 1008392) Had I not known that there was a danger of methods of violence becoming popular, even in South Africa, had I not been called upon by hundreds of my countrymen, and not a few English friends, to express my opinion on the Nationalist movement in India, I would even have refrained, for the sake of the struggle, from reducing my views to writing.
('10', 458, 1, 6, 1008737) But, occupying the position I do, it would have been cowardice on my part to postpone publication under the circumstances just referred to.
('10', 458, 1, 7, 1008877) M. K. GANDHI

('10', 458, 3, 9, 1008915) 288. LETTER TO DIRECTOR OF PRISONS 1
('10', 458, 4, 10, 1008952) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 22, 1910
('10', 458, 6, 11, 1008983) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 2 of the 19th instant in reply to my letter 3 of the 23rd ultimo addressed to the Colonial Secretary, on the subject of the treatment of Mr. Parsee Rustomjee and other matters.
('10', 458, 6, 12, 1009220) I beg to thank you for the exhaustive information given to my Association.
('10', 458, 6, 13, 1009295) As to Mr. Rustomjee’s letter 4 to the Press, he was seen leg ironed by many Indians, and the matter was reported to my Association on the very day that he was seen in that condition.
('10', 458, 6, 14, 1009478) As to the Medical Officer’s opinion, I venture to draw attention to the fact that the Medical Officer at Volksrust did prescribe a special diet for Mr. Rustomjee.
('10', 458, 6, 15, 1009641) That the language ascribed to the Medical Officer at Diepkloof by Mr. Rustomjee was used by him is beyond question, if a host of passive resisters discharged from Diepkloof are
('10', 458, 7, 16, 1009818) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was signed by A. M. Cachalia, Chairman, British Indian Association.
('10', 458, 7, 17, 1009933) 2 Reproduced in Indian Opinion, 26 3 1910
('10', 458, 8, 18, 1009975) 3 Vide “Letter to Colonial Secretary”, 23 2 1910
('10', 458, 9, 19, 1010024) 4 Vide Appendix II.
('10', 459, 0, 1, 1010044) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 459, 1, 2, 1010086) to be believed.
('10', 459, 1, 3, 1010102) Indeed, most of them have complained of unbecoming language used by that Officer.
('10', 459, 1, 4, 1010184) It was only at a later period that special instructions were issued that Mr. Rustomjee might be allowed to take exercise.
('10', 459, 1, 5, 1010306) A certificate from the family physician of Mr. Rustomjee has been produced because it became necessary to challenge the opinion of the Prison Medical Officer; and I may state that Mr. Rustomjee is still far from well, and is undergoing treatment.
('10', 459, 1, 6, 1010553) In my humble opinion, the question of the religious necessity of wearing a cap is one which Mr. Rustomjee is best able to decide.
('10', 459, 1, 7, 1010683) The gravamen of the complaint is, however, not that Mr. Rustomjee’s special cap was taken away, but that he was compelled to take it off whenever the Governor and other officers appeared, instead of being allowed to retain the cap, as was done in Volksrust and Houtpoort, where a salaam was accepted as an equivalent.
('10', 459, 1, 8, 1011001) The loss of weight complained of by Mr. Rustomjee is not during the period of incarceration at Diepkloof alone, but includes the Volksrust gaol also.
('10', 459, 1, 9, 1011151) Mr. Rustomjee was undoubtedly grateful that his obesity was reduced, but reduction took place at very great risk to his general health.
('10', 459, 1, 10, 1011287) My Association is deeply grateful for the fact that passive resisters are translated to Diepkloof in order that they may be left entirely together.
('10', 459, 1, 11, 1011435) But, if that be so, may I ask that the special provision as to the prisoners at Diepkloof receiving a visitor and being allowed to correspond only after three months may be withdrawn, and that they may be, as in other gaols which are not penal settlements, permitted to correspond every month, and to receive visitors also likewise?
('10', 459, 1, 12, 1011768) As to the sanitary services of the prison, regard being had to the special prejudices of British Indians in this matter, before passive resistance commenced, Indian prisoners were exempted from sanitary service.
('10', 459, 1, 13, 1011980) It was only after their removal to Diepkloof that this hardship was imposed upon them, and, if it is not the intention of the Government to subject passive resisters to special harassment, the Committee of my Association would once more venture to ask that this requirement may be waived.
('10', 459, 1, 14, 1012269) In his statement to the Governor of the Gaol at Johannesburg, Mr. Rustomjee undoubtedly expressed his thanks for the better treatment that was accorded to him at the Fort and the consideration
('10', 460, 0, 1, 1012462) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 461
('10', 460, 1, 2, 1012505) that was invariably shown to him by the Governor himself.
('10', 460, 1, 3, 1012563) Regarding Mr. Bawazeer, I notice that his complaint is practically admitted by the Government.
('10', 460, 1, 4, 1012658) In his case, the seriousness of the complaint lies in the fact that his disease was ignored and his complaint was pooh poohed until after the discovery that he had a high temperature.
('10', 460, 1, 5, 1012842) My Association has once more to report that the passive resisters at Diepkloof continue to send messages through discharged prisoners that they are insufficiently fed, and that the want of ghee is felt as an additional punishment.
('10', 460, 1, 6, 1013073) My Association is glad that your Department recognise the mistake made about Mr. Joseph Royeppen and his fellow prisoners having been made to walk bareheaded and barefooted and sent without any breakfast.
('10', 460, 1, 7, 1013278) In conclusion, I venture to trust that the outstanding points regarding the supply of ghee, the sanitary service and correspondence by and visitors to passive resisters will receive the attention they deserve.

('10', 460, 3, 9, 1013514) 289. JOHANNESBURG
('10', 460, 4, 10, 1013532) Wednesday [March 23, 1910]
('10', 460, 5, 11, 1013559) WRANGLE OVER KRUGERSDORP LOCATION
('10', 460, 6, 12, 1013593) The Committee on this Location has had its last meeting.
('10', 460, 6, 13, 1013650) Mr. Burger, former [Mining] Commissioner, gave evidence before it.
('10', 460, 6, 14, 1013717) Speaking with contempt and arrogance, he deposed that removal of Indians had already been decided upon before the War, and would have been carried out had the War not broken out in the meantime.
('10', 460, 6, 15, 1013912) Referring to Indians, he always used the word “coolie” in a most offensive manner.
('10', 460, 6, 16, 1013995) The gentleman stated that the Location for Indians was placed where it was because of intervention by the British Government.
('10', 460, 6, 17, 1014121) The Government then could not have done otherwise in view of the London Convention.
('10', 460, 6, 18, 1014205) If it had, the British Resident would have protested.
('10', 460, 6, 19, 1014259) Mr. Burger pointed out that, since these two difficulties no longer existed, the “coolies” must be removed immediately.
('10', 460, 6, 20, 1014379) He could not understand why for removing them an inquiry such as the present one was being held.
('10', 461, 0, 1, 1014476) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 461, 1, 2, 1014518) About the mosque, too, he was offensive and said that he did not remember what promise he had made when granting the site for it.
('10', 461, 1, 3, 1014648) He would, of course, not care to remember anything relating to “coolies”.
('10', 461, 1, 4, 1014722) He said further, replying to Mr. Seehoff, that if he had made any promise about not shifting the Location, it would have been in writing.
('10', 461, 1, 5, 1014860) The whole of this evidence is worth reading.
('10', 461, 1, 6, 1014905) Its gist is what I have given above.
('10', 461, 1, 7, 1014942) The Location is in immediate danger.
('10', 461, 1, 8, 1014979) Indians must have courage if they want to save it.
('10', 461, 1, 9, 1015030) If they refuse to move, they cannot easily be made to.
('10', 461, 1, 10, 1015085) The Location will be saved if there is unity among the Indians there; otherwise it is as good as lost.

('10', 461, 4, 13, 1015230) 290. LETTER TO T. STREENIVAS
('10', 461, 5, 14, 1015259) JOHANNESBURG, March 24, 1910
('10', 461, 6, 15, 1015288) DEAR SIR,
('10', 461, 7, 16, 1015298) You will pardon my not having written to you earlier in reply to your letter of the 20th January.
('10', 461, 7, 17, 1015396) The fact is that I have not been in Johannesburg.
('10', 461, 7, 18, 1015446) The Tamil Indians here are largely Pillays, Moodleys, Naidoos, Chettys and Padiachys.
('10', 461, 7, 19, 1015532) There are very few Tamil Brahmins.
('10', 461, 7, 20, 1015567) Some of them are Christians having been converted in South Africa, or are sons of Christian parents.
('10', 461, 7, 21, 1015668) These latter are largely sons of indentured Indians.
('10', 461, 7, 22, 1015721) The Christians are a small community, but from a material standpoint somewhat progressive.
('10', 461, 7, 23, 1015812) They have almost entirely adopted Western habits and customs.
('10', 461, 7, 24, 1015874) This, however, does not appear to have affected their love for the Motherland.
('10', 461, 7, 25, 1015953) I do not know whether the information I have given you is what you wanted.
('10', 461, 7, 26, 1016028) If you will kindly write to me further, I shall be pleased to reply to your communications.
('10', 461, 7, 27, 1016120) When the battle is won, as it is bound to be, I have no doubt that its end will have been hastened by the unexampled bravery and self sacrifice shown by the Tamil portion of the community.
('10', 461, 7, 28, 1016309) When I first landed in South Africa, there was something in them which drew me to them, but I never dreamed that they were capable of the grand pluck and capacity for suffering for the national
('10', 462, 0, 1, 1016503) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 463
('10', 462, 1, 2, 1016546) cause that they have shown.
('10', 462, 3, 3, 1016574) Yours truly, M. K. GANDHI T. STREENIVAS, ESQ.
('10', 462, 3, 4, 1016620) BARRISTER AT LAW CRITIC OFFICE KOMALESWARANPET MOUNT ROAD, MADRAS
('10', 462, 4, 5, 1016686) From a photostat of the typewritten original signed by Gandhiji: G.N. 3779
('10', 462, 5, 6, 1016761) 291. DEPORTATIONS
('10', 462, 6, 7, 1016779) The deportations of Transvaal Indians that are going on must furnish painful reading to any lover of justice.
('10', 462, 6, 8, 1016889) These deportations, when they are to Natal, are not of any very great consequence, except for their future legal effect, which we do not propose to consider at present.
('10', 462, 6, 9, 1017058) But when passive resisters are deported to India, the deportations become a very serious matter.
('10', 462, 6, 10, 1017155) They are of men who have in several cases been voluntarily registered, whose credentials are well known to the Asiatic Department, and who have even served imprisonment already as passive resisters.
('10', 462, 6, 11, 1017354) They savour very much of the process of “hunting out every Asiatic”.
('10', 462, 6, 12, 1017423) Our Johannesburg correspondent has often drawn attention to the fact that some of the persons deported are born in South Africa and some of them leave their families behind them.
('10', 462, 6, 13, 1017602) Thanks to the magnificent response from the Motherland, these families are being supported out of the passive resistance fund.
('10', 462, 6, 14, 1017729) Had the timely help not arrived, what would have been the consequence?
('10', 462, 6, 15, 1017800) Starvation would certainly have stared them in the face.
('10', 462, 6, 16, 1017857) At the risk of repeating what has been often stated in these columns, we may remind our readers that these far reaching orders take place without any judicial trial.
('10', 462, 6, 17, 1018023) The cases are administratively tried under semi secrecy.
('10', 462, 6, 18, 1018080) Against these administrative acts, there is no appeal to the Supreme Court.
('10', 462, 6, 19, 1018156) Thus, under a totally un British procedure, the liberty of a subject is taken away with a stroke of the pen.
('10', 462, 6, 20, 1018265) What is lacking in the law has been supplied by the astute subtlety of an unscrupulous Department.
('10', 462, 6, 21, 1018364) Legally, these deportations
('10', 463, 0, 1, 1018392) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 463, 1, 2, 1018434) can take place only as far as the Transvaal boundary.
('10', 463, 1, 3, 1018488) The Transvaal Government have, therefore, entered into an understanding with the Portuguese authorities (the neighbouring British Colonies would not or could not enter into such a nefarious contract), whereby passive resisters deported to the boundary of the Portuguese territories are taken up by the Portuguese Government and, without any trial, put on board a steamer going to India.
('10', 463, 1, 4, 1018875) The question naturally arises: Assuming that the Imperial Government cannot interfere with the course of the law of a self governing Colony that has received His Majesty’s sanction, why do the Imperial Government look with criminal indifference upon the smuggling away of British Indians domiciled in the Transvaal to India through Delagoa Bay?
('10', 463, 1, 5, 1019220) There is no legal justification for it.
('10', 463, 1, 6, 1019260) If, instead of a British Colony, it was a foreign state that had entered into such a compact with the Portuguese Government, it would be a breach of treaty and might even justify a declaration of war.
('10', 463, 1, 7, 1019461) Without the concurrence, then, of the Imperial Government, the Transvaal Government could not have carried out these Indian deportations.
('10', 463, 1, 8, 1019599) The Imperial Government are, therefore, party to the desolation of many an Indian home.
('10', 463, 1, 9, 1019687) The conclusion is irresistible that the Central Government has abdicated its primary function of protecting British subjects against British subjects.
('10', 463, 1, 10, 1019838) It is paralysed before the might of the Transvaal Government.
('10', 463, 1, 11, 1019900) It is unable to shield the weak from oppression by the strong.
('10', 463, 1, 12, 1019963) It exists to strengthen the tyranny of tyrants.
('10', 463, 1, 13, 1020011) This is a tragical conclusion; but it is inevitable.
('10', 463, 1, 14, 1020064) Let the Imperialists of South Africa ponder well over the facts we have given above, and ask themselves whether the conclusion we have drawn is not warranted by them.
('10', 463, 2, 15, 1020231) Indian Opinion, 26 3 1910
('10', 463, 3, 16, 1020257) 292. KRUGERSDORP LOCATION COMMITTEE
('10', 463, 4, 17, 1020293) The evidence of Mr. Burger given before the Location Committee is remarkable for its frankness, callousness and impertinence.
('10', 463, 4, 18, 1020419) We are unable to endorse the congratulations offered by the Committee to Mr. Burger for his so called valua ble evidence.
('10', 463, 4, 19, 1020541) Mr. Burger has forfeited all right to be treated as an unbiased witness owing to the statement made by him that he did not attach sufficient importance to “the coolies”, as he contemptuously
('10', 464, 0, 1, 1020732) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 465
('10', 464, 1, 2, 1020775) termed the respectable Indian merchants who saw him before the war in his official capacity, to remember all that passed between him and them.
('10', 464, 1, 3, 1020918) Mr. Burger was, however, ingenuous enough to tell the Committee that the Republican Government could do nothing, as their action was hampered by the London Convention and the British Agent.
('10', 464, 1, 4, 1021108) But now, adds Mr. Burger, that the Government have a free hand, they should drive away “the coolies” without any fuss.
('10', 464, 1, 5, 1021227) The very Government that protected the Indians during the Republican regime and that insisted on Indian Bazaars abutting public roads, is now to be utilised to drive them to an inaccessible place where they cannot do any business at all.
('10', 464, 1, 6, 1021465) One thing is clear from Mr. Burger’s evidence.
('10', 464, 1, 7, 1021512) A site for the mosque was granted by the Government with due deliberation.
('10', 464, 1, 8, 1021587) Mr. Burger is unable to swear that he did not promise the Indian deputation that waited on him that the Location might be treated as permanent.
('10', 464, 2, 9, 1021731) Indian Opinion, 26 3 1910
('10', 464, 3, 10, 1021757) 293. DEPORTATION—ITS MEANING
('10', 464, 4, 11, 1021786) A large number of Indians in South Africa are developing a spirit of patriotism.
('10', 464, 4, 12, 1021867) If they can render some service to the Motherland without any effort, they certainly want to do so; but they find themselves helpless before the claims of self interest.
('10', 464, 4, 13, 1022037) There are very few Indians who pay sufficient attention to the manner in which the Transvaal campaign is proceeding at the moment.
('10', 464, 4, 14, 1022168) Being engrossed in their own affairs, they are ignorant of what atrocities are committed on their own brethren, and why.
('10', 464, 4, 15, 1022289) There are also some who think that, since most of those who go in for self sacrifice are Tamils, no notice need be taken of them.
('10', 464, 4, 16, 1022419) We draw the attention of such Indians to the following considerations.
('10', 464, 4, 17, 1022490) Those who find themselves in agreement with them are requested to bring them to the notice of other Indians.
('10', 464, 4, 18, 1022599) For some time past, Indian satyagrahis are being deported to India.
('10', 464, 4, 19, 1022667) Several brave Tamils have been so deported.
('10', 464, 4, 20, 1022711) Some of them were born in South Africa.
('10', 464, 4, 21, 1022751) The families of some are left in the Transvaal without any means of support.
('10', 464, 4, 22, 1022828) It is impossible to say what would have happened to them, had no aid been received from India.
('10', 464, 4, 23, 1022923) The Indians who are deported are not tried in a court of law, but
('10', 465, 0, 1, 1022989) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 465, 1, 2, 1023031) only in private.
('10', 465, 1, 3, 1023048) There is no provision for appeal to the Supreme Court against an order so made.
('10', 465, 1, 4, 1023128) However, there is no great difficulty so long as men are deported only to Natal, for the Indians concerned can immediately return from Natal and go to gaol.
('10', 465, 1, 5, 1023285) It is the practice of deporting to India that calls for urgent attention.
('10', 465, 1, 6, 1023359) The Transvaal Government has legal authority only to put a person across its own border.
('10', 465, 1, 7, 1023448) How, then, can it carry anyone to India?
('10', 465, 1, 8, 1023489) Not being in a position to achieve its mean object through a British colony, the Transvaal Government has entered into an arrangement with the Portuguese Government and executes its barbarous plan with its help.
('10', 465, 1, 9, 1023701) It is clear, however, that the Transvaal Government is not competent to enter into such an agreement.
('10', 465, 1, 10, 1023803) No such step can be taken without the consent of the Imperial Government.
('10', 465, 1, 11, 1023877) If any other State had entered into an agreement of this kind with the Portuguese authorities that might have led to war.
('10', 465, 1, 12, 1023999) This means that the Imperial Government is unable to prevent its own subjects from oppressing their fellow subjects, that it is afraid of the Transvaal.
('10', 465, 1, 13, 1024152) This also implies that the authority of the Imperial Government is used to perpetuate the tyranny of the tyrant, is used to help the tyrant.
('10', 465, 1, 14, 1024293) What should we do in such a situation?
('10', 465, 1, 15, 1024332) If Indians have any spirit in them, those who have capitulated out of timidity should rouse themselves again.
('10', 465, 1, 16, 1024442) We shall obtain no justice by going to courts of law.
('10', 465, 1, 17, 1024496) We must fight on, relying on our own strength.
('10', 465, 1, 18, 1024543) As the Transvaal Government’s repression grows, we must display correspondingly greater strength, endurance and firmness.
('10', 465, 1, 19, 1024665) We desire that a large number of Indians should join the struggle.
('10', 465, 2, 20, 1024732) [From Gujarati]
('10', 465, 3, 21, 1024748) Indian Opinion, 26 3 1910
('10', 465, 4, 22, 1024774) 294. PARSEE RUSTOMJEE
('10', 465, 5, 23, 1024796) The Transvaal Government has sent a long reply 1 regarding Mr. Rustomjee; Mr. Cachalia has written 2 again.
('10', 465, 5, 24, 1024904) The matter has [also] been raised in the House of Commons.
('10', 465, 5, 25, 1024963) All this is to the good.
('10', 465, 5, 26, 1024988) The officials stopped at nothing in their effort to break Mr. Rustomjee’s spirit.
('10', 465, 6, 27, 1025070) 1 Vide Letter from the Director of Prisons to the Chairman, British Indian Association, 19 3 1910, reproduced in Indian Opinions, 26 3 1910.
('10', 465, 7, 28, 1025211) 2 Vide “Letter to Director of Prisons”, 22 3 1910
('10', 466, 0, 1, 1025261) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 467
('10', 466, 1, 2, 1025304) They are suffering the consequence now.
('10', 466, 1, 3, 1025344) However brave a face they may put on it in public, they appear to have received quite a severe reprimand over this affair.
('10', 466, 1, 4, 1025467) In the same letter, the Government has referred to the complaint in regard to the Imam Saheb.
('10', 466, 1, 5, 1025561) It had to admit the justice of the complaint.
('10', 466, 1, 6, 1025607) The sufferings of these two will help the prisoners who follow.

('10', 466, 1, 8, 1025706) We must learn to submit to that law.
('10', 466, 1, 9, 1025743) Any man who puts himself to suffering will diminish the value of that suffering if he himself enjoys its fruits.

('10', 466, 1, 11, 1026035) We wish such goodness and such strength to Mr. Rustomjee and the Imam Saheb.

('10', 468, 1, 2, 1029195) 296. LETTER TO GENERAL MANAGER, C. S. A. R. 1
('10', 468, 2, 3, 1029241) [JOHANNESBURG,] March 31, 1910
('10', 468, 4, 4, 1029272) The following incident has been reported to my Association by Mr. Ismail Adam of Pretoria, Merchant.
('10', 468, 4, 5, 1029373) He holds a first class return ticket from Park to Pretoria, which is numbered 9271. He was travelling last evening by the 8.10 p.m.
('10', 468, 4, 6, 1029505) train to Pretoria.
('10', 468, 4, 7, 1029524) He boarded the train, his ticket was clipped, and, as there was no room in the reserved compartment, he entered the next compartment, which was occupied by four Europeans, who did not object to Mr. Ismail Adam’s presence in the compartment.
('10', 468, 4, 8, 1029765) The conductor, however, seeing him in that compartment, asked him why he was there, to which Mr. Ismail Adam replied that he would gladly go to any other compartment if he could find a seat.
('10', 468, 4, 9, 1029956) The conductor then said that he would have to change.
('10', 468, 4, 10, 1030010) Mr. Ismail Adam, thinking that this meant change to another train, asked why.
('10', 468, 4, 11, 1030088) The conductor thereupon seems to have become angry, and told him that he would have to get down at Doornfontein, and there, whilst the train was in motion but had slowed down, he pulled Mr. Ismail Adam out of the train on to the platform.
('10', 468, 4, 12, 1030327) In the opinion of my Association, this seems to be one of the worst cases that have been brought to its notice.
('10', 468, 4, 13, 1030439) My Association will be glad to be assured that you will be pleased to take prompt action in the matter.
('10', 468, 4, 14, 1030543) Mr. Ismail Adam’s address in Pretoria is 63, Queen Street.
('10', 468, 4, 15, 1030602) Whilst my Association draws attention to this incident as a matter of public duty and in the interests of the community represented byit, there is no knowing whether Mr. Ismail Adam will not take independent steps.
('10', 468, 4, 16, 1030817) That the conductor should not mind even risking the lives of passengers in taking them down from a train in motion seems to show an extraordinary state of affairs.
('10', 468, 5, 17, 1030981) Indian Opinion, 9 4 1910
('10', 468, 6, 18, 1031006) 1 This letter, presumably drafted by Gandhiji, was sent over the signature of the Chairman, British Indian Association.
('10', 469, 0, 1, 1031126) 470 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 469, 1, 2, 1031168) 297. WAR AGAINST COLOUR
('10', 469, 2, 3, 1031192) The Johannesburg Municipality is being goaded into removing every Indian and Native employee, no matter how faithful his services may be and no matter what their length.
('10', 469, 2, 4, 1031362) That the Municipality or any other Department may not take a fresh supply of Coloured or Asiatic servants is a position against which not much can be said, but a summary dismissal of those who are already in its employ can do credit neither to the Municipality nor to those who force its hands.
('10', 469, 2, 5, 1031657) As the South African News very properly puts it:
('10', 469, 3, 6, 1031706) Replace the black man at the bottom by the white, take away as
('10', 469, 4, 7, 1031769) suggested the farms farmed by Natives and give them to white occupiers.
('10', 469, 5, 8, 1031841) this and what is to happen to the replaced Natives?
('10', 469, 5, 9, 1031893) That will be a harder
('10', 469, 6, 10, 1031915) problem to settle than that of the poor whites, but so long as the Natives’
('10', 469, 7, 11, 1031991) opportunities are not taken away from them, there need be no problem to
('10', 469, 8, 12, 1032063) Segregate, repress or turn the Native into permanent unemployed and
('10', 469, 9, 13, 1032131) the madness known as sitting on the safety valve will have begun.
('10', 469, 9, 14, 1032197) There can be no doubt that a ruthless removal of Asiatic and more especially Native servants will only end in disaster, but it behoves British Indians and other Asiatics, as also the Natives, to learn the needful lesson from the present activity against Asiatic and Coloured races.
('10', 469, 9, 15, 1032479) The latter must not rely upon the white Colonists finding work for them or giving it to them.
('10', 469, 9, 16, 1032573) They will have to find independent means of earning a livelihood, and once a few leaders set themselves towards solving the problem, it will be found exceedingly easy.
('10', 469, 10, 17, 1032741) Indian Opinion, 2 4 1910
('10', 470, 0, 1, 1032766) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 471
('10', 470, 1, 2, 1032809) 298. DUTY OF NATAL INDIAN CONGRESS
('10', 470, 2, 3, 1032844) From cable reports from India, we learn that a Bill for prohibiting indentured labour has been passed in the Viceroy’s Legislative Council.
('10', 470, 2, 4, 1032984) The Viceroy has said that the law will be brought into effect only after full negotiations with the Government of Natal.
('10', 470, 2, 5, 1033105) This suggests that the Viceroy, left to himself, will not stop indentured labour if Indians remain inactive.
('10', 470, 2, 6, 1033214) If they do their duty, the system is bound to end; but we observe that some Indians think that the prohibition of indenture will be a disadvantage.
('10', 470, 2, 7, 1033362) Disadvantage to whom?
('10', 470, 2, 8, 1033384) If one thinks it is a disadvantage to those who offer themselves for indenture that they should be saved from slavery, there is no more to be said.
('10', 470, 2, 9, 1033532) Who else will stand to lose?
('10', 470, 2, 10, 1033561) As for free Indians, we think the immigration of indentured labourers is a great disadvantage to them.
('10', 470, 2, 11, 1033664) Those free Indians who live by their labour do not get employment, or, if they do, it is on a very low wage.
('10', 470, 2, 12, 1033773) Both the indentured labourers and other Indians are humiliated because the continued immigration of the former leads to increased resentment against us.
('10', 470, 2, 13, 1033926) If indenture is prohibited, Indians can hope for an immediate improvement in their status.
('10', 470, 2, 14, 1034017) Once slavery has disappeared, it will be possible to get the laws about passes, etc., repealed, and there will be fewer attacks on traders.
('10', 470, 2, 15, 1034157) No doubt, even afterwards the struggle will have to be continued, but it can be continued with greater determination and better hope [of success].
('10', 470, 2, 16, 1034304) When only free Indians are left in South Africa, the community will be in a position to do a great many things.
('10', 470, 2, 17, 1034416) Thus, from every point of view, the interests of Indians will be best served by the stopping of indenture.
('10', 470, 2, 18, 1034523) It must be borne in mind that even if Indians were to give up the agitation for the prohibition of indentured labour, the Union Parliament will certainly prohibit it on its own.
('10', 470, 2, 19, 1034701) Indians would then look small and would lose the credit which they have a chance of earning today.

('10', 470, 4, 21, 1034816) Indian Opinion, 2 4 1910
('10', 471, 0, 1, 1034841) 472 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 471, 1, 2, 1034883) 299. TERRIBLE CIVILIZATION OF THE WEST
('10', 471, 2, 3, 1034922) An English journal called The New Age has published a cartoon on this subject, which we reproduce in this issue.
('10', 471, 2, 4, 1035035) It shows an army on the march.
('10', 471, 2, 5, 1035066) Behind, there is a grotesque figure, that of a general.
('10', 471, 2, 6, 1035122) On the body of this terrible form are hanging a gun emitting smoke in every direction and swords dripping with blood, and on its head a cannon.
('10', 471, 2, 7, 1035266) There is the drawing of a skull on a badge hanging on one side.
('10', 471, 2, 8, 1035330) On the arm, moreover, there is a cross.
('10', 471, 2, 9, 1035370) (This cross is the emblem of a batch which looks after the wounded.) In the mouth, held in the teeth, there is a dagger dripping with blood.
('10', 471, 2, 10, 1035511) On the shoulder is seen a belt studded with live cartridges.
('10', 471, 2, 11, 1035572) The drawing is entitled “March of Civilization”.
('10', 471, 2, 12, 1035621) No one who reads this description of the cartoon can help becoming grave.
('10', 471, 2, 13, 1035695) On reflection, we cannot help feeling that Western civilization is as cruel as, perhaps more cruel than, the terrible expression on the face of the man in the cartoon.
('10', 471, 2, 14, 1035863) The sight which fills one with the utmost indignation is that of the cross in the midst of weapons dripping with blood.
('10', 471, 2, 15, 1035983) Here the hypocrisy of the new civilization reaches its climax.
('10', 471, 2, 16, 1036046) In former times, too, there used to be bloody wars, but they were free from the hypocrisy of modern civilization.
('10', 471, 2, 17, 1036160) While drawing our readers, attention to this cartoon, we want to give them at the same time a glimpse of the divine light of satyagraha.
('10', 471, 2, 18, 1036297) On one side, look at the picture of civilization drawn above, a civilization grown as terrible as a wolf through its hunger for wealth and its greedy pursuit of worldly pleasures.
('10', 471, 2, 19, 1036477) On the other, look at the figure of a satyagrahi who, out of his loyalty to truth, to his nature as a spiritual being and out of a desire to obey God’s command, submits to the suffering inflicted by wicked men, with fortitude in his breast, with a smile on his face and without a single tear in his eyes.
('10', 471, 2, 20, 1036782) Of the two pictures, towards which will the reader feel attracted?
('10', 471, 2, 21, 1036849) We are sure it is the vision of the satyagrahi which will touch the heart of mankind, and that the effect will grow deeper as his sufferings increase.
('10', 471, 2, 22, 1037000) Is there anyone who, looking at this cartoon alone, does not feel in his heart that satyagraha is the only way in which mankind can attain freedom and strength?
('10', 471, 2, 23, 1037161) We admit, of course, that to be shot dead or hanged when trying to shoot another does test one’s fortitude; but dying in the attempt to kill another does not require even a hundredth part of the fortitude and courage implicit in the suffering that a satyagrahi goes through, in the slow, prolonged
('10', 472, 0, 1, 1037459) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 473
('10', 472, 1, 2, 1037502) torture that he calmly endures in facing a bullet without firing one in return.
('10', 472, 1, 3, 1037582) No one wields a sword strong enough to bear down the force of satyagraha; on the contrary, a man brandishing a sword of steel has to give ground when confronted by a sword sharper than his.
('10', 472, 1, 4, 1037772) That is the reason why the story of a satyagrahi is read with a feeling of reverence.
('10', 472, 1, 5, 1037858) One who is not strong enough to practise satyagraha is naturally tempted to resort to brute force, which is, in comparison, quite easy to employ.
('10', 472, 1, 6, 1038004) There are some desperate Indians who, in their mad obsession with swaraj for India, seem to imagine that satyagraha is bound to be followed by resort to brute force—that is, that satyagraha is but one step in the effort to key oneself up to the fanaticism of violence.
('10', 472, 1, 7, 1038273) It would not be wrong to compare persons holding such views to the frog in the well who sought to conceive the ocean [as a big, big well].
('10', 472, 1, 8, 1038412) The truth of the matter is that the man who cannot cultivate to its utmost limit the capacity for endurance required in satyagraha turns in his impatience to brute force and, growing desperate, takes a blind leap in an effort to end his suffering quickly.
('10', 472, 1, 9, 1038668) Such a man has never been a satyagrahi.
('10', 472, 1, 10, 1038708) He does not want to understand what satyagraha means.
('10', 472, 2, 11, 1038762) [From Gujarati]

('10', 472, 4, 13, 1038803) 300. LETTER TO MAGANLAL GANDHI
('10', 472, 5, 14, 1038834) Phagan Vadi 7 [Samvat 1966]
('10', 472, 6, 15, 1038862) [April 2, 1910]
('10', 472, 7, 16, 1038878) MAGANLAL, Your letter to hand.
('10', 472, 7, 17, 1038909) I return it to you so that you can understand my reply to it.
('10', 472, 7, 18, 1038971) I shall try to answer the questions you have raised.
('10', 472, 7, 19, 1039024) But even then you may not understand thoroughly.
('10', 472, 7, 20, 1039073) You will perhaps find the explanations you have sought from [Hind] Swaraj itself if you read it afresh once or twice.
('10', 472, 7, 21, 1039191) There is no doubt that we shall have to go back to the extent to which we have imbibed [modern] civilization.
('10', 472, 7, 22, 1039301) This part of the task is the most difficult one, but it will have to be done.
('10', 472, 7, 23, 1039379) When we take a wrong path there is no alternative but to go back.
('10', 472, 7, 24, 1039445) We have got to free ourselves from attachment to the things we are enjoying.
('10', 472, 7, 25, 1039522) For this it is
('10', 473, 0, 1, 1039537) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 473, 1, 2, 1039579) necessary that we begin to feel disgust for them.
('10', 473, 1, 3, 1039629) Whatever means and instruments appear to us to be beneficial are not going to be given up.
('10', 473, 1, 4, 1039720) Only he who realizes that there is more harm than the apparent benefit from a particular thing will give it up.
('10', 473, 1, 5, 1039832) I personally feel that no benefit has been derived from our being able to send letters quickly.
('10', 473, 1, 6, 1039928) When we give up railways and such other means we shall not bother ourselves about writing letters.
('10', 473, 1, 7, 1040027) A thing which is really free from fault may be used to a certain extent.
('10', 473, 1, 8, 1040100) We who are engulfed in this civilization may avail ourselves of postal and other facilities as long as we are so engulfed.
('10', 473, 1, 9, 1040223) If we make use of these things with knowledge and understanding we shall not go crazy over them, and instead of increasing our preoccupations we shall gradually reduce them.
('10', 473, 1, 10, 1040397) He who will understand this will not be tempted to take the post or the railway to the villages which do not have these.
('10', 473, 1, 11, 1040518) You and I should not remain passive and increase the use of steamers and other evil means for fear that these things cannot be abolished forthwith and that all the people will not give them up.
('10', 473, 1, 12, 1040712) Even if one man reduces or stops their use, others will learn to do so.
('10', 473, 1, 13, 1040784) He who believes that it is good to do so will go on doing so irrespective of others.
('10', 473, 1, 14, 1040869) This is the only way of spreading the truth; there is no other in the world.
('10', 473, 2, 15, 1040946) It is very difficult to get rid of our fondness for Parliament.
('10', 473, 2, 16, 1041010) It was no doubt barbarous when people tore off the skin, burned persons alive and cut off their ears or nose; but the tyranny of Parliament is much greater than that of Chengiz Khan, Tamerlane and others.
('10', 473, 2, 17, 1041215) Hence it is that we are caught in its meshes.
('10', 473, 2, 18, 1041261) Modern tyranny is a trap of temptation and therefore does greater mischief.
('10', 473, 2, 19, 1041337) One can withstand the atrocities committed by one individual as such; but it is difficult to cope with the tyranny perpetrated upon a people in the name of the people.
('10', 473, 2, 20, 1041505) It seems to have happened in the past that some rulers were like King Foolishman while others turned out to be wise.
('10', 473, 2, 21, 1041622) Had Edward alone been our ruler it would not have been so objectionable; but every Englishman is ruling over you and me.
('10', 473, 2, 22, 1041743) Please ponder over the meaning of this statement.
('10', 473, 2, 23, 1041793) I do not refer here to people’s fondness for this world.
('10', 473, 2, 24, 1041850) The common man in India at least believes that the Parliament is a hoax.
('10', 473, 2, 25, 1041923) Even an extraordinarily intelligent man, caught in the meshes of this civilization, loses his sanity in Parliament.
('10', 473, 2, 26, 1042039) By saying that mercy cannot have any effect on the Pindaris you have denied the very existence of the soul or its [essential]
('10', 474, 0, 1, 1042165) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 475
('10', 474, 1, 2, 1042208) attribute.
('10', 474, 1, 3, 1042219) Lord Patanjali 1 has emphasized the greatness of mercy, etc., in such a way that we feel delighted even while thinking of those virtues.
('10', 474, 1, 4, 1042356) The real fact is that fear has taken deep root in us and consequently truth, mercy and such other virtues do not develop.
('10', 474, 1, 5, 1042478) And then we think that mercy has no effect on cruel people.
('10', 474, 1, 6, 1042538) If we show mercy to the person who shows mercy to us it is no mercy; it is only the return for mercy.
('10', 474, 1, 7, 1042640) We should be considered weak if someone protects us free of charge or even if we pay him for doing so.
('10', 474, 1, 8, 1042743) If we have to seek outside help to be free from the menace of the Pindaris, etc., we are unfit for swaraj.
('10', 474, 1, 9, 1042850) If we would subdue them with physical force, we shall have to develop that force in ourselves.
('10', 474, 1, 10, 1042945) We shall not then have to pay blackmail or tribute.
('10', 474, 1, 11, 1042997) A woman seeks her husband’s protection as a matter of right; but she is considered an abala (weak) after all.
('10', 474, 1, 12, 1043107) Swaraj is for those who understand it.
('10', 474, 1, 13, 1043146) You and I can enjoy it even today.
('10', 474, 1, 14, 1043181) All the others will have to learn to do likewise.
('10', 474, 1, 15, 1043231) What is secured for us by others is not swaraj but pararaj, i.e., foreign rule, whether they be Indians or Englishmen.
('10', 474, 1, 16, 1043350) In calling the cow protection societies cow killing societies, I have but stated the truth; for their object is to rescue the cow or protect her by bringing pressure on Mussalmans.
('10', 474, 1, 17, 1043531) To rescue the cow by paying money is no protection of the cow; it is a way to teach the butcher to be deceitful.
('10', 474, 1, 18, 1043644) If we try to coerce the Mussalmans they will slaughter more cows.
('10', 474, 1, 19, 1043710) But if we persuade them or offer satyagraha against them they will protect her.
('10', 474, 1, 20, 1043790) No cow protection society is necessary for doing this.
('10', 474, 1, 21, 1043845) That body should be for teaching Hinduism to the Hindus.
('10', 474, 1, 22, 1043902) It is better to kill an ox by a single blow of the sword than to kill it by starving it, by pricking it, by over working it and thus torturing it.
('10', 474, 1, 23, 1044049) It would be very confusing to take the examples of Shri Ramachandra and others literally.

('10', 474, 1, 25, 1044251) But to imagine that he was a huge passionate senseless animal and that he was killed by Shri Ramachandra representing the divine essence may appeal to the intellect.
('10', 474, 1, 26, 1044417) Tulsidasji 2

('10', 475, 0, 1, 1044580) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 475, 1, 2, 1044622) has described Ramachandraji as the forces of the Sun who is the destroyer of pride, infatuation, and the darkness of the night of excessive attachment.
('10', 475, 1, 3, 1044774) Do you think we shall have the least desire left in us to destroy anybody when we are rid of all pride, infatuation and attachment?

('10', 475, 1, 18, 1046237) It is the mind, says the Gita, which is the cause of our bondage as well as of our freedom.
('10', 475, 1, 19, 1046329) 3 Sudhanva was thrown into boiling oil.
('10', 475, 1, 20, 1046369) The person who got him thrown into it thought that he was inflicting suffering on Sudhanva; but for the latter it was a grand opportunity to show the intensity of his devotion.
('10', 475, 1, 21, 1046546) It will never happen that all are equally rich or equally poor at the same time.

('10', 477, 1, 2, 1049335) 301. FROM “TRANSVAAL NOTES” 1
('10', 477, 2, 3, 1049365) Monday [April 4, 1910] Messrs David Solomon, Moonsamy Chellan, Moonsamy Paul, John Edward, Dhobi Samy and Chillia have now been deported.
('10', 477, 2, 4, 1049503) On the 2nd instant were arrested Messrs Govindsamy N. Pillay, Kanabathe N. Pillay, Ellary Moonsamy, Maduray Muthoo, John Lazarus, Moonsamy, Chinasamy and Govindsamy.
('10', 477, 2, 5, 1049669) Of these, two are youngsters, and they were all engaged at a European cigar factory.
('10', 477, 2, 6, 1049754) These are very typical cases; Mr. David Solomon and his three companions were serving as waiters at the Trocadero.
('10', 477, 2, 7, 1049869) So that, literally, bread had been taken out of their mouths.
('10', 477, 2, 8, 1049931) Most of these men are voluntarily registered, but the fact is that the Government intend to crush the Tamil community, and so they are hunting them out from every nook and corner, and these men, instead of being immediately sentenced, are driven from pillar to post, undergo all kinds of administrative inquiry, and then, if the Government can possibly arrange it, they are deported to India.
('10', 477, 2, 9, 1050324) Whilst on this question of deportation, I have just heard that steamer after steamer refuses to take these deportees.
('10', 477, 2, 10, 1050442) I trust that the information is true.
('10', 477, 2, 11, 1050480) The remedy certainly lies with the shippers in India.
('10', 477, 2, 12, 1050534) If they would make it known to the different steamship companies that, if they become party to the nefarious design of the Transvaal Government, they will not receive Indian patronage, they will certainly decline to take these unlawfully deported Indians.

('10', 481, 3, 4, 1056309) I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter 2 No.
('10', 481, 3, 5, 1056375) 1459/10 of the 1st instant regarding the treatment of passive resistance prisoners.
('10', 481, 3, 6, 1056459) My Association has no desire to ask for passive resisters any other treatment than that to which their classification entitles them; but the complaint of my Association is that, if the Government do not wish to impose additional hardships on these prisoners, they may not be sent to a penal settlement, where, my Association imagines, hardened criminals are sent, and where they are deprived of facilities allowed in all other prisons.
('10', 481, 3, 7, 1056895) With reference to the restoration of ghee to the diet scale, my Association does not ask for it in connection with passive resistance prisoners only, but regarding all Indian prisoners, because the deprivation places them in a position more unfortunate than that of the Natives, who are allowed one ounce of fat per day.

('10', 482, 5, 6, 1058193) 306. LETTER TO THE PRESS 1
('10', 482, 6, 7, 1058220) April 8, 1910
('10', 482, 7, 8, 1058234) SIR, I have read the report of the unfortunate Indian disturbance that took place yesterday.
('10', 482, 7, 9, 1058327) 2 It is entirely an error to suppose that it has anything to do with the passive resistance struggle that is going on.
('10', 482, 7, 10, 1058446) The fight took place among the members of a particular clan which is known for its martial spirit.
('10', 482, 7, 11, 1058545) The members had mutual quarrels among themselves, into which I need not go, and they thought that they would settle their differences by duelling.
('10', 482, 7, 12, 1058692) It is remarkable that, although the police, according to the reports, knew that thefight was about to take place, they were unable to take sufficient precautions to prevent it.

('10', 482, 9, 14, 1058895) 307. NEVER MIND
('10', 482, 10, 15, 1058911) The letter 3 from the great Tolstoy which was published in this journal was reproduced in Gujarat of Nadiad 4. A notice under the new Press law has been served on the journal, that it is to be prosecuted for this.
('10', 482, 10, 16, 1059125) Our readers probably remember the letter from Tolstoy.
('10', 482, 10, 17, 1059180) To all who have not read it, our advice is that they read it immediately.
('10', 482, 10, 18, 1059254) It is not a little surprising that, though it does not contain a single sentence which can promote violence, the person who reproduced it is being prosecuted.
('10', 482, 10, 19, 1059413) This betrays sheer madness on the part of the officers.

('10', 483, 0, 1, 1059820) 484 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 483, 1, 2, 1059862) They are in a panic and in that state of mind they are not able to judge what is permissible and what is not.
('10', 483, 1, 3, 1059972) Our only regret is that, though ours is the primary responsibility for publishing this letter, nothing is done to us and it is the editor of Gujarat who is in danger.
('10', 483, 1, 4, 1060139) We hope that the editor and the manager of Gujarat will do their duty fearlessly and not retrace a single step.
('10', 483, 1, 5, 1060251) India is being severely tested now.
('10', 483, 1, 6, 1060287) For the repressive laws that have been passed and the suppression of writings, the primary responsibility lies with the terrorists but the matter does not rest there.
('10', 483, 1, 7, 1060454) Indiscriminate suppression of newspapers by the Government will not ensure peace.

('10', 483, 1, 9, 1060639) Those who have no bitterness in their minds will also be embittered now.

('10', 483, 1, 14, 1061015) In this connection, we want to address a few words to our readers.
('10', 483, 1, 15, 1061082) We think they ought not to remain quiet.
('10', 483, 1, 16, 1061123) We certainly will not.
('10', 483, 1, 17, 1061146) It is not possible for us to look on helplessly when someone has come into trouble for reproducing what was published by us.
('10', 483, 1, 18, 1061271) But a newspaper does not mean only its editor and management; the vast majority of those connected with it are its readers.
('10', 483, 1, 19, 1061395) Will our readers be intimidated by these developments or will they do their duty?
('10', 483, 1, 20, 1061477) That is what remains to be seen.
('10', 483, 1, 21, 1061510) Everyone who reads an issue should try to get someone else to read it.
('10', 483, 1, 22, 1061581) The chief object of anewspaper is to ensure the propagation of the views expressed and to see that they are acted upon.
('10', 483, 1, 23, 1061701) This cannot be done without the co operation of its readers.
('10', 483, 2, 24, 1061762) [From Gujarati]
('10', 483, 3, 25, 1061778) Indian Opinion, 9 4 1910
('10', 484, 0, 1, 1061803) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 485
('10', 484, 1, 2, 1061846) APPENDIX I
('10', 484, 2, 3, 1061857) LORD AMPTHILL’S INTRODUCTION TO “M. K. GANDHI : AN INDIAN PATRIOT IN SOUTH AFRICA”
('10', 484, 3, 4, 1061940) The writer of this book is not known to me personally, but there is a bond of sympathy between him and me in the sentiments which we share in regard to the cause of which he is so courageous and devoted an advocate.
('10', 484, 4, 5, 1062156) I commend his book to all who are willing to take my word that it is worth reading.
('10', 484, 4, 6, 1062240) I respectfully suggest that others who attach no value to my opinion would do well to avail themselves of the information afforded by this book in regard to the question of which few, unfortunately, in this country have any knowledge, but which is nevertheless an Imperial question of the highest importance.
('10', 484, 5, 7, 1062549) Mr. Doke does not pretend to give more than a short biography and character sketch of Mr. Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi, the leader of the Indian community in the Transvaal, but the importance of the book is due to the facts that men and matters are inseparably connected in all human affairs, and that the proper comprehension of political affairs in particular ever depends on a knowledge of the character and motives of those who direct them.
('10', 484, 6, 8, 1062992) Although I am not in a position to criticise I do not doubt that in these pages the facts are accurately recorded, and I have sufficient reason to believe that the appreciation is just.
('10', 484, 7, 9, 1063178) The subject of the sketch, Mr. Gandhi, has been denounced in this country, even by responsible persons, as an ordinary agitator; his acts have been misrepresented as mere vulgar defiance of the law; there have not even been wanting suggestion that his motives are those of self interest and pecuniary profit.
('10', 484, 8, 10, 1063487) A perusal of these pages ought to dispel any such notions from the mind of any fair man who has been misled into entertaining them.
('10', 484, 8, 11, 1063619) And with a better knowledge of the man there must come a better knowledge of the matter.
('10', 484, 9, 12, 1063708) The Indian community in the Transvaal are struggling for the maintenance of a right and the removal of a degradation.
('10', 484, 9, 13, 1063826) Can we as Englishmen find fault with them for that?
('10', 484, 9, 14, 1063878) The only method of protest, except that of violence and disorder, which is open to them, who have neither votes nor representation, is that of passive resistance.
('10', 484, 9, 15, 1064041) Can we find fault with for that?
('10', 484, 9, 16, 1064074) They are not selfishly resisting a tax or insidiously striving for new political privileges; they are merely trying to regain that which has been taken from them—the honour of their community.
('10', 484, 9, 17, 1064267) Let him who blames them say what he would do in similar circumstances.
('10', 484, 9, 18, 1064338) Is there one of us who, out of respect for the law, would submit meekly and without protest to deprivation of rights and social degradation?
('10', 484, 10, 19, 1064479) The Colonial Government can remove both grievances without sacrificing an
('10', 485, 0, 1, 1064553) 486 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 485, 1, 2, 1064595) ounce of principle or losing a grain of dignity.
('10', 485, 1, 3, 1064644) Will the Colonial Government do so for the sake of the Empire at this moment of reconciliation, union, and new hope for the future?
('10', 485, 1, 4, 1064776) That is the question to which we are anxiously expecting an answer at the present moment—the question whether or not the Indians, who have their homes in the Transvaal and who have assisted as a community in the development of South Africa, who are British citizens and subjects of His Majesty the King, are to have any lot or share in the general rejoicing over the Union of South Africa.
('10', 485, 2, 5, 1065166) The Colonial Government has but to repeal an Act, which has served its purpose, which is now useless and unworkable, and which they themselves declare to be a dead letter, and to make slight amendment of another Act, so as to remove the explicitracial distinction imposed by these laws and in practice admit a maximum of six Indians annually to the Colony, on the old principle of right, and the question would be settled.
('10', 485, 2, 6, 1065589) The Indians would then have no further reason for persisting in a struggle which for them means suffering and ruin while for the Colony it means a scandal and disgrace.
('10', 485, 2, 7, 1065758) This does not imply that they have no further grievances.
('10', 485, 2, 8, 1065816) They would still labour under the disabilities imposed by the late Transvaal Republic—the incapacity to acquire the franchise and to own land, and the liability to segregation in Locations.
('10', 485, 3, 9, 1066006) It is not realised in this country that in the Transvaal, during the past three years, Indians have for the first time been deprived of a right which they have enjoyed, at any rate in theory, and still enjoy in every other part of the Empire, viz., the legal right of migration on the same terms as other civilized subjects of His Majesty.
('10', 485, 3, 10, 1066346) That is the simple but startling fact, and if this were understood, as it ought to be understood, surely there would be protest from men of all parties in both Houses of Parliament who have so solemnly expressed their disapproval and regret at the establishment of a “colour bar“ under the new Constitution for South Africa.
('10', 485, 3, 11, 1066671) Undoubtedly this disfranchisement, under a Liberal administration, of men on account of their colour, this deprivation of an elementary right of British citizenship on racial grounds, constitutes a reactionary step in Imperial Government almost without parallel, and perhaps there never has been so great or momentous a departure from the principles on which the Empire has been built up and by which we have been wont to justify its existence; the principles of that true Liberalism which has hitherto belonged to Englishmen of all parties.
('10', 485, 3, 12, 1067213) But the violation of the political ethics of our race is even greater in the case of the “colour bar“ which has been established in the Transvaal than in that of the new South African Constitution.
('10', 485, 3, 13, 1067411) If the Houses of Parliament and the Press cannot see this and do not think it worth while to take account of so momentous a reaction, it would seem that our genius for the government of an Empire has commenced its decline.
('10', 485, 4, 14, 1067634) What is to be the result in India if it should finally be proved that we cannot protect British subjects under the British Flag, and that we are powerless to abide by the pledges of our Sovereign and our statesmen?
('10', 485, 4, 15, 1067849) Those who know about India will have no doubt as to the consequences.
('10', 485, 4, 16, 1067919) And what if India—irritated, mortified and humiliated—should become an unwilling and refractory partner in the great Imperial
('10', 486, 0, 1, 1068045) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 487
('10', 486, 1, 2, 1068088) concern?
('10', 486, 1, 3, 1068097) Surely it would be the beginning of the end of the Empire.
('10', 486, 2, 4, 1068156) These, briefly, are the reasons why this question of “the British Indians in the Transvaal” is a great Imperial question and not one of mere internal administration of a self governing Colony in which the Mother Country has neither right nor reason to interfere.
('10', 486, 3, 5, 1068419) It is a matter which touches the honour of our race and affects the unity of the Empire as a whole; it therefore concerns every part of the Empire.
('10', 486, 3, 6, 1068567) Moreover, it is certain that any departure from principle, which may be sanctioned or ignored at the heart of the Empire, will operate as a mischievous example to other places inside and out, and then only by some rude shock to the whole system will the arrest of moral decay be possible.
('10', 486, 4, 7, 1068856) The matter therefore concerns all who would “think Imperially”, and it needs more “clear thinking” than it has hitherto received.
('10', 486, 5, 8, 1068986) The question must be decided, not by methods of temporary expediency in which practice ignores theory, but on the fundamental principles of the ethics of our race.
('10', 486, 5, 9, 1069150) Theory can be modified in practice to suit the exigencies of time and place, but if theory is cast to the winds, there is no means of steering practice.
('10', 486, 6, 10, 1069303) There is still hope that the danger may be realised and averted, for as I write I hear that negotiations for a settlement of the British Indian question in the Transvaal are still proceeding.
('10', 486, 6, 11, 1069495) I have no more earnest hope than that Mr. Gandhi and his fellow countrymen may see the accomplishment of that end, for which they have struggled so bravely and sacrificed so much, before this book is published.
('10', 486, 7, 12, 1069706) AMPTHILL MILTON ERNEST HALL, BEDFORD,
('10', 486, 8, 13, 1069744) 26th August, 1909
('10', 486, 9, 14, 1069762) M. K. Gandhi : An Indian Patriot in South Africa
('10', 486, 10, 15, 1069811) APPENDIX II
('10', 486, 11, 16, 1069823) STATEMENT MADE ON BEHALF OF NATAL DELEGATES
('10', 486, 12, 17, 1069867) August 12, 1909
('10', 486, 13, 18, 1069883) I and my co delegates have to thank Your Lordship for receiving us here today.
('10', 486, 13, 19, 1069962) The reason why we have come is to lay before you some of the very serious grievances we labour under in the Colony of Natal.
('10', 486, 14, 20, 1070087) A statement which has been sent to you deals slightly with three of the most important cases, which have been referred to in the statement.
('10', 486, 15, 21, 1070227) The British Indian population of Natal is a very large one—more than that of the other Colonies combined together; the vested rights and interests are also very large.
('10', 486, 15, 22, 1070395) As regards the grievance of the Licensing Act of 1897, the manner in which the
('10', 487, 0, 1, 1070474) 488 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 487, 1, 2, 1070516) Licensing Officers have been using their discretion in refusing British Indian licenses has caused great consternation amongst our mercantile community.
('10', 487, 1, 3, 1070669) It is therefore a matter of life and death to us, as we do not know who will be the next unfortunate trader to be deprived of his license, no matter how long he may have been established.
('10', 487, 1, 4, 1070857) This spells, practically, ruination, some of the most glaring instances of which have been stated in the statement.
('10', 487, 2, 5, 1070973) Mr. Chamberlain, who was then the Colonial Secretary, had to enter a very strong protest against its very one sided administration.
('10', 487, 2, 6, 1071105) This protest has also been slightly cited in the statement.
('10', 487, 2, 7, 1071165) This attitude has been followed by all his successors at the Colonial Office.
('10', 487, 2, 8, 1071243) The reasons given for refusal of some of the British Indian licenses by the Licensing Officers were (1) “to satisfy the popular feeling”—i.e., the European trade rivals (for whose sake our long acquired interests are sacrificed); and (2) on account of extreme prejudice, which would not hold good in courts of equity.
('10', 487, 3, 9, 1071561) Some of the European traders complain of us competing unfairly in business, which is not only incorrect, but in all civilised countries competition is considered as very healthy.
('10', 487, 3, 10, 1071740) Considerable misunderstanding exists upon the question of how we live and feed.
('10', 487, 3, 11, 1071820) Our business premises are open to inspection, and compare favourably with premises of the Europeans.
('10', 487, 4, 12, 1071921) We are burdened with such restricting laws that our fate hangs practically on a balance, especially those who possess vested interests in the Colony.
('10', 487, 5, 13, 1072071) The British Indian merchants buy land, erect business premises thereon, pay rates and taxes, custom dues, etc.
('10', 487, 5, 14, 1072182) The small shopkeepers purchase their stock from local European merchants.
('10', 487, 6, 15, 1072256) The refusal to transfer British Indian licenses to other of the same standing is very unjust.
('10', 487, 6, 16, 1072350) Not only are Licensing Officers satisfied so far, but they go even further and refuse transfers between relatives and even sons or partners.
('10', 487, 7, 17, 1072491) Natal is our adopted country, and many of us have children who have never seen India.
('10', 487, 7, 18, 1072577) We feel very much for their future because our own is not safeguarded, although in the past we have helped to push forward the trade of the Colony.
('10', 487, 8, 19, 1072725) I may mention we are not laying great stress on the political franchise, although we have it in India in a different manner.
('10', 487, 8, 20, 1072850) For instance, your humble speaker was a Municipal Councillor in India, and was also a member of the local board, chairman of the school board, and was also elected to vote for the election of a member to the Legislative Council, Government of Bombay, on behalf of the Municipality.
('10', 487, 9, 21, 1073132) Our interest in public concerns has been evidenced on numerous occasions.
('10', 487, 9, 22, 1073206) We furnished Stretcher Bearer Corps during the Boer War and during the latest Native rebellions.
('10', 487, 9, 23, 1073303) Moreover, when necessary, we have been ready to help financially or otherwise with any public work.
('10', 487, 9, 24, 1073403) During the late Boer War a relief fund was opened by several Municipalities, advantage of which was taken by large numbers of whites, even non British subjects.
('10', 487, 9, 25, 1073564) All the Indian refugees were kept by our community.
('10', 487, 9, 26, 1073616) In Maritzburg, Mr. Amod Bayat, one of my co delegates, and a few others upkept them
('10', 488, 0, 1, 1073700) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 489
('10', 488, 1, 2, 1073743) and also helped others, while in Durban we never requested any help from the relief fund, which was publicly praised by the then Mayor of Durban, Mr. Nicol, C.M.G.
('10', 488, 2, 3, 1073907) In spite of all protests made by the Colonial Office and the request for fair treatment made by us, no redress has yet been granted.
('10', 488, 3, 4, 1074040) It is not our profession to agitate, as we are born traders, and what we only ask for is justice, which if denied now, it will be difficult for us what to say to the people.
('10', 488, 4, 5, 1074214) We are a recognised loyal and law abiding people, and we wish for an amendment in the Dealers’ Licenses Act, No.
('10', 488, 4, 6, 1074327) 18 of 1897, for which the community will be grateful to Your Lordship.
('10', 488, 5, 7, 1074398) With reference to the Indentured Immigration Act, 1895, before the introduction of Indian labour Natal was in a state of bankruptcy, but after their arrival things began to prosper and the country was placed on a sound financial basis.
('10', 488, 5, 8, 1074634) The chief and nearly all the industries of the Colony rely on this kind of labour for their very existence.
('10', 488, 5, 9, 1074742) A reference thereto has been made in the statement.
('10', 488, 5, 10, 1074794) After the expiration of the indenture, and after having given the best part of their lives to the welfare of the Colony, they are allowed to settle there, on the annual payment of £3, irrespective of sex and age.
('10', 488, 5, 11, 1075007) The age limit for boys and girls is 14. The treatment meted to them is in some cases horrible, as the case which occurred of Armitage, who cut out a portion of his Indian’s ear and openly admitted doing so in the courts of law.
('10', 488, 6, 12, 1075235) What we wish done in this connection has been mentioned in the statement.
('10', 488, 7, 13, 1075309) The education of Indian children has been ridiculously restricted recently by the Natal Government.
('10', 488, 7, 14, 1075409) No child can now attend any Government School who has completed the age of 13. This is a deliberate way in which education—which is sorely needed for the benefit of both the country and the community—is hampered.
('10', 488, 7, 15, 1075622) It is our duty, therefore, to protest against such curtailing of education.
('10', 488, 8, 16, 1075698) The Immigration Restriction Act is also one of the injustices.
('10', 488, 8, 17, 1075761) No father, mother, brother, or sister of Indian birth can join a person who may have established himself, and even children of over certain age limit cannot join their parents who can upkeep them, and their presence cannot but be considered as beneficial.
('10', 488, 9, 18, 1076017) There are many more injustices, but we have related a few only of the most heartrending cases.
('10', 488, 9, 19, 1076112) I and my co delegates again thank Your Lordship for giving us this patient interview and a patient hearing.
('10', 488, 10, 20, 1076220) Your Lordship is doubtless aware of the pressing circumstances under which we are labouring in Natal, and humbly hope that you will be kind enough to give us a message to convey to our people.
('10', 488, 11, 21, 1076413) After the introduction, Mr. Abdul Caadir, on behalf of the Natal delegates, thanked His Lordship for kindly consenting to grant them an interview.
('10', 488, 12, 22, 1076560) A cablegram received from a mass meeting held in Natal was also read to His Lordship, which was in support of the deputation.
('10', 488, 13, 23, 1076686) At the close of the interview Mr. Abdul Caadir stated that he had been a member of the Natal community for over 25 years, and that from his experiences he
('10', 489, 0, 1, 1076841) 490 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 489, 1, 2, 1076883) feared that no justice to British Indians in Natal was to be expected from the Union.

('10', 489, 6, 8, 1077134) DEAR GENERAL SMUTS,
('10', 489, 7, 9, 1077154) I went to see Mr. Gandhi yesterday afternoon and spoke to him in accordance with your suggestions, but without saying that they came from you.
('10', 489, 7, 10, 1077297) I found him as clear, convincing, and unyielding from his point of view as you are from yours, and after two hours of argument, in which we discussed the question from every standpoint, practical, legal and ethical, I came away in despair of any compromise.
('10', 489, 8, 11, 1077555) Mr. Gandhi is contending for a principle which he regards as essential and, so far as I can judge, he is no more likely to abandon a cause which he considers vital and just than any of us are likely to abandon our life long principles of politics or religion.
('10', 489, 8, 12, 1077815) Indeed it seems to me that he is less likely to do so, for there are few of us who would sacrifice everything in order to secure a theoretical and unavailable right.
('10', 489, 8, 13, 1077981) It is impossible not to admire the man, for it is evident that he recognises no court of appeal except that of his own conscience.

('10', 489, 10, 15, 1078185) suggestion.

('10', 489, 16, 25, 1078679) the criticism of outsiders and you would be giving the Imperial Government an

('10', 490, 0, 1, 1079199) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 491
