('10', 491, 8, 9, 1082103) MY DEAR AMPTHILL, I also have seen General Smuts and Mr. Gandhi, and I am afraid that the divergence in principle which you mention certainly exists, though the difficulty may not be insuperable.
('10', 491, 8, 10, 1082299) Assuming, as one fairly may, that the repeal of Act 2 of 1907 would form part of any settlement, the controversy narrows itself down to the form by which the admission of six just men is to be secured.
('10', 491, 8, 11, 1082501) Assuming, again, that to secure a settlement they must be introduced as residents, not under a licence liable to revocation, it appears that legislation would be required for this purpose.
('10', 491, 8, 12, 1082690) Such legislation might provide expressly for executive power to admit a limited number of persons, notwithstanding any existing law to the contrary; or it might proceed, as your suggestion does, through the education test.
('10', 491, 8, 13, 1082913) It strikes me, however, as I told Mr. Gandhi that it is not quite logical to stand by the principle of admission under an education test, and then to say (as your last proviso does) that Government may exclude any man in spite of his having satisfied that test; and I confess I should like to feel convinced that the Indian community would accept such a solution, and not use the wide general permission accorded under your clause as a basis for further claims.
('10', 491, 8, 14, 1083375) Whether General Smuts could be got to agree to it, or something like it, I cannot say.
('10', 491, 8, 15, 1083462) I am expecting to hear from him.
('10', 491, 9, 16, 1083495) Yours sincerely,

('10', 492, 2, 12, 1085218) APPENDIX IV
('10', 492, 3, 13, 1085230) NATAL DELEGATES’ LETTER TO VICEROY
('10', 492, 4, 14, 1085265) WESTMINSTER PALACE HOTEL, 4, VICTORIA STREET, LONDON, S. W. August 27, 1909
('10', 492, 5, 15, 1085341) TO HIS EXCELLENCY THE VICEROY OF INDIA
('10', 492, 6, 16, 1085380) MY LORD,
('10', 492, 7, 17, 1085389) We took the liberty of sending through Your Lordship’s Private Secretary, a preliminary copy of a statement setting out some of the grievances of our fellow country men in Natal, by the last mail.
('10', 492, 7, 18, 1085586) We now beg to transmit 12 copies of the statement as submitted to the Secretaries of State for the Colonies and India and of the statement read to the Colonial Secretary.
('10', 492, 8, 19, 1085757) We appeal to Your Excellency to give the same the favourable consideration of Your Excellency in Committee and to take such action as the urgently calls for.
('10', 492, 9, 20, 1085915) The British Indians form a very important portion of the inhabitants of Natal; have very large interests in that Colony and are drawn from all parts of India.
('10', 492, 9, 21, 1086074) They number over 100,000, of whom 60,000 are indentured labourers imported by the Natal Government, and it is an acknowledged fact that the prosperity of Natal depends largely if not entirely, on this labour she receives from India.
('10', 493, 0, 1, 1086307) 494 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 493, 1, 2, 1086349) As will appear from the statement, we are being crushed out of existence in Natal in a threefold manner.
('10', 493, 1, 3, 1086454) Our trade is slowly being taken from us by means of the unjust and tyrannical administration of a Licensing Law, which leaves in the hands of a Licensing Officer and his employers—who are themselves our trade rivals— unlimited powers in regard to the granting or refusal of trading licenses, old or new, without any check from the judicial tribunals of the Colony.
('10', 493, 1, 4, 1086819) Indian labourers are worked and treated almost as salves for the material profit of Natal, but as soon as they have finished their services with the Natal planters or mine owners to whom they are allotted, they and their wives and their children are subjected to a special exorbitant annual tax, with a view to preventing them from settling in the Colony as freemen and earning an honest livelihood, and our future progress is almost entirely prevented, by the deprivaton of even ordinary facilities for giving a suitable education to our youths.
('10', 493, 2, 5, 1087366) Unless, therefore, the Government of India as our protector and guardian, takes up our case, and insists on some measure of bare justice being meted out to us by the authorities in Natal, it is only a question of time when we will be slowy starved out of the Colony.
('10', 493, 2, 6, 1087633) There is a tangible remedy at the disposal of the Indian Government and that is, to stop the supply of indentured labour that annually flows into it, unless the Colony will deal justly by the Indian traders and the Indian labourers.
('10', 493, 2, 7, 1087866) This is no new remedy.
('10', 493, 2, 8, 1087889) Lord Curzon accepted the proposal that was made some years ago by us and he even sent a dispatch to the Natal Ministers intimating the taking of action unless redress was granted.
('10', 493, 2, 9, 1088069) We do not know what was the result of those negotiations.
('10', 493, 2, 10, 1088127) But instead of any redress being vouchsafed to us, our condition ever since that time has become much worse, owing to the stringency of the measures stated above and their almost remorseless enforcement.
('10', 493, 2, 11, 1088331) Our means of sabsistence are every day curtailed and our very existence in the Colony, in the enjoyment even of the elementary rights of British citizenship, is imperilled.
('10', 493, 3, 12, 1088504) We therefore pray that Your Excellency in Council would be pleased to take such action and if necessary invite the intervention of the Imperial Government to that end, as might secure to us relief from the oppressive and unjust treatment of the Natal authorities.
('10', 493, 4, 13, 1088768) We remain,
('10', 493, 5, 14, 1088779) Your Excellency’s obedient servants,
('10', 493, 6, 15, 1088816) India Office Records : 179/254
('10', 494, 0, 1, 1088847) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 495
('10', 494, 1, 2, 1088890) APPENDIX V
('10', 494, 2, 3, 1088901) LORD AMPTHILL’S LETTERS TO GANDHIJI AND LORD CREWE
('10', 494, 3, 4, 1088952) (1) LORD AMPTHILL’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI PERSONAL & PRIVATE August 31, 1909
('10', 494, 4, 5, 1089026) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('10', 494, 5, 6, 1089043) I have received your letter of yesterday and I should anyhow have written to
('10', 494, 6, 7, 1089120) you this morning.
('10', 494, 7, 8, 1089138) I have not seen the statement by Reuter’s agent to which you refer, but I will
('10', 494, 8, 9, 1089217) search the newspapers and add a line to this letter if it should be necessary.
('10', 494, 9, 10, 1089296) Meanwhile, I will tell you that which I should anyhow have written to you this
('10', 494, 10, 11, 1089375) morning.
('10', 494, 11, 12, 1089384) Yesterday morning, I received a letter from General Smuts which he had written hastily on the eve of his departure.
('10', 494, 11, 13, 1089500) he said that he was sorry not to be able to see me again and told me very briefly that he had made certain proposals to Lord Crewe.
('10', 494, 11, 14, 1089632) I gather that these proposals are that Act 2 of 1907 should be repealed and that permanent certificates of residence should be granted annually to a limited number of educated Indian immigrants, but, I fear from what he says that General Smuts is not going to meet us on the question of “right”.
('10', 494, 11, 15, 1089928) I went to London yesterday and at once sought an interview with Lord Crewe in the House of Lords, suggesting to him that the moment had arrived when I might invite him to make a statement.
('10', 494, 11, 16, 1090117) Lord Crewe had not yet read the communication which had been addressed to him by General Smuts and he objected to making any statement in Parliament (and as I think quite justifiably) on the grounds that it would not do to anticipate any announcement which General Smuts might have to make on his arrival in South Africa.
('10', 494, 11, 17, 1090439) I admitted that this was quite fair bur I pointed out that you were waiting for an answer, that your time was precious and that it would not be fair to keep you waiting in this country.
('10', 494, 11, 18, 1090625) Lord Crewe then said that he would ask you to come and see him or some member of his department on his behalf and I agreed that he could not do better.
('10', 494, 11, 19, 1090777) We then proceeded to discuss the whole question and I argued the question of “right”.
('10', 494, 11, 20, 1090863) Lord Crewe seemed to be impressed by my assertion that Indians have always enjoyed the right of entry, at any rate in theory, in every part of the Empire until they were deprived of it in the Transvaal.
('10', 494, 11, 21, 1091066) He is very anxious that you should be satisfied and his general attitude was more sympathetic than it has been before.
('10', 494, 11, 22, 1091185) If, therefore, you see him personally, you will have a very good opportunity of making your position clear.
('10', 494, 11, 23, 1091293) It will be for you to decide whether you are bound to continue passive resistance for the sake of the theoretical right, but, personally, I hope that you will not feel so bound, as I am anxious for the sake of your community that the struggle should cease and because I think you have already done enough for the sake
('10', 495, 0, 1, 1091611) 496 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 495, 1, 2, 1091653) of honour.
('10', 495, 1, 3, 1091664) You will be gaining something very substantial in the repeal of Act 2 of 1907 and you can make it quite clear that your opinions on the question of right remain unaltered even though you feel justified in giving up a quixotic struggle.
('10', 495, 1, 4, 1091900) This is all the advice I can give you at present but we must consult again after you have seen Lord Crewe or his representative.
('10', 495, 1, 5, 1092029) I hope you have seen the introduction which I have written to Mr. Doke’s book, for I venture to think that it places on record that I am entirely with you on the question of “right”.
('10', 495, 2, 6, 1092212) Yours very faithfully,
('10', 495, 3, 7, 1092235) AMPTHILL

('10', 496, 2, 3, 1093435) LORD AMPTHILL’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI
('10', 496, 3, 4, 1093470) PRIVATE
('10', 496, 4, 5, 1093478) September 11, 1909
('10', 496, 5, 6, 1093497) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('10', 496, 6, 7, 1093514) I am afraid that you cannot have explained sufficiently your reason for asking for a further interview with Lord Morley or you could not have received so discouraging a reply.
('10', 496, 7, 8, 1093690) Apparently, you said that you wished to “re state your position”; if so, it was hardly a persuasive manner of asking Lord Morley to give you more of his time.
('10', 496, 7, 9, 1093849) I think that you ought to have explained the question of “right” in the light of the latest developments and in view of the movement in India, so that Lord Morley might have seen that you have something new to tell him and that you were able to throw fresh light on the situation.
('10', 496, 7, 10, 1094130) Even now I think that you would do well to write such a letter in order that your reasons for refusing to regard General Smuts’ proposals as a satisfactory settlement may be recorded in advance.
('10', 496, 7, 11, 1094325) Otherwise, you will again be accused of using each concession as an occasion for making fresh demands.
('10', 496, 7, 12, 1094428) Lord Morley does not understand the question and you ought not to neglect to let him have a clear and simple explanation in writing; something to which you will be able to point and refer later on as the definite statement of your case.
('10', 496, 7, 13, 1094665) Could you not draft such a letter and let me see it before you sent it off?
('10', 496, 8, 14, 1094741) Lord Crewe must be away from London or you would surely have had a reply to your letter.
('10', 496, 8, 15, 1094830) I hope that ere this reaches you it will have arrived.
('10', 496, 9, 16, 1094885) Yours very faithfully,
('10', 496, 10, 17, 1094908) AMPTHILL M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.
('10', 496, 10, 18, 1094936) From a photostat of the typewritten original : S. N. 5065
('10', 496, 11, 19, 1094994) APPENDIX VII
('10', 496, 12, 20, 1095007) LORD CREWE’S MINUTE
('10', 496, 13, 21, 1095027) [LONDON,]
('10', 496, 14, 22, 1095037) Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Habib came to see me today.
('10', 496, 14, 23, 1095084) I informed them of the result of our conversations with Mr. Smuts, and of the two concessions which he was prepared to make, (a) the repeal of Act 2 of 1907, and (b) the admission of 6 educated Asiatics each year as permanent residents.
('10', 496, 14, 24, 1095321) Mr. Gandhi admitted that these changes would mark a real step in advance, and so far as their practical effect was concerned, he would be ready to accept them.
('10', 496, 14, 25, 1095481) But it was not possible to abandon the position which
('10', 497, 0, 1, 1095535) 498 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 497, 1, 2, 1095577) he and his friends had taken up, and for which great sufferings had been undergone, that of the necessity of being equal before the law, even though the equality were only theoretical.
('10', 497, 1, 3, 1095762) So that even the granting of these concessions would not make him to cease from agitating for such equality.
('10', 497, 1, 4, 1095871) He added that the plan suggested in Lord Ampthill’s letter and encl[osure] to Mr. Smuts of 10 Aug.
('10', 497, 1, 5, 1095970) 1909, would be accepted, though it had been reluctantly agreed to by some, such as Mr. Gokhale.
('10', 497, 1, 6, 1096066) I said that one reason, in addition to dislike of the fictitious character of the proposed admission, which might actuate T[rans]v[aal] Ministers in rejecting this proposal, was the probability that, if the exclusion remained purely administrative, there would be perpetual agitation to increase the number.
('10', 497, 1, 7, 1096374) Mr. Gandhi said he did not mind how difficult an increase were made, if only theoretical equality were maintained, and that as a matter of fact if 6 were admitted, this side of the question would be regarded as closed, though Indians would work for reforms in other matters.
('10', 497, 1, 8, 1096649) I then asked whether, assuming that TV Ministers would not go beyond what they had offered, the Indians would or would not prefer that the whole question should stand over till Union.
('10', 497, 1, 9, 1096833) Mr. Gandhi said that, as he read the Act, Asiatics being excluded from TV under the general Immigration law, and not by differential treatment, would not for this purpose come under the Union.
('10', 497, 1, 10, 1097026) I pointed out that there was nothing to prevent the Union from adopting a general Immigration law, which, while in fact excluding, might establish theoretical equality, if statesmen were so minded.
('10', 497, 1, 11, 1097224) Mr. Gandhi said that at any rate there would be months of intervening agitation.
('10', 497, 2, 12, 1097305) The conversation ended by Mr. Gandhi asking me to telegraph to the TV Govt.
('10', 497, 2, 13, 1097381) that, though he admitted the practical advances involved in Mr. Smuts’ suggestions, yet he must still hold out for theoretical equality.
('10', 497, 3, 14, 1097518) The impression left on my mind is that, in spite of this, the TV Govt.
('10', 497, 3, 15, 1097589) would do well to make the two concessions, thus removing all practical hardship, and putting themselves right with a considerable section of public opinion.
('10', 497, 4, 16, 1097746) A telegram can accordingly be drafted, giving the substance of Mr. Gandhi’s statement, and adding the substance of the last preceding paragraph.
('10', 497, 4, 17, 1097891) C[REWE] 16. IX Colonial Office Records : 291/41

('10', 498, 2, 3, 1097996) LORD AMPTHILL’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI
('10', 498, 3, 4, 1098031) September 17, 1909
('10', 498, 4, 5, 1098050) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('10', 498, 5, 6, 1098067) Your letter of yesterday which I have just received has cheered me up.
('10', 498, 5, 7, 1098138) I was beginning to be rather despondent about the whole situation, prejudiced as it is by the intense preoccupation of the Government in the critical fortunes of their party at the present moment.
('10', 498, 5, 8, 1098335) It is indeed satisfactory that Lord Crewe should have actually promised to telegraph to General Smuts pressing him to accept our amendment.
('10', 498, 5, 9, 1098475) I have been in correspondence with Sir George Farrar and have arranged to see him when I return from Scotland, so you will see that I have not lost sight of the necessity of squaring the opposition.
('10', 498, 5, 10, 1098674) If you can now get an interview with Lord Morley and enlist his sympathy in the same manner as you did that of Lord Crewe, I think you will have done all that is possible and that you will be able to leave this country feeling that no stone which could be of any avail has been unturned.
('10', 498, 5, 11, 1098962) If you are leaving shortly, I am afraid that I shall have no opportunity of seeing you again, which is a matter of great regret to me.
('10', 498, 5, 12, 1099097) I am obliged at last to take a short holiday while it is still possible and I go up to Scotland for a fortnight, tomorrow.
('10', 498, 5, 13, 1099220) I shall be somewhat out of reach so that you must not be surprised if there is delay about answering your communications.
('10', 498, 5, 14, 1099342) Meanwhile, I bid you and Mr. Hajee Habib “farewell” with every good wish, and I trust that, when we next meet, it will be to rejoice over an honourable and notable success.
('10', 498, 6, 15, 1099515) Yours very faithfully,
('10', 498, 7, 16, 1099538) AMPTHILL M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.

('10', 499, 2, 3, 1099678) M. C. ANGLIA’S LETTER TO UNDER SECRETARY FOR COLONIES WESTMINSTER PALACE HOTEL, 4, VICTORIA STREET, [LONDON,] S. W. September 20, 1909
('10', 499, 3, 4, 1099813) TO THE UNDER SECRETARY OF STATE COLONIAL OFFICE [LONDON,] S. W.
('10', 499, 5, 5, 1099877) I have the honour to acknowledge with thanks the receipt of your letter of the 13th instant, in reply to the Natal Indian deputation that recently waited on the Earl of Crewe and subsequently on Colonel Seely.
('10', 499, 6, 6, 1100087) On behalf of my colleagues and myself, I venture to express our regret and disappointment over the substance of the reply.
('10', 499, 6, 7, 1100210) We fully appreciate and are grateful for the sympathy expressed by Lord Crewe, but we miss any assurance on the part of His Lordship that further friendly and firm representations will be made direct to the Colonial Government in connection with the existing grievances.
('10', 499, 6, 8, 1100481) May we point out once again that these grievances bear harshly on the community at the present moment, and that they are not such as to admit of delayed redress.
('10', 499, 6, 9, 1100643) The trading community approaches the ensuing year with fear and trembling, because that is the time when the Licensing Officers will be applying the pruning knife vigorously to the Indian licenses.
('10', 499, 6, 10, 1100841) Similar apprehension is felt by the poor Indians, who will be called upon to pay the annual £3 tax for themselves, their wives and their major children, while the education of Indian boys is now being sorely neglected.
('10', 499, 7, 11, 1101060) It is perhaps not realised that the Licensing Law being of a general nature,
('10', 499, 8, 12, 1101137) does not fall within amendment that was secured at the instance of His Majesty’s
('10', 499, 9, 13, 1101218) Government in the South Africa Bill, placing the control and administration of
('10', 499, 10, 14, 1101297) matters specially and differentially affecting Asiatics in the Union Government.
('10', 499, 11, 15, 1101378) Licensing Law is applicable to all, irrespective of race.
('10', 499, 11, 16, 1101436) It is, in the opinion of the
('10', 499, 12, 17, 1101465) deputation, capable of being amended by the present Natal Parliament, and will be
('10', 499, 13, 18, 1101547) when it is converted into a provincial legislature.
('10', 499, 13, 19, 1101599) The deputation also regretfully notice the absence of any reply to its [sic] humble submission that the supply of indentured labour to Natal may be stopped, unless the serious grievances are redressed.
('10', 499, 14, 20, 1101801) The deputation therefore respectfully venture to draw Lord Crewe’s attention to the desperate nature of the Natal Indian case and request His Lordship to urge upon the
('10', 500, 0, 1, 1101969) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 501
('10', 500, 1, 2, 1102012) Natal Government the desirability of granting relief.
('10', 500, 2, 3, 1102066) I have the honour to remain,
('10', 500, 4, 4, 1102095) Your most obedient servant,
('10', 500, 5, 5, 1102123) M. C. ANGLIA

('10', 500, 9, 9, 1102210) YASNAYA POLYANA,
('10', 500, 10, 10, 1102227) October 7, 1909
('10', 500, 11, 11, 1102243) M. K. GANDHI TRANSVAAL
('10', 500, 12, 12, 1102266) I have just received your most interesting letter, which has given me great pleasure.
('10', 500, 12, 13, 1102352) God help our dear brothers and co workers in the Transvaal.
('10', 500, 13, 14, 1102412) That same struggle of the tender against the harsh, of meekness and love against pride and violence, is every year making itself more and more felt here among us also, especially in one of the very sharpest of the conflicts of the religious law with the worldly laws—in refusals of military service.
('10', 500, 13, 15, 1102712) Such refusals are becoming ever more and more frequent.
('10', 500, 14, 16, 1102768) The letter to a Hindoo was written by me, and the translation is a very good one.
('10', 500, 14, 17, 1102850) The title of the book about Krishna shall be sent you from Moscow.
('10', 500, 14, 18, 1102917) As to the word ‘reincarnation’, I should not myself like to omit it, for, in my opinion, belief in reincarnation can never be as firm as belief in the soul’s immortaliy and in God’s justice and love.
('10', 500, 14, 19, 1103117) You may, however, do as you like about omitting it.
('10', 500, 14, 20, 1103169) If I can assist your publication, I shall be very glad.
('10', 500, 14, 21, 1103225) The translation into and circulation of my letter in the Hindoo language can only be a pleasure to me.
('10', 500, 15, 22, 1103328) A competition, i.e., an offer of a monetary inducement in connection with a religious matter would, I think, be out of place.
('10', 500, 16, 23, 1103454) I greet you fraternally, and am glad to have intercourse with you.
('10', 500, 16, 24, 1103521) LEO TOLSTOY

('10', 501, 8, 16, 1104917) APPENDIX XII
('10', 501, 9, 17, 1104930) GUJARATI MEETING IN LONDON
('10', 501, 10, 18, 1104957) EXTRACT FROM Indian Opinion REPORT
('10', 501, 11, 19, 1104992) A letter was received by Mr. Jethalal Parikh, Bar at law, and other Gujaratis from the Secretary of the Gujarati Literary Parishad, Mr. Balvantrai Thakore, requesting encouragement to the third session of the Parishad to be held at Rajkot in Kathiawar.
('10', 501, 11, 20, 1105245) A meeting of Gujaratis was accordingly held on October 5 in Westminster Palace Hotel under the Chairmanship of Sir Muncherjee Bhownaggree.
('10', 501, 12, 21, 1105384) Sir Muncherjee, on being proposed to the chair, said : “.
('10', 501, 12, 22, 1105442) I took keen interest in Gujarati when I was young.
('10', 501, 12, 23, 1105493) I translated into Gujarati an account of Queen Victoria’s travels.
('10', 501, 12, 24, 1105560) This is sufficient evidence that I know a little Gujarati.
('10', 501, 12, 25, 1105619) Hence, I agreed to take the chair.
('10', 501, 13, 26, 1105654) A body named Gujarati Sahitya Parishad been in existence the past few years.
('10', 501, 13, 27, 1105731) It meets every year.
('10', 501, 13, 28, 1105752) There is no intrusion of politics into the activities of this body.
('10', 502, 0, 1, 1105820) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 503
('10', 502, 1, 2, 1105863) Its main object is the preservation and development of Gujarati.
('10', 502, 1, 3, 1105928) If anyone asks why this should be necessary, the answer is that the Indian languages are in some danger.
('10', 502, 1, 4, 1106033) Not that there has been an attack by an enemy; but, these days, an attitude of indifference to our languages and to other things of our country is in the air.
('10', 502, 1, 5, 1106192) All the men and women are taking to the study of English.
('10', 502, 1, 6, 1106250) That is, of course, in the fitness of things.
('10', 502, 1, 7, 1106296) People are naturally eager to learn a language that is the language of administration and commerce.
('10', 502, 1, 8, 1106396) But that does not justify one in giving up one’s own language.
('10', 502, 1, 9, 1106459) Many of us learn French, German, etc.
('10', 502, 1, 10, 1106497) How, then, can we give up a language that Nature has made our own?
('10', 502, 1, 11, 1106564) It would not be in the least proper to ridicule that language.
('10', 502, 1, 12, 1106627) And yet, no one will deny such indifference is prevailing in India.
('10', 502, 1, 13, 1106695) I remember that, when I was a child, there were young men who would not talk Gujarati even in their homes.
('10', 502, 1, 14, 1106802) I can give the names of some of these.
('10', 502, 1, 15, 1106841) And a few of them went to such lengths in imitating the British that even the Ayahs they engaged would be from North India, so that the children might talk only Hindustani, whenever necessary, as the British did.
('10', 502, 1, 16, 1107054) All this happened because of half baked education.
('10', 502, 1, 17, 1107105) We come across fewer such instances now.
('10', 502, 1, 18, 1107146) For the past many years, I have been settled here (in England), but I have not given up the use of my own language.
('10', 502, 1, 19, 1107262) If anyone writes to me in Gujarati, I reply in Gujarati.
('10', 502, 1, 20, 1107319) It occurs to me, as I use the phrase ‘Reception Committee’, that we must find a Gujarati equivalent for it, but in the draft of the Parishad constitution which we have received they have used the English phrase and so I, too, use the same.
('10', 502, 1, 21, 1107559) We can see from this that we have lost control over our own language.
('10', 502, 2, 22, 1107629) FIRST RESOLUTION
('10', 502, 3, 23, 1107646) Mr. Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi moved the following resolution : 2
('10', 502, 4, 24, 1107712) Seconding it, Mr. Nusserwanji said :
('10', 502, 5, 25, 1107749) I have pleasure in seconding this resolution.
('10', 502, 5, 26, 1107795) The first Gujarati newspaper was started by a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 27, 1107848) Gnanprakash was started by a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 28, 1107884) Mr. Kabraji, who started Stri bodh, was a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 29, 1107933) It was a Parsi who started writing humorous pieces.
('10', 502, 5, 30, 1107985) Kautuksangraha was also started by a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 31, 1108029) Parsis have also translated numerous books from English.
('10', 502, 5, 32, 1108086) Bacon’s Essays were translated by a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 33, 1108129) Munchersha, who wrote a book on Gujarati grammar, was a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 34, 1108192) The first dictionary was also compiled by Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 35, 1108241) Drama was introduced in Gujarati by a Parsi.
('10', 502, 5, 36, 1108286) Parsis have thus done valuable work indeed for the progress of our language; it is a matter of regret, however, that they do not take the same pains now.
('10', 502, 5, 37, 1108440) SECOND RESOLUTION
('10', 502, 6, 38, 1108458) Mr. Edulji Khodi next moved the following resolution :
('10', 502, 7, 39, 1108513) “This meeting welcomes the efforts being made for the progress of the various languages of India and believes that the progress of entire India depends upon such
('10', 502, 8, 40, 1108675) 2 Here followed the resolution and Gandhiji’s speech; vide “Speech at Gujarati Meeting”, 5 10 1909.
('10', 503, 0, 1, 1108775) 504 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 503, 1, 2, 1108817) efforts.”
('10', 503, 2, 3, 1108827) Speaking on the resolution, Mr. Khodi, who has been a well known writer since his young days, said :
('10', 503, 3, 4, 1108928) Really speaking, Gujarati is the language of the Parsis : .
('10', 503, 3, 5, 1108988) Parsis in rural areas speak much better Gujarati than those in cities Prarsi writing is quite interesting, but not correct in expression as the Hindus’ .
('10', 503, 3, 6, 1109142) I have been able to see from this that we can contribute to the development of Gujarati.
('10', 503, 3, 7, 1109231) Though Manekbai is a Parsi, her paper was lucid enough.
('10', 503, 4, 8, 1109287) Mr. Jorawarsinghji of Bhavnagar, Mr. Khaparde of Nagpur and Mr. Hajee Habib and Mr. Anglia of South Africa also spoke on this resolution.
('10', 503, 5, 9, 1109425) Mr. Hajee Habib said :
('10', 503, 6, 10, 1109448) The efforts being made to preserve our mother tongue must be welcomed.
('10', 503, 6, 11, 1109519) I am proud that I was born in Gujarat.
('10', 503, 6, 12, 1109558) THIRD RESOLUTION
('10', 503, 7, 13, 1109575) Dr. Ghadiali moved the third resolution as follows :
('10', 503, 8, 14, 1109628) “If an Association which would function entirely through Gujarati is established to promote the development of Gujarati, the Gujaratis present here would be happy to join it.” Three persons opposing the resolution, it was carried by a majority vote.
('10', 503, 9, 15, 1109878) Mr. Parikh then proposed a vote of thanks to the Chairman, which was carried, and the meeting terminated at 6.30 p.m.

('10', 503, 13, 19, 1110065) DISPATCH IN “SOUTH AFRICA”
('10', 503, 14, 20, 1110092) Another Indian invention exploded!
('10', 503, 14, 21, 1110127) A few weeks ago, London was being dosed with cablegrams from the agitating Asiatics in this part of South Africa, alleging that a poor young Indian had died as a result of his treatment while serving a short sentence for deliberate defiance of the ordinary laws of the Colony.
('10', 503, 14, 22, 1110404) Whatever the effect of this yarn upon the credulous section of the British public, such statements as this could not go without an official inquiry.
('10', 503, 14, 23, 1110553) Major Dixon, the Magistrate appointed to report on the circumstances concerning the treatment of Nagappen, who died shortly after discharge from prison, says that Nagappen was passed as fit by a medical officer.
('10', 503, 14, 24, 1110765) It is not, he says, clear whether the deceased had two blankets in the camp, and there is nothing to warrant the opinion that sleeping on coir mattresses would have an injurious effect.
('10', 503, 14, 25, 1110951) Though no rice was supplied, there was an ample supply of water.
('10', 503, 14, 26, 1111016) The allegation that deceased was assaulted he finds to be groundless, as also allegations regarding Nagappen’s sickness in camp, he having left camp in an apparently healthy condition.
('10', 503, 14, 27, 1111201) The allegations of two Indian
('10', 504, 0, 1, 1111231) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 505
('10', 504, 1, 2, 1111274) witnesses are, he holds, entirely refuted.
('10', 504, 1, 3, 1111317) Deceased had a right to leave camp at any time on payment of a proportionate part of his fine.
('10', 504, 1, 4, 1111412) The Commissioner, having inquired into prison conditions, suggests two or three small improvements, but these have no bearing on the case.
('10', 504, 1, 5, 1111551) The result of all this fuss and invention on the part of the Asiatics has been to show that their compatriot was healthier when in custody and on his discharge than when he returned to his old manner of life.
('10', 504, 1, 6, 1111760) Indian Opinion, 16 10 1909
('10', 504, 2, 7, 1111787) APPENDIX XIV
('10', 504, 3, 8, 1111800) LETTERS FROM COLONIAL OFFICE AND LORD AMPTHILL
('10', 504, 4, 9, 1111847) (1) LETTER FROM COLONIAL OFFICE TO GANDHIJI DOWNING STREET,
('10', 504, 5, 10, 1111907) November 3, 1909
('10', 504, 7, 11, 1111924) I am directed by the Earl of Crewe to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th ultimo further respecting the proposals referred to in the letter from this Department of the 4th ultimo as a possible basis of legislation with regard to the British Indian controversy in the Transvaal.
('10', 504, 8, 12, 1112217) I am to inform you that the proposals in question were those put before you by His Lordship on the 16th of September as having been made by Mr. Smuts, viz., the repeal of Act 2 of 1907 and the admission of six educated Asiatics each year on certificates of permanent right of residence, which would involve, in your own view, a real step in advance and would, so far as their practical effect is concerned, provide a solution of the present difficulty.
('10', 504, 8, 13, 1112670) They were not, nor were they connected with, those made by yourself, and involving a theoretical claim for which His Lordship is not able to hold out any hope of obtaining recognition.
('10', 504, 8, 14, 1112855) Indeed, at the interview on the 16th of September, His Lordship explained to you that Mr. Smuts was unable to accept the claim that Asiatics should be placed in a position of equality with Europeans in respect of right of entry of otherwise.
('10', 504, 8, 15, 1113097) His Lordship cannot, therefore, admit that at the interview he undertook, as stated by you, to place your proposal before Mr. Smuts for his acceptance.
('10', 504, 8, 16, 1113249) His Lordship understood you to desire that he should telegraph to the Transvaal Government that, though you admitted the practical advance involved in Mr. Smuts’ suggestions, yet you could not consent to abandon your claim for theoretical equality, and this has been done.
('10', 504, 8, 17, 1113522) I am,Sir,
('10', 504, 9, 18, 1113532) Your obedient servant,
('10', 504, 10, 19, 1113555) FRANCIS G. S. HOPWOOD
('10', 504, 11, 20, 1113577) From a photostat of the typewritten original : S. N. 5157

('10', 505, 2, 3, 1113768) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('10', 505, 3, 4, 1113785) The contents of your letter of the 4th inst.
('10', 505, 3, 5, 1113830) are a rude shock to me.
('10', 505, 3, 6, 1113854) The letter from the Colonial Office shows either that you were entirely mistaken in the impression which you derived from your interview with Lord Crewe, or else that Lord Crewe’s recollection of what he said to you is at fault.
('10', 505, 4, 7, 1114083) In the former case much time has been needlessly wasted; in the latter case there is remedy, for it is a question of Lord Crewe’s word against yours.
('10', 505, 4, 8, 1114233) In these circumstances, I see no objection to your proposed reply which is, at any rate, dignified and restrained.
('10', 505, 4, 9, 1114348) I should say more myself if I were in your position and quite sure of my ground.
('10', 505, 5, 10, 1114429) We will talk the matter over if possible on Monday.

('10', 505, 10, 15, 1114583) COLONIAL OFFICE MINUTE [LONDON,
('10', 505, 11, 16, 1114615) November 15, 16, 1909]
('10', 505, 12, 17, 1114638) This contains little or nothing that is new—it is substantially what Mr. Gandhi has been saying everywhere (e.g.
('10', 505, 12, 18, 1114751) Times 13 Nov.
('10', 505, 12, 19, 1114765) meeting at Westminster Palace Hotel) and is all summed up in his statement that legal equality in respect of entry though never a man enter is what the British Indians want.
('10', 505, 12, 20, 1114939) 36631) If is a strong case and well stated and when the Union Government is well launched, I think we shall have to make an effort to get an immigration law on the lines of Natal and Australia and the Governor General should be instructed accordingly before the time comes.
('10', 505, 12, 21, 1115213) But, for the moment, we must take the concessions which Transvaal offers (answer to telegram on 36631 not yet in).

('10', 506, 1, 2, 1115655) APPENDIX XVI
('10', 506, 2, 3, 1115668) COLONIAL OFFICE MINUTE
('10', 506, 3, 4, 1115691) [LONDON,
('10', 506, 4, 5, 1115700) November 9, 1909]
('10', 506, 5, 6, 1115718) See today Times p.
('10', 506, 5, 7, 1115737) 5, headed “Failure of the Negotiations”—we must get
('10', 506, 6, 8, 1115789) Tr[ansvaal] to say what they mean to do.
('10', 506, 6, 9, 1115830) I submit draft for consideration.
('10', 506, 7, 10, 1115864) This is a very strong letter indeed.
('10', 506, 7, 11, 1115901) If Mr. Gandhi means what he says, viz., that
('10', 506, 8, 12, 1115946) there is no justification for home rule in India—he does not quite, but almost, says this in so many words.
('10', 506, 8, 13, 1116054) We cannot dispute the rightness of his claim to equality before the law, it is indeed a fundamental principle, we only refuse to press for the recognition of the principle about which we feel no doubt, because we have no power to enforce our views on those who have the settlement of the question in their hands.
('10', 506, 8, 14, 1116367) When a colony is given responsible Government, the settlement of such questions necessarily passes into the hands of the Colonial Government and Parliament and though the Transvaal Government have shown readiness to meet us on points of detail, they have on the point of principle shown a tenacity (due, no doubt, to the historical abhorrence of equality of white and Coloured shown by the Dutch) quite equal to that of the Indians.
('10', 506, 8, 15, 1116800) If they will not accept our principle, the Empire being what it is, we cannot dragoon them.
('10', 506, 9, 16, 1116892) Possibly an answer somewhat on these lines might be desirable for publication.
('10', 506, 11, 17, 1116971) In using the phrase “Colour bar”, Mr. Gandhi has an eye to the Debates in Parliament on the South Africa Bill, and the position of His Majesty’s Government is the same in both the cases, viz., that they have been obliged to accept the local view
('10', 506, 12, 18, 1117217) which is strongly held.
('10', 506, 13, 19, 1117241) The statement in Mr. Gandhi’s telegram to Mr. Polak (in the Times summary of
('10', 506, 14, 20, 1117318) the position) is no doubt based upon Lord Crewe’s interview and our letter of 3rd Novemeber.
('10', 506, 15, 21, 1117411) We might await an answer to the telegram before replying to the letter.
('10', 506, 17, 22, 1117483) The telegram should go at once—the reply may give us some answer to the letter.
('10', 506, 17, 23, 1117563) In any event, the true answer can only be found in describing in detail the sympathetic action of the Home Government, at the same time referring to the present policy of South Africa historically and not with animus.

('10', 508, 1, 2, 1118913) APPENDIX XVIII
('10', 508, 2, 3, 1118928) PARSEE RUSTOMJEE’S LETTER TO THE JOHANNESBURG PRESS
('10', 508, 3, 4, 1118980) JOHANNESBURG, February 12, 1910
('10', 508, 4, 5, 1119012) SIR, I was sentenced on the 11th day of February, 1909, at Volksrust to six months’ imprisonment with hard labour for having dared to assert my right as an old resident of the Transvaal to re enter.
('10', 508, 4, 6, 1119211) I finished my sentence on the 10th August last.
('10', 508, 4, 7, 1119259) I was deported the same day.
('10', 508, 4, 8, 1119288) I recrossed the border on the same day, and was sentenced to another term of six months on the 11th August last, and was discharged yesterday.
('10', 508, 4, 9, 1119431) I was removed from Volksrust to Houtpoort, and from Houtpoort to Diepkloof on the 7th October last.
('10', 508, 4, 10, 1119531) From Houtpoort to Johannesburg I was only handcuffed, but from Johannesburg to Diepkloof not only was I handcuffed but my leg, together with that of another fellow prisoner, was heavily ironed.
('10', 508, 4, 11, 1119725) At Volksrust and Houtpoort I was medically examined, and considered weak enough to receive an extra blanket and special food—that is bread and milk.
('10', 508, 4, 12, 1119874) I am only 48 years, though the medical officers have taken me to be 55. At the first two gaols I was allowed, for religious reasons, to retain my sacred thread and my own cap, which I was permitted to wear, whether in the presence of the Governor and other officers, or at the time of taking meals.
('10', 508, 4, 13, 1120173) At Diepkloof, the next morning, the medical officer came to examine all the prisoners.
('10', 508, 4, 14, 1120260) There were several fellow passive resisters.
('10', 508, 4, 15, 1120305) The doctor started by saying to us, “What the devil are you here for?” One of us said, “for conscience’ sake.” The medical officer retorted, “Your conscience be damned.” He then ordered that we should all be at the same time entirely undressed.
('10', 508, 4, 16, 1120550) This was objected to.
('10', 508, 4, 17, 1120572) For an Indian this is a very painful ordeal, but, as we feared violence, we all did as we were told.
('10', 508, 4, 18, 1120673) When my turn came to be examined, I reported that I was put upon the sick list at both Volksrust and Houtpoort, and that I had special food allowed, but the medical officer simply said, “There is nothing the matter with you.
('10', 508, 4, 19, 1120898) You are too fat.” I had only ordinary food allowed, but an extra blanket had been allowed to me the previous evening by the head warder.
('10', 508, 4, 20, 1121035) I was immediately given hard work in the shape of stone breaking.
('10', 508, 4, 21, 1121101) I was not allowed to rest at all, and was expected to keep the hammer going continuously.
('10', 508, 4, 22, 1121191) The third day the work proved too much for me, and I complained, but the warder in charge said that he could do nothing, that I had to report myself as sick, but that, until he received other instructions, he was bound to see to it that I did my work without interruption.
('10', 508, 4, 23, 1121464) I, therefore, continued it, and several times fit as if I were finished.
('10', 508, 4, 24, 1121537) Subsequently, I was examined by the doctor, who told me that there was a little soreness in my sides owing to the work, but that there was nothing in it, and that I would be all right when I had thrown off superfluous fat.
('10', 508, 4, 25, 1121760) I had to continue the work, which resulted in my health becoming worse.
('10', 508, 4, 26, 1121832) I reported again to the Governor, who ordered a re examination, but that resulted in my being deprived even of the extra blanket that had been allowed, the doctor remarking that I had simply to work harder to become all right.
('10', 508, 4, 27, 1122059) This state of things continued for nearly a fortnight, I becoming
('10', 509, 0, 1, 1122125) 510 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('10', 509, 1, 2, 1122167) worse and worse day by day, until, at last, I became restless at night and could not sleep at all.
('10', 509, 1, 3, 1122266) My fellow prisoners used to shampoo me and try to warm me.
('10', 509, 1, 4, 1122325) I, therefore, reported to the hospital orderly, and he restored the blanket that was taken away from me, and gave me some pills.
('10', 509, 1, 5, 1122454) Throughout all this time the work to which I was put was never interrupted.
('10', 509, 1, 6, 1122530) After I had been in this gaol for over a fortnight the Governor came and ordered me to leave my special cap.
('10', 509, 1, 7, 1122639) I told him that I had received special permission to retain it, and that the matter was decided even by the Natal Law Courts.
('10', 509, 1, 8, 1122765) The Governor said that the order formerly given was given in mistake, and that the Director had written to him saying that I could not retain the cap.
('10', 509, 1, 9, 1122916) I was, therefore, reluctantly obliged to give it up.
('10', 509, 1, 10, 1122969) My religious feeling was thereby hurt.
('10', 509, 1, 11, 1123008) The ordinary cap that I was given I was ordered to take off on the slightest pretext by most of the warders.
('10', 509, 1, 12, 1123117) I was subjected generally to much harassment by the medical officer, the Deputy Governor, and most of the warders at Diepkloof.
('10', 509, 1, 13, 1123245) I continually complained about sickness, but my complaints were unheeded, sometimes they were jeered at.
('10', 509, 1, 14, 1123350) My eyesight was very much affected, and one of my eyes still remains in a bad condition.
('10', 509, 1, 15, 1123439) When I complained to the medical officer about my eye, he said that I should, on being discharged, spend from £10 to £20, and be operated upon.
('10', 509, 1, 16, 1123583) Every time I complained to the medical officer he made flippant remarks.
('10', 509, 1, 17, 1123656) The Deputy Governor disregarded the complaints almost entirely.
('10', 509, 1, 18, 1123720) It was only the Governor who took any interest at all in me or, for that matter, in other prisoners.
('10', 509, 1, 19, 1123821) When I had finished all but about twenty days of my imprisonment I was obliged to again complain about absence of medical treatment to the Deputy Governor, as a result of which I was removed to the gaol at Johannesburg, after which time I received greater attention.
('10', 509, 1, 20, 1124088) The work given to me there was less exacting, being light store work and tailoring.
('10', 509, 1, 21, 1124172) The Governor and the warders were kind, and listened to all I had to say.
('10', 509, 1, 22, 1124246) My health considerably improved during the time.
('10', 509, 1, 23, 1124295) I have lost 73 lbs.
('10', 509, 1, 24, 1124315) in weight throughout my imprisonment, now extending over fourteen months, with a brief interruption after my first incarceration.
('10', 509, 1, 25, 1124445) It is my opinion that the passive resisters were removed to Diepkloof in order to break their spirit and resolution.
('10', 509, 1, 26, 1124562) Diepkloof is a penal settlement, and the prisoners there, unlike the prisoners in the other gaols of the Transvaal, are deprived of the privilege of receiving monthly visitors, and of writing and receiving monthly letters, these privileges being allowed only after the expiration of three months, and as most passive resisters can get only three months with hard labour, they never enjoy the privilege of receiving a visitor or of receiving or writing a letter.
('10', 509, 1, 27, 1125024) The food has been so selected as to partially starve Asiatic prisoners.
('10', 509, 1, 28, 1125096) Whereas native prisoners get 1 oz.
('10', 509, 1, 29, 1125131) of fat per day, Indian prisoners for three months have no fat allowed at all.
('10', 509, 1, 30, 1125209) This change was made when Indians complained that they could not take the ordinary animal fat that was given.
('10', 509, 1, 31, 1125319) They asked for ghee, which was allowed in the Johannesburg Gaol, and in reply there was a complete stopping of fat or its substitute.
('10', 509, 1, 32, 1125453) The result has been disastrous to many Indian prisoners.
('10', 509, 1, 33, 1125510) At Diepkloo the prisoners were compelled to carry slop pails.
('10', 509, 1, 34, 1125572) This work is most repugnant to most Indians, but the majority of us consider that, as passive resisters, we should not object to doing any work no matter how offensive it may be, so long as we are physically able to perform it.
('10', 509, 1, 35, 1125800) One among us, however, made it a matter of conscience
('10', 510, 0, 1, 1125854) VOL. 10 : 5 AUGUST, 1909 9 APRIL, 1910 511
('10', 510, 1, 2, 1125897) and for that reason suffered 33 days’ solitary confinement and half rations for the greater part of this period.
('10', 510, 1, 3, 1126010) I say nothing as to minor matters, such as constant insults by warders both European and Native.
('10', 510, 1, 4, 1126107) Most of the warders, contrary to regulations, insist upon Indian prisoners addressing them as Sir, &c.
('10', 510, 1, 5, 1126210) I do not know why this time the Government have left me alone and not deported me.
('10', 510, 1, 6, 1126293) The almost complete ruin that has overtaken my business requires my presence in Natal for the time being.
('10', 510, 1, 7, 1126399) My health, too, demands attention.
('10', 510, 1, 8, 1126434) But I venture to assure the Government that there are some Indians at least left, including myself, who will not be broken, no matter what hardships they are subjected to, and I shall soon have the privilege of affording the Government an opportunity of sending me to Diepkloof or any other place they choose.
('10', 510, 1, 9, 1126744) I am, &c.,
('10', 510, 2, 10, 1126755) PARSEE RUSTOMJEE JEEVANJEE
('10', 510, 3, 11, 1126782) Colonial Office Records: C.D. 5363
('10', 510, 4, 12, 1126817) APPENDIX XIX
('10', 510, 5, 13, 1126830) TOLSTOY’S LETTER TO GANDHIJI
('10', 510, 6, 14, 1126859) YASNAYA POLYANA, May 8, 1910
('10', 510, 7, 15, 1126888) DEAR FRIEND, I just received your letter and your book Indian Home Rule.
('10', 510, 7, 16, 1126961) I read your book with great interest because I think that the question you treat in it—the passive resistance—is a question of the greatest importance not only for India but for the whole humanity.
('10', 510, 7, 17, 1127159) I could not find your former letters, but came across your biography by J. Doss 3 which too interested me much deeply and gave me the possibility to know and understand you better.
('10', 510, 7, 18, 1127340) I am at present not quite well and therefore abstain from writing to you all what I have to say about your book and all your work which I appreciate very much.
('10', 510, 7, 19, 1127500) but I will do it as soon as I will feel better.
('10', 510, 7, 20, 1127548) Your friend and brother.
('10', 510, 7, 21, 1127573) Mahatma, Vol. I
('10', 510, 8, 22, 1127589) 3 In fact, by Rev.
('10', 510, 8, 23, 1127608) J. J. Doke; vide “Letter to Lord Ampthill”, 10 11 1909
